HEADLINE: Nicaragua Might Prefer Benign Neglect

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Testing Time for Mrs. Chamorro" (editorial, July 30) demands that Gen. Humberto Ortega, head of the Nicaraguan army, "will have to go." You also support Congressional cutoff of all funds, again, for this tiny country of three million people, mostly poor peasants and children. 
 The poor folks there wouldn't see the aid anyway. Some 70 percent of it returns to the United States for the balance of payments deficit. In the years I lived in Nicaragua (1989-91), I saw the country plunged deeper into unemployment and poverty as a result of United States Government pressure through the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.
You state that disaffected former combatants from both sides of the civil war attacked the town of Esteli, that 41 people were killed and the attack was carried out with the knowledge of the army, which allowed the combatants into the town and was slow to contain the fighting.
The facts as I know them are that 100 to 300 former contra and former Sandinista soldiers joined in capturing Esteli to demand that the Chamorro Government keep its promises to them when they disarmed at the end of the contra war, which the United States paid for and directed.
The combatants were willing to negotiate an end to the Esteli takeover, but the Government sent in at least 1,000 army troops, helicopters, tanks and rocket launchers. The 25-hour combat left 45 dead and 98 wounded.
Esteli residents are asking why so much force was needed to displace a group who "were asking only for justice, a little land and resources."
Your conjecture that the army, under General Ortega, is also guilty of terrorism would be funny if it were not so dangerous. Many of my friends and I wondered what pretext the rich and powerful nations would use for attacking the Sandinistas when they could no longer cry "Communist."
Maybe the best gift that we can give to the Nicaraguans is to let them alone.
 
SYLVIA METZLER
Co-chairwoman
Medicines for Nicaragua
Philadelphia, Aug. 4, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: In California, Logging Dispute Hits Home for Some

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Aug. 11

 BODY:
As he worked in the dappled shade of his home office one day in June, Rich G. Kelso could hear the whine of chain saws and crunch of breaking wood from what he had been assured was tree trimming on his neighbor's property.
Then sunlight suddenly flooded his house, and Mr. Kelso said he got a sinking feeling. Looking out a 14-foot-wide picture window, he could see men cutting down the last row of trees next to his property, giving him a clear view of a stump-filled hillside that only hours earlier had been an impenetrable shroud of redwoods. 
 "I ran out yelling, 'What are you doing? This is logging, not tree trimming!' " recalled Mr. Kelso, a photographer and musician who bought his two-and-a-half-acre property here five years ago. "By that time, it was too late. They just took every tree out of there."
 
Door to Door Logging
 With the price of timber skyrocketing, property owners in this Northern California coastal region, where the redwoods thrive, are making lucrative deals with small timber harvesters who have gone door to door offering thousands of dollars to clear several acres, a service for which residents normally would have to pay. Neighbors like Mr. Kelso have been shocked to discover their wooded environs suddenly transformed into flat landscapes peppered with stumps.
In Santa Cruz County, a Silicon Valley bedroom community whose population has increased 22 percent, to 230,000, since 1980, the conflict over backyard logging is increasingly pitting newcomers against old-timers, between those who came to live cloistered in nature and those who resent being told what they can and cannot do with their property.
When Mr. Kelso called local officials, he learned that his neighbor was within his rights to chop down redwoods. Unlike large-scale harvesting, an independent logger cutting down trees for a homeowner does not face many hurdles, he discovered. No environmental or community review is required to cut as many as three acres of redwoods.
The price being paid for redwood these days might tempt an ardent conservationist. Four years ago, 1,000 board feet of redwood, roughly half the size of an average tree in Santa Cruz County, could bring $200 to $500. This year, it can bring up to $1,100.
 
Reasons for Rise in Prices
 One reason for the price explosion is that the Federal Government has closed hundreds of thousands of acres of public lands in the Pacific Northwest to logging to protect the spotted owl. In 1988, 1.96 billion board feet of timber was harvested in California, according to the United States Forest Service. For 1994, the agency projects that only a fourth of that amount will be harvested.
Another reason is that timber companies harvested their own lands so heavily in the 1980's that they instilled fear among owners of large private tracts of forest about opening their property to loggers.
Local governments, too, are taking advantage of the current high prices being paid for timber. In Mendocino County, where the unemployment rate is 12 percent, officials are considering harvesting 25 acres of redwoods and firs that could bring in $500,000.
"It would close some gaps," James C. Eddie, a county supervisor said of the windfall. After losing several million dollars in the latest state budget, the county laid off workers and sold its only golf course.
"When you cut from a county this size in times like this, "Mr. Eddie sai, "you get caught. There is an end of the number of people you can lay off."
In Santa Cruz County, where Mr. Kelso lives, almost all of the 150,000 acres of forest land are privately owned. Despite the county's reputation as a liberal stronghold and its tough rules on timber harvesting, small-time loggers have arrived from other parts of the state, setting up their businesses in motels.
Dave Hope, who oversees all timber harvesting in the area as Santa Cruz County's forester and watershed manager, said that there were some bad examples of residential logging, but that mostly the problem lay with the attitude of newcomers.
"People get almost a religious feeling about trees if they haven't grown up in a consumptive environment," Mr. Hope said. "They would rather have the wood come from a place they don't see, like the moon."
 
Reducing Fire Hazard
 Eight miles south of Mr. Kelso's home in unincorporated Aptos, a logger traveled up and down Fern Flat Road throughout the early spring, approaching about half of the 50 property owners. He offered to reduce their fire danger by removing unwanted trees and to pay them for the timber.
Elizabeth Herbert, who lives in an geodesic dome on 13 acres, said the offer seemed too good to be true. Expecting that her neighbors would go through a review process to discuss the logger's proposal, she held a neighborhood meeting in her home that was attended by about 15 people. But before anyone could act, she said, the chain saws began without announcement.
In some cases, Ms. Herbert said, acres of redwoods were being clear-cut, a practice that leaves no trees standing in an area and that is illegal in Santa Cruz County. But when she contacted local officials, she was told of a loophole that allowed homeowners to clear-cut land they wanted to convert to another use. No review process was necessary, she was told.
But her neighbor, Jerry W. Henry, a horticulturist, said he saw the harvesting of redwoods as beneficial, creating more open space and reducing fire hazard. Like many other old-timers in the area, he sees the dispute as an overreaction by newcomers.
"When San Francisco hillbillies buy private property on a road and try to force their wills, they're cutting their own throats," said Mr. Henry, whose 26 acres resemble a city park with lamp posts and lush gardens. He had intended to cut a redwood grove on his property this summer to reduce the fire hazard, he said, but his plans have been put on hold because of the controversy. County officials have asked him to wait while they review his plans.
Another property owner on Fern Flat Road, Nick Kusalich, had a redwood grove harvested in the spring so he could "plant it, make it beautiful and sell it," he said.
"Let's not kid ourselves; the price is right now," said Mr. Kusalich, a retired carpet store owner whose family has owned the property since 1928.
 
Emergency Rules Passed
 After a public outcry about piecemeal logging, a state regulatory board passed emergency rules last month requiring property owners in counties in the San Francisco Bay Area to wait 10 days after filing a permit before they start logging. The rules are intended to give officials time to see if there are going to be problems in logging a certain property.
Ken Delfino, deputy director of resources for the State Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, said the neighborhood conflicts, along with stories of below-market rates paid to inexperienced homeowners, had given forestry "a black eye.".
"In some neighborhoods, trees are the character, the reason why people live there," Mr. Delfino said. "When you cut trees from a residential area, they're not coming back."
Accepting that the landscape is probably permanently altered has been hard for Mr. Kelso, who said he regrets naively allowing his neighbor the use of his driveway to take out the trees. Since the logging, he said, he has missed the bobcats and coyotes he used to see in his yard, and he says he now has to wears sunglasses in his living room.
"My wife and I are crying every night," he said. "We can't believe we had a hand in this."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Mamaroneck

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
NOWHERE was there greater jubilation when Stars and Stripes '87 beat the Australians and brought home the America's Cup than in Mamaroneck. The sleek 12-meter craft had been built there at the Derecktor Shipyard by Portuguese, Chinese and American craftsmen who live in the village.
Boat-building and sailing have a long tradition there, and marinas and beach clubs line the shore of the second largest natural small-boat harbor on the East Coast -- sometimes hard to see through the forest of masts from 1,500 boats. 
 Harbor Island Park, along the water at the foot of Mamaroneck Avenue, is the 45-acre centerpiece and focus of village life. The former island started being changed into a peninsula early in the century with rock removed in building New York City's subway system. Today there are tennis courts and ballfields, a 700-foot public beach and several fishing floats. Along a border is the newly upgraded Westchester County Sewage Treatment Plant whose Art Deco tower serves as a modern lighthouse. Residents are proud of their local landmark and hope the upgraded plant will help reduce harbor pollution caused by runoff from the Mamaroneck River.
Pollution is decreasing, said Matthew Galligan, the Village Manager, but the community took the unusual step this year of installing a floating filter around the public beach, which has kept out flotsam and jetsam. The village also has a station where heads and bilges can be pumped out free.
Sgt. Andrew S. Landau of the village Police Department's Marine Division, who is in charge of patrolling the village's 9.5-mile coastline, is optimistic. "The Sound has really gotten cleaned up in the last two years," he said. "The lobster population is thriving and even the blue-claw crabs have returned. People are scooping them out in bushels."
Residents are following a tradition started by the Siwanoy Indians, who named the area where the Mamaroneck and Sheldrake Rivers converge on their way to the sea as "the place where the salt water meets the fresh."
Recognizing the value of this snug harbor with its two rivers, John Richbell, a Boston merchant and West Indies trader, bought it from the tribe in 1661 with shirts, wampum and gunpowder.
From the Revolution until the present day, the village has grown because of its harbor, attracting commerce with help from a former Indian trail that is now the busy four-lane Boston Post Road, the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad -- which arrived in 1848 -- and the New England Thruway.
Diversity increased as the railroad brought waves of European immigrants from New York City, including Germans, who started a rubber factory, and Italians, many of whom worked in the MacIntosh coat factory creating fashionable coats for New York stores.
By 1895, when the village was incorporated as part of two towns, Rye and Mamaroneck, 12 neighborhoods had taken shape; by 1950, most of the land had been developed and most industry had arrived. The village doesn't look much different from the way it did half a century ago -- economically and ethnically diverse, with both luxurious estates and overcrowded apartments.
"We're almost a mini-city," Mr. Galligan observed.
Gloria Poccia Pritts, the village historian, agreed. "You can find anything you want in Mamaroneck," she said, "any kind of house, any kind of people, any kind of food."
There are about 6,600 housing units, including 2,461 one-family homes and about 1,600 co-ops and condominiums. There are also 2,433 rental units. Many houses went up on the former estates of the wealthy Manhattan industrialists who built summer homes along the harbor. Among the most sumptuous is the onetime home of Henry Flagler, who co-founded Standard Oil with John D. Rockefeller.
In 1919, Flagler's 32-acre estate on Orienta Point, a peninsula west of the harbor, was acquired by D. W. Griffith, the film director, who ushered in a short but brilliant golden age for the village as a kind of East Coast Hollywood. A silent-screen-era movie studio attracted such early stars as Lillian and Dorothy Gish, who lived in a house that is still on the corner of Bleeker and Walton Avenues.
Today, Flagler Drive leads to a security gate beyond which lies Edgewater Point, with some of the village's most luxurious homes. A six-bedroom, four-bath modern ranch-style home on the drive recently put up for sale at $1.995 million included a heated pool, dock and mooring, said Marco DiBernardo, principal broker at Houghton and Banks.
The peninsula is the farthest extension of Orienta Point, the largest neighborhood in the village, with the most one-family homes and town houses and the most beach frontage. Several homes are on private peninsulas. Fairway Green, a complex of town houses bordering the Hampshire Golf Course, is tucked into the top portion of Orienta Point, where two-bedroom units with cathedral ceilings sell for $400,000 to $500,000.
ON the eastern side of the harbor, bordering the City of Rye, is Harbor Lawn-Shore Acres, expensive one-family homes on extensive water frontage similar to Orienta Point. Two of the village's 16 beach clubs are there, including the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club, formerly the estate of the New York financier Charles W. Osborn. Some buildings on the estate, designed by Stanford White in 1883, are still intact, including the turreted carriage house.
Rye Neck, the eastern half of the village, encompasses some older homes, including turn-of-the-century houses in the proposed Melbourne Avenue Historic District. North of the Metro-North rail line are more one-family homes, many of them historic, and a recently built 52-unit town-house complex, North of the Ridge.
Rye Neck is bordered on the north by the 850-acre county-owned Saxon Woods Park.
Mamaroneck Avenue, which divides the village into nearly two equal parts, is the center of the thriving but somewhat worn business district whose small shops offer a wide variety of goods and services. Popular restaurants include Satsumaya, combining Japanese and Western cuisine, and Abis, specializing in sushi. The Crab Shanty and Maguires are longtime local favorites, and Chef Antonio's offers Italian fare.
Since 1919, Walter's Hot Dogs on Palmer Avenue has purveyed its offerings from a pagodacomplete with copper roof and carp.
"You can hardly get a parking place, but the downtown needs a facelift," said Mayor Paul J. Noto, adding that the village was about to begin a $2 million esthetic improvement plan that will include burying overhead wires and installing new signs.
Because the village lies in two towns, children attend two school systems. In the Town of Mamaroneck they go to one of two k-6 elementary schools operated by the Mamaroneck Union Free School District, which also enrolls Larchmont children; Rye Neck children have their own k-4 elementary school, and there are separate middle schools through grade 8 and high schools for both systems.
The Mamaroneck system, with 3,718 students, has a high school noted for arts and music programs and a science program that produced a Westinghouse scholar three years ago. Three-quarters of the seniors go on to higher education.
The Rye Neck district, with 1,196 students, has won state and national recognition for its team approach to school management. Special high school programs include theater arts and such electives as Japanese culture and Sports in Literature. About 85 percent of the senior class goes on to college.
Students from both systems can use and attend performances at the 282-seat Emelin Theater adjacent to the Mamaroneck Free Library and founded by it. Today the Emelin operates independently as a performing-arts showcase that has major actors, musicians, cabaret artists and other performers.

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about living in Mamaroneck referred incorrectly to a condominium complex. It is Top of the Ridge, not North of the Ridge.

There But for . . .: When the congregation at the Mamaroneck United Methodist Church sings "Amazing Grace," it means it. Three years ago, the church's one-ton bell crashed down from the tower just two minutes before the service, narrowly missing several parishioners and prompting a fervent rendition of the hymn. The incident became the catalyst to renovate the 134-year-old church -- work is still being done -- which was built by ship's carpenters to resemble an inverted hull. In March it was listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

HEADLINE: Water Farm In Catskills Has Enemies

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON

DATELINE: CALLICOON, N.Y.

 BODY:
The burbling brooks that cut through the hills here have made this area on the edge of the Catskills a trout angler's paradise -- a world-renowned fishing center where environmentalism is a passion verging on a religion.
It was just the kind of place for a conservationist and former Sanskrit scholar like Andrew J. Krieger to move to after leaving Wall Street six years ago and giving up his claim to fame as the world's most daring trader in currency options. A vegetarian, he named his rolling estate Karma Farms "as a place where good things happen," and even planted grasses and grains so that wildlife would have food during the long, hard winters. 
But now Mr. Krieger has drawn the wrath of his equally environmentally minded neighbors by selling one of the area's most precious resources, the crystal-clear water that bubbles up from an aquifer beneath his farm, to the Great Bear Spring Company.
 
A Boost for the Area?
 One of Mr. Krieger's harshest critics is Mia Koerner, who says Mr. Krieger's water farm has spoiled the environment by drying up trout streams nearby.
"It makes me sick; it makes me cry," she said, tears welling in her eyes as she surveyed the bone-dry bed of the Sandelee Brook, the stream that once separated her property from Mr. Krieger's farm. "I had black bear, raccoons, all kinds of wildlife come drink. Now, nothing."
But Mr. Krieger, who wants to double the capacity of his holding tanks, dismisses her complaints, saying she is desperate for attention. He said the region's continuous drought had caused the trout streams to dry up, and argued that his farm's connection with Great Bear was a heaven-sent image-builder for the region. He added that he would "shut the whole thing down before I did anything to damage the environment."
Mr. Krieger's planned expansion has served as a lightening rod for opposition to the water farm. Chad Reed, the regional coordinator of the Watershed Association of the Delaware River, recently wrote the town Planning Board complaining that the harvesting had damaged the environment and asked that the town require Mr. Krieger to a conduct a detailed environmental review of the project. The town is still considering the expansion.
The battle is more than a fight between neighbors with shared passions. It has pointed up some of the loopholes in the state's water regulations and has focused attention on the growing demand for the region's water, which has long been thought of as virtually inexhaustible.
State officials say they have received a small but increasing number of complaints about the taking of water, and have begun to push for new regulations that would govern the taking of even small amounts.
"It's more important than oil," said Sheila Shultz, a longtime resident and a member of the conservation committee of the Theodore Gordon Fly Fishers, a local environmental group. "This situation may be mirrored in a whole lot of other places. It's always presented as clean industry. But it's given very little benefit to the area and it's a withdrawal of resources. It's a New York State resource, which is being extracted without any real benefits to New York."
 
A Clear Message
 In a letter to the town, Paul Levy, another resident, questioned Mr. Krieger's ownership of the water. "There are larger issues raised," he noted. "Can anyone truly be given permission to sell ground or surface water simply because they flow through that person's property? Do riparian rights have any influence on upstream water withdrawals? I think the message is clear. Water can no longer be considered an infinite resource."
But the dispute is also an example of the decisions confronting rural areas as they try to balance the need to grow and the desire to conserve a traditional way of life.
"Conservation is the keynote of modern living," residents concluded in a history of the area published four years ago as part of a celebration of the central school building. "To us this means conservation of all that makes our land beautiful; the woods, the streams, fish and game, so that for all who come here life may hold the charm and solace it held for James Beecher, the minister from Beecher Lake, when life moved so gently that he did not notice each day passing and mistook a Monday for a Sunday."
Once the borderland of Iroquois and Algonquin territories, the dense black forests of this region have held an abundance of game -- deer, elk, moose, panthers and beavers -- that attracted the first white settlers. Though most were from New England, they were soon followed in large numbers by Europeans fleeing the Irish potato famine and Germans escaping the 1848 revolution.
Most quickly found work in the logging industry and in the many tanneries, which flourished amid the hemlock trees, whose bark provided a nearby resevoir of tannic acid.
But once those industries collapsed, the region turned to its streams and rivers, including the Beaverkill, to attract residents and tourists. The rivers soon became synonymous around the world with great trout fishing.
 
Reliance on Rivers
 "The economy is based on the recreation of the rivers," Mrs. Koerner said as she drove through the area, which is 120 miles northwest of New York City. "Everything in this town survives on the rivers. This community would just fold up without it."
Robert Redford recently bought property in the area. So did Dan Rather. Laurance S. Rockefeller bought huge tracts along the Beaverkill, donated much of it to the state and sold small parcels to wealthy environmentalists. But Mr. Krieger, now the managing director of KB Currency Advisors, a trading company in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., saw another opportunity.
Hydrologists found his water among the purest in the country. So three years ago, he formed the Alpine Springs Waterworks, built a collection of pools, shelters and two 14,000-gallon storage tanks and began selling the water to Great Bear, a subsidiary of Perrier.
Mr. Krieger and Great Bear declined to say how much money Mr. Krieger is paid for the water or how much is taken each day from the farm. But researchers said that given the water's high quality, he should be earning at least a penny a gallon. And based on the capacity of the water farm, he could earn as much as $500,000 a year.
Richard Formuth, a water-resources engineer for the Delaware River Basin Commission, said Mr. Krieger should have obtained a permit from the interstate planning and regulatory agency when taking 100,000 gallons a day over a 30-day average anywhere in the basin. He also said harvesting should have stopped as soon as the stream's flow dropped under the seven-day low expected every decade.
But the commission, which has a staff of just 38 to oversee 12,755 square miles in three states, doesn't have an enforcement division and relies on the states for notification of projects needing permits.
The state Department of Environmental Conservation said Mr. Krieger did not need to obtain a permit from the agency. And Mr. Krieger said he didn't think he needed a permit. Although he told town officials he would harvest up to 124,000 gallons a day, he said he had never even come close to surpassing the threshold.
 
Growing Fury
 Mrs. Koerner said she did not oppose opening the water farm. But her spring dried up, forcing her to spend more than $5,000 for a new well. Her fury grew each time Great Bear trucks violated the schedule Mr. Krieger set for collecting the water. She began complaining. But she didn't become strident until the brook went dry -- she says for the first time in memory and weeks before any other area streams.
She said she finally received a telephone call from an unidentified man offering her a bribe if she would forget the problem.
But Mr. Krieger said the worsening drought had caused the streams to dry up. In the last three months, state figures show the upper Delaware River Basin has received just 6.72 inches of rain -- 45 percent less than normal. Mr. Krieger said his annual water harvest was less than a drop in the bucket when one considered that an inch of rain produced 17.5 million gallons per square mile and that the Cattail Brook, which received the flow from the Shandelee, carries 10 billion gallons of water a year.
"What we do has no effect on the environment," he said. "It's ludicrous. Pure water is a nice thing to be associated with. It's a nice, clean image. It's a good thing for the town. It should be proud of it."

HEADLINE: Spring Hill Journal;
Rural Town Ages Rapidly Under Saturn's Influence

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPRING HILL, Tenn., Aug. 11

 BODY:
For its first 176 years, Spring Hill was known for -- well, as Charlie Brown, the buildings superintendent, says, for "nothing."
Then, in 1985, the Saturn Corporation, a new unit of General Motors, announced that it would build a plant at the south end of town to produce spiffy new cars in a newfangled way, and suddenly Spring Hill became a dot on the map. A good map. 
 "Now," said Freeman Cowherd, the 62-year-old Mayor, "even the Japanese know Spring Hill."
Through five years of planning and construction of the plant and three years of automobile production there, the arrival of Saturn has generated stunning growth throughout Maury County. The population of Spring Hill, which is 35 miles south of Nashville, nearly doubled in a decade to 1990, to 1,464 people. The nearby town of Mount Pleasant grew by 27 percent, to 4,278. Columbia, the county's commercial center and its largest town, grew by 7.5 percent, to 28,583.
The spurt is continuing. Saturn added a third shift at the plant this year, for a total work force of about 7,000.
Yet like any new relationship, the union of Saturn and Spring Hill has brought about other changes as well, some undesirable and some still taking shape. Traffic is thicker than ever before. Schools are more crowded. Sewage lines are strained. Crime has increased. Even Saturn is having problems: The company recalled more than 380,000 cars last week to address an electrical flaw that was causing engine fires.
Analysts say the recall, Saturn's eighth in three years, could cost the company $8 million and briefly shake public confidence in a car that has been highly rated in customer-satisfaction surveys. But people here simply shrug their shoulders. "Maybe some might feel embarrassed for them," Mayor Cowherd said of his constituents. "I'd say most don't."
More evident through conversations with people here are feelings about a pace of life quickened by the influx of so many outsiders. By agreement with the United Automobile Workers, nearly all of those at Saturn were workers who had been laid off from other G.M. plants. As a result, Saturn has not substantially cut unemployment of about 6 percent in Maury County.
The arrival of the newcomers has created a curious blend of accents and cultures, with Northerners learning to slow down while Southerners try to speed up. This is a place, after all, where $4.95 buys a lunch of meat loaf and three vegetables at the Poplar House restaurant."
"Worst crime before Saturn arrived?" said Paul Williams, a former police chief. "I don't know. Weekend drunks, maybe." Now, the police force, which has grown to seven, from four, has to deal with more serious problems, like drugs.
The residents have other issues of communal importance to consider, like traffic, which becomes gridlock during shift changes at Saturn. Also, the town still has no doctor. And Mayor Cowherd says he worries about residents on fixed incomes who face certain tax increases for additional water and sewage lines, street work and police officers.
Most of the county's commercial growth since 1985 has occurred in Columbia, where last year Peter Hudson opened a bar. Many of Mr. Hudson's customers are Saturn workers on their way home to towns like Pulaski, Hohenwald and Mount Pleasant. Without their business, he said, "I wouldn't have opened this place."
Born and reared in Maury County, Mr. Hudson calls the whole area a boom town for Saturn's impact on real estate prices. After 1985, speculators began buying land and driving up prices all over. Mr. Brown, the Spring Hill buildings supervisor, said a new house of 1,200 square feet that cost $29,000 before Saturn found Spring Hill would now sell for $90,000.
One of the buyers was J. R. Guerrero, who built Pontiacs for 15 years in Fraser, Mich., 25 miles north of Detroit, before the plant there closed. Unemployed more than two years, he jumped at the chance to join Saturn and work in a parts warehouse. Upon arrival with his wife, he took in the slower pace and rustic landscape and told a real estate agent that he wanted a house with 10 acres, five minutes from a golf course and with water on the property.
"He laughed and said he'd call me back," Mr. Guerrero said, finishing a beer at Mr. Hudson's bar. The next day the agent told the Guerreros that the only problem was the acreage -- it was 11.3, not 10. And the golf course was 10 minutes away. The price: $53,000.
Mr. Guerrero, who is 36, describes himself as a typical Saturn employee, someone who is concerned about problems like engine fires and is sensitive to differences with his new neighbors.
"It's a lot like changing schools," he said. "You don't fit in until they get to know you. There has to be an adjustment period."

HEADLINE: Law Protects Mexico's Workers But Its Enforcement Is Often Lax

SERIES: A Partner's Hurdles: Mexico Faces Free Trade/First of two articles.

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MERIDA, Mexico, Aug. 13

 BODY:
"There's no way I can get my labor costs down to $1 an hour," groused an American executive pictured in a magazine advertisement promoting the state of Yucatan this year. Below his photograph the Yucatan government promised low wages and workers willing to accept them.
"When the U.S. is too expensive and the Far East too far," the advertisement said, "yes you can, in Yucatan." 
 Ross Perot and other American critics have cited just such an attitude in maintaining that thousands of American jobs would be shifted to Mexico if the United States enters into the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada, an accord that would gradually eliminate most trade and investment barriers among the three countries.
Worried that the advertisement could hurt the chances for the trade agreement, which Mexico has made a priority but which the United States Congress has not yet approved, Mexican officials withdrew it. But that did not allay concerns that American workers would lose jobs and receive lower wages under the agreement.
 
Side Accord Approved
 On Friday, after months of difficult negotiations, the three countries involved in the free-trade agreement announced a side accord that would impose fines or trade sanctions against any nation that did not enforce domestic labor laws or standards. That auxiliary pact is essentially aimed at preventing Mexico from exploiting its cheap labor to lure businesses away from the United States. In 1992, the average hourly compensation, including benefits, for production line workers in the United States was $16.17; in Mexico it was $2.35.
Another side agreement was reached to insure that pollution standards will be upheld after most trade tariffs are eliminated.
The free-trade agreement will reduce or eliminate tariffs on most goods moving across the borders of the three countries. Proponents say it will be a boon for workers, especially those in Mexico, who will find more jobs and higher wages.
But critics on both sides of the border say that the side agreement on labor may be too weak to bring deep changes in the structure of labor in Mexico: large but weak unions, indifferently enforced wage regulations and Government interference.
 
Pledge on Minimum Wage
 Hours after the side accords were announced, Mexico's President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, said his Government would raise the current minimum wage of $4.21 a day to reflect increases in the productivity of Mexican workers. Mr. Salinas promised that the trade agreement and side accord would generally improve the well-being of Mexican workers and bring in "more jobs, clean and better paid."
But Mr. Salinas's pledge would directly affect only the 16 percent of Mexican workers receiving the minimum wage. The side agreement does focus on health and safety standards and child labor laws, but leaves out what many critics in the United States say are crucial labor rights, like guarantees of free unions and the rights of workers to pick their own representatives.
"The side agreement deals with an image of Mexico, not the reality," said Harley Shaiken, a professor of industrial relations now at the University of California at Berkeley and the author of two books on Mexico's economy. "The difficult issue of the lack of real labor rights in Mexico and the way in which that might affect jobs and wages in the U.S. is not dealt with at all."
Critics of the agreement say that the continuing weakness of Mexican labor will undercut American workers, who must negotiate with plant managers already threatening at every turn to move to Mexico. They paint a frightening picture of a Mexico filled with industrial hazards, labor exploitation and a cozy relationship between unions and the Government that can compromise worker rights or squash those who oppose the status quo whether at small factories or multinational corporations like Ford, Volkswagen or General Electric.
 
The Record
Labor Rights Exist, At Least on Paper
 A brickmaking settlement in the town of Ixtapaluca, 19 miles southeast of Mexico City, illustrates the complexity of the Mexican labor scene, and the gap the agreement would have to bridge to harmonize working standards here with those in the United States.
The 600 families there scrape a living from the mud around them, which they mix with straw or dung to make bricks. Jose Gomez Rosario, 71, and his family have lived there 28 years, and he is proud to show his membership card in a family brickmakers' union. The trucks that haul out the handmade bricks also bear prominent union symbols.
But neither unionizing nor constitutional labor rights have made much difference in Ixtapaluca. The brickyard itself is all mud and much misery. Water comes from a truck. The only way to get electricity is to tap light poles on the nearby highway illegally. Some brickmakers fire their ovens with an oil mixture that darkens the sky. Children draw water, women haul bricks, even grandparents spread around the sawdust that is used to fuel the fires more cleanly on the rare occasions when inspectors show up.
Working conditions are generally considered to be better at big corporations, which are under the most pressure to obey labor laws. But for many Mexicans, the reality of work is rough. The 16 percent who are street vendors or who otherwise work in Mexico's informal economy are unprotected by labor laws. And since more than 80 percent of workers in the formal sector are employed in companies of fewer than 15 employees, they too are excluded from nearly all Government supervision.
The percentage of Mexican workers who belong to unions is more than twice as high as in the United States, 36 percent to 14 percent. They have comprehensive labor rights, guaranteed by Article 123 of the 1917 Constitution and enforced through the Federal Labor Law.
A workweek here is 48 hours but Mexican workers are guaranteed six paid vacation days after one year's work. They have the right to organize and freely choose their unions. Profit-sharing is expected, child labor is illegal, women are entitled to a total of 12 weeks' paid pregnancy leave and working mothers are given two special half-hour rest periods in which they can breast-feed their children.
Officials in the ministry of labor declined to comment on Mexico's labor rights record because of the sensitivity of the negotiations on the trade agreement. But in a report prepared in response to Washington's concerns, the Government defends its record.
Safety inspectors made 4,728 visits to plants last year, while 48,783 more were conducted to insure that employers were following labor laws, the report said. It said that last year there were 6,814 notices of intent to strike by union locals, although only 2 percent of the strikes actually occurred.
Still, groups like the Mexican Association of Democratic Lawyers say labor rights exist only on paper. "Violation of workers' rights persists, but workers can't turn to the authorities because it is the authorities themselves who commit the violations," said Manuel Fuentes, a lawyer in Mexico City involved in labor issues.
 
A Case History
Blacklist Charged At Border Plants
 Fearing reprisal at home, Mexican workers have been most outspoken when they have gone to the United States.
Alma L. Molina of Ciudad Juarez, across the Rio Grande from El Paso, Tex., testified before the House Subcommittee on Employment, Housing and Aviation last month that she was blacklisted for trying to organize workers at Clarostat, an American-owned assembly plant on the border. At the plant, called a maquiladora, 300 employees earn the Mexican minimum wage making electrical switches.
She said that after she was dismissed by Clarostat she found another job at Electrocomponentes, a plant owned by the General Electric Company that makes wiring for refrigerators.
"I had been at G.E. for only 7 days when I was called into the personnel office and shown a list with my name on it," Mrs. Molina testified. "The list was kept in a black folder. The personnel man said that he did not know why my name was on the list but that he would have to fire me anyway."
General Electric denies that there is a blacklist and said Mrs. Molina was dismissed because she was not doing her job satisfactorily. She has filed a lawsuit against G.E. with the Mexican Labor Board.
American unions have fiercely opposed the agreement, and Mexican unions have quietly acquiesced, a strong indication that thousands of low-skill American manufacturing jobs will probably be shifted south of the border. Estimates range from a low of 19,000 jobs to a high of 900,000, with the Institute for International Economics in Washington predicting 112,000.
Many analysts say they believe that workers in the United States who lose their jobs will be least likely to benefit from the export-related jobs that would be created by an increase in trade with Mexico. For that reason, President Clinton is expected to include a revamped worker retraining program as part of the sweeteners he will use to try to get Congress to approve the agreement and its side accords.
The side accord on labor basically establishes a special commission to inspect and review working conditions in all three countries. It will be able to issue fines of up to $20 million or, as a last resort, impose trade sanctions to suspend the benefits of the agreement until the fines are paid.
It will be empowered to look into accusations of violations, focusing on safety and health. But Mexico was not willing to give any commission the power to investigate allegations concerning problems between the Government and unions, a key area that many critics in both countries have said will have to be open to scrutiny if the condition of Mexican workers really is to improve. "
 
The Government
Officials Accused Of Intimidation
 The United States decided years ago that protection of workers' rights should be a condition for lowering tariffs on goods from developing nations, a program known as the Generalized System of Preferences.
Mexico is already the largest beneficiary of 140 developing countries in the system. In 1991, and again this year, the International Labor Rights Education and Research Fund -- a nonprofit organization led by Ray Marshall, a Labor Secretary in the Reagan Administration -- has tried to disqualify Mexico because of its labor record. The first attempt was rejected by the United States Trade Representative, and Government action on the current one is considered unlikely because it could imperil the trade agreement.
Still, the labor rights group focuses on concerns that others, including President Clinton, have raised before. The petition argues that the Mexican Government restricts the rights of workers in various ways, manipulates union activities and intimidates dissident union leaders.
In one example, Agapito Gonzalez Cavazos, head of the Day Laborers' and Industrial Workers Union in Matamoros, across the Rio Grande from Brownsville, Tex., tried openly last year to negotiate higher wages than allowed by a longstanding pact between the Government and the national labor federation. The federal police arrested him on four-year-old tax evasion charges and detained him for months. The settlement reached in his absence was substantially less than he had been seeking.
 
The Unions
Inflation Is Curbed, But Workers Pay
 Every Monday, Fidel Velazquez, the 92-year-old leader of Mexico's national labor organization, the Confederation of Mexican Workers, holds a news conference to discuss the state of Mexican workers. In a country where the President and all major political leaders cannot run for re-election, Don Fidel, as everyone refers to him, has been head of organized labor for more than 50 years.
His long reign, and his role as a political figure, is one sign of how unions here are tied much more closely to the Government than in the United States. Stability is a key element in a six-year-old pact between Government and unions on wage and price controls that has helped bring inflation below 10 percent for the first time in 20 years and keep Mexico attractive to many American executives.
President Salinas acknowledges Mr. Velazquez's help in reducing inflation. But it is the Mexican worker who has in effect paid the price for the pact's strategy. While productivity has risen, the buying power of wages has dropped.
Critics of the agreement are disturbed by the gap between theory and reality in the labor situation here. Official unemployment figures are usually below 3 percent, but many analysts say the real rate is higher, perhaps 15 percent. Mexico counts as employed anyone working one hour a week or more. Because Mexico does not have unemployment insurance, jobless Mexicans are forced to do something to bring in money, so the chewing-gum peddlers on almost every Mexico City street corner are technically employed.
 
The Workplace
Safety Is Slighted: The Wage Is All

The new $25 million Mercedes-Benz automobile assembly line in Santiago Tianguistenco northwest of Mexico City is the type of investment that proponents of the trade agreement say will benefit Mexico. Workers build $90,000 sedans in efficient, well-lighted spaces, and where appropriate they are given hard hats, safety glasses and advanced training.
But a more typical experience is that of the 50 mechanics in the body shop at Consa Ford, one of Mexico City's largest auto dealerships, who use neither masks nor other safety equipment in their dangerously crowded shed. On a recent afternoon, Roberto Morales, 23, struggled to remove a shattered windshield without protective gloves or goggles, using only a dirty floor mat to push out the broken glass.
"Sure, it's dangerous," Mr. Morales said. Then he shrugged and went on pushing against the jigsaw of shattered glass.
Across the shed, Samuel Gomez Davilla was busy spray-painting the front fender of a Ford Topaz midnight black. Proud of his work, he bent close to see any bumps or misses. Spray clouded his face and spilled on a co-worker who was lying on the ground nearby to remove a bumper.
Mr. Gomez Davilla said that Consa was inspected a few times a year but that no one made an issue of respirator masks. After searching for a few seconds he found his at the bottom of his locker. He said that it had been two years since he used it and that he had no idea where to obtain replacement filters.
But what is important to him is that he is working, and making money. As for working conditions, the 31-year-old father of two girls, who has been painting cars since he was 18, said: "It's always been this way. We're used to it."
NEXT: Mexico's environmental efforts.

HEADLINE: As Nynex Jobs Depart Changes Are Made

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
ON the surface, Nynex's announcement last month that it was moving 600 workers from an office building here to Manhattan appeared to be just another piece of bad news for Westchester, which has been hit hard in recent years by job losses because of corporate restructuring. The global telecommunications company said it was moving the employees to streamline operations and cut costs.
Local officials, who said they were at first dismayed that yet more jobs would be lost in the county, recently learned that a developer planned to include Bloomingdale's in plans for a major shopping mall adjacent to the Nynex site -- and that in the long run, economic growth and more jobs could result. 
 "My first reaction was that the changes at Nynex would come as a real blow to the county," said Sy J. Schulman, a member of this city's Common Council. "All these big companies are always readjusting, and Westchester keeps feeling the effects."
The county's jobless rate in June, the latest month for which figures were available, was 5.9 percent, up from 5.6 percent in May. The rate for June was the second highest for the month in 10 years, according to the State Department of Labor. Because many large corporations, including Nynex, are situated in the county, the effect of staff reductions in recent years has been reflected in unemployment figures.
 
Bloomingdale's to Move
 Shortly after Nynex announced that it would be moving some workers out of Westchester, Alexius C. Conroy, a Greenwich-based developer, announced that he had negotiated with Bloomingdale's, a division of Federated Department Stores, to move its White Plains store to the Nynex site. Mr. Conroy purchased the 156,000-square-foot Nynex building at 120 Bloomingdale Road for $21.5 million,
Bloomingdale's is now less than a mile away on Bloomingdale Road.
Mr. Conroy said he plans to demolish the Nynex building, a former Nestle Foods headquarters, and construct the 900,000-square-foot shopping mall there, at the corner of Maple Avenue and Bloomingdale Road, at the site of Saks Fifth Avenue.
If the Conroy Development Company's plans are approved by the city, the new mall, Westchester Place, would become the third new shopping center planned for this city.
 
New Malls Under Way
 "It's a perfect situation," said John H. Rostenberg, a partner with the Rostenberg-Doern Company, a corporate real estate concern in Stamford and Purchase. "Nynex is doing what it needs to do, and the city may get what it needs in terms of new shopping and increased sales revenues."
The Manhattan-based O'Connor Group, a real estate investment firm, is building a one-million-square-foot shopping mall at the corner of Maple Avenue and Bloomingdale Road, across Maple from the proposed Conroy project. The Westchester, as it is called, will include the present Neiman Marcus store and add 150 smaller stores and the first Nordstrom store in New York State.
Another mall, the Westchester Pavilion, in the former Alexander's building at South Broadway and Maple Avenue, plans to open discount stores, like Toys 'R' Us, this fall.
Also, the Galleria, an 880,000-square-foot mall in downtown White Plains, is undergoing an $8 million renovation.
Mr. Conroy has suggested that the current Bloomingdale's site on Bloomingdale Road -- which Federated leases from the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center -- could become an entertainment center with a movie theater and a supermarket. He said that he is taking over Federated's lease obligations for the property.
The Nynex employees who will be moving early in 1995 are part of the company's Telesector Resources Group, a technical support, information services and marketing division.
Another 5,600 Nynex workers in White Plains will not be moving, said Linda Ruggiera, a spokeswoman.
The employees' move to 1160 Avenue of the Americas will bring the Telesector division closer to New York Telephone employees who use their services, Ms. Ruggiera said. She said no layoffs were involved.

HEADLINE: Years After Bias Ruling, Yonkers Still a House Divided

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
MARY MUNSON is weary from the din in the streets, the filth in the elevators and the ever-present threat of drugs and violence that stalks her son and daughter as they travel to and from school. After 10 years of living in this rundown west side neighborhood, Ms. Munson -- who is black and raising her children alone -- said she hopes the next phase of a court-ordered housing desegregation plan will mean an opportunity to finally better her family's circumstances.
Ms. Munson, locking the steel gate behind her in the courtyard of the federally subsidized apartment building for people of low and moderate income where she lives, escorted a visitor to her apartment, to meet Ha-Saun and Tamara, her 15-year-old twins. Once inside, Ms. Munson, who is an executive assistant for Barnes and Noble Bookstores in Manhattan, talked about how the mostly black and Hispanic areas of this city have deteriorated over the years, how her children rarely go outside anymore and about how much she wants to move to a neighborhood where there are lawns, shade trees and safe places to ride a bike. 
 On the east side of this city, in a mostly white neighborhood known as Mohegan Heights -- where the streets are named after Indian tribes and where flower beds flatter well-watered lawns -- Anthony C. Romeo, a retired paint salesman, remembered when he moved here from the Bronx 39 years ago. He said he purchased his four-bedroom house, which cost $28,000 then, "by the skin of my teeth."
The Tudor-style home with its circular driveway is worth about $285,000 in today's market. But Mr. Romeo and his wife, Mary, who are white, fear that a Federal judge's order to build subsidized housing in their neighborhood for west side residents like Ms. Munson could cause the value of their home to plummet.
"Real estate agents will tell you that no one wants to buy if that kind of housing is coming in," Mr. Romeo said.
But Kenneth W. Jenkins, president of the Yonkers branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, disagreed. "Affordable housing," he said, "doesn't bring down the neighborhood, it just brings in new people."
The N.A.A.C.P., along with the United States Department of Justice, are plaintiffs in an ongoing desegregation lawsuit against the city. In 1986, Federal District Judge Leonard B. Sand found the city and school system guilty of intentional segregation over a nearly 40-year period. He ordered racial integration of the schools and extracted a consent decree from the city to integrate its housing.
Judge Sand's order to build 200 units of low-cost housing for mostly minority families in largely white neighborhoods of this city is close to completion. Most of these units have been occupied for more than a year and although there was initially strong objection to the plan by neighborhood homeowners, there have been few substantive complaints since then.
The second part of his housing plan -- the scattering of an additional 800 units of affordable moderate-income housing in white neighborhoods in east and northwest Yonkers -- has not yet begun.
Last month in United States District Court in Manhattan, Judge Sand directed a court-appointed Fair Housing Implementation Office to seek proposals from builders willing to construct 170 rental and ownership units on three east side sites. At least half of the units in any building would be available at market rate, and the rest would be affordable units for people who have lived in public housing in Yonkers within the last 22 years or who live or work in Yonkers now within income guidelines.
The judge also directed the city to work with a nonprofit housing agency to implement a plan for developing at least 250 units of affordable housing in existing sites, like cooperative or condominium buildings. The judge indicated that if the city were successful in placing families in more than 250 existing units, the additional units might be credited against the number of new housing units that needed to be built.
In interviews last week, some east side residents said Judge Sand was unfairly imposing a housing plan on people who had worked hard for their money and wanted only to preserve the equity in the homes they owned. Also, they flatly rejected stereotyping that suggested their opposition to the plan had racist roots.
"The bottom line is economics, not color," Mr. Romeo said. "Personally, I don't care what race someone is. If you have the money, you have the right to live where you want. It's as simple as that."
Dionisia Sanchez, a nurse, and her husband, John, who owns a self-service laundry, also live in Mohegan Heights. The Hispanic couple purchased their Tudor-style home three years ago for $300,000. Mrs. Sanchez said that her white neighbors have always been friendly, greeting the family with home-grown vegetables and flowers when they moved in. Over the years, they began to socialize, forming close friendships and celebrating birthdays and anniversaries together.
 
'It's Not Fair'
 The Sanchez and Romeo families have never met, but they share in common their opposition to Judge Sand's latest proposals, because one of the sites being considered by the Fair Housing Implementation Office is on an empty lot at the corner of Tuckahoe Road and Cross Street, close to the Mohegan Heights neighborhood.
"It's not fair," Mrs. Sanchez said. "You have to work for what you get, like we did. People who get something for nothing don't take care of property, and then the rest of us suffer."
Ms. Munson may live across town in a poor neighborhood, but she is dealing with a similar problem.
"Our building used to be nice," said Ms. Munson, who pays $850 a month for a three-bedroom apartment. "But some welfare people are coming here now and messing it up. I, too, resent people getting something for nothing and abusing it."
 
A Chance to Buy a Home
 Ms. Munson said she tries to insulate her family from negative influences in the neighborhood, and she has not allowed Ha-Saun to cut designs into his hair or wear baggy pants, as some other black youths do. "We want to stay away from being stereotyped," she explained. She said she is raising the children, both of whom are studying to be architects, as Jehovah's Witnesses.
Despite her efforts, she said the only way she could truly escape the problems of her neighborhood would be to buy a cooperative or condominium apartment in a "nice area on the east side" with the help of a government subsidy. She earns $35,500 a year and has not been able to save enough money for a down payment on a home of her own.
But an advertisement placed in a local newspaper in April by the Yonkers Bureau of Community Development recently caught Ms. Munson's attention. It read: "Interested in affordable housing? You could be enjoying your new home in as little as one month!"
The ad explained that the city was creating opportunities for first-time home ownership. To be eligible for government subsidies, the ad said, individuals who apply must earn less than $46,800. For a family of four, the limit was $66,960.
 
Many Coops and Condos for Sale
 Because the city wants to scatter subsidized units in existing buildings throughout the east and northwest sections of Yonkers, its plan "offers a cost-effective way to more completely integrate minorities and other people into the fabric of the community," said Marie E. Burkart, director of the Community Development Bureau.
Ms. Burkart explained that the city, through the outside housing agency, could draw on the large pool of cooperatives and condominiums that are for sale in east and northwest Yonkers, some at below-market prices in a flagging real estate market.
She said that families or individuals who are found creditworthy would be matched with a bank and would be eligible for mortgage or down-payment subsidies, using Federal Community Development Block Grant funds. Other applicants would receive credit counseling to prepare them for purchasing a home in the future.
More than 1,000 applicants responded to the ad the city ran, Ms. Burkart said.
 
Objections Are Unwarranted
 At the Fair Housing Implementation Office, Linda D. Blake, the program coordinator, termed the residents' objections to the housing plans unwarranted and "arrogant." She said the income of those who would be eligible for subsidized housing could well be the same as many of the people already living in the east side neighborhoods -- particularly those who bought their homes years ago at cheaper prices.
Ms. Blake pointed out that if someone purchased a home in the 1950's, they may have been eligible for Veterans Administration or other Federal loan guarantees. "Now the Federal Government is putting loans into place for others under this program," she said.
The east side property owners say it's a matter of economics "because that's a more comfortable argument," she said, adding, "But the issue was certainly race in the 1950's, when minorities' rights were being denied."
As the city and Fair Housing Office Implementation Office explore their plans, Mr. Jenkins of the N.A.A.C.P. has grown increasingly impatient.
"This is all taking far too long and far too many resources," he said, explaining that the legal costs alone for the plaintiffs in the lawsuit had exceeded $26 million.
"For that amount of money," he said, "we could have built single-family units in Scarsdale."
Meanwhile, Ms. Munson waits. "I dream, but I try not to get too excited one way or the other," she said. "For now, here is just a place to sleep and eat, like a filling station. Someday, though, maybe my children will be able to go outside on the street again, or have a friend next door."

HEADLINE: At a Movie-Money Lifeline, It's a Wrap

BYLINE: By ANNE THOMPSON; Anne Thompson is a Los Angeles-based writer.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
AST February, Dan Sherkow was gearing up to begin filming an independently made thriller, "Cops." The movie producer had a cast and a director in place and about $13 million in financing lined up through the usual patchwork of banks and advance guarantees from key European distributors. Then his completion bond fell through, and the entire project was in jeopardy.
Completion bonds are the insurance policies that independent movie makers must get as a prerequisite for bank loans. They guarantee that if a movie misses deadlines or goes over-budget, a bond company can take over and complete production or repay the lenders. 
 Mr. Sherkow had been working on a deal with the Completion Bond Company when he learned that it was about to stop issuing bonds. Now, six months later, Mr. Sherkow says he is confident that "Cops" will be made after all, but at least eight months later than planned.
He has a letter of intent from one of the two remaining American bond companies, Film Finances Inc. As an established producer ("Suspect" is among his credits), he will probably get his bond and the money to make his movie. "It's the fringe pictures that have a real problem," Mr. Sherkow said. "There are only two companies out there."
Indeed, the impending demise of Completion Bond -- which will close its doors as soon as the films it has already bonded are completed -- has sent ripples of concern through the ranks of independent film makers, underscoring the importance of the bonds to the movie industry.
In its 12-year history, Completion Bond, based in Los Angeles, won a reputation as the most aggressive in the business, guaranteeing more than 1,000 movies, including some of the most expensive high-risk projects, like "1492," a Paramount release in the summer of 1992. It stopped issuing bonds in April after the Trans america Corporation, the insurer that bought the company in 1990, decided that the responsibility and risks of the business outweighed the rewards.
Completion Bond had been buffeted by stiff competition from its big rival, Film Finances, in a battle that forced bond fees down for both. And last year, Completion Bond had to step in and spend millions to complete "Malcolm X" and "Hoffa."
The departure of Completion Bond leaves the field to the more conservative Film Finances and a small newcomer, International Film Guarantors, both of Los Angeles.
With fewer and more cautious bond companies to choose from, independent producers have found that bond fees have gone up sharply, to between 3 percent and 5 percent of a movie's budget, according to Mr. Sherkow. At their nadir, the fees had dropped to as little as 1 percent.
Some producers are also experiencing delays in getting bond commitments. Even Film Finances is not issuing some bonds because it is renegotiating with its re-insurer, Lloyd's of London, in light of its more advantageous position in the market. It is expected to issue more bonds within the month. Re-insurers are the insurers that stand behind bond issuers as the ultimate guarantors.
Worst of all for the independent producers, those with the riskiest projects may find it impossible to get bonds, some in the industry say.
Film Finances, for example, has a limit on the size of the pictures it will bond, and is turning down projects. "With more projects submitted, they can pick and choose," Mr. Sherkow said. "It's ironic that this is happening at a time when independent pictures are at the pinnacle of growth, with high-profile movies like 'Howards End,' 'The Player' and 'The Crying Game' making distributors more open to them."
The bottom line is that some movies will reach the screen only if the producers can find sanctuary among the major studios. But getting studio support is a long shot for the less commercial projects.
Terry Curtis Fox, the screenwriter of "Cops," said if the remaining bond companies "say 'no,' you're dead. You can make a movie without a studio, but you can't make a movie without a studio or a completion bond."
He added: "The bonders used to be the enemy that kept a movie on track with the threat of a takeover. After C.B.C. got out of the business, they started to look like the savior of the Western world."
The practice of buying a completion bond to get funding for low-budget independent movies gained popularity in Europe in the early 1970's, and became widespread in the United States during the next decade.
By the late 1980's, the completion bond industry was booming in this country, with Completion Bond splitting the market with Film Finances, which was founded in 1950. Last year, Film Finances bonded $800 million in movie productions and Completion Bond was not far behind, said Lenore Nelson, a vice president at the Imperial Bank, a lender here to movie companies. Neither company would comment on revenues and earnings.
AS the global financing of independent movies became increasingly common and complex, "the completion bond became the spine of the movie deal," said Fred Milstein, a former vice president at Completion Bond.
In the good old days, it was rare for a bond company to become involved with the actual production of a movie; not enough was on the line to warrant such close attention.
It was rarer still to have a bond company take over a production -- after all, producers certainly didn't want that blot on their reputations.
Slowly, however, more of the riskier, higher-budget projects, like "Baron Munchausen," "1492" and this summer's "Cliffhanger," were funded by groups of foreign distributors with completion bonds, rather than being underwritten and supervised by the Hollywood studios that intended to release them in the United States. In many of those deals, the studios, by making promises of distribution, helped the independent producers get their bonds as a way to reduce the studios' risk on favored projects.
The recession made the stakes much higher in those deals. "It put tremendous pressure on producers and financiers to squeeze every ounce of creativity out of every nickel," Mr. Milstein said. "When we had a budget years ago, there was a certain amount of breathing room that would be sufficient for any problem, barring a catastrophe. A bond was only supposed to cover unforeseen events."
Because of their larger exposure, bond companies gradually became active participants in the movie-making process, signing off on schedules and budgets down to the minute details, from expensive locations to the numbers of cameras and extras. Representatives of the bond companies became a daily presence on the movie sets, and if anything went wrong, they were prepared to take over.
Film Finances had to take over the special-effects fantasy "Baron Munchausen" when the production went out of financial control in 1988, and the bond company wound up spending $15 million to finish the project.
BUT as the risks and costs increased for the bond companies, their fees went down as Completion Bond and Film Finances competed for business.
"We're between a rock and a hard place," said Bette Smith, the founder and president of Completion Bond, at the American Film Market, an industry gathering here in February. "Completion bond companies have taken on an exposure never contemplated when this insurance was conceived."
The squeeze proved fatal to Completion Bond two months later. Trans america stopped underwriting the bonds "as part of our overall corporate restructuring," a spokeswoman for Transamerica said, "as well as due to marketplace pressures that hinder our ability to achieve a reasonable profit in this line."
With Completion Bond out of the way, conditions appear to be improving for the survivors. "Our rates have gone up," said Richard Soames, president of Film Finances, who also cited the ongoing negotiations with Lloyd's.
Higher bond rates translate, of course, into increased production costs -- making producers think harder about staying independent.
In a dramatic illustration of the new bond calculus, producer-writer-director James Cameron ("Terminator 2: Judgment Day") recently renegotiated his independent deal for "True Lies," a movie starring Arnold Schwarzenegger due to be released next summer. Rather than Mr. Cameron raising the bulk of the financing from foreign banks, and paying dearly for a bond, Twentieth Century Fox will foot most of the bill. "It didn't make sense to stay independent," said Mr. Milstein.
While there would seem to be opportunities for new entrants in the completion bond field, Mr. Soames of Film Finances says would-be players will find "it's too hard to get credibility" with re-insurers.
STILL, Ms. Nelson of Imperial Bank said, "a lot of people see an opening here in the bond business."
Some of the smaller regional bond companies in Canada and Europe are expected to enter the American market. And Mr. Milstein said he thought he could get a re-insurer to back him.
"The re-insurers are wary because it's clear completion bonds can be a treacherous business," he said. "But some of them are expressing interest because they realize there is a market need and opportunity. The business can return to being healthier if the guarantors get tougher and smarter."
That means higher rates will not be going away any time soon, Mr. Milstein said, adding that the bond company representatives promise to be an even more intrusive element in the production process.
"I see guarantors being selective about the business they agree to underwrite," Mr. Milstein said. "They want producers to act responsibly. Producers will have to bear a greater proportion of the risk."

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
The Challenging Life of a Corporate Nomad

BYLINE: By Michael S. Malone; Michael S. Malone writes frequently about Silicon Valley from Los Altos, Calif.

 BODY:
A LITTLE-TROD career path bred in the technology industry over the last 10 years may yet offer opportunities for the most independent-minded of the nation's unemployed managers: joining the ranks of "rented execs." But would-be rent-execs should be forewarned: the job requires a unique personality and can come with considerable emotional sacrifice.
Typically senior managers, rent-execs have lost interest in the concept of a long-term job at a single company and are hungry for new experiences and independence. They may be brought in by new companies on the way up, or to help rescue companies on the way down. Or, in the latest developments of a downsizing age, they may be rented by established companies to deal with special short-term projects. 
 Said Peter Van Horne, vice president of State of the Art Computing Inc. of San Diego, a firm created to manage just such rented technical managers at established companies: "A company has a new product it wants to develop but realizes that by the time it puts together a staff, that product won't reach the market in time. So the company comes to us. We can provide it with a complete product development team, senior management, a facility, computers, telephones, even a janitorial service."
One rented exec handled by Mr. Van Horne is Jesse B. Hillman. A veteran of I.B.M. who has worked at a number of companies and founded several others, Mr. Hillman, 52, is acting director of applications development for Mitchell International Inc., a leading maker of estimating and repair systems for car repair shops and insurance companies. He works on a month-by-month contract, yet has five managers and 57 employees working for him.
Why? "I get more control over my finances than just a 1040 with a W-2 stapled to it," said Mr. Hillman. "Mitchell pays me more per hour than if I were an employee, but it's also not paying my benefits. I'm in the driver's seat on those matters."
Rented execs hired by hot startups tend to bring a special skill that the entrepreneurial team is missing. In a technology company, this gap is often in sales and marketing. R. Greg Lynott, 46, of Boulder, Colo., has been hired by several companies, typically for only six months and usually as a vice president, to help establish relationships with distributors, set product value and define future products.
"It's addictive," Mr. Lynott said. "The adrenalin rush is fun. I personally get a kick out of calling people and saying 'I'm with XYZ company' and have them say 'With who?' I get a special thrill out of introducing a new company, product or concept. And the potential payoffs can be huge: A lot of guys in smaller companies take an equity position -- then they're off doing something else years later and they learn they've hit the jackpot.
"Best of all, there's almost no politics. When you're a lifetime employee working for that gold watch, you live office politics or die. In this job, politics isn't your concern -- you won't be there long enough. What counts is success."
John B. Carrington is the rarest of rented execs, specializing in the sometimes emotionally draining business of taking the top job at troubled startups and trying to salvage them. At 49, he has saved the operations of seven companies by selling them to larger corporations like Encyclopaedia Britannica, Cybertek and American Publishing.
On average he has salvaged firms with $10 million or more venture capital that have stalled and are sliding into oblivion. For C.E.O.'s pay and as much as 20 percent of the eventual sale price, Mr. Carrington performs what he calls "damage control," turning the company around and establishing a strategic alliance with another corporation that usually ends up buying the operation. The process is often touch and go, he said: "I've been to Bankruptcy Court more than once, but I've never had to file."
Now, however, Mr. Carrington is ready to settle down for a while. He recently turned down two bigger salvage deals to take a job with Digitalk, a $15 million maker of software development tools in Los Angeles. He admitted he was "getting tired of the nomadic existence."
For the life of the rented exec does come with considerable costs.
For one thing, it is unpredictable. Said Mr. Lynott: "Remember, you are entering a company at its highest risk point. You live and die by the sword. The statistics say you are going to work for a lot of companies that won't make it. It can be very depressing."
Just as important, as Mr. Van Horne put it: "You have to be willing to sell yourself every day. You have to determine what needs to be done and see the job through, not just put in your time."
Mr. Carrington added to this list a short attention span, a real desire to learn new things at a high level, a good network of investors who will hire you and specialists who can help you, and the ability to recognize your own weaknesses and find an employee who can compensate for them.
But most of all, you have to naturally be a lone wolf. "You always know you're going to be moving on," said Mr. Lynott.
Added Mr. Carrington: "It's lonely. It's the difference between the house you live in and the house you buy to resell. You find that you don't want to get too close because you are going to be selling the place. Yet even though you're not supposed to, you get the 'White Knight Syndrome.' There's a tremendous sense of accomplishment that comes from taking a dying company and not only finding a buyer but jobs for the employees in a company with good benefits and a future. You feel like you've done something."
So how long does he expect to stay at Digitalk? Probably years instead of months -- or, he said, "At least until my attention wanders again."
