HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Tennis Brings Life To Part of New York

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
"The Bronx has been too many people's prop for too long," said Borough President Fernando Ferrer. "It's always somebody's photo op, somebody's victory, somebody's chance to put blame on everything that's wrong with the world."
He surveyed Crotona Park, sprawling languid and green in the heart of the South Bronx on this warm, sweet Friday afternoon. "The Bronx is about good people who haven't given up, who've stuck it out. They become empowered when something like this comes around." 
Ferrer was enjoying a photo op and a victory of sorts, the coming around of a professional tennis tournament that begins today. The first $50,000 Bronx Pro Classic is only a borough and a dream away from the United States Open.
"I've heard of the South Bronx, I see the movies; I was a little worried," said Miles Maclagan of London, who is ranked No. 343 in the world. He glanced around, for muggers, junkies, drive-by shooters, but saw only police officers, ball-fetchers, other tennis players.
But Maclagan is 18 years old and he needs to win some matches, accumulate some touring pro points, write his name on draw sheets that matter. He would go almost anywhere.
"The Bronx is not Bosnia," said Ferrer, a snappy 43-year-old who alone among local politicians has been publicly rushing the net at George Steinbrenner's Bronx slurs. "Did you know we are the leading locality in America in housing production?"
"Yes, yes," said Leighton Alfred, Maclagan's 31-year-old coach, pulling his pupil out of the picture. "As Miles tours the world he learns that there are good places and bad places in all different places. We really must practice now."
Miles and Leighton hurried back to one of the 20 newly resurfaced public hardcourts, surely one of the best-kept tennis secrets in a court-starved city. But the Britons might as well have been on planet Reebok as the South Bronx; they were shuttled back and forth by van from their Manhattan hotel. They hadn't come from Europe to chat with Ferrer, or even Migdalia Figueroa.
Saturday, as Maclagan fought for one of the four qualifier berths, Figueroa, a 22-year-old mother of three, sat on a blanket about 100 yards from the fence that separated the tennis courts from the rest of Crotona Park. She would have been closer, but the police had moved her family and friends, about a dozen picnickers, out of the players' line of vision.
The cops had asked if they planned to barbecue or play loud music in the park to which they come most every weekend to barbecue and play loud music. No, they said, on this particular day they had brought cold food, which was good because the police were concerned that smoke might get in Miles's eyes or the throbbing salsa might disturb the rhythms of his game. Local police commanders had apparently been persuaded that professional tennis in the Bronx was a good thing.
Figueroa thought it was a good thing, too, but she wondered how permanent. "This is not a bad park," she said. "There's crime and drugs, you can get mugged at night. You have to be careful. With all the cops around now it's very good. After the tennis . . ." She shrugged and smiled.
Perhaps the Bronx Pro Tennis Classic is such a fine event because it is such a prop.
For rising players who need a boost in the world rankings, such as Britain's Chris Wilkinson (126), France's Jean-Philippe Fleurian (135) and Venezuela's Maurice Ruah (161), as well for more established players who need an upturn in their fortunes, such as Israel's Gilad Bloom (171) and India's Ramesh Krishnan (230), this tournament offers attention and opportunity just as the tennis world begins to focus on New York. The Open in Queens is two weeks away.
For local fans, it is a rare chance to watch seven days of men's singles and doubles -- for free -- in that same kind of clubby accessibility that has made minor league baseball so popular. Parking is available and the Nos. 2 and 5 subway trains stop at nearby 174th Street. Watch the stars of tomorrow shine right in your face today.
For the Bronx, it is a rare plug on the Happy News Network. The Yankees' presence, about two miles southwest of Crotona Park, has been devalued by Steinbrenner's Bronx-bashing, which both Ferrer and Mike Gill, chairman and chief fund-raiser for the Classic, deplore as a cynical negotiation tactic.
"It wouldn't be that economically harmful if the Yankees left, but it would be an enormous psychological loss," said Ferrer. "And the debate has been harmful. His arguments about crime, parking and attendance are nonsense, but they fit the misconceptions about the Bronx."
"This tournament is not about tennis," said Gill, a management consultant whose clients are among the patrons. "This is about a chance to look at a community in a new way. A chance to reposition the Bronx."
It is also a rare opportunity for tennis to find common court for both commerce and education. The main sponsor of the event is the New York Junior Tennis League, a City Department of Youth Services agency whose mandate, according to Deputy Director Sheri Sobrin, is to "provide free tennis to every kid in the city and make good citizens."
The 39 ball-fetchers, culled from the 35,000 city youngsters in the program, thought it was hard work, especially when they had to go to the bathroom and were trying not to laugh at the intense, muttering, wild cards, like Andy Adler, who was telling Crotona Park to shut up as he lost in the qualifying round.
"I was nervous," said Adler, an upbeat 25-year-old who just got his M.B.A. from Hofstra and is now trying to get his game back. "The ball kids would say things like, 'Ooh, how could you miss that?' and it relaxed me. It's a well-run tournament. They're even generous to the players. You know at my level you don't always get as much free water as you want."
"He needs to decide what do with his life," said his coach, Da-Lai Wu, a 35-year-old former Chinese Davis Cup player who said he left the tour himself 10 years ago after stubbing his toe on a hotel bedpost in Hawaii. The injury was minor, but the lesson was a major one he shares with all his students.
"I needed some stitches between my toes," said Wu. "It was going to put me out of action for a while. So I called my sponsor, and he said, 'Funny thing, my race car blew an engine today and my thoroughbred broke his leg. I'm going to rebuild the engine and put the horse out to stud, but I can't give you any more money.'
"I realized I was just an object. I had a wife and kid. So I went into coaching."
Wu coached at the State University of New York at Old Westbury for four years, and then opened "Rush and Crush," strategic consultants for touring pros. He said he thought the Bronx Classic was a terrific event, and was sorry he was leaving early. He said he expected to be back next year, maybe with Andy Adler if he got it together.
On the way out, Wu and Adler passed Maclagan, who had also bombed out of the qualies, and Alfred, his coach. They were trying to figure out how to get to the next tournament, which was on Long Island, which might just as well have been the Bronx.

HEADLINE: PULSE: Consumer Spending

 BODY:
Metropolitan-area consumers spent an average of $34,538 per household in 1990-91, up 10 percent from 1988-89, according to the Labor Department. Despite the increase, expenditures in many discretionary categories, like new cars and entertainment, wer down because of the region's sluggish economy. Consumer spending in the region was higher than the national average in most categories. One exception is transportation - because area consumers spend almost three times more than the national average on public transportation and less on new cars and gasoline, their total outlay for transportation is 4 percent less.
 
*26-county area including New York City and surrounding suburbs in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

HEADLINE: California Scapegoats

 BODY:
America's cultural and political trends traditionally premiere in California. For that reason the growing enthusiasm of California politicians from both parties for making immigration a scapegoat for their state's many social and economic ills is alarming and dangerous.
Leading the charge is Republican Gov. Pete Wilson, expected to seek re-election next year amid spiraling defense layoffs, relentless fiscal pressure, acute racial tension and growing anxiety about violent crime. The flow of impoverished job seekers across the Mexican border only heightens the competition for jobs and dollars. 
 Despite recent enforcement efforts, the Federal Government seems unable to control human traffic across the San Ysidro-Tijuana frontier. But the package of punitive anti-immigrant measures Governor Wilson proposed to Washington last week would bring no more than marginal relief. And the proposals would do so at a high cost to the traditional and humane values of this immigrant nation.
Governor Wilson wants to deny U.S. citizenship and public education to children born in this country if their parents are here illegally. He asks that states be freed to deny even emergency health care to illegals. He wants a new "tamper-proof" system of immigrant identity cards. And he wants Washington to pressure Mexico, in the negotiations for the North American Free Trade Agreement, for a police crackdown on its side of the border.
The proposal on citizenship would require amending the Constitution and diluting its proud offer of full citizenship to "all persons born" on American soil. And the right to public education was established by a 1982 Supreme Court decision. Congress could, if it chose, enact the Draconian health care proposal. But does Governor Wilson really want to see emergency rooms turn desperately ill, possibly infectious patients onto the street?
Tamper-proof identity cards, however, may be feasible and are already under consideration by the Clinton Administration. And no one can argue with the need for better policing of the border by Mexico.
Governor Wilson contends that he is targeting Federally mandated benefits that draw in millions of illegal immigrants. But a more powerful draw is surely the jobs and wages available even in a depressed California economy. That's why Washington's most recent legislative attempt to limit illegal immigration, in 1986, aimed at the workplace, imposing penalties on employers who knowingly gave jobs to illegals.
That law has not worked nearly as well as its backers once hoped -- the penalties may have been too modest to deter violations and enforcement has been inconsistent. But in light of the continuing lure of jobs and the near impossibility of physically policing the entire Mexican border, closing loopholes and increasing employer penalties would seem the most promising areas for further action. Yet Governor Wilson has had curiously little to say about tougher workplace enforcement.
Mr. Wilson stood on stronger ground earlier this year when he requested additional money from the Federal Government to offset the costs of Federally mandated expenses for immigrant needs. Although the full amount of his request was turned down, Washington eventually provided $500 million.
Asking Washington to pick up more of the costs of its failure to enforce Federal immigration laws makes sense. Last week's foray into nativist demagogy only makes political mischief.

HEADLINE: The Phony Retroactivity Scare

 BODY:
Repeal retroactivity. The mantra isn't quite as catchy as, say, "no taxation without representation." But that hasn't stopped the Republicans from using it to rouse voter anger at the budget bill passed by the Democrats and signed by President Clinton. The Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, and friends are incensed that the bill backdates the tax increases to the first of the year, three weeks before Mr. Clinton took office and months before he sent the legislation to Capitol Hill.
The backdating may not be fair play. (In a slightly macabre twist, the bill raises taxes on the estates of about 1,000 individuals after they died.) But it's not illegal, and the damage is minor, hardly enough to justify Mr. Dole's raucous outrage. 
 Retroactive tax hikes aren't new; Mr. Dole approved them when he served as chairman of the Senate tax-writing committee. In the current bill, the hikes apply only to the richest 1 percent of Americans and 4 percent of small businesses -- a fact that opponents conveniently forget to tell their audiences. And everyone knew at the start of the year that tax hikes were coming along with the new President. Besides, the Administration eased the sting by permitting taxpayers to spread their extra over two years starting next April.
The essence of the Republican argument is that the tax hikes should have been made effective this month, when the bill was passed. That principle is absurd. Tax changes often take effect as of the date they are announced in order to cut down evasion. If Congress had started the tax hikes on Jan. 1, 1994, for example, some executives would have bumped part of their '94 pay into '93.
In retrospect, Congress would have been wiser to choose April as the start date. That's when the legislation went to Congress. With this simple change, Congress could have torpedoed Mr. Dole's public relations campaign and lost only $5 billion in revenue, 1 percent of the total package.
It would also have been wiser on strictly economic grounds with the economy limping. The July 1 start date originally suggested by the Senate would have left $9 billion in private pockets to generate more spending and, therefore, more jobs. The extra spending wouldn't do wonders in a $6 trillion economy, but at least it would have been a push in the right direction.
Mr. Clinton understood this, which is why he originally proposed a $30 billion stimulus package that would have raised the deficit temporarily in order to pick the economy up before the heavy deficit reduction began. But his clever two-stage policy was buried by a Republican filibuster.
Retroactive tax hikes aren't fair to a handful of wealthy Americans, nor do they represent flawless economic policy. That said, they are hardly the disaster portrayed by Mr. Dole. The $500 billion deficit-reduction bill is chock full of other arbitrary, ill-advised provisions. But it's also a serious first step in getting Federal accounts in order. Mr. Dole's contempt should find other targets.

HEADLINE: Ex-Soviet Republics Look Again to Russia;
Undemocratic Belarus

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While Belarus can be commended for its policy on getting rid of nuclear missiles, promoting the country as a model for other former Soviet republics seems out of place ('Belarus, a Model for Ukraine," editorial, Aug. 4). Belarus is one of the least democratic of the former republics, with the former Communist bureaucracy entrenched at all government levels. 
 Since gaining independence in 1991, Belarus has made little progress in democratization and hardly any in economic reforms. Last year the parliament ignored a petition, signed by 400,000 voters and validated by the electoral commission, for a referendum on early parliamentary elections. Most news media are government owned or subsidized. Last Jan. 1 the few independent radio and television stations were shut down.
As for the economy, Soviet-style price controls and production quotas remain in effect, and 90 percent of the property is state-owned. In terms of governance, Belarus has a long way to go before it can be promoted as an example to be followed by any other country.
 
ART B. ARTMAN
Research Assistant, Freedom House
New York, Aug. 4, 1993

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
CLINTON OUTLINES HEALTH CARE PLAN PAID BY EMPLOYERS

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 16

 BODY:
Appealing for support from the "vital center," President Clinton today put forward the broad outlines of his plan to guarantee health care for all Americans, in part by requiring every employer to provide insurance coverage for employees.
While Republicans and small-business advocates warned that the plan could result in the loss of millions of jobs, the White House said it intended to ease the burden on employers by recommending that the plan not take full effect for five to seven years. 
 A senior adviser to Mr. Clinton said the delay would allow the Government to use money saved by cost-control measures in the first phase of the plan to subsidize the costs of small and low-wage businesses that otherwise could not afford to buy the insurance.
 
Providing a Rationale
 The cost of the insurance to employers would range from 3.5 percent of payroll for the smallest business to 7 percent for larger ones.
"I don't pretend to have all the answers," Mr. Clinton said in his first speech on health care since becoming President, "but I am absolutely sure that this is a problem that America cannot let go, that we cannot walk away from." [Excerpts, page A14.]
He said a failure to adopt changes now would send the cost of health care skyrocketing to 19 percent of gross national product by the end of the decade. Today's 14 percent is already the highest rate in the world. The details of the White House proposal will not be released until next month, and today's speech, to the National Governors' Association meeting here, aimed more to provide a rationale for strong action and to counter emerging criticisms.
 
Clearest Picture Yet
 But the sketch presented today by Mr. Clinton and his top aides offered the clearest picture yet of his long-promised plan to slash the soaring cost of health care while extending coverage to the 37 million Americans who lack health insurance.
Besides mandating employer-paid insurance, the plan Mr. Clinton discussed would seek to do the following:
*Guarantee health coverage to every American, with people paying "in proportion to what they can afford."
*Develop a system of insurance buying cooperatives in each state, through which most individuals and businesses would be offered a selection of health plans, enabling small businesses to get better insurance rates than they usually do today.
*Slow the increase in health spending by encouraging competition among health plans and by setting overall health budget ceilings for each state.
*Allow self-employed people to deduct 100 percent of their health insurance costs instead of the current 25 percent.
 
Questions Remain
 Mr. Clinton made it plain that his effort would seek first to reduce health care costs by revamping the insurance system and reducing Government red tape. Only then, his advisers said, would the Government require all employers to provide coverage to their employees.
But many crucial questions about the proposal remain unanswered, including: which businesses and individuals will receive subsidies to help buy health insurance; how much the subsidies will cost and exactly where all the money will come from; what benefits will be included in the standard insurance package Mr. Clinton said would be offered to all Americans, and how national or state health spending ceilings will be determined and enforced.
In his 45-minute address to the governors, Mr. Clinton also made clear that he had rejected health care alternatives that would have established a Canadian-style system giving Government the leading role or that simply would have required that individuals buy their own health insurance.
By putting the financial burden on employers, Mr. Clinton said, his Administration would build on a central feature of the current health care system. He said he regarded the approach as "the fairest way to go." Most the country's businesses, including nearly all larger ones, already help pay for health insurance for their employees.
But some smaller companies and those that pay low wages say they cannot afford it. A majority of the country's uninsured people are workers in such firms and their families.
 
Possible New Taxes
 Aides to Mr. Clinton said most of the costs of the new plan would be covered by savings generated from the revamping of the system. But they said the White House was considering increasing taxes on cigarettes, liquor or both to raise about $10 billion to help pay for long-term care for the elderly, including more home care.
Along with laying out the President's plan, the White House was trying to drown out the criticisms of those who have begun to shout down the plan even before it is released. Governor William F. Weld, Republican of Massachusetts, told reporters here today that members of his party would oppose "tax increases, price controls" and any proposal that shifted costs to the states.
Mr. Clinton warned that a divisive political fight could deprive the nation of a historic chance to change the health care system. "We cannot continue to do nothing," he declared.
But he acknowledged that his Administration could face a major task in seeking to overcome "fear of the unknown" as it campaigns this fall to win support for the plan.
With his call for cooperation, Mr. Clinton displayed some of the wounds of a man still bruised by the battle over his budget plan. He portrayed Washington as too fixated on "process instead of product" and too preoccupied with trying to "beat each other up" and said he was determined not to relive the bitter partisanship of the six-month budget fight.
He today that he was convinced that "what this nation really needs is a vital center -- one committed to fundamental and profound and relentless and continuing change."
Mr. Clinton said today that he was "absolutely convinced" that Republicans and Democrats could find common ground in overhauling the bloated health care system "if we can meet around a table without regard to party and listen to the facts and work through it."
 
Business Objections
 In defending the mandate requiring employers to provide health care for their workers, the President appeared to be responding in particular to sharp criticisms made today by Gov. Carroll A. Campbell, Republican of South Carolina, and John Motley, vice president and chief lobbyist for the National Federation of Independent Business, who portrayed the requirement as potentially devastating.
Governor Campbell, the incoming chairman of the group, told his fellow governors shortly before Mr. Clinton arrived that such an approach "could really chill our already lukewarm economy."
And Mr. Motley, whose organization represents 600,000 small businessmen, warned that the plan would have "immense consequences" for employers.
But the President assured the governors that his plan would serve to lessen that blow.
In outlining the details of that effort, Ira C. Magaziner, Mr. Clinton's top health care adviser, told reporters later that the mandate requiring all employers to pay 80 percent of employees' health insurance costs would be phased in only over five to seven years.
He said all employers would be given "a couple years' notice" before the obligation took effect, and said a Government subsidy would limit the health care cost for businesses employing four workers or less to no more than 3.5 percent of their payrolls. He said the payment for larger enterprises would rise to a maximum of 7 percent of payroll, the estimated real cost of health premiums for their employees.
To provide the subsidies, Mr. Magaziner said the White House intended to establish a fund of $30 million to $40 billion from savings in Federal medical programs including Medicare and Medicaid that are generated by the overhaul. He said one reason that the plan would be phased in slowly was that time would be needed to allow those savings to accumulate.
Just how the savings would be achieved in programs that have already been cut in the recently passed budget plan was not explained.
In his speech, Mr. Clinton also said that a plan to provide a prescription drug subsidy for low-income Medicare recipients not poor enough to qualify for Medicaid would also be phased in over time.
But it was not clear whether this implied that drug coverage would not be part of the plan's basic coverage for all Medicare recipients or all citizens, either immediately or ever. An Administration official said tonight that no decision had been reached on whether prescription drugs would be covered under the basic plan available to all Americans.
Nor did Mr. Clinton say whether other steps would be taken to require pharmaceutical companies to reduce the costs of their products, and White House officials said it was unclear whether that would be part of his proposal.
Mr. Magaziner said the White House had reached no final decision about whether the new cigarette or alcohol taxes would be needed to provide for the costs of long-term care for the elderly and those with disabilities.
But he said the Administration may need revenues "in the high single digits or low double digits" of billions of dollars a year, a goal that if met through cigarette taxes alone would require raising the Federal tax to $1 per pack from the current 24 cents .
 
Fondness for Former Post
 Mr. Clinton delivered his speech during a quick break from a vacation he began last weekend in Vail, Colo., and resumed tonight in Springdale, Ark., where he, his wife, Hillary, and their daughter, Chelsea, are to spend two nights with longtime friends.
The President's visit here also served as a reunion of sorts; he was an active member and onetime chairman of the governors' association during his time in the Arkansas Statehouse. After seven difficult months in Washington, Mr. Clinton spoke today of his nostalgia for that more amiable environment.
"Back East, where I work, consensus is often turned into cave in; people who try to work together and listen to one another instead of beat each other up are accused of being weak, not strong," he complained.
"I miss you," he added later. "I miss this. I miss the way we make decisions. I miss the sort of heart and soul and fabric of life that was a part of every day when I got up and went to work in a state capital. Somehow we've got to bring that back to Washington."

HEADLINE: Angered by Japan's Barriers, U.S. Apple Growers Retaliate

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WENATCHEE, Wash., Aug. 12

 BODY:
As pampered and protected as nothing else on the American farm, Columbia River apples grown specifically to break a 22-year Japanese trade ban are taking on a blush of red, a few weeks shy of harvest.
But what was supposed to be a celebration of fruit and free trade is fast becoming a major source of friction between Washington and Tokyo. The apple farmers here in the nation's most productive fruit-growing region, who have spent more than decade setting up 3,500 acres of orchards to meet Japan's standards, now say they have been betrayed.
 
Isolated Apple Orchards
 Concerned about protecting its own highly lucrative apple-growing industry, Japan has long insisted that American fruit be free of any insects that might cross the Pacific. American farmers say most of Japan's pest concerns are phony, used as a convenient trade barrier. Still, until now, the Americans have dutifully done everything the Japanese said they would have to do to get their fruit into Japan.
American apple growers planted trees that were isolated from other orchards to minimize possible contact with insects. Special traps for bugs were set up. And some of the fruit has been individually wrapped in paper while still on the tree.
All was set for this year's breakthrough crop. But then, earlier this summer, Japan raised fresh concerns about pests that the American growers say are nonexistent.
Infuriated, the apple farmers of Washington State, who raise half the nation's crop and ship their fruit to 24 countries, including several in Asia, have taken the first step to bring trade sanctions against Japan. They are also talking about smashing Japanese electronic products in symbolic acts of defiance.
And at a recent food fair in Japan, American apple growers had a barren display with a sign that read, "Empty boxes, empty promises."
"We have gone through every hoop they have asked us to go through, and we're just fed up," said Doug Pauly, an apple grower and shipper here. "We've had people tearing out pear trees and vineyards and rose bushes so they wouldn't be near these special orchards. Then, we get this close and the Japanese move the goal posts again. We can't win."
Apples are to Japanese and American trade policy what intercontinental missiles were to the cold war. Both sides have them. They have long been a bargaining chip. And now one side says it is time to put up or shut up.
In Japan, where a single apple can cost up to $5 at a fruit stand, American apples are forbidden by a long-standing agricultural policy that requires importers to prove that the produce is free of insects. The Americans say they have done this, but the Japanese say other scientific concerns remain.
The Americans, from the growers here to the highest reaches of the Clinton Administration, say it is a clear-cut issue. As such, apples have become the symbol of President Clinton's effort to open Japanese markets by appealing to the consumer.
 
Gains for Both Countries
 American apples would be a bargain to the Japanese consumer, while bringing huge profits to growers here. The growers had expected to sell up to 700,000 42-pound boxes, offering Japanese consumers the red and golden Delicious variety of apples at roughly half the price of Japan's major domestically grown variety, the Fuji. If, as expected, the growers were to get from $75 to $100 a box, it would bring them more than four times what they would receive in this country.
Two weeks ago, the Administration demanded that Japan take steps to import American apples beginning with next year's crop.
"The U.S. side, for its part, has bent over backwards to accommodate Japanese concerns," Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, and Mike Espy, the Secretary of Agriculture, wrote in a letter to Masami Tanabu, Japan's Agriculture Minister. The American officials demanded a "written Japanese commitment" of all the steps needed for apples to get into Japan next year.
The Japanese, who already import a small amount of apples from New Zealand, have yet to respond to the specific complaints of the letter. Nor have they explained why these new insect questions were raised at the 11th hour. In a brief letter to the Clinton Administration they said the recent change in Government in Japan would delay an answer to the questions.
In the past, Japanese agriculture officials raised concerns about the possibility of pests infecting their own fruit if American apples were allowed into Japan. And they have denied that apples were being kept out for political reasons.
"What Japan needs is for the the United States to prove that its apples are safe," KenjiNOr Nakano, a spokesman for the Japanese Embassy in Washington, said in an interview. "This is not a political issue. It is purely a technical one."
With the United States running a $50 billion trade deficit with Japan, apples are a relatively small item on the bargaining table. But, as Mr. Kantor said in his letter, the issue has become "highly symbolic."
He raised the issue last month in talks between the two governments during Mr. Clinton's trip to Japan. In the American view, Japan bans United States apples for only one reason: to protect their own farmers.
Washington State's 3,500 apple farmers produce twice as many apples as their Japanese counterparts. But Japan has more than 10 times as many apple farmers, who raise their fruit on small plots and receive high prices for the produce, primarily Fuji apples.
Nor do they see any market logic behind Japanese protectionism. They contend that Washington apples, marketed for lunch buckets and snacks, would not cut into the markets of Japanese growers because the addition of American varieties would complement the more delicate Japanese product, change eating habits and expand the market.
They point to past food barriers on cherries and beef, which were lifted to the satisfaction of farmers in both countries. The success of Pacific Northwest cherries, which sometimes sell for as much as $1 a cherry in Japan, has fueled the drive by American growers to get into the lucrative Japanese market.
"Here you have an industry that has played by the rules, done everything right, and in the end still cannot get into Japan," said Bill Bryant, an agricultural trade consultant in Seattle. "Now it's becoming symbolic of blatant, unfair trading policies."
Of particular concern to the Japanese officials in the past has been whether American apples might carry a pest known as the coddling moth. The growers here say any such pests are killed during cold storage, when the apples, before shipment, are kept in a dark room at near freezing temperatures with almost no oxygen.
But after the coddling moth issue was satisfied, the Japanese raised a new concern about fire blight, a bacteria that typically infects pears. They wanted to make sure that no pear trees were grown near the apples; the Washington growers complied, planting orchards that were at least 500 meters, or nearly 1,641 feet, from pear trees.
Since then, new pest issues have been raised. "We call it the bug-of-the-month club," Mr. Pauly said.
The Japanese say that even if these pests have not shown up in American fruit, their precaution is warranted by the need to protect their own produce from foreign insects.
Although they demanded that Japan take steps that would lead to apple imports by next year's harvest, some growers here have given up hope that diplomacy will work. They want to use the stick of reciprocal trade sanctions.
As for all those well-tended apples fattening on isolated trees near the Columbia River -- perhaps as many as 25 million pieces of fruit -- the growers say they will try to sell them to some other country. But given the cost it has taken to grow them, they say, they may not break even.

(Therese Frare for The New York Times) (pg. A13)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Yen, Trading Near 100 in Tokyo

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 17

 BODY:
The dollar continued to sink against the Japanese yen in trading here today, coming extremely close to reaching 100 yen to the dollar before rebounding in the late afternoon.
Indeed, at one point today the dollar hit 100.20 yen, another record low. But by late afternoon, the dollar had surged to 101.35, which was a tenth of a yen above its Tokyo close on Monday. The dollar finished at 101.62 yen in New York on Monday, down 0.23 yen. 
 The dollar had opened somewhat stronger this morning and there seemed at first to be some psychological resistance to reaching so-called parity, when one yen will be worth one cent. The dollar traded as high as 101.80 yen.
But then a Japanese news agency reported that an unidentified Japanese Government official anticipated that the dollar would go below 100 yen soon. Market sentiment shifted abruptly and the dollar began sinking.
"It seemed like the bottom fell out," said Richard H. Hardesty, vice president for foreign exchange at Chase Manhattan Bank's Tokyo branch. He added, "I think the overall sense is that it's really only a question of time before we break through 100."
The seemingly inexorable fall of the dollar and rise of the yen has set off alarm bells here that export-oriented industries will be severely hurt and Japan's economic slump prolonged.
Business leaders called on the Government of the new Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, to take whatever steps are necessary to stop the yen's rise and counter the negative economic effects of the currency situation. The Government has called a meeting on Thursday of concerned Cabinet members to discuss actions to cope with the yen's rise.
Mr. Hosokawa said this morning that while the yen's rise was "really worrisome," Tokyo was not yet ready to ask other nations to join in concerted action to stabilize currency values.
The United States and Europe have so far not shown much interest in arresting the yen's rise, in part because a stronger yen is seen as a way of reducing Japan's huge trade surplus.
One reason the yen has risen so sharply, dealers and economists said, is precisely because there has been no sign of support for a weaker yen from Japan's trading partners. While there had been reports since last week that the Bank of Japan was intervening in the market to stem the yen's rise, the intervention has not been effective because it has not been joined by the Federal Reserve of the United States and other central banks.
"The conspicuous absence of any intervention by any other central bank is seen as a de facto endorsement of the higher yen," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, senior economist for Morgan Stanley & Company in Japan.
A few months ago, Clinton Administration officials had said the yen's rise would work to cut Japan's trade surplus with the United States, and those remarks were interpreted by currency traders as a wish for a stronger yen. More recently, the Administration has refrained from commenting publicly but its view that a stronger yen is desirable is believed not to have changed.
The higher yen would make Japanese exports of such products as cars and camcorders more expensive on world markets. It could also make imported American and European products less expensive in Japan.
Beyond this direct action on the trade surplus, the rising yen is putting pressure on the Japanese Government to stimulate its economy and to deregulate industries and allow more imports into the country so that consumers can benefit from lower prices. Any such deregulatory or stimulatory measures would also help reduce Japan's trade surplus with the United States and the rest of the world.

German Mark Surges
 By The Associated Press
 The dollar fell sharply against the German mark yesterday, pulled down in part by its growing weakness against the Japanese yen.
In New York, the dollar lost 2.4 pfennigs against the mark, falling to 1.6870 marks.
Gold prices rose in reaction to the weakness in the dollar. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery gained $3.80 an ounce, to $373.10. December gold, the most actively traded contract, also gained $3.80 an ounce, to $376.40.

Companies
A.T.& T. will acquire McCaw Cellular, the nation's biggest cellular-telephone company, for $12.6 billion. The deal could profoundly alter telecommunications in the United States and give A.T.& T. control of a vast wireless network that would blur the line between local and long-distance service. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: One Verdict Reached on Detroit Officers

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 16

 BODY:
One verdict was reached today in the racially tense trial of three white former police officers charged in the death of a black motorist here last November, but the decision was sealed until all the verdicts are in.
The verdict was reached shortly after closing arguments in the case of Robert Lessnau, who had declined a jury trial and asked that a judge decide his fate. Separate juries began deciding the cases of his two co-defendants on Friday. 
 Until now, Mr. Lessnau had been somewhat of a minor player in the drama unfolding in Courtroom 402 for 11 weeks. Of the three officers, Mr. Lessnau was charged with the least serious offense, assault with the intent to do great bodily harm. So his case has been overshadowed by those of his former colleagues, Larry Nevers and Walter Budzyn, who were charged with second-degree murder and face life in prison if convicted on those counts.
 
'I've Heard Enough From You'
 Their juries went into the third day of deliberations today as the prosecution and defense made their final arguments in the Lessnau case.
At one point in the closing arguments, Judge George W. Crockett 3d seemed to sum up the feelings of this anxious city when he told both lawyers, "I've heard enough from you."
After court today, Mr. Lessnau, who is 33, nervously paced the halls or sat on the edge of a bench with his relatives. The mood in the rest of the city, where this case is sometimes likened to the Rodney G. King beating case in Los Angeles, is harder to gauge. Jeffrey G. Collins, a lawyer and host of a cable television program on the trial, said, "It's tense but hopeful."
"I don't think we're anticipating a violent reaction" like the riots that followed the original acquittals of the four police officers in the King case, he said. "I think everyone expects a conviction on something."
 
No Special Precautions
 Police officials say no special precautions are being taken to prepare for the verdicts. But local television stations plan live coverage when they are announced.
The Rev. Jim Holley, president of the Detroit Council of Baptist Pastors, said the death of the motorist, Malice Green, a 35-year-old unemployed steel worker, had shocked and saddened the city, which is more than 70 percent black.
"He represented a lot of young black people in the city," Mr. Holley said. "It could have been any one of our children or any one of our adults."
But he said he expected only small pockets of violence if there was any at all. Unlike blacks in Los Angeles, he said, black Detroit residents seem to have more faith in the government and the court system because the people who run these institutions mirror the city's population.
The two juries are made up mostly of blacks, the judge is black, one defense lawyer is black, as is one prosecutor, and the police department is more than 50 percent black. Both the Mayor, Coleman A. Young, and the police chief are also black. In addition, the prosectors in this case have mainly argued that the officers overstepped their bounds.
 
'Landscape Has Changed'
 Another clergyman, the Rev. William Cunningham, said that the trial had a good mix of races and that "without a card, you couldn't tell the players."
"The landscape has changed," he said. "The whole political environment has changed."
In case not everyone has enough faith in the system, Mr. Holley sent a letter last week to the leaders of the city's 2,200 churches, asking them to urge their members to keep the peace, regardless of the trial's outcome.
When the city will learn the outcome is hard to say. The juries have requested extensive trial transcripts, which may take up to a week to prepare.
They have testimony from 50 witnesses about what happened on the night of Nov. 5, 1992, when two plainclothes officers, Mr. Nevers and Mr. Budzyn, confronted Mr. Green, parked in front of a crack house on the city's west side and asked for his driver's license. At some point Mr. Green refused to show the officers what he held in his hand and a struggle ensued.
 
Witnesses Tell of Beating
 During the trial, Mr. Nevers, 53, testified that he struck Mr. Green with his flashlight when Mr. Green tried to grab his gun. Mr. Budzyn, 47, testified that he had never hit Mr. Green and did not see who had.
Medical experts testified that Mr. Green had died from at least 12 blows to the head, and several witnesses said that both officers had slammed their heavy flashlights into Mr. Green's head.
Mr. Lessnau arrived near the end of the confrontation. Witnesses said he pulled Mr. Green from the car and kicked him at least once in the back and the face as he lay handcuffed and dying in the street.
During closing arguments today, Mr. Lessnau's lawyer, Fred B. Walker, said his client had pulled Mr. Green out of the car and away from the confrontation with the other officers and did not use undue force in handcuffing a struggling suspect.
Out on West Warren Street, where Mr. Green was beaten, Vincent Williams, 33, said, "I'm scared of the verdict and what might happen." Holding his hand just below his chin, he added: "They murdered that man and everybody is full up to here. Everybody is tired of not being treated equal."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Excerpts From President's Speech to Governors on Health Care

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech on health care that President Clinton gave today in Tulsa, Okla., to the National Governors' Association, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:
I never want to go through another six months where we have to get all of our votes within one party, and where the other party has people that want to vote with us, and they feel like they've got to stay, and the whole issue revolves around process instead of product, political rhetoric instead of personal concern for what's going to happen to this country. There's plenty of blame to go around. As far as I'm concerned, there'll be plenty of credit to go around. I don't much care who gets the credit for this health care reform as long as we do it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Nobody wants to mess up what is good with American health care. We must preserve it and preserve it with a vengeance. But we also know what is not so good. 
 I want today to tell you what I think we should do. Next month, I will outline a plan to Congress that will offer real hope for all Americans who want to work and take responsibility and create opportunities for themselves and their children. I think the elements of that plan ought to be as follows:
One, we've got to provide health care security to people who don't have it. That means not just those who don't have health insurance coverage now, but those who are at risk of losing it. I don't know how many people I met last year all over this country, all kinds of people, who knew they would never be able to change jobs again because someone in their family had been sick. I don't know how many other people I met who couldn't afford their health insurance package because there was someone in their job unit that they needed to get rid of in order to be able to afford it. We have got to have a system of universal coverage that provides security to Americans.
Second, I think we have to have a system of managed care that maintains the private sector, organizes Americans in health alliances operated within each state, contains significant new incentives for prevention and for wellness and against overutilization, and that has a budget, so that the competition forces should keep things within the budget, but ultimately, especially in the early years, there must be some limit.
I will say again, if we don't change this, we're going to go from 14 to 19 percent of our income going to health care by the end of the decade. It is going to be very difficult for us to compete and win in a global economy with that sort of differential.
Third, there must be insurance reform. There has to be a basic package of benefits; there needs to be community rating; there has to be some opportunity -- I heard Governor Wilson talking about this before I came out -- for pooling for small employers. We cannot permit price differentials that exist today to get worse instead of better simply because of the size of the work units.
 
Cutting Paper Work
 And finally, in this connection, if we do these things, there will be massive cuts in paperwork because you won't have to have every health unit in this country trying to keep up with thousands of different options and all the myriad complexities that flow from that.
We won't have another decade when clerical employment in the health care area grows four times faster than health care providers. No one believes that that is a very sound investment in our nation's future.
Next, we have to have significant -- significant -- increases, not decreases, in investment and research and technology.
Next, in my judgment, we should attempt to take the health care costs of the worker's comp system and the auto insurance system into this reform. That might be the biggest thing we could do for small businesses. It would also perhaps be the biggest thing we could do to reduce some of the inequalities -- some of you might not like this and others would love it -- but the inequalities in economic incentives that various states can offer because of the dramatic differences in worker's comp costs from state to state, occasioned more than anything else by the health care burden of worker's comp.
Next, I think that we should have 100 percent tax deductibility, not 25 percent tax deductibility, for self-employed people. And that will be a part of the plan we will offer to Congress, something that will increase the capacity of people who are self-employed to maintain health insurance, whether they're farmers or independent business people.
And finally, I think the states must have a strong role and essentially be charged with the responsibility and given the opportunity to organize and establish the health groups of people who will be able to purchase health care under the managed care system.
I think we should expand options for people of low incomes on Medicare but not poor enough to be on Medicaid to get a prescription-drug benefit phased-in over a period of years. Similarly, I think we must do the same thing with long-term care. But as we provide more long-term care opportunities for the elderly and for persons with disabilities, we must also expand the options so that they can get the least costly, most appropriate care. . . .
And finally, I think there has to be some responsibility in this system for everyone. There are a lot of people today that get a free ride out of the present system who can afford to pay something. I think there should be individual responsibility. I think every American should know that health care is not something paid for by the tooth fairy, that there is no free ride; that people should understand that this system costs a lot of money -- it should cost a lot of money; it ought to be the world's best. But we should all be acutely aware of the cost each of us impose on it.
But I also believe that in order to make individual responsibility meaningful, and in order to control the costs of this system, there has to be some means of achieving universal coverage. If you don't achieve universal coverage, in my judgment, you will not be able to control the costs adequately. Why? Well, for one thing, you'll continue to have cost shifting. If you have uncompensated care, the people who give it will shift the cost to the private sector or to the government, and that will create significant economic dislocations.
Now, it seems to me, there -- we have four options, if you believe -- you have to decide, if you believe everybody should be covered, you have only four options. And I would argue that three of them are not -- at least based on what I have seen and heard -- very good options in practice as opposed to in theory.
 
Single Payer System
 Option No. 1 is to go to a single payer system, like the Canadians do, because it has the least administrative cost. That would require us to replace over $500 billion in private insurance premiums, with nearly that much in new taxes. I don't think that's a practical option. I don't think that is going to happen. And you talk about---- That would be significantly dislocating in the sense that overnight, in a nation this size, you'd have all the people who are in the insurance business out of it unless they were in the business of managing the health care plans themselves, as more and more are doing.
Option No. 2 would be to have an individual mandate rather than a mandate that applies to employers and to employees, saying that every individual's got to buy health insurance, and here are some insurance reforms to make sure you can get it. This approach has found some favor in the United States Congress, primarily among Republicans, but not exclusively, because it has the appeal of not imposing a business mandate, which has a bad sound to it. Here's the problem with that, it seems to me.
If you have an individual mandate, on whom is it imposed? And don't you have to give some subsidy to low-income workers just the way you'll have to give some subsidy to low-income businesses if there's an employer mandate? Who gets it and who doesn't? And if you impose an individual mandate, what is to stop every other employer in America from just dumping his employees or her employees, to have a sweeping and extremely dislocating set of -- chain of events start? So it seems to me that there are a lot of questions that have to be asked and answered before we can embrace the concept of an individual mandate.
The third thing you could do is not worry about it. You could just say, "Well, we'll have all these other reforms and just hope that everybody -- that you could lower the cost of insurance and simplify the premiums and have big pools -- that sooner or later somehow everybody will be covered."
The problem is that there is a lot of evidence that some people will still seek a free ride. And make no mistake about it, people that never see themselves as free riders still ride the system, because everybody in this country who needs health care eventually gets it. It may be too late; it may be too expensive.

 	 	 		. . .	 	So I don't think we can rationally expect to stop cost shifting or to have a fair system if we say we're going to organize all this and just hope everybody will get into it. That leaves the fourth alternative, which is to build on the system we now have.
The system we now have works for most Americans. Most Americans are insured under a system in which employers pay for part of the health insurance and employees pay for part of the health insurance, and it's worked pretty well for them except for the laundry list of problems that we talked about. But most Americans are covered under it. What are the problems with doing this?
Well, first of all, if you just passed an employer mandate and did nothing else, there'd be a ton of problems in doing it because the vulnerable businesses would have the highest premiums, and a bunch of them would really be in deep trouble. No one proposes to do that. In other words, an employer mandate itself would not be responsible unless you also had significant insurance reforms, a long period of phase-in, and a limitation on how much the premium could be for very small businesses or businesses with very low-wage workers that obviously are operating on narrow profit margins.

 	 	 		. . .	 	There may be some other issue, but I see only those four options for dealing with this. And it seems to me the shared responsibility, in a fair way, of employer and employee, building on the system we have now, which works, taking proper account of the need to phase it in and to maintain limits on lower-income and lower-wage employment units, is the fairest way to go.
Now, it seems to me that all this will be discussed and debated in the Congress. The governors will be a part of it. But the first decision we have to make is whether we can fool around with this for another 10 or 20 years or whether the time has come to act. Just consider this one fact: If health care costs had been held in check -- that is, to inflation plus growth -- since 1980, state and local governments would have on average of 75 percent more funding for public school budgets. In 1993, fiscal year 1993, states spent more on Medicaid than on higher education for the first time. And state spending on Medicaid is expected to jump from $31 billion in 1990 to $81 billion in 1995 if we don't change this system.

 	 	 		. . .	 	And let me say again, everybody who says, "Well, this is just too complicated and this is too much trouble and it's too hard to think about," ought to consider the consequences of doing nothing. Doing nothing means more people lose their coverage, and those who don't will pay too much for their coverage. Doing nothing means that all those uninsured and under-insured Americans will be covered by vast outlays by state, local and Federal governments. And the rest of us will pay more at the doctor's office, the hospital and our own businesses. Doing nothing means insurers will continue to be able to charge prices that are too high to those who don't have the good fortune of being in very large buying cooperatives, and that the paperwork burden of this system, I will say again, will continue to be a dime on the dollar more than any other country in the world. We cannot sustain that sort of waste and inefficiency.

 	 	 		.. .	 	We have focused this debate only on the minority of people who don't have health insurance and don't cover their employees and assumed that we would lay some mandate on them and make no other structural changes. I wouldn't be for that. You couldn't be for that. Although at least that would stop the cost shifting, it would not be enough. That is not what we propose.
 
'We Can Make This Work'
 But if you do this right and we phase it in so that as we deal with problems, we find them, we can correct them---- If the states are dealing with the management side of this through these health alliances, we can make this work. It just defies common sense to say that we can't maintain the world's finest health care system, stop all this cost shifting, bring our costs back at some competitive level, cover everybody and create jobs. We'll still, no matter what happens, we'll be spending a lot more than any other country on health care at the end of the decade, but we'll be protecting people and we'll be working with them.
I'm convinced that the biggest problem we've got right now is the fear of the unknown and the exaggeration into the unknown of what, in fact, is already known. To say that we're talking about some untried, untested thing ignores the experience of Hawaii, ignores the experience of every other country that we're competing with, ignores what we know about how our private sector could actually manage the problem better in some ways than Germany and Japan have managed it, and basically is rooted in our, somehow, our lack of belief that we can overcome all the ideological divides and the rhetorical barbs and the fears that are gripping us.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Surely to goodness, we can stop wringing our hands and roll up our sleeves and solve this problem. And surely we can do it without the kind of rhetoric and air-filling bull that we hear so often in the nation's capital. We can do it.
Now, I miss---- I miss you. I miss this. I miss the way we make decisions. I miss the sort of heart and soul and fabric of life that was a part of every day when I got up and went to work in a state capital. Somehow, we've got to bring that back to Washington.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Before making his speech to the National Governors' Association, President Clinton spoke with Gov. Tom Carper of Delaware. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeking New Asian Trade and Security Links

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Reflecting what Secretary of State Warren Christopher calls a new "primacy" for Asia in American policy, the Clinton Administration is quietly working with the economically vital region to forge links through security and trade agreements.
But State Department officials and Asian leaders concede that even as Washington turns more toward Asia, it is difficult to keep its gaze focused across the Pacific with Bosnia and the Mideast soaking up its attention. 
 As if to underscore the point, two days after Mr. Christopher said on a trip to Singapore that Asia had gained "primacy" in foreign policy, he had to cut short his trip and rush home to deal with the violence in southern Lebanon and the siege of Sarajevo.
 
'On the Back Burner'
 "If you're not a crisis area, if you're good guys, then you're put on the back burner in official Washington," said Tommy T. B. Koh, Singapore's Ambassador at large, and its former Ambassador to the United States. "It doesn't mean that you're not important."
So far, the arrangements are loose, informal and, in the Asian tradition, evolving slowly. Efforts are bring made to build the links through existing, although loosely organized, groups.
"The Asian preference, unlike the Western preference, is to take a very non-legalistic approach to things," said Mr. Koh. "We take actions step by step and allow things to evolve, rather to sit down and say, a priori, we want to create an institution, this is our charter, this is our mission statement."
One of the more solid plans is for the first Pan-Pacific summit meeting, planned for November in Seattle. It would bring together the heads of state of members of Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, known as APEC.
The organization, established in 1989, includes Australia, Brunei, Canada, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.
 
Talks in Singapore
 Strengthening APEC and another group, the Asean Regional Security Forum, were a major focus of discussions by Mr. Christopher and Pacific Basin leaders in Singapore in conjunction with annual meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, known as Asean.
At a news conference last week, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, the new ambassador to Japan, said that the Administration is also trying to fit American-Japanese relations into a regional structure. While calling the United States-Japan relationship "the key, the core," Mr. Mondale said, "we're trying to broaden the focus to include a more vigorous approach to regional mutual concerns and to concerns that cross the whole Asian Pacific region through APEC."
The idea of regional groups is also being pushed by Asian leaders who fear that America will scale back its military presence, leaving a worrisome vacuum.
To increase stability in the region so that economic ties can grow, the leaders are discussing the establishment of a regional security structure, similar to the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
 
Focus on Economics
 For the Clinton Administration, the focus on Asia goes beyond a normal diplomatic desire to head off any potential problems in what is now a relatively stable region.
The big reason for the increased attention is simple: money. For an Administration whose political life rests squarely on its promise to revive the American economy, the 2.3 million jobs tied to the $120 billion worth of exports to East Asia are riveting facts.
While the Clinton Administration delicately dances towards Asia, leaders on both sides are aware that progress could be brought to a crashing halt by a flare-up in some of the region's hots spots like Cambodia or Korea or over human rights issues. Some advocates say that the Administration's desire to get a part of the action is leading it to mute its criticism of political repression in a number of Asian governments.

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Grew Moderately in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Industrial production increased moderately in July after a two-month decline, helped by hot-weather demand for electricity, the Government said today.
The Federal Reserve Board's industrial production index gained a seasonally adjusted four-tenths of 1 percent in July, following drops of one-tenth of 1 percent in June and two-tenths of 1 percent in May. The Fed also revised previous reports of May, in which output was unchanged, and June, in which output was down two-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Sweltering temperatures in the East and elsewhere early in July kept air-conditioners working overtime. Thus, production at utilities jumped 3.3 percent, helped by a 4 percent gain in the output of electricity.
Economists were expecting the increase, but they warned that the overall number was not as good as it looked.
Manufacturing output advanced a modest two-tenths of 1 percent and production slipped three-tenths of 1 percent in mining, which includes oil drilling.
"The contribution from utilities obviously is not a good thing," said Louis Crandall, an economist with R. H. Wrightson & Associates. "The improvement in utility output will do nothing more than increase electric bills in August and act as a drag on consumer spending."
But, on the positive side, the overall gain in manufacturing came despite a decrease in auto production, which fell 3.7 percent, the third consecutive monthly decline.
Auto makers, in response to stronger sales in May and June, have already scheduled increased production for this month, which will probably continue into the fall. That alone should keep overall industrial production growing, economists said.
"The auto industry seems to have cut back production significantly enough to lay the foundation for future production gains," Mark Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., said.
In July, production of consumer goods other than autos and trucks advanced strongly, by six-tenths of 1 percent, with output of appliances, televisions and air-conditioners soaring 5.3 percent.
The output of durable goods -- items like cars and computers expected to last three or more years -- increased three-tenths of 1 percent. Production of nondurable goods was unchanged.
The various changes in production left the Fed's index of industrial production at 110.6 percent of its 1987 base in July, up 3.5 percent from a year earlier.
 
Operating Use Up Slightly
 With production increasing, the operating rate for industrial companies edged up to 81.5 percent of capacity, from 81.3 percent in June and matching that of May, but still below April's rate of 81.7 percent, the highest in recent months.
Economists watch capacity use closely for signs of production bottlenecks that could lead to inflation. An overall operating rate below 85 percent is considered noninflationary.
Economists are hoping to see the industrial sector shift out of stagnation. Production had advanced solidly during the fourth quarter of last year, in response to strong sales before Christmas, but has since lapsed.
Mr. Zandi said he expected production to be better during the second half of the year but warned that job growth in manufacturing might remain slow. "Many manufacturers came close to going under in the recession or saw others actually go under," he said. "They've been chastened and as a result they're not going to be aggressive about expanding their operations."

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Capacity Utilization" tracks total output as a percentage of capacity, seasonally adjusted, since February 1992; "Industrial Production" tracks index of total industrial production, seasonally adjusted, over the same period. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Zoning Rules Altered to Cover the Waterfront

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Approving the first zoning rules specifically for the waterfront, the New York City Planning Commission yesterday said it was signaling its desire for more public access and less high-rise development along the shoreline.
The rules could shape decades of construction on the city's 578-mile waterfront by requiring that developers of certain large residential projects open 15 percent to 20 percent of their land to the public. The rules also limit building heights in certain zoning districts from 110 to 350 feet, or about 11 to 35 stories.
 
Sending a Message
 Although the text of the zoning amendment, which was approved unanimously, did not specify the areas in which given rules would apply, planners said a general message was intended. 
 "The text effectively says, 'The megaproject is dead,' " said Marilyn Mammano, director of zoning and urban design for the City Planning Department. "We're looking for reasonably scaled projects with public access on the waterfront."
To take effect, the rules must be approved by the City Council, which has 50 days to consider them.
The stakes are high enough that negotiations continued until moments before the commission's vote.
The approval of the new rules follows years of pitched battles over waterfront development among neighborhood groups, real-estate interests and city officials. Fueling these fights, in part, was the absence of any zoning or planning standards by which projects could be judged.
"We came to decisions, but we didn't have a framework," said Eugenie L. Birch, a mayoral appointee to the planning commission, as she cast her vote. Instead, she said, projects like Brighton by the Sea in Brooklyn and Riverside South in Manhattan were considered "in a vacuum."
Richard L. Schaffer, the chairman of the planning commission, said that the city's overall zoning law, known as the Zoning Resolution, "breaks down at the water's edge." He called the new rules "an unprecedented zoning text amendment that will -- for the first time -- put the waterfront in the Zoning Resolution."
Yet the impact of many of the new rules will be impossible to assess until city planners actually apply them to specific areas along the waterfront. Such "mappings" are months, if not years, away.
For instance, in the lowest density districts of single-family houses, there would be no public access requirement. In lower- to medium-density districts of multifamily homes and small apartment buildings, 15 percent of the lot area would have to be set aside in developments involving at least 1.5 acres of land and at least 600 feet of shoreline.
But in the highest-density residential districts, 20 percent of the lot area would have to be set aside in developments involving at least 20,000 square feet of land, a little less than half an acre, and 100 feet of shoreline.

HEADLINE: McCall Dismisses 4 Aides for New Deputy

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 16

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall has dismissed four senior members of the office responsible for auditing New York City's finances, leading Republicans to charge that he is trying to protect Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Mr. McCall's spokesman, Marvin G. Nailor, said, however, that the Comptroller was simply cleaning house so that his new deputy compotroller for New York City can assemble her own team. 
 Mr. McCall, a Democrat, was elected by the Legislature in May to replace Edward V. Regan, a Republican who resigned. He later appointed Rosemary Scanlon as his deputy for New York City. The State Senate has not yet confirmed her appointment.
Those dismissed from the New York City office are Joan Westmeyer, director of the Bureau of Agency Analysis; Jeanne Ostrow, assistant director of that bureau; Brian Perlee, director of the Office of Fiscal and Economic Analysis, and Norman Gertneer, assistant director of that office. The dismissals were first reported today in The Bond Buyer.
Some Republican leaders suggested that Mr. McCall was weakening the New York City office in order to control its occasional criticism of Mr. Dinkins's fiscal practices.
Mr. Dinkins appointed Mr. McCall to the New York City Board of Education, a job he gave up to become Comptroller. Mr. McCall's wife, Joyce Brown, is a Deputy Mayor.

HEADLINE: To Governors, All Eyes on Clinton's Fight Ahead

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 16

 BODY:
The passage from President Clinton's speech that drew the heartiest applause from the nation's governors today was not about the substance of his health care package but about the politics of getting it passed.
Straying far from his text, Mr. Clinton declared: "Surely, we can do it without the kind of rhetoric and air-filling bull that we hear so often in the nation's capital." 
 But many of the President's aides must not have heard his admonition to the National Governors' Association; they were too busy pumping out more material. Even before the governors' applause had died down, Democrats were issuing a point-by-point "fact sheet" to knock down remarks made earlier today by John J. Motley, the chief lobbyist for the National Federation of Independent Business and a leading critic of Mr. Clinton's proposal.
Mr. Motley said the Clinton plan would have "immense consequences for employers," especially small businesses. Later, Ira C. Magaziner, a chief Presidential adviser on health care, came out to contradict Mr. Motley.
The speech by the President here today officially opened the marketing of his health care plan, a campaign that promises to be far more extensive than were the White House's sometimes fitful efforts to build public support for its economic package. In that effort the White House had limited success in overcoming Republican contentions that that plan was no more than a tax-raising scheme. But with the health care plan, Democrats vow to move much more quickly to identify the opposition and take it on in the five weeks before Mr. Clinton unveils the package before Congress.
The pitch is directed largely toward middle-class voters, many of whom already have adequate coverage and fear that changing the system may do them more harm than good. It is also intended to overcome campaigns against the plan by pharmaceutical companies and other industry groups.
"The bottom line is, this has to be sold to people who have health insurance if this is to be politically winnable," said David Wilhelm, chairman of the Democratic Party. "I think that we can convince people that after year after year of skyrocking premiums, that we can do something to bring down the costs."
Much of today's opposition came from Republicans, who also sought to get their concerns into play. Haley Barbour, the Republican Party chairman, stressed the fear that a new health plan would result in new taxes. "There was a lot of talk in the meeting about taxes," he said. "I'll tell you that."
 
Opposition Not United
 But the Republicans do not present united opposition on overhauling health care, as they did on the President's economic plan. Many Republican Governors and members of Congress, especially senators, say they genuinely want to support Mr. Clinton's effort.
Yet signs of partisan differences could not have been sharper than they were this morning at the governors' meeting, at the Doubletree Hotel in downtown Tulsa. The Democratic governors met in a suite with Mr. Wilhelm and Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, to talk about how to win support for the President's proposal. At the same time, the Republican governors met in a suite down the hall with Mr. Barbour to discuss how they would respond to the plan.
Echoing his colleagues, one Republican Governor, William F. Weld of Massachusetts, emerged from the meeting saying he and his colleagues were for improving health care but not for new taxes. "Certainly," he said, "I think Republican governors are going to oppose tax increases, price controls and oppose cost shifting to the states."
But he added, "That doesn't mean we can't get together on a health care plan."
 
Meeting With Constituents
 While the President was delivering his speech, other Democrats were meeting with their constituents, trying to pull public opinion to his corner. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, was talking up the plan in Hyde Park, Mass.
Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat, said he spent the last several days in his district holding forums on health care. "Republicans better get ahead of this parade," he said. "Those politicians who stand in the way are going to get run over."
It sounded as if Mr. Synar was following guidelines distributed to party members by the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, with instructions on how to carry out grassroots sales campaigns.
One tip from the committee was this: "Dealing with the naysayers -- pro-active inoculation: With a historic and landmark legislation like health care reform, we should anticipate the opposition to the plan to be mobilized, well-funded and strategic in its operation. They will run campaigns against the plan both nationally and in each district. Your organization will need to anticipate which groups in your district are likely to join the opposition and bring them over to our side -- or at least neutralize their activities."
Missing from the sales pitches are specifics. As much as they talk about how they are against new taxes or new mandates for the states, many Republicans have no answers when asked how to finance health care overhaul in the short term. And frightened of the tax-and-spend tag, Democrats are not eager to give their opponents any ammunition. So they are sticking to the simple slogans.
Jeff Eller, a White House communications official, said he and his colleagues had learned after the battle over the economic package that they need to move faster to identify opponents and take them on. As they did for the economic package, the White House and the Democratic Party will each set up command centers to promote the health care plan.

HEADLINE: Rifkin's Lawyer Seeks Jury From Outside Nassau

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 16

 BODY:
Arguing that Joel Rifkin cannot get a fair trial in Nassau County, his lawyer today proposed bringing in a jury from upstate New York to hear the murder case against him.
Mr. Rifkin is the unemployed landscaper who the New York State Police say has admitted killing 17 women. He was arrested on June 28 when the police found a body in his pickup truck after stopping him for a traffic violation. 
 At a pretrial conference today in State Supreme Court here, Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, Robert Sale, said that his client would seek to have the case moved from Nassau or, failing that, would request that a jury be brought in from another county, possibly upstate. He cited a case in a Florida county that was heard by jurors from a different county.
Because of the publicity the case has attracted, Mr. Sale said, "I do not believe that Joel Rifkin can receive a fair trial anywhere in the state, to some degree, but in Nassau County, certainly not."
The prosecutor, Fred Klein, who handled the Amy Fisher shooting case, disagreed. "This case has certainly gotten nowhere near the media attention that some other cases that have been tried in the county have gotten," he said.
Mr. Sale, who formally notified prosecutors today that he intended to use the insanity defense in the case, told reporters outside the courthouse that he would ask again that any other charges against his client be consolidated into one trial.
 
Agreement on Evidence
 The prosecution today agreed to give the defense a copy of Mr. Rifkin's school records, the results of DNA tests on evidence in the case and a copy of the report of an autopsy performed on the body found in Mr. Rifkin's Mazda pickup truck.
At his arraignment last month, Mr. Rifkin pleaded not guilty to charges of second-degree murder in connection with that case. State investigators said that Mr. Rifkin later confessed to killing 17 young women, who he told the police were prostitutes that he had picked up in lower Manhattan, had sex with and then strangled. The authorities say Mr. Rifkin killed most of the women in Manhattan and dumped their bodies in rivers and woods in a broad swath from eastern Suffolk County to northern Putnam County. No formal charges have been brought against Mr. Rifkin in any other county.
He is undergoing psychiatric evaluation by experts called in by the defense. Once the testing is concluded on September 3, the prosecution will send in its own experts. A pretrial hearing on the psychiatric evaluations was set for October 5.
