HEADLINE: Group of Governors Supports Trade Accord

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 16

 BODY:
A group of Republican and Democratic governors announced their support today for the North American Free Trade Agreement as President Clinton embarked on a tough battle to push it through Congress.
Several governors said they were satisfied with the side agreements reached last week on environmental and labor issues after discussing them today with Mr. Clinton, who was in Tulsa for the annual conference of the National Governors' Association. 
 Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican from Wisconsin, said he had raised concerns with Mr. Clinton that the Administration had not been aggressive enough in promoting the plan. But, he said, he was reassured.
 
 
'We Can Start Selling It'
 "We've let the opponents have a field day as far as making up arguments about why we should be opposed to Nafta," Mr. Thompson said at a news conference here. "Ross Perot is a prime example of getting a lot of attention from the media. We haven't had a real product. The product is now here. Now we can start selling it."
Gov. Ann Richards, Democrat of Texas, agreed that governors needed to do more to convince the public and the Congress that the agreement was vital to the economy. "We think somehow by looking east we will find the mecca of economic prosperity," she said. "I would suggest to you that the future front door of the United States lies to the south, on the border of Texas, Arizona and New Mexico and California. That's where we're going to sell our products, and this free-trade agreement is going to help us do that."
The support of governors is important because the Administration needs allies in the states to sell the program to the public and to Congress in the face of stiff opposition from many lawmakers, particularly Democrats. Prospects for passage suffered a significant blow when Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, said he could not support the accord as it stands with the side agreements.
Mr. Clinton made his brief pitch for the trade agreement during an address to the governors on health care. Most of the governors have expressed support for the pact in one form or another.
 
 
Assurance on Labor
 The President assured the governors that the side agreements on environmental and labor issues would protect this country, asserting that the Mexican Government had tied its minimum wages to productivity and economic growth and that any violations would be subject to fines.
"Nothing like that has ever been found in a trade agreement before," Mr. Clinton said. "It insures that workers on both sides of our border can benefit. And I appreciate the support of the governors for the whole issue of expanding trade."
Before the news conference, the governors' Committee on Economic Development approved a resolution affirming its support for the trade agreement, saying "it represents a positive step toward further opening the North American market for U.S. exporters."
But the resolution said that "states must have a role in formulating the domestic implementation of Nafta and its side agreements because they have the primary responsibility for items such as setting environmental standards, issuing permits and enforcing compliance with these provisions."
During the discussion of the resolution, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, a Democrat, said he was not sure he could back the trade accord. "It's not a partisan thing," he said. "There is a real founded fear that there will be a job loss. I'd have to be very concerned with anything that would affect the present economy."
 
 
Misinformation Cited
 Roger Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, told the economic committee of the governors that there had been too much misinformation put out by opponents of the trade agreement, and he singled out Mr. Perot for criticism. The Texan is often quoted for his comment that there would be a "giant sucking sound" of jobs leaving the country if the agreement was approved.
"His opposition reminds me of the Luddites in England who opposed the Industrial Revolution," Mr. Altman said. "We intend to fight tooth and nail for this agreement."
Other governors who announced their support for the agreement included these Republicans: Jim Edgar of Illinois, Kirk Fordice of Mississippi and William F. Weld of Massachusetts. Democratic Governors who offered their support were William Donald Schaefer of Maryland, Roy Romer of Colorado, Bruce King of New Mexico and E. Benjamin Nelson of Nebraska.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Rates Fall To 6.30%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates fell to their lowest level in two decades yesterday, as predictions of a retrenchment after last week's quarterly Treasury auction have yet to prove true.
At the same time, shorter-term interest rates also eased a little as investors and traders became more confident that the Federal Reserve would not move soon to raise those rates to keep inflation from re-emerging. 
 For those dealers who bought during the auction of a record $38.5 billion in 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds last week, the rise in prices on Friday and yesterday helped bring yields below the averages for each of the three auctions. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
 
 
Secondary Market
 In trading in the secondary market, the price of the new 6.25 percent 30-year bond rose 21/32 point as the yield dropped to 6.30 percent, the lowest in the 16 years since the Treasury began to issue 30-year bonds on a regular basis. The yield is down from 6.35 percent Friday and is the lowest yield on a Treasury security with 30 years to maturity since the beginning of 1973, according to data kept by Salomon Brothers. Last week the new bond was auctioned at an average rate of 6.33 percent.
The yield on the new 5.75 percent 10-year note dropped to 5.68 percent, as the price rose 7/32 point. The yield, which was 5.70 percent on Friday, is a new low for this year and the lowest since April 1971. Last week, the new note was auctioned at an average yield of 5.78 percent.
The rising Treasury prices and falling yields come as the Fed's policy-making committee meets today in one of its regular sessions to review its monetary policy. But because last week's economic data showed inflation rising at an annual rate below the 2.9 percent climb in 1992 and the economy still sluggish, analysts expect no action by the Fed to raise or lower interest rates.
Still, some analysts are predicting that the Fed might reverse a move it made in its May meeting at a time when the pace of inflation was rising at rate faster than last year's.
 
 
Fed's Bias
 In an apparent attempt to convince investors and traders that the Fed would take whatever moves necessary to keep inflation in check, the Fed approved a policy directive that shifted its bias to higher short-term rates from neutral. The shift would have made it easier for the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, to raise the Federal funds rate between the May meeting and the July meeting. The Federal funds rate, which is the overnight interest charged on loans between banks, is the short-term interest rate that the Federal Reserve uses to put into effect its monetary policy.
The reports of a shift to a bias toward higher rates and the subsequent testimony by Mr. Greenspan in July when he made the Fed's semiannual report to Congress, indicated that the Fed was ready to raise rates to curb inflation. And that fear sent short-term rates much higher.
The discount rate on the six-month Treasury bill rose to 3.29 percent in early June, after the Fed's May meeting and then dropped only to jump again to 3.24 percent in July after Mr. Greenspan's testimony. The yield on the two-year Treasury note followed the same pattern, hitting 4.31 percent in June, falling, and then jumping to 4.21 percent after the second wave of Fed fears in July.
With June and July inflation reports showing prices increases are slowing from the more than 4 percent pace at the beginning of the year and with economic growth still slow, the pressure is now off the Fed, and that is why some analysts have predicted a switch back to a neutral bias. And the market has reflected removal of the threat of an interest rate increase with a drop in short-term yields.
In trading yesterday, the discount rate on the six-month bill had fallen back to an average of 3.03 percent at the weekly auction of Treasury bills. And the yield on the two-year note dropped to 3.95 percent, as the price rose 1/32 .
 
 
'Out of the Window'
 "Both the long and short end have figured in that a Fed tightening is out of the window," Stephen Slifer, financial market economist at Lehman Brothers, said.
While he acknowledged that some analysts were betting on the Fed to drop its bias toward higher short-term rates, Mr. Slifer said he would not support such a move because it might backfire by making some investors and traders think that the Fed might not be as tough on inflation as they had thought. Such a backfire could lead to a rise in long-term interest rates, which would run counter to the Fed's goals.
Some traders and analysts had said on Thursday, when the auction of the 30-year bond did not go that well, that the market would probably back off a little, pushing yields higher, until dealers were able to sell a lot of the securities that they bought during last week's auctions.
Mr. Slifer said he was not sure why there had not been such a retrenchment yet. But he suggested that many portfolio managers apparently still had plenty of cash on hand and were ready to buy at the first instant it appeared that prices might be falling slightly.
Because of this lingering demand, although prices and yields are at levels not seen for more than two decades, Mr. Slifer said that any retrenchment might not be large. And he is still forecasting that the yield on the 30-year bond will drop to 6 percent by the end of the year.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of three-month and six-month bills yesterday:

HEADLINE: Taking Some Pain Out of Luxury

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
At least one Park Avenue household is eagerly awaiting a $190,000 refund from the Internal Revenue Service.
That is about how much the financier who lives there paid in Federal "luxury tax" on a $2 million emerald and diamond necklace he bought his wife for their 25th anniversary. 
 The tax bill passed by Congress on Aug. 6 repealed the two-year-old luxury tax on jewelry, furs, expensive boats and private airplanes and promised a refund to all who paid such taxes on items purchased in 1993.
 
Removes Most Items
 The tax, which originated in a budget bill that went into effect in 1991, applied to the portion of retail prices that exceeded certain thresholds: $30,000 for automobiles; $100,000 for private boats and yachts; $10,000 for furs and jewelry, including watches, and $250,000 for private airplanes. All but the automobile tax were repealed by the most recent bill.
Purveyors of luxury goods have welcomed the repeal as a silver lining tucked inside an otherwise gloomy tax package, which contains higher marginal rates for the wealthy, who are their customers.
"We believe the absence of this tax will probably be a catalyst for improved sales," said Burton Tansky, the chairman of Bergdorf Goodman, the exclusive Manhattan specialty store that sells more sable coats than any other store in the city. "Obviously, we're quite happy about the repeal."
There are signs, though, that the repeal may not fully resuscitate the market for high-priced luxury items. Asked how he intended to spend his $190,000 windfall, the New York financier, who asked not to be identified, said glumly, "on higher income taxes."
Still, several merchants who sell goods that have been affected by the tax are determined to push forward with plans to use the repeal as a marketing tool. Hatteras, which bills itself as the world's premier yacht builder, is running advertisements to bring the repeal to the attention of potential customers and offering a rebate on purchases made before Sept. 30. And Cartier, among other luxury goods retailers, is preparing to send letters to clients who are eligible for refunds for taxes they paid on jewelry purchases, explaining that it would be happy to provide the rebates by check or as a store credit.
"Income tax applies to everyone," said Simon Critchell, the president and chief executive of Cartier U.S.A., brushing aside the suggestion that higher income taxes might inhibit spending more than the luxury tax did.
"The luxury tax was discriminatory, and people resented it," he said. "If your idea of luxury was having a $50,000 hi-fi system, you weren't subject to a tax. But if you preferred a $50,000 bracelet, you paid $4,000 extra."
And if your idea of luxury is a $100,000 Mercedes, be prepared to pay about $7,000 in luxury taxes. Congress maintained the luxury tax on automobiles, which have provided by far the largest revenue stream of the five categories that were subject to the 10 percent levy.
(Lawmakers did make a concession on the automobile tax: The threshold, now $30,000, will be indexed to account for inflation.)
When it was passed in 1990, the tax was politically popular in Congress, where lawmakers described it as a way for the Government to extract money from the wealthy to close the budget deficit. But people in some of the affected industries argued that it also affected blue-collar workers and others of modest means, who suffered because their employers lost business.
"It's simple," Lawrence O'Donnell Jr., the chief of staff of the Senate Finance Committee, said of the tax on expensive cars. "It was the only component of the luxury tax that was working as intended and did not seem to be inhibiting sales in any way."
In fact, luxury taxes imposed on cars accounted for 91 percent of the total taxes collected on luxury items in the first six months of last year, the latest data available, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
Mr. O'Donnell said people buying jewels, furs, airplanes and boats either found inventive ways to avoid the taxes or simply decided not to make a purchase.
 
Ways to Get Around Tax
 Many wealthy American customers, for example, made their jewelry purchases at the Cartier stores in Europe to avoid the tax. Some retailers, like Ronald Winston, the president of Harry Winston Inc., said they simply paid the tax themselves to make sales.
Mr. Winston estimated that 90 percent of the purchases in his stores in Manhattan and Beverly Hills exceeded the $10,000 threshold for jewelry. "Most of our clients had to pay something, or in many cases we paid it," he said. "Particularly in New York, where clients had to pay a combined sales and luxury tax of 18.25 percent, it was hard for many of them to accept that an item they were buying for pleasure could incur such extraordinary expense."
Others said the tax on furs and most jewelry was so minimal that customers regarded it as an annoyance rather than a deterrent. Most furs, for example, cost less than the $10,000 tax threshold, and the coats that cost more exceeded the threshold by a few thousand dollars.
"I don't think anyone didn't come in and buy a fur coat because of the tax," said Steven Korn of Steven Korn Furs Inc., which has three stores in the New York area. "Anyone who wanted a fur coat in those price brackets wasn't worried about paying an extra $120 or even $1,000 for it." He said he thought higher income taxes would harm fur sales more than the luxury tax had.
 
Concern Over Economy
 And some are worried that the economy may be the biggest impediment to improving sales.
Jim Gardella, the president of the Norwalk Cove Marina in Norwalk, Conn., said that in the two and a half years the tax was in effect he sold only one boat that was subject to it. "The man called Monday morning and asked when he could get his money back," Mr. Gardella said.
In the years before the luxury tax, he said he sold an average of 50 boats a year that would have been subject to the tax.
Mr. Gardella said he kept his business alive by bolstering his services and selling used boats, which typically fell below the $100,000 threshold for boats. And while he said he was pleased the tax was gone, Mr. Gardella was uncertain how big a boon the repeal would be.
"The biggest problem these days is the economy," he said. "And while I am very happy this luxury tax is gone, at the same time they're over-taxing the people in the class who could buy expensive boats."

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
Swimsuits That Aren't Just for the Beach

BYLINE: By BERNADINE MORRIS

 BODY:
Back in the days when the bikini dominated the beaches and tanning was the prevalent sand sport, the more flesh the swimsuit exposed, the better. Times change. The one-piece suit, thanks to flesh-clinging stretch nylon no thicker than an onion skin, has caught up with the bikini. It can be long enough to cover the hips; it can have cap sleeves or a halter neckline. Baring all is not top fashion.
Even the bikini is no longer a thing of triangles held together with string. The bra provides adequate cover, even a bit of control when wired. The bottom is not as low at the waist or as high at the hips as before, and a small skirt or a scarf often ties over it. 
 Perhaps the most significant advocate of the covered bikini is Calvin Klein, whose bottoms have tiny skirts and whose tops have halter necklines that cover the chest. But in no way can they be termed matronly.
Since sunning no longer has priority, at least not for every woman all of the time, swimsuit designers have more flexibility. They are blurring the lines between fashions designed primarily for going into the water and other types of apparel, from casual to evening clothing.
"There's a multiple use for almost everything," said Miriam Ruzow, the president of Gottex of Israel, which sells its swimwear in 62 countries. "The striped sweaters that match the knitted suits can be worn separately with shorts," she said. "The fishnet and the lace tunics can be used as mini-dresses, and the sheer shirts can be worn in the evening with black pants or skirts. "We really think of the swimsuit as a base for warm-weather dressing, like a bodysuit."
The Gottex show, staged this month in New York, will be in Dusseldorf, Germany; Paris; Tokyo; Singapore, and Tel Aviv by the end of the year.
The best styles had a sportswear feeling, including creamy swimsuits knitted with cable effects accompanied by matching sweaters that sometimes extended to the floor. A modern switch on the traditional beach coat, the long sweaters could be worn alone as a coat or a dress. Also traditional were the red-and-white or black-and-white suits and cover-ups that suggested the nautical theme that is a perennial in resort and cruise collections.
 
Swimsuits Meet Ready to Wear
 Crocheted suits and cover-ups with the look of macrame provided the obligatory echo of 1960's fashions, along with the one- and two-piece tie-dyed styles. Both illustrated the growing connection between swimsuits and ready to wear.
The brilliant prints represented a specialty of the house, strong enough to hold their own against the most luxuriant tropical foliage. The Matisse-inspired prints with their vibrant blues were the most esthetically satisfying. There were also leopard spots with palm fronds, African-inspired brown prints with matching wooden beads and underwater patterns with ropes and pearls.
The design range of the 300 styles at the show was as broad as that of most ready-to-wear presentations. The suits are to turn up in stores in the United States starting in November, in time for the resort season.
The other shows were considerably more modest, in line with what Anne Cole called her austerity program. A member of a swimsuit dynasty -- her father started Cole of California in 1925 -- Ms. Cole is preoccupied with the 1930's, not only its economy, but its fashions. She particularly likes the period's long, lean line and has translated it into swimsuits with longer legs. "I never loved the high-thigh cuts," she said.
She called the halter the neckline of the season, used prints inspired by Provence and replaced last year's dots with stripes.
Many of Ms. Cole's styles, including those with the longer body lines, offered more coverage, and she believes she is on the right track. A one-piece suit with a pleated skirt was so successful last year that she has repeated it, this time with a striped top.
Although Taren Holdings, the owner of the Anne Cole line and other swimsuit lines, filed for Chapter 11 protection under Federal bankruptcy laws last week, Ms. Cole said yesterday, "I'm confident the line will be produced."
Michael Kors, who designs swimsuits for Trulo, also based in Israel, introduced swimsuits in nylon resembling charcoal gray flannel as his contribution to the season's ready-to-wear look. Some had openings in the front or back crossed by lacings. This design technique wouldn't have been acceptable when women were primarily interested in tanning; it would have left patterns on the skin.
High necklines and cap sleeves would have been similarly taboo. Now they have a significant place in his collection.
"It's beginning to come together," Mr. Kors said. "The line between swimwear and lounge clothes is not so clear anymore. And who is to say a woman can't throw on a pair of black jersey pants over a clingy black swimsuit and go out to dinner?"

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
Nascar Invades Indy, Which Looked Forward to It

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Chris Anderson's snazzy red Chevy looked almost fast enough to be out on the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today. Unfortunately for Anderson, it was stuck on Georgetown Road, a few hundred feet from the track, being outpaced by pedestrians.
Anderson and his buddy Rob Hunter had come here from Bloomington, Ind. The bulk of the trip takes an hour. Today, the last couple of miles -- amid 83-degree heat and 72 percent humidity -- took more than 90 minutes. 
 At least they weren't alone. About 50,000 other people had come here today to see 31 of the best stock-car drivers practice for a race that won't take place until next August, the Brickyard 400. A few drivers might be on the track at the same time today and Tuesday, the second day of the two-day session, but none would risk scratching a fender in anger.
Nonetheless, Anderson, who helped paint some of the highway signs that he had plenty of time to admire on the way into the track, wasn't questioning his sanity for a moment. "Oh, yeah," he said, "it'll be worth it, once you're in there."
Maybe it was the sheer incongruity of seeing 3,500-pound stock cars bellow through turns that are usually the runways for race cars that look and sound more like jet fighters.
Or it could have been the feeling for race fans, akin to spring training starting in December, that they had been blessed with a second season at a track that awakens the first week in May and goes back to sleep on Memorial Day.
Another spectator, Tim Kelso, knows the subconscious call of this place. He lives in Speedway, the small middle-class community on the west side of Indianapolis that is home to the track. He described the appeal of a day like today in Pavlovian terms: Open the gates, fire up a racing engine and it's feeding time at pitside.
"The track itself has a pull to it," he said as he stood by the fence in Turn One under the blanket of heat and humidity. Kelso, who said he wasn't that much of a stock-car fan, nonetheless could feel the track's magnetism.
"With the track's being open in August, that in itself is an inaugural event," he said.
 
The End of a Long Wait
 And a couple of hours in traffic aren't much when considering that stock-car fans have been waiting since 1909, the year this two-and-a-half-mile oval opened, to have any reason to come here.
Since the first Indianapolis 500 in 1911, this track has been the exclusive domain of Indy cars. But the explosive growth of stock-car racing in the last decade, along with the ascension of a new, under-40 generation in the Speedway's front office, made next year's Brickyard 400 too rich a vein not to mine.
"My initial feeling was I hated to see hallowed ground violated by anything other than Indy cars," said Johnny Rutherford, a three-time Indy 500 winner. "But times change, and maybe it's time to have something else here."
Rutherford's opinion has been so swayed that he was patrolling the garage area today, looking for a ride for the race.
 
The Family Track
 Although Nascar's version of stock-car racing has been around since the 1950's, early attempts by its founder, Bill France Sr., to hold a race here were turned down by Anton Hulman, who bought the track after World War II and whose family still runs it. Hulman felt, probably correctly at the time, that such a race wouldn't draw well.
He died in 1977, and 12 years later, his grandson Tony George took over as president of the speedway.
George, 33, brought with him a group of assistants, all under 40, who saw the track differently than his grandfather did.
"Well, I think with Tony Hulman, it was really more of a hobby with him," said Bruce Jaffee, the chairman of the Department of Business Economics at Indiana University's School of Business. "They've invested more in the track in the last few years than was done in the last 50 years. It's a new generation that's more bottom line and promotion-oriented."
The bottom line for residents of Speedway is that they will now have three more days of traffic and drunken revelry each year to go along with the bacchanals that accompany the race in May and its two qualifying weekends.
 
A Crowd, or a Small City?
 Peggy Swalls, the Speedway's director of ticket operations, said today that she expected all the seats to sell out for the Brickyard 400, which is scheduled on Aug. 6. (The first day for acceptance of ticket mail orders, by a happy convenience, is Wednesday.)
Last May, two accounting students at a local college counted the track's seats and determined there are 282,713. With infield admission tickets, the crowd next August could approach 325,000.
"For the most part, the people of Speedway have been pretty positive," said Mary Houldson, a Speedway resident and manager of the trailer park directly across the street from Turn One. "People are either for it or they're moving out."
Jaffee, who teaches in Bloomington, agreed.
"And now," he said, "instead of being dead 90 percent of the time, the town will be dead only 85 percent of the time."

 
 
PIT STOPS

 In Monday's practice, BOBBY LEBONTE have the fastest time of day, averaging 165.624 miles an hour. in his Ford. GEOFF BODINE averaged 165.256 miles an hour, and KEN SCHRADER was at 164.754.

HEADLINE: Biologists' Deaths Set Back Plan to Assess Tropical Forests

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
WHEN Theodore A. Parker 3d and Alwyn Gentry died two weeks ago in a plane crash in Ecuador, their loss left a void in the practice of tropical field biology not likely to be filled easily or soon. They had no peers, colleagues say.
Early in his career, Ted Parker astonished fellow scientists by walking into a Peruvian forest cold and immediately identifying 15 species of birds that biologists working there for years had never noticed. In time he could recognize nearly 4,000 tropical species solely by their calls. Al Gentry was often introduced on the speaking platform simply as the man who knew more about tropical plants than anyone who had ever lived. 
 The ornithologist and the botanist each reputedly could discover more about the life of an unexplored rain forest in a week than most other scientists could in months or even years. That made them ideal for the exciting work to which they seemed born: plunging into tropical forests on the run, often half a step ahead of the chain saws, to take stock of the tropics' rapidly disappearing biological riches. The aim was to determine, and fast, what areas most urgently deserved to be protected from destruction.
Mr. Parker, Dr. Gentry and two other colleagues constituted what some called an ecological SWAT team. Search-and-rescue specialists, others termed them. By whatever name, the enterprise in which they had been engaged for the last three years put them in the forefront of an emerging new strategy for exploring the world's threatened store of living things under the pressure of galloping habitat destruction.
They loved it.
Their work was just beginning to realize its potential for conservation when, on Aug. 3, the plane from which Mr. Parker and Dr. Gentry were scouting out the possible boundaries of a new forest preserve in Ecuador crashed into one of the heavily shrouded mountainside cloud forests -- wet, mossy, lush with the orchids so well known to Dr. Gentry -- that had been an object of their labors.
Both were killed, along with three other passengers.
The loss is a stunning setback to the Rapid Assessment Program (RAP for short) in which they were key figures, along with their colleagues, Dr. Louise Emmons, a mammalogist, and Dr. Robin Foster, a botanist and ecologist, neither of whom were on the plane. "Two-thirds of the unpublished, critically important information on the Andes went with them in a split second," says Dr. Russell Mittermeier, the president of Conservation International, the Washington-based nonprofit organization that put the rapid assessment team together. "You'll never find in this lifetime anyone like those two," he said. "Those two were worth twenty."
The world's panoply of biological diversity, as familiar as some of its elements are, is mostly unexplored territory. About 1.4 million species of plants, animals and microorganisms have been given scientific names. But scientists have no idea how many species really live on earth. It could be 10 million; it could be 100 million. Most are thought to exist in the tropics, where a species may be confined to a single mountainside or river valley. Biologists fear that as a result of deforestation and other habitat destruction, uncounted species are going extinct before they can be discovered, named and studied for their scientific and economic value.
That is where the Rapid Assessment Program comes in. Conceived as an emergency adjunct to more traditional programs of tropical field research, it focuses on threatened, largely unexplored regional ecosystems thought to harbor especially rich assortments of life. The idea is to send in the team experts to make a quick survey -- two-to-six weeks is typical -- of large organisms like mammals, flowering plants, reptiles, amphibians and birds that can provide a rough gauge of diversity. The information is turned over to local officials and conservationists so that decisions on what areas to protect can be based on science rather than politics or mere opportunity.
Rapid assessment is not seen as a panacea; longer-term research on finer biological levels like those of insects and microorganisms, which account for the bulk of biodiversity and the bulk of undiscovered species, is universally considered just as important. Some scientists have worried that the glamor of the program could divert funds from the equally essential fine-grained studies requiring more time.
But rapid assessment is nevertheless widely seen as having an important role. The idea of the "RAP team" originated in a series of conversations among Mr. Parker; Dr. Murray Gell-Mann, a Nobel prize-winning physicist and conservationist, and Spencer Beebe, a founder of Conservation International. Too few biologists were working in the tropics, they felt, and their research was going too slowly to be of much use in conservation. Mr. Parker told Science magazine in 1991: "I realized there is no way in the world we would know enough in 20 years" to decide what land to preserve in places like eastern Bolivia or parts of eastern Colombia, where few biologists have been.
The answer, it was decided, would be a new type of scientific investigation that would largely dispense with the traditional, time-consuming and painstaking collection and cataloging of specimens. Nor would the investigators take time now to write up definitive studies. They would instead brief their local counterparts, conservationists and officials and move on to a new place.
The program was inaugurated in 1990 with start-up funds from the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. Mr. Parker -- stocky, filled with enthusiasm, impatient to forge ahead, a former tour guide who took people bird watching in the tropics -- was named the leader of the team. His skill at identifying the subtle differences in bird songs especially fitted him for the rapid-assessment role, since tropical forests are home not only to bright-colored species but also myriad species with plumage blending in with the jungle background, species that can be picked out only by their calls.
 
Outstanding Field Scientists
 Dr. Gentry joined the team on loan from the Missouri Botanical Garden in St. Louis. "He was the most adept person in the world at going to areas of tropical forests, looking through them, seeing how many species of plants were there," says Dr. Peter Raven, the director of the Missouri institution. He could "recognize more plants than anyone else in the field. His abilities were very much like those of Ted Parker." Dr. Raven described the lean and intellectually hungry Dr. Gentry as "very driven: He really wanted to get over the next hill to look at the next place."
Dr. Gentry once said that what fascinated him was understanding how nature "is so beautifully organized; things fall into place; there are patterns."
Dr. Emmons signed on from the Smithsonian Institution. A favorite modus operandi of hers is to go out into the forest at night with a miner's lamp on her head, prospecting for animals. Once, colleagues say, she was stalked through the Peruvian rain forest by a jaguar wearing a radio collar, its presence clearly signaled by Dr. Emmons's clicking tracking receiver. "She's crazy," says Dr. Mittermeier admiringly.
Dr. Foster joined the group from the Field Museum in Chicago and the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama. His specialty is analyzing ecosystem types and patterns of vegetation. He is no slouch at identifying tropical plants, either: Once, says Dr. Mittermeier, Dr. Foster identified a species of plant from a fragment of leaf that had come from a seedling being eaten by a turtle.
The team's first efforts have been concentrated in Bolivia, Ecuador, Colombia, Peru, Belize, Guyana and Mexico. The Northwestern part of South America, including Bolivia, Ecuador, Colombia and Peru, have been of special interest to the team because biologically it is one of the richest areas in the world. The region is sometimes called the globe's epicenter of biodiversity. About half the biodiversity in South America is found there, said Dr. Raven.
Deforestation has cut heavily into this region. The forest cover of the Pacific coast lowlands of Ecuador, for instance, has shrunk from 90 percent at the end of World War II to 5 percent today. As the rapid-assessment team went about its work, the tree cutters were sometimes literally on their heels.
 
Competing With Bulldozers
 "Studies of the fauna were made difficult by the constant whine of chain saws," the team wrote in a 1992 report on its work in southwestern Ecuador. Once, Dr. Gentry inventoried plants at one end of a designated study plot while a bulldozer cutting the path for a road knocked down the other, the felled trees crashing dangerously close by.
The job has many risks besides that of a plane crash, most especially to health. Dr. Emmons contracted bubonic plague from forest rats, and Dr. Foster had both malaria and hepatitis.
The team's studies have been revealing, as a sampling of findings indicates. Along the Pacific coast of Ecuador, for instance, the biologists found that up to 20 percent of the plant species on most sites and 20-to-40 percent of bird species exist nowhere else in the world. In the same region they discovered a genus of trees, the Exarata, that is new to science. It was described in the team's report as "a large, locally common tree well known to local people. Indeed, we even ate our meals while sitting on sections of a trunk of this species."
In Bolivia, the team discovered that the region north of La Paz, from the high Andes to the mouth of the Rio Heath in the lowlands, probably harbors more bird and mammal species than any comparable area of the country, and that possibly 1,000 species of birds, "or an amazing 11 percent of all bird species on earth," live there.
The rapid assessment team identified a similar area of high conservation value in Guyana: the Kanuku Mountains, where the surveys indicated that more than 60 percent of the country's bird species and 80 percent of its mammal species live. And in Belize, they found 15 species of plants, 22 percent of the country's known total, not known to exist there before.
In terms of conservation results, the program was just beginning to move, said Dr. Mittermeier, and Mr. Parker, the team leader, was undergoing something of a metamorphosis. "Ted had gone from a hard-core field ornithologist to an international conservation bio-politician," said Dr. Mittermeier, referring to Mr. Parker's efforts to see that the team's findings were put to use.
The most concrete results so far have come in Bolivia, where several million acres of "the most diverse habitat on the planet" are in the process of being set aside as a national park, according to Dr. Adrian Forsyth, Conservation International's director of conservation biology. Other countries are less far along, but there is movement in them, too, he said.
While the deaths of the 48-year-old Dr. Gentry and the 40-year-old Mr. Parker have clearly set back the rapid assessment program and devastated their associates, recovery plans for the program are already under way. Previously made plans to move into other regions of the tropics -- New Guinea next year and Madagascar and Africa down the line -- still hold.
"All this is in a state of flux," said Dr. Mittermaier, "but it will be a maximum of six months before we have another team deployed in the field. Otherwise, we lose a lot of the momentum."
The organization plans to honor Mr. Parker and Dr. Gentry in a number of ways. The main one will be the establishment, with private and foundation contributions and in collaboration with other institutions, of the Parker-Gentry Fund. It is intended eventually to provide scholarships "for the new Parkers and Gentrys," as Dr. Mittermeier calls them, from tropical countries, and for the continuation of the Rapid Assessment Program.
In the near term, the fund will finance a Spanish translation of Dr. Gentry's recent book, "A Field Guide to the Families and Genera of Woody Plants of Northwest South America." It will also pay for the transcription and publication of the information in Mr. Parker's field notes and his many microcassettes of bird calls. The long-term objective of the fund would be to promote the creation of bioreserves throughout the region.
Conservation International has also broached the idea of establishing a biodiversity reserve in the part of Ecuador where the two scientists died, as a memorial to them.
"It still hasn't sunk in," Dr. Mittermeier said a few days after the plane crash. "I keep looking at pictures of Ted and saying, 'I'm going to give him hell when he gets back for doing something so stupid.' And then I remember he's not coming back."

Surveys many types of habitats, plants, birds, mammals and reptiles have been made by the Rapid Assessment Program (RAP) teams sent out by Conservation International into Central and South American countries. Part of the mission of the teams was to determine conservation status. The comments that follow give a flavor of the assessments made.
 
FOREST REMNANTS IN ECUADOR
A few of the remaining forest fragments were visited. In Cerro Mutiles, a protected area, the report said, "Studies of fauna were made difficult by the constant whine of chainsaws in the forest." As many as 6,300 vascular plants occur in western Ecuador; North America has only 16,000. The vertebrates of western Ecuador are similarly diverse. More than 800 bird species are known. 125 species of bats have been recorded.

KANUKU MOUNTAINS, GUYANA
This relatively small geographic area supports a large percentage of Guyana's biodiversity. Well over 60 percent of all the country's avian species occur in the Kanuku Mountains. The combination of savannas and semi-deciduous to evergreen forest accounts for the mammalian richness of this region. Several nearly intact ecosystems lie along the Rewa River.
 
COLUMBIA RIVER FORESTS, BELIZE
Nearly all the reserve is covered by old-growth forest. Many plant species were recorded for the first time in Belize, among them a rare mountain palm, several species of vine, orchids and a "curious shrub that grows only on limestone outcrops in the forest." Many bird species live in the threatened moist and wet forests in other parts of Central America and Mexico.

HEADLINE: Stop Nibbling at Nafta

 BODY:
Finally, President Clinton has completed the easy job: negotiating supplemental accords to the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada. But that leaves him the hard job of negotiating with the people down the block -- members of Congress intimidated by fear-mongering attacks by Ross Perot and the stalwart opposition of some powerful Democrats like the House majority leader, Richard Gephardt.
Congressional opposition is unfortunate because Nafta would have a positive, though small, impact on the U.S. economy even without the supplemental accords. The accords make Nafta even better by adding a thin layer of protection for U.S. companies facing potentially unfair competition from Mexico. 
 Mr. Clinton promised during the campaign to improve the trade agreement negotiated by the Bush Administration by eliminating the unfair competitive advantage that would be gained by Mexican companies that cut costs by violating their country's environmental and labor laws.
Mr. Clinton suggested at the time that the answer might be to set up international commissions to establish mutually agreed rules and regulations. But none of the countries were comfortable with such extraterritorial rule-making. Besides, Mexican laws weren't the problem; they're generally as good as their U.S. counterparts. The problem is the enforcement record of the Mexican Government, which is execrable.
The supplemental accords zero in on enforcement. If an international panel of experts finds that a country, say Mexico, persistently fails to enforce its laws, then its government would be fined. If violations persist, trade sanctions could follow. The accord is the first trade agreement to use fines and trade sanctions to back up labor and environmental protections.
Imposing fines on governments, rather than on non-complying companies, may seem an odd proposal. But it's quite clever. The fines are designed to compel the government to improve its enforcement record, especially when trade sanctions are lurking close behind. If Nafta were instead to impose fines directly on non-complying companies, it would give U.S. businesses ferocious incentive to bring frivolous charges against Mexican competitors on the outside chance of driving them from the market.
Mr. Gephardt objects that the proposed fines won't be imposed for an important category of violations: failure to protect labor's right to strike, organize and collectively bargain. But the Mexican Government refused to give in on this politically charged issue and it's unclear how much Mr. Clinton wanted to open U.S. companies to such accusations.
Mr. Gephardt also wanted to force Mexico to raise wages along with productivity. But as Mexico's market reforms take hold, wages will rise; if the U.S. imposed artificially high wages on Mexican employers, the policy would produce the same result in Mexico that it did in eastern Germany after unification: widespread unemployment.
Careful studies show that Nafta would have a minor overall impact on jobs and wages in the U.S. Some U.S. workers would lose work, but the number wouldn't be large. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that over 10 years Nafta would add fewer than 500,000 to the 20 million workers who would be displaced for other reasons.
The proper response is not for Congress to reject Nafta, and thereby deny benefits to hundreds of millions of others. Rather Congress should provide generous retraining and relocation assistance to those who will suffer.
Over the past several years, and under pressure from Washington, Mexico has launched important market reforms. And to overcome Congressional resistance to Nafta, Mexico has spent millions of dollars more to monitor and clean up the environment. It started near the bottom and still has a long way to go; but there are at least signs that it is taking the United States' environmental concerns seriously.
Had President Clinton now overreached and kicked away Nafta, he would also have kicked away real progress. That would have been bad economics and even worse politics. The supplemental protections that Mr. Clinton negotiated are porous, but the holes in the original agreement weren't large and didn't need major surgery.

HEADLINE: Old Ball Game Has New Demands for a Town

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUBURN, N.Y.

 BODY:
This is a story about how the warm and fuzzy mythology of baseball can collide with the cold and calculating business of baseball. It's about a community whose love affair with a team may soon end because its aging stadium is no longer good enough for the people who pay the salaries.
Remarkably, this story is not about George Steinbrenner. 
 It is about Auburn, which has been told by major league baseball that it must replace its 67-year-old stadium -- where the outfield dips and dives downward from the infield, and the locker rooms are cramped and musty -- by next year or lose its Class A franchise, the Astros.
To residents of this aging industrial city of 32,000 nestled amid the rolling cornfields of central New York State, the message was not, "If you build it, they will come," but, "If you build it, they won't go."
 
Passionate Fans
 To jaded New York City residents, the loss of a minor league team might sound as dire as the closing of a drugstore. And even the price for a new stadium, $2.7 million, sounds paltry.
But in Auburn, like hundreds of small communities around the nation, minor league baseball is a passion with few equals. Fans collect and trade minor league baseball cards. They swarm about locker rooms and team hangouts looking for autographs. They go on road trips, following their favorite players to towns named Oneonta, Depew and Pittsfield. They let players live in their homes all summer just for the chance to say someday: "I knew him when . . ."
Baseball here still fairly drips with nostalgia, warm nights and family outings and wholesome boys playing hard and fair. No multimillion-dollar players dousing sportswriters with bleach or tossing firecrackers into the crowd, if you please.
"I can't imagine my life without it," said Diane McNabb, a 51-year-old insurance company representative who is the president of the Astros' booster club. "I live for this time of year. I count the months until it arrives."
But whether Auburn can finance the summertime dreams of its Diane McNabbs is another question. Though the state has agreed to help pay for some stadium improvements, a resolution to borrow money for a new 2,500-seat stadium failed in the Auburn City Council last month amid concerns about the weak economy and the city's declining tax base. The new debt would add $30,000 to the city's budget of about $30 million a year, more than some Council members think the city can afford.
The resolution will be voted on once more before Labor Day, when the city -- which owns the franchise and the stadium, thought to be the oldest in all the minor leagues -- has agreed to begin looking for a new owner in another town.
If the city loses the Astros, it is unlikely to get another team because there are fewer minor league franchises available and more cities seeking them thanks to the growing popularity of the business, minor league baseball officials say.
 
'An Obnoxious Big Brother'
 In that respect, Auburn is similar to about six other communities in upstate New York and about two dozen others around the nation that, under an agreement with major league baseball, must improve their stadiums by April or lose their minor league teams. In an era when professional baseball seems more profitable than ever, the order has caused resentment in towns that have nurtured minor league teams through decades of thick and thin.
"There is a sentiment that the majors are less of a helpful partner and more of an obnoxious big brother toward minor league communities," said State Senator John B. Sheffer 2d, a Republican from LeRoy who sponsored legislation to provide state money for minor league stadium improvements. "There are millions to pay to individual ballplayers, and yet precious little to assist in these stadium needs."
But a stroll through Auburn's Falcon Stadium provides a good idea of why the major league Houston Astros want a better field for their prospects. The field has eroded so much that the infield slopes downward to the outfield. As a result, more than a few infielders have fallen while backpedaling for pop-ups and outfielders often cannot see home plate because they are too far downhill.
The league also considers the 1,850-seat stadium too small, its cinder-block locker rooms too cramped and its concession stands too outdated to make the field presentable for fans or players. The team draws an average of 960 a game.
"It's tough to have somebody of that caliber playing in a facility that's risky," said the president of the New York-Penn Baseball League, Robert Julian, as he watched an Astros pitching prospect warm up. "The Houston Astros have been very loyal to this community. But either the facility improves or they're out of here."
 
Vines and Painted Signs
 To many fans, however, the stadium has an old-time charm. Grapevines cling to the fences. The outfield wall is covered with hand-painted billboards for local banks, restaurants and car dealers, some of which closed years ago. And the stands are so close to the field that most children looking for baseballs will catch a foul ball if they wait long enough.
"You're right over the dugout, so you can hear the manager call plays before the players do," said Tim Latson, a 35-year-old Binghamton resident who took a day off recently to see the Binghamton Mets play the Astros in Auburn. "You can smell the pine tar."
Among the Astros' most passionate fans, Steven Russo is a recent convert. A major league Mets fan before he moved from Brooklyn to Auburn nine years ago, Mr. Russo discovered the Astros when he peeked through a hole in the fence at batting practice.
What he saw were 19- and 20-year-olds, fresh out of college or high school, playing with more verve while making more mistakes than big leaguers. He has been a season ticket-holder since.
"I hate to make the pun, but it's a whole different ball game here in the minors," said Mr. Russo, the 37-year-old director of a high school planetarium. "I still follow the Mets, I'm ashamed to say, but I really follow the minors more. This is baseball at its purest."
Auburn baseball devotees claim the city is rich in baseball lore, dating from the time that Abner Doubleday lived here briefly before moving to Cooperstown. The city had a team in the defunct Border League between 1938 and 1952. Then, after six years without professional baseball in town, three local businessmen went door-to-door selling $1 shares to buy a Class-A franchise and Falcon Stadium.
In 1981, when the team was near bankruptcy, the city assumed its debts and became one of only a handful of municipalities in the country to own a professional baseball team.
"When you move to a community and try to find where to meet families, it's usually the shopping mall," said Michael Chamberlain, a Xerox official who is the unpaid president of the Astros. "We've lost those places where the community comes together as a community. That's the special thing about ball parks. We don't go as individuals."
After a recent night game, which the last-place Astros lost, 10-5, a group of boys took to the field after the teams had departed. As one pitched a make-believe ball, another took a deep cut, sending a third backpedaling deep into right field.
At the very moment he closed his glove on the invisible ball, the lights went out.
"That's what it's all about," said Peg Lane, Auburn resident, mother of four and baseball fan.

HEADLINE: CLINTON MAY LET U.S. TROOPS SERVE UNDER U.N. CHIEFS

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Shifting away from the longstanding tradition of American commanders for American troops, the Clinton Administration is considering an expanded role in United Nations peacekeeping operations that would include having Americans serve under foreign commanders on a regular basis.
Administration officials say a presidential policy directive to allow for such an expansion of the American role has been drafted and is expected to be signed by President Clinton next month. It has the backing of the Defense Department, the State Department, the National Security Council and Madeleine K. Albright, delegate to the United Nations. 
 Since the end of World War II, the United States has only detailed individual officers as monitors for United Nations peacekeeping efforts, or has generally provided air and sea transport for such operations.
 
Precedent for U.N. Command
 Before the United Nations operation in Somalia, the United States has only once placed an American military unit under direct United Nations command -- a small air transport unit in Western New Guinea in 1962, according to William J. Durch, author of "The Evolution of U.N. Peacekeeping."
But American troops fought under foreign commanders in both world wars. American forces also served in Korea as part of a United Nations operation, but their commanders were American.
"If we were asked to contribute an engineering unit that nobody else had, we would do it," a State Department official familiar with the directive said of the present policy. "But if we were asked to contribute an infantry unit, we would say, there are plenty of others who can contribute infantry units."
The directive goes beyond the Bush Administration's acceptance of a multilateral approach to regional conflicts, the officials said, and reflects a belief that military responsibilities must be shared in the post-cold-war world.
 
U.N. Role Widening
 It also comes at a time when the United Nations is undertaking more peacekeeping efforts than at any time in its history -- and is being criticized for being too aggressive in its efforts in Somalia and too passive in Bosnia.
The tradition of American command was first dented when the United Nations took over the Somalia operation from the United States in May. But even that precedent is limited. The only force under United Nations command in Somalia is the 2,700-person logistical contingent. The 1,300 combat troops in the Quick Reaction Force, which carried out the assaults against Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid and his supporters, remain under the command of American officers.
And the various proposals for Western military intervention in Bosnia have all called for the action to be undertaken under the command of NATO, not the United Nations. The current commander of NATO is Gen. John Shalikashvili, an American who was chosen last week to be the next Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
 
U.S. Role 'in Any Capacity'
 "The difference with this Administration is that it envisions the United States, in principle, taking part in any peacekeeping operation in any capacity," the State Department official said.
Still, the Administration proposal falls far short of what some, including Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, would like to see the United States do. Last year, Mr. Boutros-Ghali asked United Nations members to provide up to 1,000 troops each to be part of a standing army to be used to deter aggression.
In an interview, Ms. Albright said of the idea of a standing force, "I see it as way, way down the line. I think there are genuine questions at the moment about the U.N. having its own anything."
Ms. Albright said that while it is not current Administration policy, it might be conceivable in the future to have members designating units that would be available to the United Nations on short notice.
 
A Data Base Is Needed
 "What we need is the development of a data base of who has what so that the Secretary General doesn't have to go around with a tin cup," Ms. Albright said.
She stressed that the primary mission of these troops would be the needs of their particular countries, and that participating in United Nations operations would be secondary.
Even so, aware of the difficulty of selling the new directive to Congress and to reluctant military officers, the Administration is strongly considering allowing heads of American military units to ignore or disregard orders from United Nations commanders that they consider to be illegal or militarily questionable.
Such a policy might create resentment among some members. Last month the United States and other countries called for the ouster of the commander of the 800-member Italian contingent in the Somlia peacekeeping operation for refusing to carry out orders from the central United Nations command.
Also, in order to make American participation in United Nations peacekeeping operations more politically palatable, the Administration is seeking to improve the efficiency of the United Nations and thereby lower costs. Currently, the United States pays about 30 per cent of all United Nations peacekeeping costs. This year the United Nations total may exceed $3.6 billion. Some of the changes the Administration would like the United Nations to make include setting up a round-the-clock operations center, beefing up logistical support for peacekeeping operations, and improving accounting and budgeting procedures.
 
Operation in the Caucasus
 Last week, Ms. Albright wrote to Mr. Boutros-Ghali asking questions about the cost of a proposed peacekeeping operation in the former Soviet republic of Georgia before the United States would commit itself to vote in favor of the operation. Ms. Albright asked for detailed explanations of the length of the peacekeeping operation, the projected cost and the basis for the cost estimate, the precise responisbilities of the peacekeepers and what would determine when their mission was fulfilled.
Aides to Ms. Albright, who is president of the Security Council this month, say she hopes that such detailed queries will become a regular feature of future discussions of peacekeeping operations.
Some critics say, however, that such efforts at making the United Nationsmore efficient do not address the political problem of building domestic support for American peacekeepers in places like Somalia where the broad American economic or strategic interest is not clear.
"It's a mistake to look at mechanistic solutions to the problems of the U.N.," said John Bolton, the former Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations in the Bush Administration. "The problems the U.N. faces is a lack of real political will by the parties involved to come to solutions. Somalia and the former Yugoslavia are not difficult because of operational reasons. They're difficult for political reasons."

HEADLINE: Many Patients Unhappy With H.M.O.'s

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
A nationwide study of more than 17,000 patients has found widespread dissatisfaction with health maintenance organizations, adding fuel to a growing national debate over the merits of managed health care.
Patients were more likely to be satisfied with the explanations of their treatments from doctors working in their own offices or in small single-specialty groups than from H.M.O.'s, the researchers said. The patients also said that independent doctors had showed more interest in their well-being. 
 And independent doctors were easier to reach by telephone and more apt to schedule office appointments on short notice than were doctors in large medical groups and H.M.O.'s, the study found.
By contrast, people enrolled in health maintenance organizations or treated by large multispecialty practices were more likely to complain of long hours in the waiting room, followed by too short a visit with the doctor.
To slow the growth of health-care costs, managed-care organizations typically restrict payments unless care is approved in advance by a designated primary-care doctor.
 
What Critics Say
 Critics say many organizations economize by making it difficult to get a doctor's appointment, shuttling patients from one doctor to another and giving the doctors incentives to see too many patients in too little time.
"Patients bounce around in these systems," said John E. Ware Jr., a senior researcher at the New England Medical Center. "It's the dark side of managed care."
In the study, which was financed by the Federal Government, researchers at Johns Hopkins University and the New England Medical Center analyzed how 17,671 patients rated their treatment in small offices, large multispecialty medical practices and H.M.O.'s with salaried doctors.
The study, reported in today's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association, was based on interviews conducted in 1986 in 367 medical offices in Boston, Chicago and Los Angeles and updated in 1990. The findings had not been previously reported.
The researchers asked patients to rate services from excellent to poor and then compared the percentage of excellent ratings that patients gave to their overall care, as well as to particular kinds of service.
Don White, a spokesman for the H.M.O. industry, said his group's ratings would have been much higher if responses of "very good" and "good" had been included. But Mr. Ware said that patients were generally reluctant to criticize medical services, so ratings of less than excellent were misleading.
 
Politically Hot Subject
 "The study's findings are particularly important in light of President Clinton's health care reform efforts," said Dr. Haya R. Rubin, director of quality of care research at the Johns Hopkins medical school, who was the lead author of the article. "To the extent that managed care encourages doctors and hospitals to be in very big groups, that may be less desirable from a patient's point of view."
The Clinton Administration is drafting plans for a medical system that would offer incentives to enroll in health maintenance organizations and similar prepaid medical plans, which typically limit the use of hospitals and specialists.
The President said on Monday in a speech to the National Governors Association that the system should contain significant new incentives to prevent overuse of health care services.
Dr. Rubin said patients' views of their doctors could often affect their health. "Studies show the more satisfied you are, the more likely you are to come back to that doctor," she said.
Dr. Joseph Painter, a Houston oncologist who is president of the American Medical Association, agreed that "a patient who is happy with the physician, both individually and professionally, will carry out the doctor's order, whether it is exercising, losing weight or taking pills."
But Mr. White, the industry spokesman, said, "The deck was stacked against H.M.O.'s" in the three-city study. The Group Health Association of America in Washington said the authors should have asked about features that H.M.O. members appreciate, like low out-of-pocket costs and fewer medical forms to fill out.
The association said a number of other studies had found that H.M.O. members were as satisfied with the managed care organizations as others were with traditional insurance.
 
Other Studies
 But Mr. Ware said the authors and the experts who reviewed the study for the medical association journal were not aware of any comparable studies that contradicted the three-city study.
Indeed, a 1992 Government-financed study of elderly Medicare patients also reported that members were less likely to rate their health plans as excellent as to how well the care was explained, how long they had to wait both for appointments and in the office, and how thorough the treatment was.
Several large employers said some of their people had similar complaints. "I'm not terribly surprised by their findings," said Gary Yeaw, director of benefit services at Allied-Signal Inc., where 48,000 of the 70,000 American employees are in managed-care programs, including 5,000 in H.M.O.'s with staffs of salaried physicians.
He said that when given a choice, this type of organization attracted younger people with large families who like the one-stop shopping. Employees who do not like these model H.M.O.'s often transfer to other types of health plans.
While they urge their employees to join H.M.O.'s because of the cost savings, a number of larger employers, including Allied-Signal and the Xerox Corporation, are prodding the organizations to improve patient services. "H.M.O.'s have to do better," said Helen Darling, a Xerox benefits executive. "You have to push them."
 
Varyied Ratings
 Not all H.M.O.'s are alike, of course. Dr. Rubin noted that one of the three organizations in the survey received excellent ratings from 55 percent of the patients, compared with 49 percent and 37 percent for the other two. The overall excellent ratings in the three cities for independent doctors in small offices were between 62 percent and 69 percent. For small offices working with H.M.O.'s, the range was 51 percent to 66 percent.
"Patients seem to like to receive their care in doctors' offices, whether they are members of H.M.O.'s or not," said Dr. Steve Zatz, head of a quality of care unit of U.S. Healthcare, based in Bluebell, Pa., a large H.M.O. whose members are cared for by independent doctors.
His organization is one of a growing number of large managed-care organizations that say they are always analyzing their performance and polling patients, and trying to improve. Dr. Don M. Nielsen, who is in charge of quality at Kaiser Permanente, the big, nonprofit national H.M.O. based in Oakland, Calif., said Kaiser had also "worked very hard to improve access and meet our members' expectations."
Dr. John Ludden, medical director of the Harvard Community Health Plan, based in Brookline, Mass., added, "Large organizations can become impersonal quite easily." He said his organization had a training program for doctors to show them "how to produce satisfaction for patients."

HEADLINE: Budapest Journal;
Gentrifiers March On, To the Danube's Banks

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Nearly four years after the Communist system collapsed, a sharp debate is developing in this grand city of broad boulevards and opulent buildings astride the Danube: how the metropolis, still grand but faded, should be restored and renewed.
The debate is similar to those that have long absorbed New York, London and Paris. But what used to be an almost entirely Western phenomenon, urban gentrification, has come to the fore here as city leaders and citizens alike confront decades of Communist neglect of an eclectic architectural heritage that ranges from a graceful Neo-Gothic Parliament building to fanciful Art Nouveau bathhouses. 
 Pushing the concerns is Budapest's position, with more than two million people, as a commercial headquarters for $5 billion of post-Communist foreign investment in Hungary, the largest amount of any country in the region.
Architects and town planners here say they feel an added responsibility because as the wealthiest city in Eastern Europe what happens here is likely to be the vanguard for Prague and Warsaw.
Some rules for urban renewal have been set: new construction is welcome, but not skyscrapers. Some priorities are being established, particularly to do something about the chaotic traffic and pollution caused by the greatest concentration of cars in Eastern Europe. Some significant bundles of money have been nailed down, mostly from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, to improve public transportation.
But little has been done to resolve the conflict between a chronic housing shortage that has left many city residents crammed into rundown, crime-encrusted apartment buildings and the desires of developers to build or renovate for more lucrative commercial use.
From his spacious office hung with modern paintings and furnished with classic Hungarian chairs, the city's Deputy Mayor for urban development, Istvan Schneller, struggles with these issues every day.
"It is very hard to preserve the city against the investors," said Mr. Schneller, who was a practicing architect before assuming one of the most powerful posts in the city and who has sent many a foreign developer back to the drawing board to scale back grandiose plans.
For example, he rejected a plan by French developers to build a 40-story building near the city stadium, a height Mr. Schneller noted they would not be allowed to construct in Paris.
"I don't want to be against the investor, but I would like to channel the development further along the Danube," Mr. Schneller said. "But everyone wants to be very close to the center."
At the heart of Budapest's debate is an urban renewal proposal for the city's most crowded and rundown inner district. The mayor of District 7, the site of Budapest's Jewish quarter and home to seven synagogues, wants to build a $1.2 billion commercial center of office towers, pedestrian mall, shops and luxury apartments. Many of the residents, most of whom are elderly and have lived in the tiny apartments on the proposed site all their lives, are against the project, known as the Madach Promenade Business District.
"To have more stores, 8,000 people should move?" a woman asked at a town meeting called last week to discuss the project. "I'm a citizen too. Why do we have to open up a new street for more french fries and hamburgers everywhere? Where are the traditional restaurants where you can get good Hungarian food at acceptable prices?"
 
Idea for a Mall Is Old
 Janos Farago, the district's mayor and a longtime resident of the District 7, says the complex is a necessary step to enhancing property values. "The project would revalue the district and be another step toward a market economy," he said. "It would restore the district's image as a trading center."
Mr. Farago acknowledged that there were members of his council and his constituents who thought the money spent on the construction could be better used on "solving social problems." But mostly, he said, the residents feared change.
The idea of the pedestrian mall that would effectively extend the current commercial area on the Pest side of the Danube is such a good one, he said, that it was not dreamed up in the last few years. It was first considered, in more modified forms, at the turn of the century when Budapest was blossoming into a true European city and then again in the 1930's, he said.
A feasibility study prepared by the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrandestimated that the district would have to borrow heavily for the initial upgrading of water and electricity supply and for the cost of moving people whose apartments would have to be pulled down, Mr. Farago said.
He said that about 522 apartments would be demolished, meaning that about a thousand people would have to be moved to other places. Others in the district assert that Mr. Farago was underestimating the number of people to be relocated -- the real number is more like 3,000, they say -- and there is no place to move them anyway.
 
A Cascade of Worries
 At the crowded meeting of constituents, a gathering that would have been unheard of in the Communist era before 1989, Mr. Farago listened to a barrage of complaints.
"Why sell to foreign interests, local entrepreneurs should be given a fair chance," one man said. Another said, "People live in horrible conditions, but at the same time newly built offices are left empty."
One of the younger residents of the district, Robert Braun, a professor of history at Budapest University, said he opposed the project, in part, because it paid little attention to the origins of the area. "This was the center of Jewish life," he said. "This place has memories of the Holocaust that should be nurtured, not ruined."
Deputy Mayor Schneller, who holds great sway on whether development plans receive permits, said he would not oppose the project, the biggest commercial development proposal under consideration in Budapest. But he has reservations.
Rather than ease traffic congestion, the complex would just move the traffic a few blocks away, he said. And expressing a pet worry, he said he would try to persuade the Hungarian architect Janos Posimar to ignore the financial demands of investors and knock some floors off the highest tower in his plan.
"We don't need tall buildings at all, we can put the function of the city in smaller, more friendly buildings."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Under the urban plan, some of Budapest's old buildings would give way to a commercial center of office towers, a pedestrian mall, shops and luxury apartments; Urban gentrification has arrived in Budapest's neighborhoods after decades of Communist neglect of the city's architectural heritage. In District 7, above, a $1.2 billion renewal plan would demolish more than 500 apartments and displace about a thousand people, an official said. HEADLINE: DOLE IS CAUTIOUS ON HEALTH PLANS

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 17

 BODY:
In a speech that was more conciliatory than confrontational, Senator Bob Dole said today that Republicans wanted to cooperate with the Clinton Administration on health care. But he warned that he had "genuine concerns" about the President's proposal, particularly one that would require employers to provide health insurance for workers.
Addressing the National Governors' Association from the same stage where Mr. Clinton outlined the basics of his health plan a day earlier, Mr. Dole, the Senate Republican leader, warned the President not to "get set in concrete" with his plan. 
 Despite his objection to requirements on employers, Mr. Dole stopped short of saying he oppose any package that included them. And he said he could be persuaded if small businesses were protected.
"In the view of Senate Republicans who are working on proposals of our own," he said, "employer mandates would damage the economy and hurt those who need help the most -- new hires, small businesses and low income workers."
While Mr. Clinton said his plan would call for mandatory insurance, he also emphasized in his speech here that he would seek to ease the burden on employers by phasing the plan in over five to seven years.
 
Bipartisanship Has Its Limits
 The tone of Mr. Dole's comments seemed to reflect the tone of governors from both parties in the four-day conference that ended today: They sought to strike a bipartisan note, but the divisions remained apparent.
From start to finish, the issue of health care was paramount here. At a closing news conference, Gov. Howard Dean, a Democrat from Vermont who is a physician, emphasized Mr. Dole's call for accommodation on health care. "This is not a bipartisan love fest," he said. "But the commitment here is to start working together."
Brushing aside disagreements over financing, Mr. Dean said, "The unwritten story is that a national consensus appears to be developing around a state-based plan."
Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, who today assumed the chairmanship of the association, praised Mr. Dole for "holding out an olive branch." After the governors' private meeting with Mr. Clinton and Administration officials on Monday, he said, he was confident that partisan conflicts could be kept to a minimum.
"Nobody was pulling punches," Mr. Campbell said. "We saw a willingness from the President to try to find answers."
Acknowledging that he had become known as Dr. Gridlock, Mr. Dole made unusually friendly comments that seemed intended to demonstrate that he was not simply the Republicans' pit bull.
 
Passage, Perhaps, in a Year
 Mr. Dole is the most visible spokesman for Republicans and will play an important role in the coming health care battle as the White House seeks the backing of many members of his party.
But he strongly suggested that the months of consultations between the Administration and Republicans in Congress may not satisfy him, even if many Republicans support the Clinton health care proposals. And he advised the White House not to try to rush the plan, which he predicted would be approved by Congress "maybe the middle of next year."
"In my view, bipartisanship is not just picking off enough Republicans to get the bill to pass," Mr. Dole said. "That may be a victory, but it's not bipartisanship."
While he called on the White House to move more cautiously on health care, Mr. Dole also made a pitch for more aggressive efforts by the Administration on the North American Free Trade Agreement. Noting that many lawmakers might not want to deal with the pact in an election year, he said, "My view is if we don't move on Nafta fairly soon, it may become a victim of the 1994 election."
