HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Touches a New Low Against the Japanese Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved slightly higher against the Japanese yen in early trading today, after falling to its fifth straight record low yesterday.
Meanwhile, gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery dropped $1.50 an ounce, to $371.60. December gold, the most actively traded futures contract, also lost $1.50 an ounce, to $374.90. 
 In Tokyo today, the dollar was quoted at 101.48 yen in afternoon trading, up about half a yen from the New York close. But early yesterday in Tokyo, the dollar plunged as low as 100.35 yenbefore rebounding late in the session to close at 101.55 yen. Traders said the currency was being supported by heavy intervention in the markets by the Bank of Japan.
 
Early Gains Cut
 In New York yesterday, the dollar initially rose above 102 yen. But, after a small financial news agency, the Market News Service, quoted unidentified officials in Washington as saying the Treasury approved of the rising yen, the Japanese currency shot up.
"All of a sudden, it got hectic," said Jack Griffin, a vice president at Fuji Bank in New York.
The report apparently calmed some investors' fears that the Federal Reserve might intervene in the markets to strengthen the dollar. The yen finished trading at 101.02, down from 101.62 late on Monday.
The Japanese Cabinet in planning to hold an emergency meeting on the yen. "A lot hinges on this meeting, to give us a clue" what the Government will do, said Kevin Lawrie, a foreign-exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
The German mark, meanwhile, lost ground against European currencies and the dollar yesterday, after France cut its overnight interest rate and denied it planned to impose currency controls. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6941 marks, up from 1.6870 marks on Monday.
Traders have been expecting most European countries to lower their interest rates below Germany's to try to spur their economies. Such a move is probable because European Community officials recently decided to weaken their coordination of exchange rates and interest rates.

HEADLINE: New-Home Starts Fell 2.7% In July

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Housing starts fell 2.7 percent in July, hurt by flooding along the Mississippi River and a slump in construction activity in the West, the Commerce Department reported today.
Despite the lowest mortgage rates in more than 20 years, housing starts in July, at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.21 million units, fell for the second straight month. Starts in June, previously reported as unchanged, were revised to show a two-tenths of 1 percent decline, the Government said. 
 The July decline was concentrated in the Midwest, where starts fell by 4 percent, to a rate of 265,000 units, and in the West, where they plummeted by 11.9 percent, to a rate of 273,000.
Analysts said flooding along the Mississippi hampered building but that the report over all was worse than expected.
 
 
'Not Doing Much'
 "The July housing starts statistics are disappointing, as they indicate that the lower mortgage rates are not doing much in terms of luring consumers back into the housing market," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York.
In the West, the California economy remained under severe pressure from military base closings and from the winding down of defense industries, analysts said, so there is little incentive for home building.
Starts rose in the South during July by 2.5 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 541,000, and were up fractionally in the Northeast, by eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 133,000.
Despite July's fall in national construction activity, analysts say there are reasons to be hopeful about the rest of the year. Low interest rates are making homes more affordable, while the supply of single-family units is down to about a seven-year low.
Mortgage rates inched down to 7.2 percent in July, their lowest level in more than 20 years. In June, rates for 30-year fixed mortgages averaged 7.36 percent, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
 
 
'Good Underlying Fundamentals'
 "We think that good underlying fundamentals like a slowly improving labor market and low mortgage rates in July were more than offset by floods in the Midwest and rains in the West," said David Berson, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association.
"But bad weather doesn't eliminate stronger sales and starts, it postpones them," Mr. Berson said. "We should see an improvement starting to take place by September."
Over all, the July rate of starts on homes and detached town houses was still 9.6 percent higher than the seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.11 million units in July 1992.
Additionally, applications for permits to build new homes rose in July by 3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.15 million units, after falling by five-tenths of 1 percent in June.

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans to Offer Aid, Not Protection, in Chips

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
In a closely watched test of the Administration's approach to strategic industries, the Commerce Department has drafted a plan to subsidize research on certain computer chip devices but has refused to protect the industry from foreign rivals, American officials said today.
The decision is the clearest sign yet of the Administration's desire to help high-technology industries in the international marketplace through technical assistance rather than through protectionist tariffs on imports. An Administration official said that while the nation's reliance on imports of the devices "doesn't present an immediate threat to national security, improving the capabilities of the domestic industry is desirable for both economic and national security."
 
 
Legislation Not Needed
 The Administration official insisted on anonymity because the White House was told only on Monday evening about the research assistance plan, which the Commerce Department could undertake with its own resources and without special legislation. 
 But when told about the Administration's plans, economists expressed concerns that the Federal Government could not pick technological winners and losers more accurately than the financial markets.
"The good part of the story is that they're not protectionist," said Jagdish Bhagwati, an economics professor at Columbia University. "On the other hand, they're most likely opening a floodgate, which they'll find very difficult to close."
Two American manufacturers of the computer chip devices filed a petition with the Commerce Department last winter seeking assistance under a Federal law that gives the President broad powers to limit imports or help domestic industries for national security reasons. The case was the first under the law to contend that the nation's economic competitiveness -- in addition to military needs -- was essential to national security in the post-cold war world.
The devices at issue are ceramic packages with implanted metal circuitry that links crucial silicon chips inside to other, less important chips. The chip packages are used in everything from cars to personal computers to missiles.
The Kyocera Corporation of Japan controls more than half the world market for these ceramic packages. The company and some smaller Japanese companies together supply as much as 90 percent of the Defense Department's needs, according to documents filed in the case.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, in a letter to President Clinton on Monday night, ruled that the chip-packages industry did not meet the national security test in the law. But the Commerce Department has nonetheless decided that the industry needs Federal help and has drafted a four-part plan to do so.
The plan calls for the creation of a federally financed research center for chip packages, which would probably be in San Diego and be run by the Navy; more research spending on chip packaging materials by the Energy Department and the National Institute of Standards and Technology, a Commerce Department agency; Defense Department advice to the domestic industry on how to win more military contracts, and a working group of Federal and industry officials to review ways to increase efficiency.
The total cost of this effort has not yet been worked out.
Several domestic industries that are facing foreign competition and claiming strategic importance have been watching the case, notably commercial aircraft manufacturers and domestic oil drillers.
 
A Difficult Test
 The Commerce Department's ruling that the chip-package industry did not meet the national security test "would suggest that this is not going to be an easy hurdle to clear," said William R. Cline, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, a nonpartisan Washington research group.
The United States consumes about $1.2 billion a year worth of ceramic packages, including about $200 million worth of packages in military applications. The Coors Electronic Package Company, based in Chattanooga, Tenn., and the Ceramic Process Systems Corporation, based in Milford, Mass., had filed their petition under Section 232 of the Trade Enhancement Act of 1962.
Section 232 is the little-changed replacement for legislation passed in 1955, at the height of the cold war, that gave the President broad powers over the economy when national security was involved. Presidents Ford and Carter invoked section 232 to impose temporary taxes on imported oil and to encourage American self-sufficiency in oil production.
I.B.M., which makes ceramic chip packages for its own use and occasionally for sale to other companies, opposed the petition, as did American computer companies that rely on foreign chip packages.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Computer Maker's Net Hurts Stock

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company surprised Wall Street today with fiscal third-quarter earnings well below the consensus estimate, sending its share price plummeting.
While earnings, revenues and orders all grew in the quarter, profit margins hit a new low, a victim of price cuts, primarily in personal computers and printers. 
 For the quarter ended July 31, Hewlett-Packard had earnings of $271 million, or $1.06 a share, up 44 percent from $188 million, or 75 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Sales grew 23 percent, to $4.96 billion from $4.04 billion.
Hewlett-Packard shares closed today at $74 each, down $1.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, after moving up for the last two weeks. The price was down $6.75 a share earlier in the day.
Analysts, who had anticipated per-share earnings in the $1.20 to $1.25 range, revised their estimates downward for the full year and for the 1994 fiscal year to reflect the squeeze on margins.
 
 
Gross Profit Margins
 "More and more, this company is making its living from printers and PC's, which are sold through indirect channels where the margins tend to be lower," said Robert Herwick, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. He added that the company had also reduced prices on its Emerald line of large, multi-user computers. Mr. Herwick said the gross profit margin was 40.2 percent, "the lowest we've ever seen, and a full point drop" from the second quarter. "I don't think anybody expects a recovery in the October quarter," he added.
Lewis E. Platt, Hewlett-Packard's president and chief executive officer, said in a telephone interview that the decline in gross profit margins "is a continuation of what we've been talking about for some time." He attributed the shrinking margins to pricing pressures in personal computers, printers and disk drives. "We're working as hard as we can to offset that by lowering all of our expense ratios," he said.
"Over all, we consider our results a decent outcome in a difficult economic environment," Mr. Platt said. "Given this environment, in which several major economies have been in recession, we didn't assume that our strong first-half order-growth rate would continue," he said. "However, we are a bit disappointed by how much it moderated this quarter. Order growth slowed substantially in Europe and slightly in Japan, but we're encouraged by continued healthy order growth in the United States."
Hewlett-Packard said orders for the third quarter totaled $4.7 billion, an increase of 19 percent over the $4 billion reported a year earlier. United States orders grew 24 percent, to $2.2 billion, while orders from outside the United States grew 14 percent, to $2.5 billion.
The company said that orders grew 17 percent in the Asia-Pacific area, compared with 23 percent growth in the previous quarter. Orders from Europe increased 10 percent over the quarter a year earlier, compared with 28 percent growth in this year's second quarter.

HEADLINE: Frank R. Barnett, 72, an Expert On Military Strategy and Security

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Frank R. Barnett, founder and president of the National Strategy Information Center of Washington and New York, died on Sunday at a Manhattan nursing home. He was 72 and lived in Manhattan.
The cause was heart failure, the center said, adding that he had had cancer. 
 Mr. Barnett's interest in national security studies grew from a belief that questions of war and peace should not be the left to Federal officials and the military alone. To that end, he worked to develop educational programs in conjunction with the American Bar Association, universities, organized labor and business.
He founded the center, a nonprofit, nonpartisan body, in 1962. Its goal was to bring together leaders of public opinion and provide information on national defense and international security through seminars, policy workshops and briefing sessions.
Known for its anti-Communist and pro-military stance, the center continued to monitor the military equations after the demise of the Soviet Bloc. But it also developed educational courses for the 1990's that discussed economics, the environment and ethics. It also continued its research on American intelligence policy and sponsored unclassified workshops with intelligence specialists.
A native of Chillicothe, Ohio, Frank Rockwell Barnett was educated at Wabash College, Bradley University, Syracuse University, the University of California at Berkeley, the University of Zurich and, as a Rhodes Scholar from Indiana, at Oxford University.
In World War II, he was a Russian interpreter in the 69th Infantry Division, which met the Soviet Army on the Elbe River in April 1945. After the war, he was attached to the staff of the United States Military Government in Berlin.
From 1955 to 1962 he was a vice president and director of research of the Smith Richardson Foundation, an anti-Communist group founded in 1935.
He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the International Institute of Strategic Studies in London.
Mr. Barnett is survived by his wife, Marjorie, and a brother, Frederick, of Florida.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
The Governors' Untouchable Subject

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 17

 BODY:
Talk about touchy. Ask Republican governors about health care or welfare or Federal mandates and they won't stop talking. Ask them about their ambitions for the White House and there is dead silence. Then they back away.
That's just what happened the other day here at a news conference by Republicans attending the summer meeting of the National Governors' Association. The question-and-answer session was dominated by four Republican Governors who are widely thought to harbor visions of national office: Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, Pete Wilson of California, William F. Weld of Massachusetts and John Engler of Michigan. 
 Only Mr. Campbell answered the question about 1996, and that was probably because he was standing nearest the microphone. His reply, though, was intentionally not enlightening.
"I really don't think that's a subject that's appropriate for discussion here," he said. "We have to go back and deal with reality. We're going to be governors before we're anything else. You're talking about something that's three or four years off."
 
A Political Subplot
 Despite the governors' reluctance to discuss 1996, the campaign that is three years off was an unmistakable subplot of the conference that ended here today. Throughout the discussions, there was one central but unspoken question: Who will emerge as the Republican nominee?
It is also on the minds of the Democrats. Catherine Moore, the Democratic Party's spokeswoman, followed the jockeying here closely. "They're like animals trying to get ahead of the herd," she said.
Governors dominate the early list of possible Republican Presidential candidates, and their subtle maneuvering provides a case study in how politicians stake out positions on the national stage by speaking out on issues.
In what some of Mr. Wilson's possible rival camps viewed as an effort to shift the attention from home-state economic troubles and his own political difficulties, the California Governor seized on the issue of health care. For Mr. Engler and Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, another Presidential prospect, the issue was overhauling welfare.
 
A Successful Maneuver
 And Mr. Weld made his splash even before the conference opened: he proposed cutting taxes by $200 million in Massachusetts to ease the effect of tax increases at the Federal level that are required under Mr. Clinton's budget. White House officials denounced Mr. Weld for playing politics with the budget, but it won him the attention he sought. He delivered the Republican response to Mr. Clinton's weekly radio address on Saturday.
Still, Mr. Wilson was testy when asked about 1996. "This is three and a half years away," he snapped. In an apparent reference to Mr. Clinton, he added, "Give the guy a break."
By contrast, Haley Barbour, the chairman of the Republican Party who spends much of his time encouraging people to focus on 1994, not 1996, maintained his sense of humor. Asked about Presidential prospects, he flipped on his sunglasses and quipped, "You know when I put these glasses on, I really can't see past 1994."
But he went on: "There certainly are a lot of bright lights among our governors. And I'm sure that they, like I, are not thinking about anything beyond 1994. They're all smart people."
Smart enough not to speak publicly about their ambitions. But it does not take much to get the governors' aides to dive into a detailed handicapping of their bosses' prospects (and the shortcomings of their possible opponents) -- all off the record, of course.
 
Projecting the Proper Image
 Mr. Campbell, who began a one-year term as chairman of the association today, was so anxious not to be perceived as using his new post to pursue the Presidency that he told his supporters that they should take it easy and that he would not be joining other Republicans making treks to New Hampshire, site of the first Presidential primary.
"New Hampshire is like a flare and he wasn't ready to send that flare up," said Tucker Eskew, Mr. Campbell's press secretary. "We have some very zealous supporters in Washington, some of whom were suggesting a more aggressive timetable. The cheerleaders took the field before the team had even suited up."
The governors' model, of course, is President Clinton, who built contacts in state capitals around the country and became identified with issues like welfare changes when he was chairman of the governors' association.
He was not the first to succeed at using the group to promote his political career. So did these former governors: Lamar Alexander, the Tennessee Republican who went on to become Education Secretary; John H. Sununu, the New Hampshire Republican who became White House chief of staff, and Michael S. Dukakis, the Massachusetts Democrat who won his party's Presidential nomination in 1988.
"The N.G.A. has been increasingly seen as a jumping-off point," said Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the association. "Bill Clinton started a long time ago doing speeches for governors in their states, That's very important."
 
Other Republican Contenders
 The governors, of course, have other Republicans to contend (and compete) with, like Jack F. Kemp, the former Housing Secretary; Senator Phil Gramm of Texas; William J. Bennett, the former Education Secretary and drug policy director, and Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader who has emerged as the party's most visible spokesman.
Fresh from New Hampshire himself, Mr. Dole addressed the governors today, and, not surprisingly, the Republicans who are most talked about as White House hopefuls made a beeline to be seen with him at the end of his speech. (Not to leave anyone out, other big-state governors is also part of the rumor mill are Jim Edgar of Illinois and George V. Voinovich of Ohio.)
Who will emerge? No one knows, of course. Could it be a surprise from an obscure state, like Gov. Mike Leavitt of Utah?
Mr. Leavitt stood in the shadows at the news conference with his fellow Republican governors. But he caught the eye of Republicans and reporters when he stood up to the microphone and leveled a fresh, punchy attack against the Democrats on health care. He declared that it could be "the mother of all unfunded mandates."
So a few moments later, when the potential Presidential prospects were asked about their ambitions for 1996, Mr. Weld put his arm around Mr. Leavitt's shoulder. And everyone laughed -- but not too hard.
"I think," Mr. Leavitt said later with a chuckle and a touch of diplomacy, "he was trying to deflect attention from himself."

GRAPHIC: Photos: While governors are topping the list of candidates to seek the White House in 1996, few are posturing in public. At the governors' national meeting, Gov. Carroll A. HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Short-Term Issues Still Alluring

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Despite the persistent rally in the long end of the Treasury market, there are signs in the corporate bond market that many money managers still prefer the safety of shorter maturities.
Stephen Clark, senior corporate market analyst at Technical Data, notes that the spreads between the yields on shorter-term corporate bonds and comparable Treasury securities have narrowed recently, which is a sign of strong demand for corporates. At the same time, he said, the yield spread on longer-term corporate debt has held constant in the new-issue market and, in some cases, has widened when issues begin trading in the secondary market. 
 "Some people think there is no place to go in price but down, and up in yield," he said.
Yesterday, Philadelphia Electric sold $500 million in first and refunding mortage bonds. The $225 million of five-year notes were sold at a yield of 5.44 percent, which was just 40 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, higher than the yield on the five-year Treasury note.
But Mr. Clark said that based on the talk about the issue before it was priced, the spread was expected to be 50 to 55 basis points for the company, which has a rating that is just a few notches above investment grade.
New York Telephone sold five-year bonds yesterday with a yield of 5.358 percent, which was just 30 basis points over the five-year Treasury note yield. As recently as April, Pennsylvania Power and Light, which has the same credit rating as New York Telephone, sold five-year corporate bonds at a spread of 50 basis points over the five-year Treasury note.
This is not to say there is no demand for longer-term paper or the desire of companies to issue it. According to the Securities Data Company, the share of longer-term new issues of corporate debt has jumped sharply since the beginning of July. For the year to date, longer-term debt from 10 years to 30 years accounts for about 44.5 percent of all new issues while since July 1 that share is up to 56.7 percent.
But Mr. Clark argues that because the yield spreads on this longer-term corporate debt have held steady or widened some, it signals that investors are still favoring shorter-term, less-price-sensitive debt. That might indicate that there is more caution in the market than one would think, even though the yield on the 30-year bond is in a steep downward tilt.
 
Treasury Market
 Low and behold, the downward move of the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was halted yesterday. For the first time in eight trading days, the yield on the 30-year bond did not set a new 16-year low. But traders expect the downward march to begin again soon.
"There is no reason for rates not to go down further," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, referring to the fact that the economy is still sluggish and the inflation rate is rising at a pace below last year's 2.9 percent.
In trading yesterday, the price of the 6.25 percent bond due in August 2023 slipped 4/32 , as the yield inched up to 6.31 percent, from a 16-year low of 6.30 percent Monday.
But earlier in the day, the price of the bond was up about 11/32 , with the yield down to 6.27 percent. The gains, which came in light trading, were lost in the afternoon. Mr. Fine suggested that the reason might have been disappointment that the Federal Reserve did not enter the market to buy Treasury securities, which some analysts had expected.
The prices of other Treasury securities were also off on the day. The price of the 10-year note fell 8/32 as the yield rose to 5.71 percent, from 5.68 percent the day before. The price of the two-year note slipped 2/32 as the yield rose to 3.98 percent from 3.95 percent.
The next event that could give the market some trouble is the Treasury auction next week of two-year and five-year notes. But it is not clear that if this auction disrupts the shorter end of the market that it will have any impact on the 30-year bond. Traders say the long bond seems to be in a world of its own, influenced by the positive inflation data that affect the entire market and by its own special factors, like the Treasury's decision to cut annual sales of the bond by 40 percent.

HEADLINE: Man's Nemesis: Dotted Line on Map;
Trying to Rebuild, Bronx Store Owner Faces Phantom Road

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Among the biggest fears for any businessman hit by catastrophe is that he'll wind up on the street. But for one Bronx landlord trying to rebuild after a devastating fire, the problem is that the street is on him.
Lazar (Bernie) Berkovits, the owner of the largest property destroyed in a five-alarm fire 13 months ago on East Tremont Avenue says that although he is ready to build a bigger store on the site, the city says he can't just yet. A dotted line planners drew on a map half a century ago has East Tremont Avenue cutting through his property, meaning that even rebuilding on the site requires a ruling from the city. And $8,000 in legal fees.
 
'This Is Impossible'
 The city's stance vexes Mr. Berkovits, considering that to help him with his expansion plans the city sold him a small parcel next to his original lot without, he said, telling him that the street is plotted through the land. Even more perplexing to him, and most people, is that East Tremont Avenue is where it has always been -- on the street in front of Mr. Berkovits's land. 
 "It's crazy, but we don't know where to turn for help," he said, adding that if things had gone without a hitch he could have finished construction by the fall, rather than next year. "I understand it's a big city and it takes time and everything has to be done according to law, but this is impossible. Here's one of the reasons the economy is not moving."
Even a spokesman for the city agency that denied Mr. Berkovits his construction permit agreed the situation defied some measure of common sense.
"It's one of those things," said Vahe Tiryakian, a spokesman for the Buildings Department. "New Yorkers, aren't we something here? Every time you think you're doing well, whammo, the city hits you right in the face."
The stall in obtaining a building permit is only the latest obstacle facing some half-dozen businessmen whose stores were destroyed in a fire July 6, 1992. They complained bitterly last year that city officials initially seemed indifferent to helping them cut through the bureaucracy and promised more help they could deliver, including low-interest loans that never materialized. All that remains, is a half-block-long vacant lot.
Mr. Berkovits said he learned of the phantom road last spring, after the city sold him a parcel next to his lot, at 410-414 East Tremont Avenue, that, together, he would use to build a 12,766-square-foot building that would re-house a hardware store and restaurant that were lost in the fire. But when his architect went to the Buildings Department to obtain a construction permit, he was told that the mapped street prevented immediate rebuilding.
Planners who have studied maps for the area did not know why that stretch of Tremont Avenue was mapped differently from the way it currently runs, saying that it appeared to deviate from its current route for only that one block between Webster and Park Avenues.
Nevertheless, its existence on tax maps is enough to block new construction, said Mr. Tiryakian. Even replacing an existing building requires a variance from the city's Board of Standards and Appeals, he said.
"It's the pre-existing nonconforming use concept here," Mr. Tiryakian said. "Probably what happened here is those buildings existed and the street was mapped, and then by general city law, you're not allowed to build on mapped streets."
In other words, buildings that existed before the mapping were not affected, but any new construction would need permission from the city. City officials said Mr. Berkovits should have known about the restriction that would have been revealed in a title search.
Jennifer Pitts, a spokeswoman for the Economic Development Corporation, which helped Mr. Berkovits acquire the parcel from the city, said they had no inkling of the mapped street.
"It was just a sliver of a building on a much larger property and no one realized there was a street through that whole block," she said, referring to the property the city sold to Mr. Berkovits. The development corporation, she said, is speeding up the process to get Mr. Berkovits a hearing by late September. The corporation has also gotten assurances from the Transportation Department that it has no plans to widen or move East Tremont Avenue.
That is small comfort to Mr. Berkovits, who still will have to spend $8,000 on fees for lawyers to obtain the ruling. Worse yet, by the time the variance is granted, he worries that he will have lost out on the construction season until next year, and his agreement for buying the land calls for him to begin construction within six months -- from last May. Ms. Pitts said the city would not take action against Mr. Berkovits as long as he made a good faith effort to seek the city's permission for the construction.
 
'A Summons for Everything'
 Of course, he could build without a permit, but that would only invoke the wrath of the bureaucracy. He has already been hit with one summons for clearing the property without a permit.
"You can't do anything," said Stanley Brill, a business associate of Mr. Berkovits's. "If you start to build the city would hit you with some kind of summons for being in violation of the law. The city has a summons for everything."
To insure that other merchants are spared Mr. Berkovits's predicament, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer said he has instructed his staff to see how he could officially remove the street from the map.
"Bernie, we're going to try to persuade people that East Tremont doesn't really go through your land," Mr. Ferrer said he would like to tell Mr. Berkovits, when informed of the landlord's predicament. "We want your sales tax and we want you. This is nuts."
Mo Stein, the owner of Frank's Sporting Goods, agrees. There may be no traffic on the imaginary street, but there hasn't been too much traffic on the real one since the fire, either, and that means sales are down for those merchants who survived the fire.
Don't get him started on the city, because he'll only regale you with tales of how the city has not done much for him or his block, a once bustling strip that now is home to one very large, vacant lot.
"It goes to show you the ineptitude of the whole thing," said Mr. Stein, whose business has been on the block for 70 years. "Instead of helping you, they throw hurdles."
As is his wont, Mr. Stein peppered his talk with references to the area's somewhat colorful history, noting that local legend has it that the building next to Mr. Berkovits's vacant lot was once owned by the gangster Dutch Schultz.
Mr. Schultz, he presumed, would have had no difficulty rebuilding.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Prices Fall Sharply On Weakness in Housing

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Lumber prices fell sharply yesterday after the Government reported that housing starts were weaker than expected in July.
Adding to the pressure on lumber futures were signs that a rail strike in Canada, which has been hampering lumber deliveries, could be resolved as soon as this week. 
 On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, spruce two-by-fours for September delivery fell $9.10 to close at $260.80 per thousand board feet.
Starts of new housing construction fell 2.7 percent in July, the biggest decline since March. Contributing to the decline was the flooding along the Mississippi River and a slump in construction activity in the West. Housing starts have fallen in four of seven months this year, even though mortgage rates are the lowest in two decades.
Permits for new construction rose 3 percent last month, but activity in the wholesale lumber market remains light. Although mills are offering lumber at $270 per thousand board feet, "there's just no interest," said Bud Merrill, an analyst with Smith Barney Shearson.
Meanwhile, traders said the government of British Columbia could intervene to end the monthlong BC Rail strike as soon as tomorrow. BC Rail's main business is transporting forest products from British Columbia, one of the largest timber producing areas in North America.
"Many people feel the government is getting close to settling the BC Rail strike with a 30-to-45-day cooling-off period," said Curt Cunningham, president of Pacific Futures Trading in Seattle. "That would free up a lot of wood that has been trapped up there."
On other commodity markets, oil futures rose, led by renewed interest in gasoline. Crude oil for September delivery closed 6 cents higher at $17.92 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Heating oil finished 0.10 cent higher at 52.91 cents a gallon and unleaded gasoline finished 0.14 cent higher at 55.78 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: An Uneven Corporate Tax Bite

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
No two industrial giants fit identically into the folds of the new tax law, any more than two portly accountants would share the same custom-made suit.
The profitable will feel the pinch one way, the unprofitable another; manufacturers and service industries will enjoy different tax breaks. A company might find itself heavily affected by international tax provisions, by the arcana of financial accounting rules, by increased fuel taxes or by the loss of deductions for the lobbying expenses with which corporations defend their interests whenever their tax burden is at stake. 
 The following cases of car makers, airlines, drug companies and banks illustrate how various industries will be affected by the new tax law.
 
Higher Rate for Ford
 At the Ford Motor Company, it is simple which provision of the new law has the biggest effect: the increase in the top corporate income tax rate from 34 percent, to 35 percent.
Like the other big American car makers, Ford has turned the corner back into profitability this year, and although the company would not predict how much higher taxes would cost in the years ahead, there is no question that it will be many millions of dollars.
But the full effect will not be felt right away, said Burton B. Smoliar, Ford's associate general counsel, because the company in recent years paid taxes under the alternative minimum tax system even while losing money. As a result, however, it has earned credits that can reduce its tax burden in the future.
Aside from the corporate rate increase, the bill is a mixed bag for Ford: the tax credits for research and development will help; the costs of international tax provisions are very difficult to predict; the flexible limits on pay for top executives are a new layer of red tape with only marginal economic consequences.
Any disappointment over not receiving an investment tax credit was mitigated. The idea was steadily whittled down from the day it was first introduced, so its absence came as no surprise, and the credit would have been paid for by an additional point on the tax rate, which would have then been 36 percent.
One disappointment for Ford was the law's modest gasoline tax increase of 4.3 cents a gallon, Mr. Smoliar said. Ford advocated a broad- based energy tax or a gasoline tax increase of up to 25 cents a gallon to cut the deficit and conserve energy. That opinion, however, countered the views of some other corporations and ultimately lost.
 
Airline Fuel Costs
 If a higher fuel tax is the sword to cut the Federal budget, the airline industry looks at it with all the enthusiasm of Damocles.
Although the airlines won an exemption from the increase for two years, the Air Transport Association predicts that when they start paying the tax it will cost them $500 million a year and have a significant effect on the industry's profitability. That is about 30 percent of the profits the industry reported in 1988, its record profit year, when the airlines earned $1.7 billion.
But those profits seem distant memories, so the last thing the industry is concerned about is the higher top corporate tax rate. The industry has lost $10 billion in the last three years, and when airlines pay taxes, it is almost always under the alternative minimum tax system, said Richard Janis, head of the Air Transport Association's tax committee.
The industry already has an aggregate $673 million in unused alternative minimum tax credits, a number that grows every year; when an airline does make enough money to incur tax liabilities under the regular tax calculation, the credits are used to reduce those taxes.
More important to the airlines is how the alternative minimum tax itself is calculated. Here, they were moderately pleased by a change in how depreciation is treated in calculating alternative minimum taxes. Depreciation of airplanes is a big factor on airline tax returns, and the savings to the industry will come to an estimated $17 million annually.
But that entire tax savings was outweighed by a provision reducing to 50 percent from 80 percent the deductible portion of business meal expenses. Because the airlines pay per diem costs for flight crews who must stay away from home, the change is expected to cost the industry an estimated $27.5 million a year.
 
Burden for Drug Makers
 The corporate rate may be rising just one percentage point, but the effective rate of taxation for some companies will be skyrocketing because of other provisions -- as the pharmaceuticals giant Pfizer I illustrates.
The changes, especially a cut in the tax incentives for companies that manufacture products in Puerto Rico, will have the effect of raising Pfizer's effective tax rate to 30 percent in 1994 from the 26 percent expected in 1993, the company said.
Pfizer Inc. has been the biggest beneficiary of this tax break, and pharmaceuticals makers in general have historically accounted for about half of all the tax benefits won under the provision, according to the General Accounting Office. Congressional tax experts have estimated that the change in the rules will increase tax receipts by $3.8 billion over five years, but industry experts say the amount will probably be greater.
Other provisions, which affect foreign operations, will also greatly affect the company, said a tax expert at Pfizer, who asked not to be identified.
A new test of whether foreign earnings are subject to taxation will be especially burdensome on pharmaceuticals companies, she said. It will prevent them from deferring payment of American taxes on earnings that are retained overseas for operating expenses like research and marketing.
"Pfizer does not have a choice about whether to manufacture in the European Community or not," she said. "If we are going to sell in Europe, we have to manufacture there." But many of the assets involved are not bricks and mortar but intellectual assets, she added, and consequently the company fails the tests of whether its retained earnings are earned by "active" or "passive" assets as defined under the law. The resulting tax will make it harder to compete with European concerns, she said.
The reinstatement of the research and development tax credit surely will help companies like Pfizer. But because the riskiest of businesses finance most of their research out of retained earnings, the consequences of raising the corporate tax and other tax increases are likely to more than offset this, industry officials said.
 
Intangibles in Banking
 At Amsouth Bank N.A., an $11 billion bank holding company centered in Alabama, financial officers are most interested in the effects of one section of the new law: the provision affecting the amortization of intangible assets, like "good will value."
It is a provision with an impact on banks and savings and loans nationwide. It greatly affects the tax consequences of banking acquisitions over the last two years, when surviving financial institutions took over the assets of those that were seized by the Government.
"We acquired branches from the Resolution Trust Corporation back in 1991 that will be covered," said Lynda Kern, the bank's vice president for tax matters. Sales of credit-card portfolios, mortgage servicing rights and other intangible assets are also affected, she added.
For years, banks reckoned that the premium they pay for acquired deposits represented the hidden value, known as good will, attributable to relationships with customers. In a series of disputes with the Internal Revenue Service, banks had sought to depreciate such intangibles over time. A Supreme Court ruling this year tilted the argument toward the taxpayers, and the new law makes clear that these assets can be written off against income, generally over 15 years.
The provision does not affect only financial institutions, but any company that buys another and gains intangible assets like subscription lists or advertising relationships.
"We haven't pushed all the numbers yet," Ms. Kern said. But she said that clearly this provision was the most important one in the law for the bank. (The provision does not, however, apply to many bank mergers because they so often involve exchanges of stock.)
There are several other effects of the bill that banks must consider, she said, starting with the inevitable increase that the one-point rise in corporate taxes will add to the cost of capital and credit.
For banks that deal in securities, as more and more of them do, there is a new provision requiring securities dealers to mark their securities inventories to market values for Federal income tax purposes. Bank loans are generally not affected by the provision.

HEADLINE: Real Estate

BYLINE: By Maureen Milford

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
A FLAGGING urban redevelopment project here, promoted as the state's largest single real estate undertaking when it was announced in 1986, has received a much needed lift from a lending giant that for years had only a limited presence in the state.
The Beneficial Corporation, whose headquarters are now in a suburban Wilmington office park, in June signed a lease with an option to buy on a long-vacant office building in Wilmington's downtown Christina Gateway Financial District near the Christina River. 
 Beneficial, a big multinational lender, also said it might move its management unit from Peapack, N.J., to the Gateway district by the end of the decade, when the New Jersey lease is up.
The company has also taken an option on the last developable parcel in the Gateway Financial District, next door to the 12-story tower in which Beneficial will occupy six floors by 1995.
"Delaware is looking very attractive to us right now, very attractive," said James H. Gilliam Jr., Beneficial's executive vice president. Mr. Gilliam also serves as volunteer chairman of Wilmington 2000, a redevelopment group created by the new Mayor, James H. Sills Jr.
The Beneficial relocation, which will begin by early next year, was cause for celebration by the Sills administration and state officials after three years of a moribund real estate market. The company's decision is the biggest such victory for the city since 1980, when Hercules Inc., the chemical giant, decided to stay in Delaware in a new tower on the Brandywine River.
Downtown Wilmington's 26 or so large office buildings, with 4.5 million square feet of space, have been hard hit in the economic downturn. Developers broke state construction records in the 1980's in a scramble to cash in on the influx of financial institutions attracted by the state's banking and credit card laws. But the heavy corporate migration was over by the late 1980's.
Leasing activity in 1992 was just 126,000 square feet, down 61 percent from the five-year average, according to studies by the Jackson-Cross Company, a commercial real estate firm with offices in Wilmington. The largest lease signed last year was for 17,000 square feet, while total space available at the end of the year was 1.1 million square feet. Vacancy rates were well over 20 percent.
Building owners, facing competition from suburban parks, have been trying to survive, seeking just to maintain their rent rolls, something Gateway has not been able to do.
The 321,500-square-foot building to be occupied by Beneficial went up in the late 1980's for Marine Midland Bank, but the bank decided to get out of Delaware in 1990 and it never moved into the tower. Marine Midland tried unsuccessfully to sublease the space, then eventually bought the building.
A few nibbles on the space that all came to naught made Beneficial's position strong in negotiations with Marine Midland, leasing agents said.
Finn M. W. Caspersen, chairman of Beneficial, said: "Let's just say we got a super deal. Most important to us was that it gave us flexibility, which is a euphemism for expansion."
The Sills administration has provided Beneficial and other large employers with tax breaks.
When Gateway was announced in 1986, the plan called for 1.2 million square feet of office space in three office towers and a waterfront marketplace on the Christina River. Eleven acres in the southeastern section of downtown were assembled by a city and state partnership, cleaned up and readied for development.
A development agreement was signed with the Linpro Company of Berwyn, Pa. and Delledonne & Associates of Wilmington.
Plans called for at least half the project to be finished by 1988, with the marketplace to be completed before 1990. Neither goal was met.
Despite the government backing of the Gateway project, the private sector continued a long trend of moving into space north and west of the city's downtown retail district. The Du Pont Company headquarters on Rodney Square, approximately nine blocks from Gateway, remained the hub of the office district.
Only two office towers have been erected in Gateway: the one that Beneficial has agreed to lease and one leased by First U.S.A. Bank, the first and only major tenant in Gateway since 1989.

HEADLINE: Book Notes;
General Powell to Trade the Sword for the Pen

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
For months, New York's big-bucks publishers have been working themselves into a frenzy over Gen. Colin L. Powell, who is to retire as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on Sept. 30 and then, at least in the publishers' minds, immediately begin working on his memoirs.
Yesterday, his agent, Marvin Josephson of International Creative Management, announced that Random House had acquired world rights to the general's autobiography. Rival publishers familiar with the negotiations said the final price was about $6.5 million, which would make it $1.5 million more than Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf reportedly received for his vastly successful autobiography, "It Doesn't Take a Hero" (Bantam), which sold more than a million copies. 
 The announcement followed an intense battle of the publishing titans. The final round of competitors included the Putnam-Berkley Publishing Group. For six months, publishers have been traveling to Washington in a constant caravan, but Random House seems to have deployed the heaviest forces. Harold M. Evans, the publisher of Random House's adult trade group; Alberto Vitale, the chairman of Random House Inc. and Mr. Evans's boss, and S. I. Newhouse Jr., the chairman of Advance Publications and both men's boss, first approached the general more than a year ago and then kept up with frequent visits, telephone calls and letters.
 
Up the Ranks
 Of course, it is far too early to tell whether the hefty advance will be recouped after the book is published, although the publisher stands to take in considerable sums for things like foreign, serial and book club rights. Rival publishers said that among General Powell's most attractive qualities were his record as both a soldier and a policy maker, and his background as the Harlem-born son of Jamaican immigrants.
"This book is about a capable, brilliant man called Colin Powell who happens to be black," said Mr. Evans, who said he would edit the book himself. The as yet untitled book, to be published in 1995, is to be co-written with a professional writer who has yet to be selected, he said.
People familiar with the process said at least one rival publisher, and possibly two, had matched Random House's final price. "Clearly there are at least two publishers who feel that Colin Powell will be at least as successful as Schwarzkopf, if not more so," said Carolyn K. Reidy, the president and publisher of Simon & Schuster's adult trade group, which dropped out of the bidding before the final round.
Mr. Josephson said that before General Powell made the agreement with Random House, he had consulted lawyers to make sure it was legal to sign a book contract before leaving public office. "The contract is very clear that he does zero before Oct. 1," Mr. Josephson said. "The Department of Defense ethics office and a number of lawyers examined it, and there's no question that this is totally and completely legal and aboveboard."
 
'Bridges' Backlash
 "The Bridges of Madison County" -- whose publisher, Warner, has quietly raised its price to $16.95, from $14.95 -- continues to steamroll its way into people's homes. But Tom Clancy's thriller "Without Remorse" (Putnam) has knocked "Bridges," by Robert James Waller, from its berth at No. 1 on the New York Times best-seller list for Aug. 29.
In other "Bridges" news, a sort of backlash against the book, small but increasingly enthusiastic, has developed. Garry Trudeau is even using this week's "Doonesbury" to depict a flood version, "The Washed-Out Bridges of Madison County."
Mr. Trudeau's strips capture quite accurately the tone and language of the actual book. "I was just trying to move it slightly off center and let it condemn itself," said Mr. Trudeau, who read "Bridges" about a month ago after he found it on the desk of his wife, the NBC News correspondent Jane Pauley. "There's no question that this book is deeply resented by some people who think they understand what literature should be."
And Plume announced plans to publish a parody, "The Ditches of Edison County," which chronicles the affair between Pancetta and Concave. (In the real book, they're Francesca and Kincaid.) "We'll make the margins nice and wide, and throw in some of the photos I could never unload anywhere else," said the author, Ronald Richards Roberts. (His real name is Billy Frolick.)
 
Returning an Advance
 In May 1991, when the star of good fortune was shining on President George Bush, Edward Klein, a journalist, signed a contract with Little, Brown to write "a highly personal, minute-by-minute, hour-by-hour account of a political, professional and personal day in the White House with George and Barbara Bush." The publisher promised a fat $500,000 advance, of which one-third, or $166,666, was paid immediately. One-third was to be paid when Mr. Klein submitted the manuscript by Jan. 1, 1992, and the rest was to be paid on publication.
But the plan unraveled quickly. By October 1991, with the economy souring and the President's political future increasingly uncertain, his staff informed Mr. Klein that Mr. Bush would not cooperate until after the election. That meant, in turn, that Mr. Klein could not meet his deadline and fulfill his contract with Little, Brown. The publisher canceled the contract on Nov. 6, 1991, and demanded its $166,666 back.
It is not uncommon for authors and publishers to quarrel about advances and contracts; the business is full of cases of blocked writers who fall behind schedule, and of publishers who decide that submitted manuscripts are unacceptably bad or too far afield from the topics agreed upon. What does seem unusual about this case, however, is that after a year of haggling in which both sides tried to settle the issue, Little, Brown sued Mr. Klein for the money -- and won.
In an opinion dated Aug. 13, Justice Peter Tom of State Supreme Court in Manhattan granted summary judgment to the publisher, saying Mr. Klein had clearly breached his contract. Details of the ruling were first published on Monday in The New York Law Journal.
Both sides said in interviews that they had not wanted the matter to go to court. And each accused the other of acting in bad faith.
After the book project fell apart, both sides said, they set about resolving the matter, either by finding another book for Mr. Klein or by negotiating a repayment schedule. Neither plan worked.
Mr. Klein, a contributing editor at Vanity Fair and a former editor of The New York Times Magazine, said he certainly thought he owed something to the publisher. "It was never a case that I felt I had no obligation to Little, Brown," he said, adding that when the contract was canceled, he had already spent part of the money on general expenses and preliminary research. He said Little, Brown had demanded the money back much more quickly than he could afford to repay it and then gave scant attention to a number of ideas for new books. "I came up with numerous written proposals and made numerous presentations for substitute books," he said, "but they were strangely uncooperative, to say the least."
Charles E. Hayward, the president of Little, Brown, said almost exactly the same thing about Mr. Klein. "I didn't think he was making a serious enough effort to repay the money," he said, adding that Little, Brown had proposed a repayment schedule that Mr. Klein rejected out of hand.
"A six-figure advance was paid to an author for a book that was clearly contingent on the cooperation of the President, and it wasn't long after the money was paid that it became clear the President wasn't going to cooperate," he said. "I said, 'Let's try to find a new book,' and he came up with what I thought were a bunch of superficial ideas. At the end of the day, I felt we were dealing with someone who wasn't acting in good faith."
Mr. Klein's lawyer, Leon Friedman, said the next step had not been decided.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
Cabernet On Tap (Not for Cork Sniffers)

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
"THERE'S no wine in the house. Run out and get a box of chardonnay."
A box of chardonnay? Sure -- why not? Chardonnay, cabernet sauvignon, sauvignon blanc, whatever you like. 
 While you may have been poring over vintage charts, joining tasting groups, trying to use precisely the right glass and wondering if your precious 1982's are over the hill, lots of people have been just drinking wine.
There is no law that says you have to be a connoisseur to enjoy a glass of wine. Nor is it written that you have to read a wine textbook before you pull a cork -- or, more often, unscrew a cap.
Don't get nervous: this is not going to be an anti-intellectual tract or an exercise in praise of wine boorishness. It's just pleasant, now and then, to recognize that there is another world of wine, far removed from the precious confines of the cork sniffers.
Who are the cork sniffers? The term is one of mild derision applied to folks who take wine very seriously. Who applies it? Beer salesmen, whisky salesmen -- people in the more traditional, more unbuttoned segments of the liquor business.
All cork sniffers drink wine, presumably, but not all wine drinkers are cork sniffers. What provokes this insight is a report, admittedly self-serving, from the people at Franzia Vineyards in California predicting that in 1993, Americans will drink some 40 million gallons of wine out of boxes.
Now, 40 million gallons is a lot of wine, more than 16.5 million cases. No cork sniffer would be caught dead with a box of wine, but if the Franzias are to be believed, there are plenty of Americans who think the wine box is a good idea.
The wine box, or as it is more commonly known, the bag-in-the-box, has been around for at least 20 years. It first enjoyed considerable popularity in Australia. It has had some success in Europe but until recently never made any serious inroads on the American market. In this country, about the only thing shared by connoisseurs and the consumers of inexpensive wine has been the conviction that wine should come in bottles.
There is little doubt among wine professionals that the recession has given the bag-in-the-box a boost. Indeed, there has been a minor revolution in the wine business as a hugh segment of the market discovered that wine does not have to be expensive to taste good.
"Five years ago, I predicted that within 10 years, 80 percent of all wine in large sizes -- three liters or more -- would be in boxes," said Arthur Ciocca, president of The Wine Group, Franzia's parent company. "We're at 33 percent now."
Franzia has about 90 percent of the wine-box business in this country, mostly under its own name but also under the Summit and Colony labels. Almaden Vineyards, now a subsidiary of Heublein, produces some wine boxes. Heublein also sells some under the once legendary Inglenook label.
The most common size of wine box bought by individuals is five liters, which holds slightly less than seven bottles of wine. (There is also an 18-liter box, bought primarily by restaurants.) It costs anywhere from $9 to $12, or about $1.30 to $1.70 a bottle. The box -- Franzia calls its version the Winetap -- takes up about a third less space than a four-liter glass jug and about the same space as four single bottles. A built-in tap makes pouring wine simple; there is no need to remove the box from the refrigerator. The bag that holds the wine inside the box is an airtight polyethelene container that collapses as the wine is poured. No air gets in, which means the wine can last for days.
What about quality? Within their category, the Franzia wines are first rate. If that sounds like a qualfied statement, it is. They are relatively soft and fruity with a touch of sweetness. A devotee of great Bordeaux will find little excitement here. But devotees of great Bordeaux are few, and people who like an occasional glass of easy-to-drink, unpedigreed wine are, apparently, legion.
Franzia offers 11 different wines in boxes. In the past, bag-in-the-box wines were almost exclusively generics, that is, blends of wine from various grapes, given names like burgundy and claret. Many box wines are still generics, like Franzia's Mountain Chablis, which is certainly not Chablis and probably has nothing to do with mountains but is a fresh, pleasant wine. Burgundy and Rhine are the other two generics in the line.
But now there are varietals in boxes. A varietal is a wine that bears the name of the principal grapes from which it is made; cabernet sauvignon, for example, or chardonnay, or the most popular of all, white zinfandel. Franzia boxes all three. Other Franzia varietals are sauvignon blanc, white grenache, French colombard and chenin blanc. Note that only two of the 11 Franzia varietals are red wines: cabernet sauvignon and Burgundy.
Not too many years ago, the idea of putting cabernet or chardonnay in a box would have been unthinkable. They were the noble grapes of France and the great vineyards of northern California. They were hard to grow and expensive to turn into wine.
Today there are plenty of good grapes available, and wineries like E.& J. Gallo, Glen Ellen, Fetzer and Sutter Home produce millions of bottles of these once rare wines at highly competitive prices -- so competitive that the wines are called fighting varietals. In 1992, according to Impact, a wine and spirits trade publication, California table-wine shipments increased by 8.1 percent from the previous year.
Generic wines were up a modest 2.2 percent, but varietals, led by white zinfandel, were up 15.3 percent from 47.7 million cases to 55 million.
There is little argument over the fact that the bag-in-the-box is one of the most economical and efficient ways to package wines that will be drunk soon after purchase. Image is what has held the boxes back. Wine drinking has long been inextricably intertwined with prestige and tradition. What other product could survive with so inconvenient a package as the cork-stoppered bottle?
Finally, faced with a shortage of good corks and a proliferation of bad ones, the industry is grudgingly turning to alternate stoppers. And there is less consumer rejection that anyone predicted. In France, for the longest time, the only wines found in boxes were heavy reds and dull whites from the furnacelike vineyards of Languedoc-Roussillon. In recent years, good Cotes du Rhone has made its appearance in a box, along with some pleasant whites from the Loire. Can Beaujolais be far behind?
And in this country, will wine in a box move up the social scale? With chardonnay and cabernet already boxed in, it looks like it already has.
 
TASTINGS
Chateau de Jau, Cotes du Roussillon, 1988. About $4.50.
 Consumers have good reason to be wary of yet another label from the South of France. Wines of all kinds spring forth in great profusion from that fruitful region, mostly to disappear without a trace in a few months. Here is an exception.
The Daure family, wine and spirits distributors, has invested healthy amounts of love and money in the Chateau de Jau, an impressive estate in the arid, Arizona-like country north and west of Perpignan.
The Cotes du Roussillon appellation, created in 1977, is a testimony to the steady improvement in the wines of this hot region. But the Chateau de Jau has gone further, producing a lovely, aromatic, medium-bodied red wine from carignan, grenache and some minor local grapes. A remarkable bargain.

LENGTH: 320 words

HEADLINE: A Challenge for Kids -- and the Military

 BODY:
America's military forces are redefining themselves in the post-cold-war era. At the same time, many poor and minority youths aren't succeeding in school or in life. That's why a new National Guard initiative seems like a good idea for the military, for troubled youths and for society.
The initiative is the Youth Corps ChalleNGe program (the capitalized NG is for National Guard), which enlists current and former military personnel to teach and counsel young men and women who have dropped out of school. The teaching is aimed at preparing them to obtain a high school equivalency diploma. The counseling is to help them cope with life. 
 To qualify for the program, which is now getting its first test in Connecticut, a dropout must be 16 to 18 years old and unemployed; only those on probation or parole or with charges pending against them will be disqualified. The program's mission is to intervene before it's too late in the lives of youths who are at risk. While these young people are not recruited for military service, they do get a healthy dose of military discipline. Their uniforms consist mainly of T-shirts and sweat pants, and their days are carefully structured.
Over 22 weeks, participants attend classes in academic subjects like English, math and science. They also hear talks on citizenship and leadership and learn routine skills like balancing a checkbook. At the end of the program, each participant who receives an equivalency diploma, gets a job or goes on to college will be awarded a stipend of $2,200.
The Federal Government has appropriated $44 million for the program's first year, which will finance pilot projects in 10 states. "We offer the gift of hope," says Dan Donohue, the Guard's public affairs director and the principal developer of the ChalleNGe program. That could be true for the military services seeking new challenges as well as for the dropouts.

HEADLINE: The Military Is Not a Social Program

BYLINE: By James Webb; James Webb was Assistant Secretary of Defense and Secretary of the Navy in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
Our society is becoming ever more divided between people of thought and people of action. Thus, it is not surprising that a wide array of politicians and commentators found the order by the Marine Corps Commandant that would have limited enlistments to unmarried recruits an object of easy derision.
Administration officials concede that Gen. Carl E. Mundy Jr. possesses the authority to change Marine recruitment policy without their approval. Nonetheless, the order was quickly rescinded, and he was subjected to a public dressing-down for having exercised his judgment without their concurrence. 
 The general may, indeed, have committed a procedural error. But the reaction to his order and the inability of those in political and media power to clearly see the problem he is trying to address give us a nice allegory of why our national leadership has become so derailed and unrespected.
President Clinton, who has never held a non-bureaucratic or even a private-sector job and is well-remembered for his youthful letter sympathizing with those who "loathed" the military, was said to be astonished at General Mundy's decision. According to The New York Times, the plan flew in the face of Mr. Clinton's "commitment to have the military reflect society at large."
Representative Pat Schroeder, who claims military expertise from having gone to Armed Services Committee meetings for two decades, during which she has tried to civilianize the military and cut billions of dollars annually from its operating budget, dismissed General Mundy as a cultural Neanderthal. With an arrogance that has become her imprimatur, she wondered whether he had "taken leave of his senses" and pointed out that "even the Pope allows his Swiss Guards to be married." "Marines have always been the least family-friendly," she said, "and I think we now see that policy in action."
The New York Times's front-page coverage said that General Mundy's plan involved "constitutional questions of discrimination and privacy." The Washington Post termed him a "zealous steward of tradition in what is by far the most conservative and insular of the military services."
From a chorus of people who have never handled an operating budget or been responsible for troops sent in harm's way comes an unspoken litany: We are smarter than you. General Mundy could have a field day responding to their comments. For starters:
* How far does Mr. Clinton wish to go in order to have a military that "reflects society at large"? Should we lower its educational standards, since the military's percentage of high school graduates is higher than society's? Should we reduce opportunities for minorities, since they are more prevalent in the military than in society? Should Yale lawyers and Rhodes scholars serve in the same percentages as they exist in society?
* How often does Ms. Schroeder think the Swiss Guards travel thousands of miles from their wives for a year at a time? And since when have they required the training, weapons and logistics for heavy combat?
* When do phrases like "least family-friendly" and "most conservative and insular" simply mask an arrogance toward an institution that, beyond cavil, is the least problem-filled and most combat-ready military service our country has ever fielded?
The country and the other military services should listen to General Mundy. He is not harking to the past but informing us of the realities of the future. The greatest challenge as our military weans itself from its NATO role and shapes its forces for the future will be to build and sustain a highly maneuverable and cost-effective fighting force. This will require planners to go against the grain of many recruitment policies that gave us the all-volunteer military.
The all-volunteer system has drawn heavily on young enlistees who are married or wish to marry, because of remarkable family benefits that include free medical care, housing, day care, counseling services, commissary and PX privileges and generous early retirement.
Predictably, the percentage of young marrieds ballooned as these benefits improved. Although only 14 percent of Army soldiers holding the rank of E-5 were married in 1971, by 1986 that percentage was 73 percent. Today, 40 percent of Marines on their first enlistment are married, and those marriages are suffering a 40 percent divorce rate.
During my time in the Pentagon, the Army's No. 1 budget priority was its quality-of-life programs, which cost more than $6 billion a year. Even in the 1980's, this ever-increasing spending caused concern among planners, since payments to keep the troops happy and encourage retention took money away from go-to-war budget areas related to mobilization, combat medical readiness and logistics.
But military leaders scarred from the disciplinary nightmare of the final days of conscription, as well as the leaders of our NATO allies, were comfortable with the greater percentage of marrieds. They were a more contented force; they fit well with the garrison mentality of NATO forces, causing less problems off-base and pumping more money into foreign economies.
But as our NATO bases are being shut down, these circumstances are changing. With a smaller force structure and wider range of potential crisis areas, the Army and tactical Air Force will certainly experience more unscheduled deployments, accompanied by greater family turbulence.
The Navy and Marine Corps, with its forces continually deployed worldwide without families, began feeling the magnitude of problems associated with young marrieds before the Army and Air Force.

For decades, in peace and war, a junior enlisted man or officer in the sea services has been away from home six months each year on average. As these services are cut back further -- without any reduction in the worldwide commitments demanded of them -- an even harsher operational schedule and greater family separation can be expected.
If a service chief is given less money and fewer people to perform essentially the same tasks, how can he best meet his requirements? If offered the choice between two people of equal talent, one of which needs only a bunk while the other requires full family benefits, including counseling when a teen-age marriage goes sour, which should he choose?
To put it another way, if one is given the awesome task of providing the best defense a specific sum can buy, should he be faulted for wanting to put the money into troops and weapons rather than into dependents and day care centers?
Perhaps a complete ban on married enlistees is overkill. But a Commandant who takes his stewardship seriously -- and politicians and commentators whose true focus is effective national defense -- would ask that this issue be thoroughly examined as a matter of fiscal and practical leadership.

HEADLINE: Teachers in U.S. Trail Those Elsewhere in Pay

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
American schoolteachers make less money, receive less training and spend less time preparing for their classes than their peers in many other countries, according to a new study by the American Federation of Teachers.
The study, which combines reports from other countries and original research in the United States, paints a portrait of a profession under stress. The A.F.T., the nation's second largest teachers' union, asserted that despite improvements in teacher salaries, training and preparation in many states, failure to do more might discourage bright young people from starting teaching careers. 
 These were among the study's findings:
*The top salaries for American high school teachers average $38,000 a year, as against $43,000 in Germany, $45,000 in Japan, $47,000 in Ottawa and $70,000 in Geneva. National figures were not available for Canada and Switzerland. European countries tend to pay elementary school teachers about the same as those in the United States, but Japanese and Canadian elementary teachers make more. European and Asian countries generally have school years slightly longer than those in the United States.
*American teachers are required to earn four-year degrees; Japanese teachers and most European teachers receive six years of college training, using the extra years to develop specialties or strengthen their areas of expertise.
*American teachers get less time to prepare for classes. Japanese teachers, for instance, get an average of four hours in the school day, twice as much as American teachers.
Whether American teachers will be able to close the salary gap with teachers in other countries depends on many factors, among them economic recovery, state and local politics, the various movements to overhaul public education and the willingness of teachers and their unions to submit to more training and more rigid job-performance reviews.
"We're at a crossroads, where the fate of the profession is linked to a whole bunch of things," said Albert Shanker, president of the teachers' federation, which has 820,000 members. "Either we move to the models of other industrial nations with standards and assessments, or we move to a market system with vouchers, where we give parents the money and let them find the schools they want."
Even in places where teachers have won significant pay increases, student performance has not always made commensurate gains. Teachers in Rochester, for example, won a 53 percent pay increase for three years ending in 1990; it is believed to be the largest raise ever awarded teachers. They won another 15 percent increase through 1992.
But the lack of improvement in student performance in Rochester has left the perception that "a lot of people think the teachers got the money up front and ran," said Adam Urbansky, president of the Rochester Teachers Association.
A widespread feeling among the public is that for all the increases in overall spending for education -- including teacher salaries -- schools often do not seem to produce results. One study by a group of citizens in the Johnsburg Central School District in central New York found that although spending had increased significantly since 1980, with much of the increase going for teacher salaries, gains in student performance were slight.
But teachers say they are caught in a double bind: whatever their pay, they alone cannot turn around schools, but as long as school boards do not pay them more, too few of the brightest and most energetic young people will feel compelled to enter the profession.
 
Looking for Respect
 "When you compare teacher salaries to lawyers and doctors and others, I don't think we get paid much at all given the importance of our job," said Ricky Bible, a high school English teacher in Dallas who said he was considering leaving the profession. "We do not get the respect other professions do."
The A.F.T. study recommended that teacher salaries be standardized to a greater degree, eliminating the disparities from state to state and reducing teachers' time in the classrooms to give them more time for preparation. It also said that training for high school teachers should be strengthened and that the school year be should be lengthened by two weeks.
While teacher colleges have in recent years bolstered requirements for teachers in many states, budget cuts have prompted schools to reduce services across the board, including teacher training and retraining. To strengthen such programs, as the study suggests, would cost more money than the public is willing to pay, particularly in austere times.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 19, 1993, Thursday
