HEADLINE: TERRORISTS HELPED BY SUDAN, U.S. SAYS

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
The Administration's decision to add the Sudan to the list of countries that sponsor international terrorism was based on evidence that the Sudan harbors terrorists, and not because of any Sudanese links to a reported plot to bomb targets in New York City, United States officials said today.
The State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry, said evidence indicated that the Sudan had allowed its territory to be used as a sanctuary for groups like the Abu Nidal organization, the Party of God and the Palestine Islamic Holy War. The State Deparment considers all three groups terrorist organizations. 
 "We also believe safe houses and other facilities used to support radical groups are allowed to exist in Sudan with the apparent approval of the Sudanese Government's leadership," Mr. McCurry said. "Further, we believe that reports of training in Sudan of militant extremists that commit acts of terrorism in neighboring countries are credible."
 
No Proven Links to New York
 But he said there was insufficient evidence to link the Sudan to any plot to bomb the United Nations, the Hudson River tunnels and other sites in New York.
State Department officials said the investigation, ordered last December by former Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, was ready last month, but had been delayed so links between Khartoum and the 10 people indicted in the reported New York plot could be explored.
An Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the investigation did not confirm any connection. One official said that based on information from the prosecutors, evidence linking the Sudan to the conspiracy is "weak at this time," though some State Department officials have said in the past that they believe there is evidence of a link.
Officials indicated that the Sudanese Government, led by Lieut. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, was added to the list of nations supporting terrorism because it had failed to respond to repeated requests for information on suspected training sites, safe houses and other terrorist activities.
 
Denials by the Sudan
 A State Department official said the Sudan had repeatedly denied any involvement in terrorism, but had provided no explanations for suspected activity within its borders. "They didn't respond with anything that we considered credible," the official said. "Basically, they just denied, denied, denied."
The decision to list Sudan as a terrorist state means that the Government will be ineligible for United States economic and military aid, of which it receives virtually none at the moment. Relief aid of $56 million for refugees in the southern Sudan will not be affected; about 5 million Sudanese have been displaced by famine and civil war.
Officials from private aid organizations and from the State Department expressed concern that the Sudan would block refugee assistance after the Administration's decision.
President Bashir said today that he would not accept aid from Washington, The Associated Press reported. "Talking about the continuing humanitarian assistance means talking about an American intelligence presence in Sudan," he said, which "would make our country a theater for spies and agents."
 
An Awkward Intersection
 "It's a real dicey thing," a State Department official said about the refugee program. "We have played a very, very big role in the international community's response to the humanitarian crisis. It's mostly our money and mostly our people there. What I would hate for this to do, is sort of get wrapped up around this terrorism-list issue. The two are distinct issues."
Khartoum has a long record of making promises not to interfere with relief shipments, then breaking them, officials from the State Department and relief organizations say.
"The Sudanese Government has, over time, consistently tried to manipulate humanitarian relief effort towards its own political ends," said Hiram Ruiz, a policy analyst with the United States Committee for Refugees.
Still, some officials say it is doubtful the Sudan will carry through on a threat to block aid because that would only cause more political instability. In addition, most food aid enters the Sudan from Ethiopia and Kenya and is distributed in areas the Government does not control.

HEADLINE: Magazines Remake Family, or Vice Versa

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
WHEN BMW starts advertising itself as the car for "quality carpooling," you know major movement has appeared on the sonogram of popular culture.
A new brood of magazines and their advertisers have decided that it is family fun time in America. Geared toward a generation of parents -- 52 million strong -- for whom the dictatorial blueprints of the 1950's fit as well as Guess jeans during a pregnancy, they are less about coping with colic than about the existential gestalt of it all. 
 The latest player in the Candyland of magazine publishing is Family Life, a bimonthly for families with children ages 3 to 12, which made its debut last week. It is published by Straight Arrow Publishers Inc., a k a Jann Wenner, founder of Rolling Stone, and has been promoted with this pearlescent Wennerism: "A generation that once raised hell is now raising kids."
Along with Family Fun, a two-year-old magazine that was bought by Disney last year, Family Life joins a retinue of publications trailing the modern family. They include Parenting (circulation 925,000), from Time Warner Inc.; Child (circulation 600,000), a New York Times Company magazine, and that venerable staple of motherhood, Parents (circulation 1.75 million), founded in 1926 and owned by Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing.
Together, they represent a road map for a new generation of parents who have rejected "she" in favor of the androgynous "we."
"The 80's were about glitzy consumption," said Martin S. Walker, a magazine consultant. "The magazines are about the familial version of conspicuous consumption but also about togetherness."
So long, Baby Magic, Kotex and Hamburger Helper. The stork that delivered Family Life gets clipped at Frederic Fekkai and, if the magazine's advertisements are any indication, is heavily into Sony sketch pads, Macintosh computers, Ralph Lauren Poloboys and Dodge Minivans.
But beyond the ads, which manipulate 1990's parental and even social consciousness with an eerie (and perhaps cynical) perceptiveness, Family Life and other parenting magazines are an effort to rewrite the bibles read by the readers' mothers, which seemed to treat child rearing like a Betty Crocker cake mix.
"I looked at all those magazine cover lines that said things like 'Is Your Baby Sitter a Serial Killer?," said Nancy Evans, Family Life's editor in chief. "I saw the worried brow of womanhood. They all seemed connected with anxiety. They didn't address joy. They were all about 'wrong.' "
There are some palpable trends underlining Ms. Evans's shift from "what to do with a 4 A.M.fever" to more charming, Up With People-ish subjects like a profile of the Beasley public school in Chicago.
In contrast to the 1950's, when the readers of parenting magazines were young mothers in their 20's for whom child-rearing was a full-time job, the potential audience of Family Life and Family Fun is the 52 million adults with children 3 to 12. Family Life is aimed at parents in their 30's and early 40's, what is unceremoniously known in the obstetrics field as "advanced maternal age." They are dual-income, college-educated couples who are presumably more worldly and confident and less in need of a guru than their mothers were.
The new magazines have working-parent guilt going for them and the knowledge that unstructured family time is an increasingly precious commodity. Like their predecessors, they try to offer ideas for creative parenthood, beyond getting videos to baby-sit the children. "We are an information-hungry generation," said Carol A. Smith, the president of Parenting.
But in recycling the social consciousness of the 1960's and perhaps repenting the 1980's, they are also trying something more profound, symbolized by a provocative Robert Coles essay in Family Life, "The Commitment to Doing Good." The mission of Family Life, according to Ms. Evans's inaugural editor's note, is to be "the national kitchen table where we can talk about everything from how to entertain the kids at the next birthday party to how to make our schools better."
The premise is that readers have moved beyond advertisers' admonishments, like that expressed in a recent ad for Baby Orajel, a toothpaste, which shows a beautiful baby and the tag line "She's 7 months old and she already has plaque."
Graphically, the magazine breaks the mold, exuding the winsome charm of children's book illustrations. Both advertisements and articles highlight many expensive things to buy. Among the articles in the premiere issue is a poignant article by Melissa Fay Greene on the "Left-Out Child," Jill Krementz's guide to creating a family photo album and hip critiques of children's music, in which the reviewer cautions parents to have "a long, thoughtful time-out" before exposing their children to Alvin and the Chipmunks' singing "Achy Breaky Heart."
Family Life's net is wide, but not exactly new. As Mr. Walker notes, the life style approach to parenting began in the mid-1980's, most notably with the success of Parenting and Child magazines, which have bucked the recession and created the impression that parenting is "hot."
Parenting, whose circulation has grown from an initial 200,000, to 925,000, was founded in 1987 by Robin Wolaner, a former publisher of Mother Jones. Ms. Wolaner is widely credited with pioneering the concept of a parenting magazine for educated baby boomers. Parenting addresses the delicacies of maternal eyebrow-plucking as well as the plight of children in Bosnia. And it does not forsake the droolers. A major source of readers for Parenting are subscribers of Baby Talk, a magazine for expectant and new mothers also owned by Time Warner.
The typical reader of Child, according to Daniel Ambrose, its publisher, is a college-educated woman; the average age is 34. Aware that developmental stages are specific -- translation: once you've mastered potty training, the last thing you want to do is read about it -- the magazine has begun to customize its product, tailoring editorial inserts to parents of children in particular age groups.
Family Fun, a bimonthly which will turn monthly in November, is focused on the "family fun years," devoid of diapers, in which it is finally possible, in the words of president and editor Jake Winebaum, to "start influencing how your kid learns and perceives the world."
For parents who aren't artistically inspired, it does for their creativity what Cliff Notes can do for Tolstoy. In the most recent issue, for instance, the magazine looked at educational projects at museums around the country and showed readers how to duplicate them. (Tell the truth: did you know Jell-O bends light like a magnifying glass?)
Mr. Winebaum edits the magazine from Northampton, Mass., and said he remains editorially independent of Disney, whose name does not appear on the masthead page. But the ramifications of Disney's ownership are awesome. When the feverishly awaited "Aladdin" video comes out in October, every box, according to Mr. Winebaum, will contain a Family Fun subscription card.
But parental caution is advised: The effect of reading too many parenting magazines can be a little bit like walking into your living room to discover Play-Doh in the carpeting and passionate Crayola designs on the walls.
Of course, nothing lasts forever, including the family fun years. Soon, another new crop of magazines will doubtlessly appear, catering to those glorious Macho-Maturity years.

HEADLINE: Tax Break to Aid Museums

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
In large part because a van Gogh portrait of a troubled 19th-century doctor is now on the wall of a Japanese collector instead of in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the United States tax code has been substantially revised to encourage donations of artworks to museums instead of their sale on the market.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, pushed through the change in the law, which President Clinton signed this month as part of the budget package. 
 Mr. Moynihan, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which wrote the change in the law increasing the tax advantage to donors, pointed to statistics on gifts to museums that showed a huge drop in donations when a tax break for gifts to museums was deleted from 1987 to 1990, and then a sharp rise when it was temporarily restored during an 18-month window in 1991 and 1992.
"We went through what the scientists would call a natural experiment when the break was taken away in 1986," Senator Moynihan said. "Gifts of objects of art just dried up. Bang! They stopped."
 
A Case Study
 The van Gogh that used to be at the Met, "Portrait of Dr. Gachet," is cited by museum officials as a leading example of how the tax law discouraged such donations.
The painting was owned by the heirs of Siegfried Kramarsky, a New York banker and philanthropist. It is an evocative depiction by van Gogh of his friend and physician, Paul-Ferdinand Gachet, and was lent to the Met in 1984. Until 1990, it was assumed that the painting would remain there.
"I think the implication was there," said Ashton Hawkins, the Met's executive vice president and chief counsel. But he said he understood the heirs' decision to sell the painting. "We really couldn't blame them," he said. "How can we compete? We never felt angered at them, but at the situation."
Under the old law, if the heirs had donated the painting to the Met, they effectively could have deducted from their taxes only what Kramarsky paid for it in the late 1930's, even though the value of van Gogh's works had soared. If they had chosen to deduct the current market value of the painting, it would have made them liable for the alternative minimum tax, which would have substantially increased their tax liability.
How much the Kramarsky heirs would have increased their tax liability by donating the painting would have depended on their income and their other deductions, such as those for state and local taxes, which would have been disallowed under the alternative minimum tax application. Those figures have not been made public.
So, instead of giving the painting to the Met and increasing their taxes, they put it up for auction. It sold for $82.5 million, and they paid a capital gains tax, which in their case was far less than the alternative minimum tax. If they had kept the painting until now, they could have deducted its current value from their taxes and not have been put in the minimum tax category.
The Japanese buyer, Ryoei Saito, an industrialist, got his painting, and the Kramarsky heirs got an astounding price and paid a low tax. And the Met lost a van Gogh.
 
Small Museums Suffer
 It is not just the big museums that lost donations under the old law, according to statistics gathered by the American Association of Museums.
Last October, when the association made its survey, the Columbia Museum of Art and Gibbes Planetarium in Columbia, S.C., reported that it had received no gifts since the 18-month window closed on July 1, 1992. The Peabody Museum in Salem, Mass., said gift-giving was "absolutely dry."
In Rochester, the Memorial Art Gallery said that it had received just 6 gifts in 1990, when the alternative minimum tax was in effect, but 114 gifts during the window. In the three months after the window closed, it received two gifts.
The Seattle Art Museum reported it had received 300 objects a month in May and June 1992. With the window closed, it received 7 last August.
 
The Window Effect
 Earl A. Powell 3d, the director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, was head of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art when the window closed in 1992.
"It had a phenomenal effect on drying up contributions," Mr. Powell said. "We hope things will improve now. We expect renewed interest in contributions, but it's a little early to tell."
In 1986, when donors could give tax-deductible donations to museums without being put in the alternative minimum tax category, the National Gallery received 1,890 gifts and bequests. When the law changed the next year, the number of gifts fell to 247. During the window, the number jumped to 2,444.
At the Met, Mr. Hawkins said, results were similar. The number of donors fell from 356 in 1986 to 248 in 1987 and even more sharply in the following years, then rose to 312 during the window. Stated in dollars, the impact was even greater. The 1990 gifts were valued at $9,049,980; in 1991 they jumped to $42,810,165.
Mr. Powell praised Senator Moynihan for getting the law changed, saying, "I think it's a terrific thing that it's been restored," although he added that he did not expect an immediate surge in gifts because of the poor economy.
 
Broadening the Breaks
 The fact that the chairman of the tax-writing Finance Committee was a New Yorker was important, Mr. Hawkins said. He described a session held to negotiate differences between the House and the Senate versions of the budget bill. He said Senator Moynihan had insisted on restoring the tax break for donors and quoted him as saying, "One of the things I'm not going to negotiate is full restoration of the tax deduction."
Senator Moynihan's counterpart in the House of Representatives, Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, had opposed the tax break in the past. But an aide said Mr. Rostenkowski had eased his opposition after hearing from art institutions in his hometown, Chicago.
Mr. Rostenkowski agreed to the full restoration of the tax deduction, as long as the measure was broadened to permit, for example, gifts of stocks to colleges and universities so that it was not "biased toward the art world." That was done, and the measure was approved.
One of those who lobbied Mr. Rostenkowski was Larry TerMolen, the executive vice president for development and public affairs at the Art Institute of Chicago, which had suffered under the old law.
"In December 1991 alone," he said, referring to a time when gifts to museums were fully deductible, "we received a record 1,895 gifts. In December 1992, we got five gifts. We attribute it totally to the change in the tax law.
"We contacted Chairman Rostenkowski's office; he was the key person for us. We're delighted with the change. Obviously, the public will benefit in the long term, and that's the important thing."
 
The Bottom Line
 Ed Able, executive director of the American Association of Museums, said, "I don't think there's anyone we didn't lobby." He added that he thought the impact on the Treasury would not be great.
According to a Congressional Budget Office study, he said, the change will cost the United States $400 million over five years, a figure that includes deductions for gifts of stocks to colleges and land to nature conservancies, as well as works given to arts institutions.
Senator Moynihan said allowing tax deductions for charitable gifts without imposing penalties was essential in preserving the nation's diverse cultural heritage. As an example, he pointed to the gift to the University of Notre Dame of a pair of elevator doors designed by Louis Sullivan for one of his Chicago skyscrapers.
"This is a heritage we could lose," Senator Moynihan said. "We better wake up."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Diminishing Returns in Misery Race

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
High among the reasons given by Palestinian deportees for accepting Israel's offer to let about half of them back into the occupied West Bank and Gaza next month was the deportees' lack not of food or shelter but of coverage by the news media, meaning television.
The hundreds of men stranded in rough country between Israeli and Lebanese army checkpoints aroused initial sympathy from television news, but viewers have not seen much of them in recent months. A Palestinian spokesman attributed the diminished attention to a purposeful blackout by the United States, but it probably has more to do with the competition for the camera's interest in a time of upheaval around the globe and hard going at home, and possibly with a developing viewer resistance to powerful images on the screen. 
 Television dotes on victims, but as things go these days, the Palestinians just could not compete with starving Somalis or battered Bosnians or Americans flooded out by the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers.
For one thing, despite the international displeasure with Israel's resort to expulsion, which television reporters reflected, these men could not simply be classified as innocent victims. Israel said they were supporters of Hamas, the Islamic Resistance Movement, known for attacks on Israeli soldiers and settlements. Palestinians are not among America's most favored refugee groups to begin with, and the pictures of Lebanese being driven from their homes by the recent Israeli shelling were juxtaposed with Israelis being driven to shelters by Palestinian missiles.
Although there were reports of illness among the deportees, they had tents, food and water, along with cellular phones, fax machines and, of course, television sets to keep in touch. No relief agencies solicited contributions. Since they were all male adults, photographers were denied the hungry babies and wounded boys and girls and suffering mothers who figure so strongly in coverage from other troubled lands.
But something else may be at work. Television news is by nature a sort of show, and producers have been known to play on emotions. But as dramatists know, audiences can take only so much of misery, however dramatic.
Pictures of the atrocities in Bosnia have been shown for months now on all the networks without a noticeable rise in the nation's demand for intervention. With the recession clinging like a chronic ailment, many Americans may simply be too caught up in troubles of their own to spare much more than passing sympathy for others, particularly when America's leaders have not been encouraging cries for action.
And perhaps too, viewers may be becoming a touch skeptical of the familiar images. The proclaimed military victories from Panama to the Persian Gulf, orchestrated for television by the Pentagon, have left an unsatisfying aftertaste. The acclaimed humanitarian effort in Somalia has bogged down into a campaign against thugs, and Americans have been killed.
Can it be that television, which has so often drawn sympathy for far-away peoples from soft-hearted audiences, has run into a wall of self-concern? Viewers may be asking themselves: Why so much attention to an African ganglord when gun-happy youths are shooting up our own neighborhoods? How much is the Somali effort costing while taxes are rising and services are on hold? Why get involved in a messy tragedy in Bosnia that could cost American blood and treasure with no certain benefit to the United States?
Those, surely, are the sorts of questions that people in a democracy are supposed to ask. Granted, callousness to distant miseries may not be an admirable trait, but there is something to be said for refusing to let pictures on the tube drive policy. A tough mind has always gone well with a soft heart, and never more so than in the television age.

HEADLINE: FIELD TEST;
A 2-Pound Gym (Sweat Optional)

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
A HOME exercise "gym" these days can fit into an overnight case and have the versatility of a weight machine many times its size. The jury is still out on whether these systems, which use stretch cords for resistance, build strength to the same degree as free weights or weight machines. The home exercisers are portable, of course, and cost hundreds or even thousands of dollars less than machines, but do they do the job?
One company, Lifeline International of Madison, Wis., says its apparatus works as well as weights. It began producing its stretch-cord apparatus in 1977. Through the years, its product has been revamped into a sophisticated, durable exercise tool. 
 WHAT'S IN THE BAG? The Lifeline Gym comes with a tote bag and weighs two pounds. It includes a 27-inch lifting bar that separates into two halves for easier storage and handling, a webbed jogging belt, a webbed door attachment, a safety catch and a six-foot stretch cord with plastic stirrups for hands or feet. The stretch cord comes in 10 strength levels, R-1 through R-10, ranging from about 3 pounds to about 350 pounds of resistance. A chart helps the buyer determine the cord to pick, depending on physical condition.
WHAT'S OUT OF THE BAG? Setting up the Lifeline Gym can be tricky. The heart of the system is a small circular piece of webbing with a tab that fits into the crack between a door and its frame. It takes a bit of finagling to maneuver the hand-sized loop into place. Then you have to close the door on it quickly so it won't slip out of place. When it's in there securely, the webbing acts as an anchor for the stretch cord and lifting bar.
WHAT CAN YOU DO WITH IT? The maneuvers of body building -- lateral raises, shoulder presses, lunges, side kicks, hamstring extensions, pulldowns and curls -- are part of the fitness routine suggested in Lifeline's instruction manual. For example, for a lateral pulldown stretch, secure the tab near the top of the door frame. Then, with the door securely closed, grip the stirrups with palms down in front of the body; pull both stirrups down with a smooth, steady motion; then release slowly.
HOW DOES IT WORK? Bobby Hinds, a former boxing coach who developed the Lifeline Gym, contends that stretch cables allow for a wider range of motion that develops muscles more fully than other exercise gear. You can pull a cord up or down, in or out -- even around in circles -- without letting up on the resistance. The farther you stretch the cord, the harder it gets.
"Resistance is resistance," Mr. Hinds said. "It doesn't matter where it comes from. But with weights it is constant; with cables, it is progressive."
WHAT WORKS BETTER? It helps to have an exercise system that doesn't look formidable. The Lifeline Gym is so easy to use that you need only a door and 10 square feet of floor space.
Stretch cords allow the user to target small groups of muscles at a time and add tension slowly. Fred Zamberletti, a physical therapist for the Minnesota Vikings football team, said recently that he uses the Lifeline Gym to rehabilitate injured players. "They're good for the general population that wants to tone their muscles," Mr. Zamberletti said. "It provides resistance that is safe."
ANY DRAWBACKS? Dr. Neil Gordon, director of exercise physiology at the Cooper Institute for Aerobics Research in Dallas, has studied elderly people who use stretch bands for exercise (though not the Lifeline Gym). He said: "My impression is that generally rubberized bands are effective and useful and that there may be a role for them, but that generally they're unlikely to be as effective as weight-training equipment."
Mike Duchaj, an athletic trainer at Maine South High School in Park Ridge, Ill., uses the Lifeline Gym for rehabilitation, but switches to free weights and machines for general strength building. The free weights teach balance, which you can't get with a stretch cord, he said.
"I can do any exercise with the Lifeline that you can do with free weights or exercise machines," Mr. Duchaj said. "But there are certain benefits with each type. If it comes down to an economic decision, then it really isn't a choice. It would be the Lifeline."
WHAT'S THE PRICE? About $60. It's a good idea to buy an extra stretch cord (about $10) a notch lower in tension than the one the chart prescribed for you. That way, on a bad day you can still feel strong. Orders can be placed by calling (800) 553-6633.

HEADLINE: Yen's Rise Is Pressing Japan To Deregulate the Economy

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Japanese officials said today that they would prepare plans to deregulate Japan's economy so that the benefits of the stronger yen could be passed on to the nation's hard-pressed consumers and businesses in the form of lower prices.
The statements, lacking in detail, followed an emergency meeting of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and his economic ministers that was held this morning to discuss how to contend with the rising yen. 
 On the currency markets, there was little reaction to the news of the meeting. In late afternoon trading here, the dollar was trading at 102.00 yen, up from late Wednesday's quote of 101.47. In New York on Wednesday, the dollar rose to 101.63 yen, from 101.02 yen the day before.
Cabinet ministers did not give specifics of what steps would be taken, saying that more details would be hammered out soon. "By the end of September at the latest, we would like to draft a list of concrete targets" for deregulatory steps that would let Japanese consumers and businesses enjoy some benefits of a strong yen, Chief Cabinet Secretary Masayoshi Takemura said.
The ministers seemed very cautious about promising new stimulus measures like increased public works spending, cuts in income taxes or a cut in interest rates. Hirohisa Fujii, the Finance Minister, said such actions were not discussed.
On Wednesday, Yasushi Mieno, the governor of the Bank of Japan, said he had no plans to cut the official discount rate, which stands at a low of 2.5 percent.
The currency markets were relatively calm on Wednesday, as traders awaited word from the special cabinet meeting. The lack of specifics in today's announcement and the apparent reluctance of the Government to undertake a program could have disappointed the market and sent the dollar down below the level of 100 yen.
But the markets, at least initially, seemed willing to wait for more details, some of which may come as early as Monday, when Prime Minister Hosokawa gives his first significant policy speech.
"The meat seems to exist, and they are all giving the benefit of the doubt," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, senior economist for Morgan Stanley & Company in Tokyo, adding that the announcement was somewhat "disappointing." A trader for a Japanese bank, though, said many traders had not expected a detailed statement to emerge from this morning's meeting.
Many of the actions being contemplated by the Government would be welcome by the United States.
 
 
Impact on Trade Surplus
 The yen's appreciation was generated in part by comments earlier this year by President Clinton and Administration officials that a rising yen might help reduce the trade deficit that the United States has with Japan, remarks that were interpreted by the currency market as a wish for a stronger yen. The trade picture will be sketched out in greater detail in Washington today, when the Commerce Department reports on the merchandise trade deficit for June.
In the long run, a rising yen and a falling dollar will make Japanese exports more expensive and therefore less competitive abroad, while American exports will become cheaper and presumably sell better in Japan.
But the United States may see the benefits much more quickly. While the Administration has not commented on the yen recently, analysts say it is happy to sit back and watch as a clamor arises in Japan for the Government to stimulate the economy, liberalize imports and take other steps to reduce its trade surplus -- steps that the United States has been calling on Japan to do.
One business leader here even called for a concerted effort by Japan to cut exports to the United States.
"This rise of the yen is mainly caused by Japan's large trade surplus with the United States," Hiroshi Saito, the chairman of Nippon Steel and head of the Japan Iron and Steel Federation, said in a statement on Tuesday. "To remedy this situation quickly, we cannot avoid reducing exports to the United States."
A rate of 100 yen to the dollar would result in big losses or sharply reduced profits for many large companies, especially the big exporters of automobiles and electronics. A stronger yen could also prolong Japan's recession and lead to greater unemployment as manufacturers shift production to Southeast Asia and other regions with lower labor costs.
 The Cabinet ministers today seemed to agree that the economy was in serious condition, reversing a stance taken by some Government officials a few months earlier that a recovery was on the way.
The newly elected Government has at least one opportunity, economists say, for counteracting the effects of a strong yen without creating a budget deficit: lower prices for imported products. Because of restrictions on imports like rice, apples and some industrial goods, however, the benefits of a stronger yen have not always been seen in lower prices.

Japan Stocks Drop
 TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- After a morning of flat trading, stocks slid back today, as some traders expressed disappointment that the Government failed to make strong deregulatory recommendations. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 85.71 points, or 0.41 percent, at 20,687.47. On Wednesday, the Nikkei declined 68.80 points.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Yields Continue Their Slide

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
With long-term yields plunging to another record low yesterday, John R. Williams, the managing director of global market economics at the Bankers Trust Company, thinks defense when he looks at the bond market rally.
This does not mean that he is being defensive because he expects the rally to end soon. Rather, defense means military budgets and the cuts in them that have been made here and abroad. For Mr. Williams, those cuts are a major reason the economy has slowed here and will continue to be sluggish. That, he said, is the main reason the 30-year bond yield has plunged to new lows. 
 As the market increasingly adopts this psychology of sluggish growth, along with the belief that inflation will remain low, the yield on the 30-year bond could fall further.
 
 
Falling to 6% by Year-End?
 Mr. Williams, who had thought for some time that 6.30 percent was achievable this year, is now considering that the yield may drop to 6 percent by the end of the year and below that in 1994.
In trading yesterday, the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.26 percent, its lowest point since the Treasury began to issue 30-year bonds on a regular basis 16 years ago, from 6.31 percent Tuesday. Its price jumped 22/32 of a point.
Shorter-term Treasury issues, from two years to seven years, also rallied a bit, but their yields only fell to levels reached on Monday before rebounding on Tuesday.
Still, the price of the 10-year note managed to rise just enough -- 9/32 of a point -- to push the yield down to 5.67 percent, its lowest this year and the lowest since the spring of 1971. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
The yield curve -- the differential in yields between shorter and longer term maturities -- narrowed or flattened and continues to be one of the major bets that traders are making. They buy long-term debt, like the 30-year bond, and sell short-term debt, like the two-year note. This bet is another factor contributing to the rally in 30-year bonds. Yesterday, the spread between the yields on the two-year note and the 30-year bond narrowed to 2.31 percentage points. It was 3.12 percentage points on May 3.
Treasury prices rose yesterday on strong buying from foreign investors, traders said, and reports that the Federal Reserve was buying two- , three- and five-year notes as part of its monetary policy operations.
When economic historians look back, Mr. Williams said, they will see that "the single big story is the defense cutbacks."
"The cold war ended," he said. "Cutbacks globally followed and the massive layoffs commensurate with that kept the economy in check for years."
Far from thinking that the economy will pick up in the second half of the year, Mr. Williams said, "it is at least as great a threat that we dip into lower growth rates."
Referring again to military cutbacks, he added, "There is no way the economy is going to get up and out of here in that context."
He suggested that the 1.6 percent growth rate in the second quarter, after adjustment for inflation, could be revised lower if it turns out that June exports are less than expected. The Government is to report the June trade figures today. The consensus forecast for the first revision in the gross domestic product report for the second quarter is an increase to 2.2 percent growth, according to Bloomberg Business News. The revised report is due Aug. 31.
 
Relying on Low Inflation
 Mr. Williams said an important key to further declines in the 30-year bond's yield would be whether investors gained confidence in inflation holding at 3 percent or less. If that is the case, he said, it would be logical to assume a 6 percent rate or less on the long bond because the rule of thumb now is that real interest rates -- interest rates after adjustment for inflation -- are about 3 percent.
But while inflation has been low for several years, convincing investors that it will remain so is difficult. As the two inflation scares earlier this year proved, it is very easy to get the bond market worried about rising prices. A break from the very low inflation reports of the last two months and the slow growth of the first half of the year might shake the market again.
Though Mr. Williams thinks the yield on the bond is moving lower, he predicts that the yield on other maturities, especially those from two years to five years, will remain about where they are now.
The reason is that the Fed is not now expected either to lower interest rates because the economy is weak or to raise interest rates because prices are rising. "With a steady Fed, the short end cannot do a whole lot better," he said.

HEADLINE: Perot Book on Trade Pact

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Ross Perot, the former Presidential candidate and one of the most vocal critics of the North American Free Trade Agreement, said today that he would soon release a book saying why he believes that the accord must be defeated.
"Any member of Congress who reads this book cannot, in good conscience, possibly vote for Nafta," the Texas businessman said in a statement. Pat Choate, an economist known for his criticism of foreign lobbyists' influence here, is the co-author. 
 The book, "Save Your Job, Save Our Country: Why NAFTA Must Be Stopped -- Now," is scheduled for release by Labor Day, just as lawmakers are due back from their summer break to begin work on the controversial free-trade pact.
The new book marks a step-up in Mr. Perot's longstanding campaign to defeat Nafta, which would join the economies of the United States, Mexico and Canada into the world's biggest free-trade zone in January.
President Clinton has vowed a strong campaign this autumn on behalf of Nafta, and on Tuesday Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen confirmed reports that William Daley, a Chicago lawyer and bank president who ran the Clinton Presidential campaign in Illinois, will steer the lobbying effort.
Administration officials have said that Clinton could name Mr. Daley, the brother of Chicago's Mayor Richard Daley, as Nafta "czar" as soon as Thursday, charging him with overcoming fears that Nafta will lead to big job losses and increased pollution.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Pound And Mark; Gold Prices Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against the British pound and the German mark yesterday as currency traders saw new signs that interest rates in Britain and Germany would not be heading lower soon.
Meanwhile, gold prices rose in quiet trading. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery gained $2.70 an ounce, ending at $374.30. December gold, the most actively traded futures contract, rose $2.60 an ounce, to $377.50. 
 The dollar fell as low as 1.6765 marks, before settling in New York at 1.6805 marks, down from 1.6935 marks on Tuesday.
 The dollar's slide against the mark followed a decision by the Bundesbank to leave a key money market rate unchanged at 6.8 percent. Traders interpreted the decision as a sign that the German central bank was not preparing to cut its discount rate of 6.75 percent in the near future.
In addition, a member of the Bundesbank's council, Wilhelm Gaddum, said western Germany's inflation rate of 4.2 percent was "definitely too high." Bundesbank officials have said they will not cut rates until inflation is under control.
Mr. Gaddum also repeated the Bundesbank's pledge to keep the mark stable.
"The Bundesbank dashed any hope that German rates will come down soon," said Angelo Evangelista, corporate foreign exchange adviser at the Bank of Boston.
The pound also rallied on the prospect that rates would remain stable. The pound took off against the dollar and the mark after the Chief Secretary to the British Treasury, Michael Portillo, said that the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, was satisfied with interest rates at current levels.
The pound jumped to $1.5170 in New York late yesterday, from $1.4888 on Tuesday. Last week, the pound slumped to its lowest level since March as investors bet the Bank of England would cut rates to keep the country's economic recovery on track.
The dollar was weak against other European currencies as well. It tumbled to 5.9035 French francs from 5.9570 francs and weakened to 1.4845 Swiss francs from 1.5035 francs.
Stock market investors, however, apparently believe that European interest rates will come down. Stock indexes in Britain and Germany set record highs yesterday, and stocks also rose in France and other major markets. Lower interest rates would help spur Europe's recovery from a long economic recession.
Elsewhere, the dollar rose to its highest level in almost six years against the Canadian dollar. It finished at $1.3223 Canadian, up from $1.3158 Canadian on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Dow Above 3,600 in Wide Rally for Stocks

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Falling interest rates, rallying stock markets in Europe and strengthening investor interest in drug and consumer-product issues combined to lift American stock indexes to record highs yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 3,600-point level for the first time, gaining 17.88 points, to 3,604.86. 
 Volume was heavy, with 312.9 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, up from 261.3 million on Tuesday. Gaining issues outpaced losing stocks, 1,263 to 772.
 
Follows Europe's Advance
 Other market indexes that hit new highs were the New York Stock Exchange composite, up 1.60 points, to 252.87; the Nasdaq composite of over-the-counter issues, up 3.82, to 734.83, and the American Stock Exchange composite, up 3.97, to 446.63.
Analysts said stocks were helped by strength in the European markets, where investors who expect lower interest rates pushed stock indexes in Britain and Germany to all-time highs. They also pointed to the impact of price gains in the market for United States Treasury securities, in which the yield on the 30-year bond fell to an all-time low of 6.26 percent, and renewed investor interest in pharmaceuticals and consumer-products issues, which continued a rally begun on Tuesday.
"Many of the nondurable-goods companies, which have been beaten up over the last 18 months -- drugs, package foods and tobaccos -- have cheapened," said William E. Dodge, chief investment strategist for Dean Witter Reynolds. "As a result, you can expect that short-term rallies will also move the market higher."
He added that the Dow's climb past 3,600 involved a combination of very supportive interest rates and higher corporate profits.
 
Boon for Drug Makers
 "The profit improvement has been driven by higher levels of productivity and restructuring," Mr. Dodge said, "and now major layoffs in the industrial and manufacturing sector should be behind us. We are in a multiyear business recovery that still has a long way to go."
Traders said the fact that President Clinton did not mention cutting drug prices in his speech outlining his health care plan on Monday helped spur drug stocks on Tuesday and yesterday.
Earlier expectations that the Administration would impose price controls on drugs had crushed the health-care sector, which has created a buying opportunity, the traders said.
Merck was among the most active issues on the New York Stock Exchange, rising 1 5/8, to 32 1/2. Glaxo was up 1 1/8, to 17 7/8; Bristol-Myers Squibb jumped 1 7/8, to 56 1/2; Johnson & Johnson 1 1/2, to 40; Pfizer 2 3/4, to 63 1/4; SmithKline 1 7/8, to 35 1/4, and Eli Lilly, 2 1/4, to 47 7/8.
In other trading, U.S. Filter, which was rated "attractive" by the Paine Webber analyst David Manlowe in his initial coverage of the company, rose 2 3/8, to 21 7/8.
Applied Materials gained 3 3/8 in active trading, to 73 7/8. The semiconductor company said its third-quarter earnings were 68 cents a share, more than twice those of the similar period a year ago.
 
Job Cuts Spur Gains
 Air Products and Chemicals' plans for a 10 percent reduction in its work force as part of a restructuring to bolster profits lifted its shares 2 3/8, to 44 3/4. In similar move, Eastman Kodak announced intentions to reduce its work force by 10,000 by the end of 1995. The stock rose as much as 5/8, before closing at 60 3/8, up 1/8.
General Nutrition was up 1 3/8, to 43 3/8, after the vitamin and food supplements retailer's board authorized a 2-for-1 split.
Silicon Valley Group declined 1 3/4, to 11 1/8, after the semiconductor company lost a bid for a Motorola contract worth as much as $25 million.
Mr. Coffee rose 1, to 8 3/4, after it was added to Oppenheimer's recommended list.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Justice Department is Trying to Spread the Antitrust Blanket.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
CONSPIRACIES to restrain trade are illegal. So when, say, a tractor maker is caught leaning on retailers to keep the price of a new model above $30,000 or frowning on one dealer who tries to take away business from another, it must be in trouble. Right?
Not necessarily. Economists have never worked up much enthusiasm for untangling "vertical" restraints between producers and distributors, as opposed to "horizontal" restraints among sellers in the same market. And in the Reagan and Bush years, that ambivalence became official policy. 
 But now Anne Bingaman, the new Assistant Attorney General for antitrust, has served notice that activism is back. In a speech last week to the American Bar Association, she rescinded the Justice Department's 1985 live-and-let-live guidelines on vertical restraints, burying a policy that had infuriated Congressional liberals. The big question -- one likely to keep antitrust lawyers rolling in BMW's for years to come -- is how much bite lies behind Ms. Bingaman's bark.
The century-old antitrust laws are remarkably vague (or, if you prefer, admirably flexible) about what constitutes restraint of trade. Almost everyone agrees that when sellers of competing products gang up on buyers, the result is higher prices and slower innovation. But there is no equivalent received wisdom about restraints along the vertical chain running from producer to consumer.
Robert H. Bork, Solicitor General in the Nixon Administration, argues that it is absurd to make contractual constraints on retailers illegal since it is perfectly legal for a manufacturer to accomplish the same ends by distributing its own products. Why, for example, should it be a crime for Compaq Computer to insist that independent dealers sell a laptop for at least $3,000 when Compaq can demand $3,000 on direct mail-order sales?
Charles Rule, Ms. Bingaman's counterpart in the second Reagan Administration, does not go quite this far but does believe that vertical restraints deserve every benefit of a legal doubt. Free markets are not perfect, he acknowledges. But to second-guess marketing arrangements where there is no apparent conflict between producers and consumers is to imply that government knows better than business.
Manufacturers, he argues, have no interest in enriching dealers at the expense of consumers. If they demand minimum retail prices, they are probably trying to weed out "free riders" -- discounters who leave the costly tasks of demonstrating and servicing products to high-price dealers.
The Supreme Court, notes Lawrence White of New York University's Stern School of Business, has ruled that overt resale price maintenance for any reason violates the Sherman Antitrust Act. But the Justice Department may still decide which vertical price-fixing arrangements to challenge, and there is no comparably clear legal doctrine about which nonprice arrangements are illegal. Accordingly, the Reagan and Bush Administrations left all vertical restraint cases to the Federal Trade Commission and the states.
But conservatives may not have the last intellectual word on the subject. Until the 1980's, points out Robert Pitofsky, a former commissioner of the F.T.C. who now teaches law at Georgetown University, it was generally assumed that vertical restraints were forced on manufacturers by dealers -- not the other way around.
Department stores selling a heavily advertised brand of cosmetics might, for example, insist that interlopers be prevented from selling at a discount. Thus resale price maintenance and other vertical restraints, Mr. Pitofsky suggests, are often the back door to old-fashioned horizontal price-fixing by distributors.
A more radical view (if not policy prescription) comes from F. M. Scherer at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. America's product distribution system is the wonder of the world, he points out -- a vivid contrast to the inefficient system in Japan. If vertical restraints are benign, he asks, why does the most efficient system have so few of them and the least efficient so many?
The fact that Ms. Bingaman, formerly an antitrust lawyer in private practice, looks less kindly on vertical restraints than her recent predecessors does not guarantee that big policy changes are in the works. For one thing, her senior advisers -- notably Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution -- come from an academic tradition that is skeptical about the benefits of expanding the reach of antitrust law. For another, the courts seem inclined to view vertical arrangements with sympathy. Companies that are well counseled, notes Mr. Rule, the former Reagan antitrust enforcer, can now do just about anything they want short of dictating minimum prices.
Indeed, some observers are wondering if Ms. Bingaman's assault on vertical restraints is more political than ideological. She faces a variety of controversial issues -- not least the new alliances in the computer and telecommunications industries. And when she is mustering support for what will inevitably be controversial positions, it will not hurt to have proved her good will to liberals.

HEADLINE: Father of 12 Shot to Death Near Home In Brooklyn

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
A father of 12 who was returning home from work as a dishwasher at an expensive French restaurant was shot and killed in a robbery yesterday, less than a block from his front door in Brownsville, Brooklyn, the police said.
Watching from a window of the first-floor apartment for his father's nightly return minutes after midnight, one of the man's eight sons saw his father clutching his chest, then collapse on the sidewalk. 
 It was a simple crime, nothing out of the ordinary in New York City. But now the family of a onetime farmer from the Dominican Republic, who came to the United States nine years ago in search of the proverbial better life, is left bereft and wondering how it will support itself.
The father, Jose Duran, 49, of 308 Sutter Avenue in the Brownsville Houses, had worked six days a week, every week, for eight years, never taking a vacation, to support his family.
 
'Such a Good Person'
 "It's a nightmare," Mr. Duran's eldest child, Josephine, 22, said yesterday while sitting on the arm of a chair in her living room, rocking her 16-month-old brother, Elvin, in her arms.
"Why him? He was such a good person," Miss Duran said. "He didn't do anything bad to anybody."
"Dios mio," Miss Duran said -- "My God," in Spanish.
A police spokesman, Detective Joseph McConville, said Mr. Duran was shot to death on the southeast corner of Sutter Avenue and Osborn Street. The shooting occurred as he was returning home from work at Le Perigord, a restaurant on Manhattan's East Side.
"It appears to be a robbery; he had no wallet on him," Detective McConville said. Police responded to an anonymous call over 911 and, after finding Mr. Duran on the street, took him to Brookdale Hospital, where he was pronounced dead.
Detective Steven Feely of the 73d Precinct said it appeared that a man "just walked up behind him and reached into his back pocket to take out his wallet."
"It looks like the victim turned around and the perpetrator just shot him in the chest -- one shot from a .25 automatic," Detective Feely said. The killer apparently got little. Mr. Duran had $80 in his pocket when the police found him.
"It's so sad," said Miss Duran. "We just moved here from Williamsburg. We didn't know how bad it was. We came in winter to check. Nobody was on the street. It was so nice. But in summer, a lot of crime."
Since realizing how much crime plagues the neighborhood, Miss Duran said, "my mother looks out the window when she knows he is coming; most of the kids look, too."
Mr. Duran's son, Narcisso, was at the window last night. "I saw when he fell down," Narcisso said. "He was walking like this," the boy added, clutching his hands to his chest. "Then he fell down." The boy did not see the gunman.
Mr. Duran came to the United States in 1984, followed five years later by his wife, Enedina, 43. "Now I don't know why we came," Miss Duran said. "The reason was economic, looking for a better life."
Miss Duran, a student at La Guardia Community College, where she is studying microcomputer systems, said several of her brothers work part-time to help support the family. Now, she said, "I think I'm going to have to leave school and start working."
 
Prayer in Spanish
 "Dios mio!" Miss Duran said again, tears welling in her eyes.
At that moment, Mr. Duran's cousin, Julia Collado, placed her hands on the young woman's head and prayed in Spanish, "God, give this family the strength to accept this tragedy."
Regaining her composure, Miss Duran said, "We used to live in a two-bedroom apartment and we went crazy looking for a bigger apartment." The new apartment has five bedrooms and two baths.
Marie Therese Briguet, owner of the Le Perigord, said: "He was the best employee; always on time. We didn't have to go behind him to say do this, do that. Everything was perfect."
Mrs. Briquet said Mr. Duran "was a very good father. You cannot find a better, better person than Jose. It should not happen to him."
Tuesday was Mr. Duran's last night of work before his first vacation in eight years.
"I saved a little money so that I could take him and some of the kids to the zoo, the beach, and the aquarium," his daughter said. "He never went anywhere, except to work and to church."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Several big companies announced an alliance to stimulate the market for recycled paper. Prudential Insurance, Johnson & Johnson, Time Warner, McDonald's, Nationsbank and others will work with the Environmental Defense Fund to study ways to use more recycled paper in their products and printed materials to help reduce the burden on solid-waste landfills. [Page A1.]
Lockheed's Information Management unit received special favors from the Dinkins administration when it sought a $150 million city contract to take over many operations of the Parking Violations Bureau, according to investigators. [A1.] 
 Kodak will eliminate 10,000 jobs by the end of 1995. But the plan was part of an earlier restructuring by Kay R. Whitmore, who was ousted as chief executive earlier in the month, and may be a precursor to more drastic cuts to come. [D1.]
Northwest Airlines' co-chairmen, Alfred A. Checchi and Gary L. Wilson, defended their stewardship in the face of criticism for having saddled the airline with huge debt payments that have since been reworked by creditors to avert a bankruptcy. [D1.]
The choice of Boeing as the prime space station contractor will bring more prestige than jobs and revenues. The impact of the move by NASA on McDonnell Douglas, Rockwell and Grumman, which will play lesser roles, is uncertain. [D4.]
Capital Cities/ABC and Hearst reached an agreement with Time Warner to keep their broadcast stations on Time Warner's cable systems and help them start an sports channel. [D18.]
Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield named a Cigna managed-care executive, G. Robert O'Brien, as its chief executive, underscoring its intention to become a leader in managed care. [B8.]
Ipalco again increased its offer for PSI Resources, intensifying its bidding war with Cincinnati Gas and Electric. [D4.]
Fieldcrest Cannon will issue $70 million in preferred stock and increase borrowing to finance its purchase of Amoskeag. [D4.]
 
Markets
European stock markets soared to new highs with investors anticipating that interest rates are about to begin a steady decline, which would help speed economic recovery. [D1.]
The Dow industrials closed above the 3,600-point level for the first time, gaining 17.88 points, to 3,604.86, helped by falling interest rates, rallies in Europe and drug and consumer issues [D6.]
Interest rates fell, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond sinking to 6.26 percent, its lowest point in 16 years. [D14.]
The dollar tumbled against the pound and mark but gained against the yen. Gold rose in quiet trading. [D17.]
Crude oil prices fell in response to a report that showed a smaller-than-expected drop in gasoline supplies. [D17.]
 
International
Third world countries are buying American goods at a rapid pace, giving the U.S. economy an unexpected lift. Such imports are up almost one-third over the past two years, as industrialization spreads in Asia and Latin America. [A1.]
The strengthening yen is putting pressure on the Japanese Government to stimulate its economy and liberalize imports so some the benefits can be passed on to the nation's hard-pressed consumers and businesses. [D1.]

The Justice Department says it will widen antitrust law enforcement, but some are wondering how much bite lies behind that bark. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Vote Extends Penny Increase in Suffolk County Sales Tax

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 18

 BODY:
By a one-vote margin, the Suffolk County Legislature has extended a penny increase in the county sales tax for two years.
The extra penny tax, which was to have expired in December, assures the county an estimated $248 million in extra sales-tax revenue during the two years and averts a budget crisis. The total sales tax in Suffolk is 8.5 percent. 
 Ten of the 18 legislators voted for the extension, which was authorized by the State Legislature in July. The approval came after the holder of the decisive 10th vote, Joseph Rizzo, a Republican from Islip Terrace, compelled county lawyers to produce a completed agreement under which the county would abandon efforts to buy Robins Island, which is said to be the largest undeveloped island on the East Coast.
Mr. Rizzo, who opposes the island purchase and who had been critical of delays in finishing the proposed agreement, then voted for the sales-tax extension.
 
Conservation of Island
 The agreement on Robins Island, which must undergo an environmental review and be acted on by the county legislature, would allow a California developer, the Robis Corporation, to buy the island from its German owners for $12 million. The new owners would be allowed to build a maximum of 22 houses on one-and-a half acre lots on 33 acres of the island. More than 90 percent of the land would be placed under a conservation easement.
"I don't care how the vote goes, I wanted to see the agreement on paper," Mr. Rizzo said. "Does the county want 92.5 percent of the island for free, or do they want to pay $20 million for the whole thing?" He said the $20 million figure included interest on the $9.2 million the county agreed to pay for the island in 1989.
The vote extending the sales tax spared the Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, the difficulty of preparing a 1994 county budget without the one percent in sales-tax revenues. He must submit the proposed budget to the legislators next month.
The 8.5 percent county sales tax, of which the county share is 4.25 percent, is equaled in New York only by Nassau County and stands among the highest rates in the nation. The Suffolk officials sought approval for the extra percent during a period of financial crisis that began three years ago, but now appears to have abated.
Alice A. Amrhein, deputy Suffolk County executive for finance, said county property taxes would have doubled had the extension been denied. "Either we would have to double the taxes or stop county government," she said. The estimated $124 million in revenue from the 1 percent, she said, barely kept pace with the $126 million the county pays for its local share of Medicaid expenses.
The vote on the sales-tax extension followed party lines, with all but one member of the Republican and Conservative majority voting in favor. Democratic legislators voted no, saying that Mr. Gaffney failed to make cuts in county spending that would have negated the need for much or all of the 1 percent in revenues.
Mr. Rizzo said he acted to "hold Robins Island hostage" in part because Mr. Gaffney had never made clear whether he favored abandoning county purchase of the island, and appeared to be vacillating.
Mr. Gaffney left yesterday for a trip to Israel paid for by the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York, his aides said. Ms. Amrhein said Mr. Gaffney would sign the Robins Island settlement if it is approved by the Legislature.
William J. Burke, the chief deputy county attorney, said today that there was "no linkage" between completion of the agreement and Mr. Rizzo's vote on the sales-tax extension. He said the agreement had been under discussion among the parties for several months. If approved, it would end a welter of litigation that has grown up around the island.
Paul Sabatino, counsel to the county legislature, said he expected a vote on the pact within three months. The proposed housing project would need the approval of the Town of Southold, where the island is located. Town officials said they were not bound by a county settlement.
Support for the county purchase has been strong, and proponents said they were ready to fight a settlement that would allow houses to be built.

HEADLINE: Housing Progress Demanded;
Child of the Public Projects, She Now Runs Them

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
One of the first things that Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero did after she was pressed into service as head of the nation's largest public housing agency last year was to take a series of unannounced trips around her realm. What she found, she says, was a far cry from the public housing of her childhood.
Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero, who in the 1960's lived with her family in the Twin Parks West project in the Bronx, saw a succession of crumbling walls, broken appliances, leaking pipes, stairwells without lights and tenants who complained that crime had made them prisoners of those same dreary homes. Those sights, she says now, defined her sense of what she had to do. 
 "If you put New York public housing up against any large housing agency in the country, we come up on top," she said in a recent interview. "But that is not saying much. I don't want to settle for that. I want to use as the standard public housing that I grew up with. I want public housing to be a place where people can have safe, comfortable housing again."
Nearly 18 months after she moved into the chairwoman's office at 250 Broadway, across the street from City Hall, Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero has taken strong steps to assert control over the troubled agency that is landlord to 1 in 12 New Yorkers.
 
Standing Up to City Hall and Management
 Early on, she stood toe to toe with City Hall, insisting that fewer homeless families be sent to public housing and getting the city to pay for support services for the homeless families it did take in. She has overhauled the authority's top management, introduced a strict method to screen out potentially disruptive tenants and begun a $139 million plan to reduce crime throughout the system.
But while her policies have won praise from allies in city government, colleagues and some public housing residents, they raise a series of questions whose answers will go a long way toward determining whether she can refurbish the upwardly mobile dream of the social architects who created public housing for the city's working classes 60 years ago:
Will she be able to win the support of longtime employees still bristling over her managerial housecleaning? Does the security plan have the money or the staff to constitute a truly hard line against crime? And how much can a municipal agency accomplish in the face of the social contractions that have undermined the quality of life in the projects in the last 10 to 15 years: homelessness, increased drug use, recession and cuts in Federal spending?
"I cannot undo in a few years what has happened in the past decade," she responded. "But I know public housing in this city can be better than it is now."
 
Mayor Is Ally and and Father Figure
 Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero did not seek the job she now has. Laura D. Blackburne was forced to step down as chairwoman of the Housing Authority in February 1992 when questions were raised about her spending of Housing Authority money on office furnishings and trips.
When the Mayor called, Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero had been seeking to move from City Hall, where she was Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, to a less demanding city job to spend more time with her two sons.
"City Hall is a 24-hour-a-day, seven-days-a-week responsibility," she said. "After more than a year and a half as Deputy Mayor I was looking to move on. But my husband helped convince me that if the Mayor needed me, I could not turn him down."
A close ally and personal friend of the Mayor, she speaks of him as a father figure who has encouraged her and trusted her abilities. From 1986 until 1988, Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero served as Mr. Dinkins's Deputy Manhattan Borough President.
Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero was born in the Bronx in 1953 to parents from Puerto Rico. Her father worked mostly as a dishwasher and building superintendent and her mother as a public school assistant. After graduating from law school, Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero worked with legal services and community groups in Brooklyn and in the Bronx in housing development.
 
Grit Masked by Warmth
 Friends, colleagues and staff members say her warmth and her show of respect for everyone she meets mask her grit and determination. She has been underestimated, they say, by those who take her form of political savvy, which leans toward patient consensus-building, as a sign of malleability.
She is credited, for example, with helping to revive stalled budget discussions in 1991 when strained relations between the Mayor and the City Council put the city on the brink of financial crisis.
Scott Rosenberg, director of litigation for the Legal Aid Society, gave her high marks for the quick settling of the public housing racial steering suit that she inherited.
He also said that since Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero took over, the relationship improved between lawyers in his office, who often represent public housing tenants in their battles against the Housing Authority, and the legal department in the agency.
 
Style Praised by Opponents
 Even those who oppose her tactics cannot resist couching criticism in words of praise for her personal style.
After criticizing some of Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero's new policies, Carl Haynes, who replaced Barry Feinstein in April as president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the union for many Housing Authority employees, added, "I must say about her, that a nicer person you'll never meet."
Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero says with some pride: "I've also been called a steamroller. I know I have critics, but I don't believe that I have any enemies."
Her changes will require, in part, the support of the 16,000 public housing employees. Housing Authority workers, whose average tenure is 18 years, have seen three leaders since 1986.
 
Unpopular Housecleaning
 Some say she is being hobbled by residual resentment among Housing Authority staff members over her housecleaning in her first weeks on the job. She canceled credit cards, froze hirings and promotions and dismissed or reassigned 43 of the top 55 managers.
Mr. Haynes of the teamsters' union complains of paralysis out in the field. His members resent in particular, he said, her choosing her top managers from outside the Housing Authority.
"Sally has this idea that she has to do a national hunt for top management," he said. "She is doing this at a place where people are used to seeing promotions from within."
Mr. Haynes said that to her credit, Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero had added 181 new maintenance workers. His members, Mr. Haynes said, also support her tenant-screening plan.
When asked about low morale, Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero said she believed she was gaining the staff's loyalty.
"I understand how difficult it has been for many of the people who work here," said Mrs. Hernandez-Pinero, who still visits at least one housing complex a week. "After having the same top managers for 15 years they have seen a quick succession of new bosses, each with another way of doing things.
"But just because things were done a certain way does not mean that we should not be taking steps to make the Housing Authority better."
There is skepticism, too, about how much of an impression will be made by the $139 million safety improvement plan. It was unveiled by the Housing Authority in March in a splashy ceremony at the Red Hook Houses in Brooklyn, where an elementary school principal, Patrick Daly, was killed in December while looking for a student.
 
Security May Mark Tenure
 Known within the Housing Authority as the security pact, the plan is an array of measures intended to reduce crime in all housing projects. For better or for worse, it may stand as the signature of her tenure as head of the Housing Authority.
The plan includes increased housing police officers on the beat, more social services for tenants and such safety measures as new locks and intercom systems. Critics of the program say that it is a Band-Aid approach and does not go far enough.
Mr. Rosenberg of the Legal Aid Society said he did not hold much hope that the security pact would improve safety in public housing.
"This tinkering with regulation and policies," Mr. Rosenberg said, "will not have a meaningful impact on safety. You need significant funds for training of personnel who are respected in the community and you need a lot more police officers than the security pact provides. We are not getting that yet as far as I can see."

HEADLINE: Europe's Summer of the Bulls

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Europe is mired in recession. Its efforts to forge a single currency are in tatters. Unemployment is high and rising. Crucial industries like automobiles and steel are struggling.
But if this is supposed to be a summer of gloom for Europe, nobody bothered to tell the stock markets. Stock market bulls, in fact, are stampeding as if through the streets of Pamplona. 
 Investors here, as well as from the United States, Japan and other parts of the world, seem to be pouring money into stocks in the belief that interest rates across the Continent are about to begin a steady decline, a development that would help speed economic recovery and improve the prospects of European industry.
At the same time, the prospect of lower interest rates is leading many investors to pull their money out of savings accounts and bonds and to seek higher returns in stocks.
 
A Widespread Upswing
 After languishing much of the year, shares in London, Europe's financial capital, have been surging, hitting another all-time high today. In Germany, whose economic problems have been dragging down the rest of the Continent, shares on the Frankfurt stock exchange jumped sharply today to reach their highest level in three years.
Share prices were also up in Paris and in most other European financial centers. In Stockholm, shares rose a startling 2.86 percent to a record level. Market indexes were at or near annual or all-time highs in Denmark, Finland, Italy, Spain and the Netherlands, among other markets.
The surge in Europe also helped stocks in the United States today, where the Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 3,600 level for the first time. [Page D6.]
The theory behind the belief that European interest rates will fall is that the Continent's governments have more freedom now to cut rates since the effective collapse of the European monetary system at the end of July. Under the system, most large European nations were committed to maintaining stable currency values. Because Germany has been keeping its rates high to stave off inflation arising from its reunification, other nations were forced to keep their rates high or see their currencies plummet in value against the German mark.
But when a tidal wave of speculation swamped the French franc last month, it forced the European governments to let their currencies fluctuate more widely in value. With no need to maintain stable exchange rates, there is no longer a requirement for France and other European nations to match Germany's high rates.
"The belief is that we've now got the prospect of significantly lower rates to fuel recovery in Europe," said Mike Young, the director of European investment strategy at Merrill Lynch in London.
Freed from their exchange-rate shackles, European nations are now expected by economists to begin concentrating on bolstering their domestic economies and addressing the daunting problem of unemployment that is afflicting them all. The model is Britain, which was forced out of the Exchange Rate Mechanism in the currency crisis of last September, went on to slash its base lending rate to 6 percent from 10 percent, and is now enjoying the strongest economic growth in Europe along with falling unemployment.
Investors in the European stock markets, looking ahead to next year, now see the same rebound in store for other nations, including Germany and France.
In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares closed up 48.6 points, or 1.61 percent, at 3,073.60. In Frankfurt, the DAX index closed at 1,935.72, up 25.55 points, or 1.34 percent. In Paris, the CAC-40 index was up 24.46 points, to 2,160.75, a rise of 1.14 percent.
 
Some Notes of Skepticism
 But some analysts and economists said they had doubts as to whether the market would prove an accurate predictor of economic recovery, and some said investors might be overly sanguine about Europe's prospects for overcoming its economic woes.
"Certainly there's nothing to suggest that the economies are about to leap to life in the way the stock markets are indicating," said Warren Oliver, an economist at S. G. Warburg Securities in London.
"There is still a disparity, or a contrast if you like, between the strength of the recovery that the stock market as a leading indicator would suggest and any other sign of economic rebound on the Continent," Mr. Oliver said. "The best you can say about the Continent is that the recession may be bottoming out."
Germany, for example, is a long way from the recovery that its stock markets are anticipating. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the economic research group financed by the large industrial nations, said today that the outlook for Germany remained gloomy.
In contrast to the German Government, which last week predicted economic growth next year of 1.5 percent in the western part of the country after a 1.5 percent decline this year, the organization predicted growth of just 1 percent next year after a decline of 2.5 percent this year. Unemployment in western Germany, the organization said, would rise to 9.5 percent next year from 7.5 percent in July.
 
French Outlook Is Uncertain
 There is also some question about the assumption that rates will fall quickly and substantially, especially in France, which was seen as the primary beneficiary of the weakening of the monetary system's strictures. Although France has pushed down some of its short-term rates, it has not cut its benchmark lending rates, and a debate continues within the Government over whether to pursue growth and let the franc decline further in value.
Indeed, currency trading today indicated that dealers were not convinced that European rates would fall soon. The dollar's value fell against most European currencies after comments by British and German officials indicating they were content with the current level of interest rates.
None of the caveats, however, seem to have made much of an impression on the stock markets.
Sushil Wadhwani, a European equity strategist at Goldman Sachs International in London, said that if the recovery did not begin as investors hoped, then governments would continue to lower interest rates, as the United States did when confronted with a balky recovery over the last few years. "That would keep the markets happy," he said.
