HEADLINE: Third World Economic Gains Give a Lift to U.S. Exporters

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
The third world is giving the American economy an unexpected and much-needed lift, by increasing its imports of American goods by almost one-third over the last two years, with another large jump anticipated this year.
American sales to the nonindustrialized world rose to $167 billion last year, up 14 percent over the previous year and largely offsetting weak demand from Europe and Japan, both plagued by economic slumps. Exports to the third world jumped to more than 37 percent of total United States exports last year, from 32 percent in 1990.
 
 
Several Factors Cited
 Administration officials attribute the export boom to several factors. The rapidly industrializing countries of Asia are growing at a phenomenal pace, enabling them to purchase more American metal-cutting machines and Madonna records. Mexico, Argentina and other Latin American countries have recently lowered many tariffs and removed other trade barriers, while the region's growth is picking up after years of stagnation. 
 American exports have also been helped by the drop in the dollar's value since 1985 and the increased competitiveness of American companies.
The Clinton Administration has hailed the trend, using using it as ammunition to argue for trade liberalization -- in particular the North American Free Trade Agreement, which would tie Mexico, Canada and the United States together in a giant free-trade zone. The Administration is also seeking closer political and economic ties with Asia in the hope that these moves will provide an even greater boost from sales to the third world.
To the Administration, the argument is simple: more exports mean more jobs.
"For the first time in a long time, the less developed nations will grow considerably faster than he industrial world over the next decade and their markets are becoming much more open so there is much more opportunity there," Lawrence A. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said.
"Nafta is an important first step in capitalizing on that opportunity," he said. "It's time we start of thinking of these countries more as an opportunity and less as a problem."
But some economists, especially those who oppose the trade accord, view this export boom as a mixed blessing. They argue that the surge in exports causes some job losses because the purchases often come from companies that move their factories overseas and then import American machinery and components to make them run.
Commerce Department figures show that a large part of the exports are goods to help build industry in the third world: power generators, metal-cutting lathes, computers and telecommunications equipment. Many of these orders come from multinational companies, some of them American that open factories in low-wage nations.
Administration officials, however, argue that such purchases will make these countries even stronger trading partners. "Countries are realizing that to succeed they need to make competitive, high-quality goods and before they can do that, they need to acquire the necessary machinery and raw materials," Walter Bastian, director of the Commerce Department's Office of Latin America, said. "So what you see is huge growth in purchases of capital goods from the United States."
'Much More Open'
 Thanks to factors like these, America's share of the industrial world's exports to the third world grew to 31 percent last year from 29 percent in 1990, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
"Our exports to the developing world are doing real well, especially to the newly industrializing countries of Asia," said David Blond, director of international trade forecasting for DRI/McGraw Hill, a consulting firm. "They're growing very fast and are much more open to our products than the Japanese."
Exports to the newly industrializing countries of Asia -- Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan -- jumped to $48.6 billion, or 11 percent of the $448 billion in exports from the United States last year, up from just 1 percent in 1960.
The Southeast Asian "countries have really been a hotbed for us," said Raymond E. Ross, president of Cincinnati Milacron, a leading producer of industrial machinery. "It's a good emerging market for us and other U.S. manufacturers. We have an advantage over there because people like us and like doing business with Americans, while there is some resentment toward Japan for what it did to them in World War II."
DRI/McGraw-Hill predicts that exports to the less developed world will grow by more than 11 percent a year over the next three years, more than three times the 3.5 percent rate at which exports to the developed world are expected to rise. One reason for this gap is that the less industrialized countries are expected to grow at a 5 percent annual pace over the next few years, while many economists say the industrial world will grow by less than half that.
 
 
Trade Balance
 The surge in exports is expected to improve the United States trade balance with the third world. America's trade deficit with the nonindustrialized world -- which includes Latin America and all but the richest nations in the Middle East, Asia and Africa -- dropped to $24.8 billion last year, from $53.1 billion two years earlier.
The Economic Policy Institute, a union-backed research group that has provided much of the intellectual firepower against the North American Free Trade Agreement, argues that some of this surge in exports will come back and haunt the United States.
Thea Lee, a trade expert at the institute said, "If the boom in U.S. exports to the developing world simply represents a shift in the location of U.S. investment from the U.S. to developing countries, then the boom probably isn't sustainable. These factories will eventually gear up and will start producing goods destined for our markets. Therefore at least some of the improvements in the U.S. trade balance with developing countries may be temporary."
While acknowledging that much of America's exports will help the third world build its industries, economists who favor free trade say that only by making those nations richer will they have the wherewithal to buy more American goods.
 
 
Rising Wages
 "As industries develop in these countries, workers will see their wages rise and they will begin to import more consumer goods from the United States and elsewhere," said Peter Hakim, president of Inter-American Dialogue, a public policy group. "These markets aren't going to be saturated anytime soon for consumer goods."
He said that more than 50 cents of every dollar that Latin American countries earn from exports is used to import capital and consumer goods from the United States.
The debate on whether the export boom is healthy is reminiscent of a 19th-century British controversy in which some industrialists and unions worried that exports of capital goods, like machinery, would undermine that nation's manufacturing prowess by providing the building blocks for other nations' industries. Most economists argue this did not happen.
These economists believe that the free flow of trade and capital goods maximizes economic growth worldwide, although some workers certainly lose their jobs because of increased international competition.
 
 
Export Boon
 According to some economists, putting the free-trade pact into place would be a boon for exports to Mexico. Gary Hufbauer and Jeffrey Schott, economists at the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based research group, forecast that the agreement would increase Mexico's imports of American goods -- which were $40.6 billion last year -- by $17 billion more over five years than they would have increased without such an accord. They also predict that Mexican exports to the United States would increase by $8 billion, creating a $9 billion swing in favor of the United States.
They said that during the five years, 320,000 new American jobs would be created as a result of the trade agreement and 150,000 jobs lost, resulting in a net gain of 170,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: An Alliance of 6 Big Consumers Vows to Use More Recycled Paper

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
By the end of the decade, Prudential insurance policies, Johnson & Johnson Band-Aid boxes and Time Warner's billion copies of magazines a year may all be made of recycled paper, under a project announced yesterday by these and other companies working with the Environmental Defense Fund.
The project, which will start with feasibility studies, is aimed at reducing the burden on landfills and pumping up the anemic market for recycled paper by creating demand for billions of dollars worth of secondhand pulp. 
 The undertaking resembles an effort that the Environmental Defense Fund and the McDonald's Corporation announced in August 1990 to look into packaging disposal in the fast-food business. That led McDonald's to replace its plastic foam hamburger boxes with a less bulky paper wrapper.
 
A Varied Alliance
 McDonald's has also joined the new alliance. The other members are the Nationsbank Corporation, the country's fifth-largest banking company, and Duke University.
Traditionally, environmental groups have relied on lawsuits and influence with regulatory agencies to further their goals. But John Ruston, a solid-waste expert at the Environmental Defense Fund, a leading nonprofit group in the field, said the coalition was formed as a signal to paper companies that if they make environment-friendly paper, the buyers will come. Customers like Prudential, which spends $300 million a year on paper, are hard to ignore.
"The paper industry is the most capital-intensive one in the United States," he said. "They are not going to invest in new technology without the assurance of demand."
Currently, of the 22 million tons of printing and writing paper produced in the nation each year, only about 6 percent comes from paper that has been recycled from trash.
The alliance is forming as the Clinton Administration is preparing an executive order that is expected to direct Federal agencies to buy paper with increasing levels of recycled material. The Federal Government buys 300,000 tons of paper a year. The Clinton order, expected after Labor Day, may also include incentives against buying paper bleached with chlorine and chlorine compounds. Environmental groups have been increasingly critical of the use of chlorine in bleaching wood pulp because of the toxic emissions from the process.
Although the Environmental Defense Fund did not address the chlorine issue today, it did say that its effort would include looking at the way paper is made. The group said it was focusing on paper because paper products make up one-third of all municipal trash.
Mr. Ruston said the companies were selected for their size and diversity.
 
Broad-Based Approach
 "You have financial services with Prudential and Nationsbank, packagers with Johnson & Johnson and McDonald's, and a full-service publisher with Time, including book publishing," Mr. Ruston said. "The real value of the task force is that we are working with actual users of these products. You find what works in a business setting."
Mr. Ruston said the companies, which his group first approached last summer, were the only ones sought out. None declined to participate, he said, "but the courtship for some was longer than others."
The alliance does not include any publishers of newspapers, an industry that uses recycled paper to some extent. . The New York Times Company, for example, uses 12 percent recycled newsprint in The Times and the 31 regional newspapers owned by the company. The company's magazine group, which includes Family Circle and Child magazines, currently uses no recycled paper. But a spokesman for the company said recycled paper was being tested and would be used if it was found to be of acceptable quality and readily available.
Last summer during consideration of a bill that would require newspapers to use paper with 35 percent recycled content by 1995, Congressional aides said that just 6 of the nation's 56 largest newspapers were meeting that standard.
The drawbacks to recycled paper are usually appearance and strength. Recycled paper is often not as bright as virgin paper, because not all the ink is removed in reprocessing, and it is sometimes weaker, causing rolls of paper to break in printing presses.
Given those limitations, the involvement of Time Warner is noteworthy, since its Time Inc. subsidiary requires high-quality paper stock, coated with clay, to produce magazines. Technology, however, is gradually overcoming the problems associated with secondhand paper.
David Refkin, Time Inc.'s director of environmental affairs, said the company already published six of its magazines, including Entertainment Weekly and the Canadian edition of Time, on partly recycled paper.
He said 40,000 of the 250,000 tons of paper the company consumed yearly now has 10 percent wood fiber recovered from trash. "It is only in the last two years that it has become available in quantity," he said.
 
Several Cost Factors
 It is not immediately clear whether buying recycled paper will save the companies in the task force money or add to their costs. That will depend on the availability and price of old paper to be recycled, the costs of de-inking and the economics of the paper mills making the new paper.
But generally, the larger a paper mill, the lower the cost of production. Until now, most recycled paper has been produced at relatively costly small mills. Those costs could drop if efficient large mills add de-inking equipment for recycling.
Paul Brummett, a purchasing manager at Duke University, said the price of some paper with 30 percent recycled content dropped about 20 percent about a year ago, making it comparable to virgin paper. "When the price came down, we switched to recycled," he said.
As it has in previous alliances with corporations, the Environmental Defense Fund said it would not accept financial support from members of the paper task force.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
BOWATER TO REDUCE OPERATIONS AT MAINE PLANT

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Citing the need to cut costs in the midst of a paper industry slump, Bowater Inc. said it would close certain paper-making operations at its mill in Millinocket, Me., putting 200 people out of work. The company, based in Greenville, S.C., said it would take a $10 million pretax charge in the third quarter to cover the cost of the closings. The layoffs will take place over the next 12 months.

HEADLINE: Experimental Rocket Blasts Off, Then Makes a Vertical Landing

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WHITE SANDS MISSILE RANGE, N.M., Aug. 18

 BODY:
A single-stage reusable rocket that backers hope will revolutionize the United States space effort successfully completed its maiden voyage today, officials said.
The Delta Clipper-Experimental rocket, or DC-X, blasted off at 4:43 P.M. mountain time, flew to an altitude of 150 feet, then stopped, hovered and moved to the side about 350 feet. Still under power, it then descended and touched down on its landing gear, said Tom Williams, director of communications for McDonnell Douglas, in a phone interview. The flight lasted about a minute. 
 It was the first time a spacecraft had ever landed vertically on Earth.
It was "really wild, sexy stuff," Mr. Williams said.. "There was a lot of cheering and yelling from the program people" who worked on the project, he added. He watched the launching over closed-circuit television at company headquarters in Huntington Beach, Calif.
The rocket's designers say that it will prove to be far cheaper and more reliable than current launching vehicles, which require the use of massive booster rockets that are designed to be used only once.
The flight, at White Sands Missile Range, was originally set for this morning but had to be postponed because of rain and lightning at the launching site. The test was closed to reporters.
The 42-foot-tall, bullet-shaped DC-X is a one-third-scale prototype of McDonnell Douglas's proposed Delta Clipper, a single-stage rocket that would be light enough to reach orbit and return without needing expensive disposable lower stages or boosters, which are thrown away on every flight.
 
Returns to Earth Under Power
 The rocket is designed to return intact to Earth and land upright as it eases to the ground by firing its engines to brake its descent.
The experimental model is lighter because of its skin, made of a nonmetallic composite of epoxy and graphite fiber rather than aluminum.
A similar material was used in the Voyager, a plane that flew around the world nonstop. The lightweight plane, based on composite materials, was designed by Burt Rutan, whose Scaled Composites company also made the Delta Clipper's skin.
McDonnell Douglas wants to build larger experimental versions of the rocket, but continued financing depends on the program's success. The Pentagon's Ballistic Missile Defense Organization has provided $60 million for the project and earmarked an extra $5 million for continued flight tests.
The contractor's goal is to build a 127-foot Delta Clipper that would be able to fly orbital or suborbital missions, manned or unmanned, with payloads of about 25,000 pounds.
 
Cheaper Than Shuttle
 McDonnell Douglas estimates that launching a full-size Delta Clipper would cost $10 million per flight.
By comparison, NASA estimates that each space shuttle flight costs $409 million, based on eight flights per year.
The Delta Clipper would not be able to carry as heavy a payload, but backers hope that its simplicity will make it more reliable and economical than current launching vehicles.
Aerospace engineers agree that operating costs must decrease if a commercial space industry is to flourish.
A second test flight for the DC-X is tentatively set for Aug. 27. In that test, the rocket is supposed to reach an altitude of about 650 feet.

HEADLINE: U.S. Embargo of Cuba Has a Human Cost

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Cuba's epidemic of optic neuropathy, which has resulted in the visual and neurological impairment of thousands of Cubans, marks a new and dangerous point in the United States embargo of Cuba. As of June, total reported cases had reached 45,584, which is considerable for Cuba's population of 11 million. 
 Although the epidemic is in no way related to the embargo, it is evident that the resulting lack of medicines has had a further negative impact on the health of Cubans. At the same time, the embargo has caused Havana to increase control of dissidents.
During the 30-year embargo, Cuba had achieved among the best health indicators in Latin America and the Caribbean. Its infant mortality rate fell from 65 deaths in 1,000 live births in 1960 to 11 in 1991, and its life expectancy in 1991 reached 76 years. The marked reduction in mortality rates caused by infectious and parasitic diseases has resulted in children's mortality rates comparable to developed countries.
Cuba has also reached a high level of scientific achievement despite considerable restrictions on scientific books and materials as a result of the embargo. Illiteracy, which in 1960 affected 30 percent of the population, has now been practically eliminated, and Cuba's educational system is a model for other Latin American countries.
All these medical and social advances now run the risk of being reversed. The embargo, the lost economic support from former Soviet bloc allies and the Cuban Government's economic mismanagement have combined to bring the standard of living to subsistence level.
Although some food products normally unavailable can be obtained in the black market, their price is prohibitive. More than 300 medicines and basic medical supplies are lacking, and so are laboratory reactives and surgical and X-ray materials. Surgery is done only selectively, and there are limitations on ambulance services and biomedical research.
Paradoxically, the United States embargo is also hurting many American citizens who could benefit from successful treatments by Cuban doctors, such as for the skin condition vitiligo or for retinitis pigmentosa, which affects eyesight.
The way out of this quagmire is through negotiations between the two countries, an option Havana seems interested in pursuing. The time has come to put United States-Cuba relations on a more rational, intelligent basis.
 
CESAR CHELALA, M.D.
New York, Aug. 12, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: S.A.T. Scores Improve For 2d Consecutive Year

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
For the second year in a row, the average scores of students taking the Scholastic Aptitude Test have risen, prompting test officials to be optimistic about continued improvement.
The average S.A.T. verbal score this year was 424, one point above last year's score, while the mathematics average was 478, a two-point rise over 1992, for a total of 902. The highest possible scores are 800 on each, and the lowest are 200. 
 The number of students taking the test also rose, indicating that the higher scores are a real gain, not a fluke. The test was taken by 1,109,380 students this year compared with 1,034,131 in 1992. In general, a larger pool of students who take a test results in lower overall scores, as the pool usually includes more students form lower-income, less-educated households.
Blacks maintained the gains they have made against whites since 1976, when the S.A.T. began reporting ethnic breakdowns.
On the verbal test, the average scores of black students rose to 353 this year, up 1 point from last year and 21 points from 1976. In comparison, the average score of white students was 444 this year, up 2 from last year and down 7 points from 1976.
 
Blacks Improve Scores
 On the math test, the average score of black students rose to 388 this year, up 3 points from last year and up 34 points from 1976. In comparison, the average score of white students was 494, up 3 points from last year and up 1 point from 1976.
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were among the states with the highest percentage of college-bound students taking the S.A.T. New Yorkers had average scores of 416 for verbal and 471 for math, compared with 416 and 466 respectively in 1992. New Jersey had 419 in verbal and 473 in math, compared with 420 and 471 last year. Connecticut students averaged 430 in the verbal and 474 in math, compared with scores of 430 and 470 in 1992.
State scores cannot be easily compared because of variables including such things as the demographics of the test-takers, what percentage of all students take the test and how many students in a state plan to go to colleges that do not require the S.A.T. In addition, there is a competing test, the American College Test, that is preferred in some states.
Educators said they could not determine whether this year's increase indicated a long-term trend to reverse the decline that began in the 1960's. They did note that a continued increase in the percentage of test-takers who had taken 20 or more courses in six academic areas, to 42 percent this year, up from 34 percent of in 1987.
"Rigorous academic studies makes for winners," said Donald M. Stewart, president of the College Board. Like many educators, the S.A.T. test officials said high academic standards and challenging curriculums fostered better scores.
 
Right Direction
 "We're looking at a one-point difference but it's not the amount of the change that's impressive, but the direction," said Marc Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, a nonprofit policy and analysis organization based in Rochester. "What's most important is that more kids are taking courses of substance. We need a whole lot more kids doing that."
Regardless of ethnic group, students with four or more years of study in the six academic course areas (English, art and music, social sciences and history, foreign languages, natural sciences and mathematics) attained the highest scores. The top scoring students in each academic area took the most advanced courses in these areas.
Despite the improvement, Mr. Stewart said too many students were still "not being held to rigorous academic standards or exposed to a challenging curriculum." He also expressed concern over the "painfully slow academic recovery," noting that this year's verbal score was still one point under the level of 1983 and that both scores were significantly below the historic high levels of the 1960's. The total score on the verbal test was 463 in 1969, and the total score on the math test was 493.
This year, women's scores rose one point each on the verbal test, to 420, and math sections, to 457, while men's scores rose three points on math, to 502, and remained unchanged on the verbal section, at 428.
Girls historically score lower than boys, a fact that FairTest, a Cambridge, Mass.-based organization that analyzes tests, attributes to bias.
But Howard T. Everson, senior research scientist with the College Board, said, "We don't think the test is biased. It's no secret. For a variety of reasons, young women are socialized and steered away from more rigorous math courses and that plays itself out in scores on standardized tests."
Generally, women taking the tests come from lower-income households, representing 59 percent of test-takers reporting annual household incomes below $20,000. Girls generally get higher grades than boys do in high school and college in the same courses.
Among other ethnic groups since 1976, American Indians raised their scores by 12 points on the verbal, to 400, and 27 points on math, to 447.
Asian-Americans increased their verbal scores by 1 point, to 415, and their math scores by 17 points, to 535. Mexican Americans improved their scores during this period by 21 points on the verbal, to 353, and 18 points on the math, to 428. Puerto Rican students increased their verbal scores by 3 points, to 367, and their math scores by 8 points, to 409.
Asian-Americans, whites and those who said they were from other ethnic groups reported that they had taken more academic courses and received the highest scores. Mexican-American and black students reported the fewest academic courses and were among the lowest scorers.

HEADLINE: Large Increase In Trade Deficit Startles Experts

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit widened sharply in June to $12.06 billion, the largest in more than five years, as exports shrank and imports rose, especially in trade with Western Europe.
The sheer size of the June shortfall startled trade experts, who had expected only a modest increase from the May deficit. "That's just unimaginable -- holy moly," said Wayne L. Berman, a former Commerce Department official and senior campaign aide for President George Bush, when told of the June deficit. 
 Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and some private-sector economists attributed the deterioration to economic stagnation abroad, which reduces demand for American goods, and continued growth in the United States, which leaves Americans better able to afford imports.
 
 
Third World Buys Less
 Exports to the third world, which had grown for the first five months of the year, fell in June, although by less than exports to Europe. But imports from third world countries also rose.
 The trade deficit with Japan also rose, but the dollar still soared against the yen after the Federal Reserve supported the dollar in the currency markets. [Page D1.]
 The June deficit in merchandise trade easily exceeded the large May deficit of $8.38 billion, and was the largest since a $12.56 billion shortfall in February 1988. "It further reflects that while our economy improves, the economies of several of our major trading partners remain weak," Mr. Brown said in a statement.
But Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., the president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington research group that advocates trade policies that are more confrontational, said the deficit was too large to be explained by the worldwide slowdown. He contended that closed markets abroad were also partly responsible.
Stephen L. Cooney Jr., a trade expert at the National Association of Manufacturers, said the 5.1 percent rise in imports in June, to $49.71 billion, was remarkable given Commerce Department estimates that the economy grew only 1.8 percent in the second quarter.
"It's a pretty modest recovery, but it sure hasn't been modest in terms of import growth," he said. By contrast, exports fell 3.3 percent, to $37.65 billion.
 
Exports Contribute Less
 According to Commerce Department figures, exports are contributing less and less to American economic output, after equaling three-quarters of the nation's growth during the Bush Administration. During the first half of this year, rising exports accounted for only a fifth of the nation's economic growth.
Recalling the Clinton campaign's famous slogan, "It's the economy, stupid," Mr. Berman said, "The phrase should have been, 'It's the global economy, stupid,' because you can't separate our economy out."
The biggest increases in imports were for manufactured consumer goods -- notably cotton clothing and television sets -- and manufactured industrial products, led by computers, civil aircraft and computer chips. Export categories that fell sharply included gold, computer accessories and cars and car parts.
The Commerce Department has now announced four consecutive monthly trade deficits running at an annual pace of $100 billion or more; the nation has not recorded a surplus in more than a decade.
The United States trade deficit peaked at $152.12 billion in 1987. The annual trade deficit gradually fell to $66.72 billion in 1991 as the value of the dollar shrank on foreign-exchange markets, and then grew last year to $84.5 billion as the American economy began expanding while other economies did not grow.
 
Lower Sales in Europe
 The weakest June trade figures were for commerce with Western Europe, Japan, Latin America and members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. With the European Community forecasting a shrinkage in economic output this year of five-tenths of a percentage point, sales of American goods there and elsewhere in Western Europe have steadily slackened and the American surplus has evaporated.
The United States ran a $332 million surplus with Western European nations in May that turned into a $1.7 billion deficit in June, the Commerce Department said today. Exports tumbled 11.5 percent from May while imports climbed 9.9 percent.
Exports to developing countries and Canada have offset part of the weakness in American exports to Western Europe and Japan this year.
But this pattern did not hold true in June, when exports to nonindustrialized countries fell 3.1 percent while imports surged 9.6 percent. Mr. Cooney said American sales to the third world were slowing as some countries, especially in Latin America, sought to trim their own trade deficits.
Japan and Mexico, the two countries with the most sensitive trade relations with the United States at present, posted gains in their trade with the United States. The American trade deficit with Japan widened to $4.33 billion, from $3.75 billion, while the American trade surplus with Mexico contracted to $127.9 million, from $249.9 million.
Economists disagree about the importance of monthly trade deficits. Monthly figures fluctuate considerably, and the June deficit was made larger by a sharp drop in gold exports and an increase in imports of civilian aircraft.
Experts even disagree about the method of calculating the monthly deficit. Many economists contend that the figures are misleading because they exclude trade in services, like insurance and banking.
To address this concern, Commerce Secretary Brown ordered the department in April to begin giving combined quarterly trade figures for goods and services. Until now, the department provided separate merchandise and service figures, but did not add them. For the first quarter of this year, the United States had a $29.1 billion merchandise trade deficit for goods only, and a $14.6 billion surplus in services, for a combined trade deficit of $14.4 billion.

HEADLINE: Heidi Talks Heidi, And Hollywood Listens Closely

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Heidi is starting to talk -- and talk. And while she seems to be saying nothing quite as scandalous as anyone else at lunch at the Ivy or Cicada, the movie community here remains frightened and fascinated.
"You know, it's all out of jealousy," Heidi Fleiss, the 27-year-old woman accused of running a high-level prostitution ring here, says of her arrest. "The truth is, people in this town have been in this business their entire lives. It took me one year and I did it. 
 "By the time I was 26, I was burnt out. I won't make any boasts, but L.A. is in a recession. I put a lot of people through college, maybe. A lot of people got to go on with their careers. A lot of girls got to be who they really wanted to be."
 
The Worst of Hollywood
 Ms. Fleiss made these and other comments in an interview to be published in the October issue of Details, the hip Conde Nast men's monthly with a circulation of 450,000. The interview, by Nikki Finke, a journalist and author, presents a version of the Heidi chronicles that are a measure of Hollywood's underside -- thousands of dollars tossed around by studio executives, producers and performers in a world of drugs, perversity, sleaze and threats of blackmail.
Ms. Fleiss was arrested at her $1.6 million mansion in the Benedict Canyon area and charged with running what the Los Angeles police said was an exclusive call girl ring. She pleaded not guilty last Monday, in Municipal Court, to five counts of pandering and a single count of possession of cocaine for sale. She was released on $100,000 bail and ordered to appear in court on Sept. 10 for a preliminary hearing.
What has shaken Hollywood, which is certainly accustomed to scandal but now pretends to be just a family town, is the possibility that Ms. Fleiss's clientele may have included film moguls and stars. And she is beginning to talk about it. Connie Chung, Barbara Walters, book publishers, supermarket tabloids, you name it, have sought her out.
Although Ms. Fleiss has spoken sporadically to The Los Angeles Times and Daily Variety, her comments in Details are her most extensive to date. She names no clients but speaks of a sour relationship with a television director, Ivan Nagy, who was also arrested on a pandering charge; her early life in the affluent Los Feliz section of Los Angeles, where her father is a pediatrician and her mother was a schoolteacher, and her involvement in prostitution, largely from 1991 to 1992.
 
Angry With Billy Idol
 Ms. Fleiss also briefly discusses her angry relationship with the rock star Billy Idol, who has recently acknowledged knowing her while denying that he paid for sex.
Of her relationship with Mr. Nagy, Ms. Fleiss said she phoned Michael Nathanson, an executive at Columbia Pictures, where Mr. Nagy has worked, after Mr. Nagy began harassing her when they broke up two years ago.
"I said, 'Michael, please call Ivan and stop him from bothering me,' " Ms. Fleiss said. After that call, she said: "I never made another call to Michael, ever. Never."
Asked if anybody ever gave her a check from Columbia Studios, Ms. Fleiss replied: "No. Never. Ever."
Columbia has declined to comment. Mr. Nathanson, through his lawyer, has denied any improper involvement with Ms. Fleiss. His bosses, however, are unhappy about seeing his name and Columbia's in print for the first time on the subject of Ms. Fleiss.
Ms. Fleiss showed no reluctance about seeing her own name in print. "Put it this way," she said in the interview, "the person 'Heidi' that people talk about -- in the history of time, no one did what she did in one year. No one."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The nation's trade deficit widened sharply in June to $12.06 billion, the largest in more than five years, as exports shrank and imports rose, especially in trade with Western Europe. The size of the June deficit startled experts, who had expected only a modest increase from the May figure of $8.38 billion. [Page A1.]
 
Markets
The dollar rallied sharply after the Federal Reserve system and the Treasury Department apparently intervened to halt the surging Japanese yen by buying dollars in large quantities. [D1.] Gold prices tumbled $3 an ounce, and other precious metals fell in response to the Fed's move in the currency markets. [D14.] 
 The bond market rose across the board, partly on the surprisingly poor merchandise-trade report. The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to another 16-year low, and other maturities also fell. [D1.]
Stocks were mixed as investors consolidated their positions after strong gains Wednesday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.27 points, setting another closing high at 3,612.13. [D4.]
The number of shares sold short rose to a record on both the New York and American Stock Exchanges this month, spurred in part by increased merger activity. [D2.]
 
Companies
Mattel and Fisher-Price agreed to merge in a stock swap valued at about $1 billion. The combined company, which would join Mattel's Barbie, Hot Wheels and Disney infant toys with Fisher-Price's preschool lines, is expected to challenge Hasbro, which became the No. 1 toy maker when it acquired Tonka in 1991. [D1.]
GlenFed shareholders narrowly approved a $425 million bailout and gave up most of their equity in the company to keep it from being seized by regulators. The Government would take over Glendale Federal Bank if it does not meet capital standards. [D1.]
Lockheed Information Management used a lobbying campaign that began soon after Mayor Dinkins took office early in 1990 to win a city contract, despite having been implicated in a municipal corruption scandal in the mid-1980's. [A1.]
Regulators allowed Southern Ohio Coal to maintain a flooded coal mine by pumping polluted waste water into the Ohio River because, they say, the environmental damage is temporary but the loss of the mine and more than 800 jobs would be permanent. [A12.]
The Clinton Administration wants to repeal a law that prohibits even negligible amounts of cancer-causing substances from being added to food. The move would benefit pesticide manufacturers, who have long opposed the law, known as the Delaney clause. [A14.]
Two new potential buyers have emerged for Nutri-System, and Nutri-System franchisees are independently pursuing an affiliation with other diet companies. [D3.]
Texas Instruments plans a huge new chip factory in anticipation of continuing strong worldwide demand. The company will spend $750 million to $1 billion through 1998. [D3.]
A big shareholder in Rodman & Renshaw proposed to replace the board with his own nominees. Marshall S. Geller submitted the plan after a deal to make him chairman failed. [D3.]
I.B.M. scientists developed a new method for manufacturing a sensitive device for reading magnetic information on computer disks, making it possible to store more data. [D3.]
Lower airline ticket taxes were among recommendations in the report of a U.S. panel looking into the industry's ills. [D3.]
 
Today's Columns
The groundwork for a stock market fall is being laid, many on Wall Street say, though they expect the market to continue its rise for the near future. Kurt Eichenwald: Market Place. [D1.]
The Thom McAn shoe chain is scrambling to attract younger consumers with a campaign by Kirshenbaum & Bond, the agency Thom McAn hired in June. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
U.S. Tries To Halt Fall Of Dollar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration seemed to put out a stop sign yesterday on the precipitous decline of the dollar against the Japanese yen, trying to halt it through dollar-buying by the Federal Reserve and jawboning by the Treasury.
The apparent sudden shift in the Administration's outlook and the Fed's dollar purchases in the currency market caught traders by surprise, causing a sharp rally in the dollar. In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar jumped 4.22 yen, or 4.15 percent, to 105.85 yen, the strongest the American currency had been since the end of July. In Tokyo early on Friday, the dollar slipped to 104.60 yen. 
 The dollar's surge yesterday came despite a Government report that the merchandise trade deficit jumped in June to its highest level in more than five years. The deficit with Japan alone rose to $4.33 billion. Since February, the White House has aggressively encouraged the strengthening of the yen to help reverse this trade imbalance.
Currency traders and speculators will now try to determine if the Administration has truly decided that the dollar has dropped too far. The dollar hit a low of 100.40 yen to the dollar in trading on Tuesday.
 
 
A Shift in Policy?
 "This is a new statement from the Administration, and that is why the market is wondering if there is a shift in Administration policy," said Nicholas P. Sargen, the chief investment officer at Prudential Insurance's Global Advisers.
But it will be hard to tell at first what the Administration has done. The Administration may be trying only to slow the fall of the dollar. The Administration might have been worried, as some analysts suggested, that a drop below 100 yen to the dollar would rattle the American bond market, where the move to lower long-term interest rates is about the only positive economic news for which the President can take credit.
And traders are suspicious because there have been other instances when interventions by the Fed and comments by Administration officials were mistaken for stop signs on a falling dollar.
To test the Administration, traders may sell dollars for yen, pushing the dollar lower, and then see if the Federal Reserve again intervenes to support the dollar. If the Fed does step in, the Administration's message will appear more firm.
In addition, traders will look for a sign that the United States and Japan have reached some kind of quid pro quo. The Administration may have agreed to back off from downward pressure on the dollar in exchange for a move by Japan like stimulating its economy or opening its markets that would benefit the United States by encouraging Japanese imports of American goods.
The American move did come on the same day that the Japanese Government promised unspecified plans to deregulate the economy. President Clinton had a phone conversation with Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa on Wednesday night, but White House officials said they believed that the two did not discuss exchange rates.
Traders in the currency market were quick to speculate that there was some sort of deal. If that is the case, they said, the Administration will probably continue to defend the dollar, possibly stopping its decline at least for the time being.
 
 
Traders Wait and See
 "The market wants to see what happens over the weekend to see if deals were made," said Richard E. Witten, a partner in foreign exchange at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "If a trade deal has been worked out, the pressure on the dollar may go down some."
Merely halting the decline of the dollar, however, will not bring much relief to Japanese exporters, whose goods have lost their competitive edge abroad because the strong yen has made them much more expensive. Japanese companies may also lose millions of dollars in profits from sales abroad when they are converted into the stronger yen.
 And there will not be much relief for American tourists in Japan, where a cup of coffee can cost $5. Tourists were already getting less than 100 yen to the dollar when they changed money in hotels. Even if the dollar does not sink any further, it is still 15.2 percent lower than it was at the end of 1992.
 
 
Treasury Is Concerned
 The Treasury Department would not explain its position other than to issue a statement by Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs. But his statement indicated that the Administration believed that further declines in the dollar against the yen would be counterproductive.
"We are committed to cooperating with our G-7 partners in foreign exchange markets," Mr. Summers said in part, referring to the Group of Seven nations. "In this context, we are concerned that the recent rapid rise of the value of the Japanese yen could retard growth in the Japanese and world economies."
A White House official said the decision had been made by the Treasury Department and portrayed the move as a tactical step that was consistent with the Administration's goal of avoiding excessive volatility in the currency markets. The official insisted that it did not represent a new policy by the United States.
 The backdrop for the dollar's fall and the yen's rally is the continuing dispute over American access to the Japanese market.
On Feb. 19, Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen, at the National Press Club, said, "I'd like to see a stronger yen." Traders immediately interpreted this as a license to sell the dollar against the yen.
"The yen is the most political of all currencies," Mr. Sargen of Global Advisers said. He said the fall of the dollar this year -- compared with last year, when the Japanese trade surplus was just as much of a problem -- was a new policy by the Clinton Administration to pressure Japan to open its markets.

HEADLINE: Coal Mine Sends Polluted Water Into Ohio Creeks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILKESVILLE, Ohio, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Here in this economically depressed Appalachian region of Ohio, the Southern Ohio Coal Company is saving a flooded coal mine by pumping a billion gallons of polluted waste water into 75 miles of streams and creeks that flow into the Ohio River.
Now in its 19th day, the waste water is painting the creeks the color of coffee or tea with cream, and in its wake the discharge is killing all aquatic life and posing a threat to an endangered species of mussel in the Ohio River. 
 The discharge -- harmful mainly because it contains high levels of iron and is slightly acidic -- does not pose any health problem for communities that rely on the Ohio River for drinking water. That is because the nearest municipality, Huntington, W. Va., more than 50 miles downstream, is able to remove impurities.
Nonetheless, the flow of polluted water from the caved-in coal mine has put an end to recreational fishing, swimming and boating on the creeks for six months to two years, say state officials who approved the discharge.
 
Widespread Support
 The company has won widespread support from state environmental officials, politicians, union leaders and area residents by contending that the environmental damage is temporary and reversible, but that the loss of the mine and more than 800 jobs would be permanent if the water was not quickly pumped out.
A Federal court in Columbus today blocked the Federal Environmental Protection Agency from taking any action to halt the pumping. It also prevented the United States Office of Surface Mining, Reclamation and Enforcement from executing an earlier order to stop the discharge.
"It was a jobs issue," said Jenny Camper, a spokeswoman for Gov. George V. Voinovich, a Republican, who along with the state's entire Congressional delegation, supported the company plan.
Southern Ohio Coal, the largest employer in southeastern Ohio, is a subsidiary of the American Electric Power Company, which owns three coal companies and seven electric utilities in Ohio and six nearby states.
In trying to stop the discharge, Federal environmental officials said the company was merely using the politically powerful issue of jobs to avoid the expense of purifying its waste water. "It's basic blackmail," said Dale Bryson, regional director of the water division of the E.P.A. "Severe environmental damage is occurring and I think it will be long-lasting."
But Federal District Judge Sandra S. Beckwith ruled in favor of the company, which brought the lawsuit, saying that the two Federal agencies do not have jurisdiction in the state case.
Federal and state environmental officials said they are disappointed. "I am astounded that a Federal judge would restrain two Federal agencies from exercising their primary responsibilities," said David C. Callaghan, director of the West Virginia Division of Environmental Protection.
Dr. Eli McCoy, chief of the Office of Water Resources in the West Virginia Division of Environmental Protection, said the most polluted body of water, Leading Creek, was sending a sludge blanket into the Ohio River at the confluence of the two waterways near Middleport, Ohio. Aerial photographs show that the sludge has sunk to the river bottom and is depositing an iron-based sediment in a plume up to several miles long, he said.
Environmental officials at the Ohio River Valley Water Sanitation Commission, an interstate agency, say their biggest concern is that the sediment will wipe out beds of common mussels as well as a bed of an endangered species, the pink pearly mucket mussels.
"Our immediate concern is the mussel beds," said Peter A. Tennant, a spokesman for the commission. He said the company responded to the commission's concerns last week by bringing in pumps to speed up the mixing of the creek water with the river water to dilute the pollution.
The problem began last month at Southern Ohio Coal's mining complex, one of the largest underground coal mining operations in the nation. The two mines in the complex, three miles east of Wilkesville, produced 5.2 million tons of high-sulfur coal last year.
At 8 P.M. on July 11, company officials say, a structural support collapsed in an abandoned mine that was holding about a billion gallons of waste water, flooding 10 miles of tunnels in an adjacent, active mine that holds about 100 million tons of coal.
The highly acidic floodwaters are corroding the mine's electrical systems as well as $34 million worth of mining equipment and damaging the 20-year-old mine's structural integrity, said James F. Tompkins, a vice president and general manager of the mine. "Time is the most important factor in saving the equipment and the mine," he said during a tour of the complex.
If the water had been left in the mine until it could be properly treated, Mr. Tompkins said, the damage would have been so great that it would have been too expensive to reopen that mine as well as another, which shares overhead costs with the damaged mine.
About 300 miners have already been laid off while the mine is being pumped out. If the company were to close the whole complex, it would mean a loss of 815 jobs, or $78 million a year in lost wages and benefits in a corner of the state where a quarter of the population lives below the poverty level.
The company told state environmental agencies that if the mine and the jobs were to be saved, the company would have to pump the waste water into nearby creeks and streams for 60 days without complying with state and Federal water waste standards, which the state enforces.
One state agency, the Division of Mine Reclamation, denied the company's request, but the agency's ruling was stayed pending a hearing later this month by an appellate review board. The Ohio Environmental Protection Agency, meanwhile, granted the company's request to discharge the waste water, starting July 30.
In its agreement with the state agency, the company said it would increase its capacity for treating the water, search for better solutions and mitigate environmental damage wherever possible. "If the company had not been able to meet our environmental concerns, we would not have allowed them to proceed," said Robert R. Berger, a spokesman for the agency.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Plummet On Currency Maneuvering

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Gold prices tumbled yesterday as the dollar jumped sharply against the Japanese yen.
The Federal Reserve intervened in the currency markets, buying dollars and selling yen, after a larger-than-expected merchandise trade deficit sent the dollar falling. 
 The dollar surged higher after Lawrence Summers, Treasury Under Secretary, said the recent rise in the yen could hinder global economic growth, reversing the Clinton Administration's earlier endorsements of the strong yen.
"This is a huge watershed for the dollar," said Keith Cheveralls, foreign exchange manager at Nippon Credit Bank in New York. "Japan and the U.S. have decided that the yen is not going to strengthen."
In response, gold and other precious metals fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery lost $3 an ounce, to $371.30. December gold, the most actively traded futures contract, fell $3.10, to $374.40. September silver slipped 5.2 cents an ounce, to $4.658 an ounce. And October platinum plunged $5.10 an ounce, to $386.30, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 
'Pressure on Gold'
 A rising dollar often leads to lower gold prices, in part because a strong dollar dims prospects for renewed inflation and also makes gold more expensive for foreign investors.
"When we got a good dollar rally, it put pressure on gold," said Jim Steel, vice president for commodities research at Refco Inc. in New York.
On other commodity markets, unleaded gasoline futures continued their descent on expectations that supplies would outstrip demand.
Unleaded gasoline for September delivery fell 0.58 cent a gallon, to 53.52 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. September crude oil slipped a cent a barrel, to $17.65. But September heating oil edged up 0.08 cent a gallon, to 52.37 cents.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rally On Report Of Trade Gap

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market rallied across the board yesterday on the back of surprisingly downbeat economic news in the June merchandise trade report and on some relief that the Clinton Administration may have moved to halt the decline of the dollar against the Japanese yen.
The yield on the 30-year bond, in what is becoming a routine development, dropped to another 16-year low. But more importantly, the rest of the bond market rallied, pulling the yield on the 10-year note to a new 20-year low and the yield on the 5-year note to its lowest level since 1967, according to monthly averages kept by Salomon Brothers.
 
 
Exports Fall
 The unexpectedly large jump in the June trade deficit to $12.06 billion came, in part, at the expense of American exports, which fell 3.3 percent. And economists were quick to conclude that the surprisingly steep drop could mean that the growth in the second quarter of the year, which was initially reported to be 1.6 percent, will be cut back to as low as just six-tenths of 1 percent at an annual rate after adjustment for inflation. 
 Such a downward adjustment in the second-quarter growth just adds potency to the economic theme that is playing so well in the bond market now: that inflation, despite a scare this spring, is remaining low and economic growth is so sluggish that there is no chance that there will be any worrisome price pressures soon.
On the dollar, the Federal Reserve intervened to support the currency against the yen and the Clinton Administration, in a statement from the Under Secretary of the Treasury, indicated a surprising concern about the weakness of the dollar that could signal a shift in policy. Since February, Administration officials have indicated that they favored a stronger yen and a weaker dollar.
For some traders, according to Matthew Alexy, government trading strategist at the First Boston Corporation, the move to support the dollar did relieve fears that the dollar could break through 100 yen and possibly force disruptive selling of Treasury securities by the Japanese. The dollar ended at 105.85 yen, up 4.15 percent, from 101.63 on Wednesday.
In a volatile day of trading, the price of the new 6.25 percent bond due in August 2023 jumped 15/32 of a point as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.20 percent in late trading, down from 6.26 percent the day before. The price of the 10-year note, which is becoming an alternative benchmark for long-term interest rates, jumped 15/32 and the yield fell to 5.61 percent, from 5.67 percent Wednesday and the lowest since the spring of 1971.
The price of the five-year note was up 10/32 as the yield plunged to 4.94 percent, from 5.01 percent and the lowest in 26 years. The discount rates on Treasury bills fell, as the rate on the three-month bill slipped to 2.96 percent, from 2.97 percent, and the rate on the six-month bill hit 3.08 percent, down one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point.
The trade deficit news helped send the yield on the 30-year bond as low as 6.18 percent in the morning, and then almost all the gains were lost after a big buyer of 5-year notes followed by selling the 30-year bond. But then the bond recovered, matching its 6.18 percent yield in the afternoon before closing slightly higher.
Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company, said that buying by the Japanese also helped lift the price of the 30-year bond, noting that the new issue seems to be trading in a zone of its own.
He suggested that it was the rally of the 30-year bond in the afternoon that just pulled up the rest of the market with it.
 
 
Frequency Cut
 One reason the bond is trading so much better than the rest of the market is that the Treasury has cut the annual issuance of the bond by 40 percent and will now sell it only two times a year instead of four. In addition, the bond is in demand for traders who are betting that the differential in the yield between shorter- and longer-term securities is narrowing. For this trade, one can buy the 30-year bond and sell the two-year note.
A sign of the demand for the new 30-year bond is the difference between the yield on it, which was 6.20 percent yesterday, and the yield on the old 7.125 percent 30-year bond due in February 2023, which was 6.37 percent in late trading yesterday.
Normally, this gap would be much narrower. But there is more demand than usual for several reasons. One, said Jay Goldinger, a trader at Capital Insight in Los Angeles, was that corporate bond traders have sold the new bond short as a way to hedge against adverse price moves on the corporate bonds they are buying. But because the new bond has rallied so much they need to buy it back to prevent sharp losses.
Mr. Goldinger said that the people who own the new bonds are just doing what is natural when a rally is on and other traders are caught short -- "pressing their positions."

HEADLINE: A Nemesis Revisited;
For Dinkins, the Toughest Question In a Scandal Is What Took So Long?

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
As Mayor David N. Dinkins responded this week to an official report that harshly criticized his senior aides for giving preferential treatment to a company that won a $150 million contract to collect New York City parking fines, he said, "New Yorkers may well feel angry," and added: "That is understandable. I am angry, as well."
But yesterday Mr. Dinkins's opponents, and more than a few of his own aides, were asking in one way or another, "What took you so long?" 
 It is a question that has dogged this Mayor at a half-dozen critical junctures since he took office nearly four years ago, from his reluctance to intercede in the boycott of a Korean grocery store to his initial reluctance to add police officers amid concern over crime, to his postponement of hard choices on the budget to his handling of the interracial violence in Crown Heights.
Of course, there is nothing intrinsically wrong with deliberation, and Mr. Dinkins has long insisted that it often produces superior results. But with the parking fines, as in several other cases, even his friends suggest that Mr. Dinkins may have deepened his problems by not reacting more quickly and forcefully to early warnings.
Repeated news reports over two years questioned how the company, Lockheed Information Management Services, had obtained special meetings with top city officials while its competitor was left with junior aides. There was open feuding between the budget director, who backed the contract, and the Transportation Commissioner, who opposed it, and a phalanx of well-connected lobbyists were hired by Lockheed explicitly for their personal ties to the Mayor.
But Mr. Dinkins ordered an inquiry by the City Department of Investigation only last spring. He canceled the contract only on Wednesday, when the report was issued, and accepted the budget director's resignation only yesterday.
"It basically confirms the kinds of things Giuliani has been saying about him," one senior mayoral aide said glumly, referring to Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal mayoral candidate, and speaking on condition of anonymity. "It's sad."
That Lockheed was the successor to a company that rigged bids in the corruption scandals that bedeviled the city in the mid-80's -- and that some of the same executives still ran it -- should have raised loud alarm bells at City Hall, and indeed it did. The Investigation Department itself learned two years ago of complaints by Transportation Commissioner Lucius J. Riccio that Budget Director Philip R. Michael had tried to exert undue influence on Lockheed's behalf.
But it took no action until news accounts repeated Mr. Riccio's claims last spring.
The report draws a picture of City Hall's workings that surprised few who know the Mayor or Mr. Michael, one in which the Mayor seemed perhaps too willing to delegate authority and too tolerant of his subordinates' shortcomings.
In fact, late on the night of June 30, 1991, after Mr. Dinkins and the City Council had finally reached agreement on the bleakest, hardest-fought municipal budget in years, a befuddled reporter asked Mr. Michael whether the final package amounted to $28 billion or $29 billion.
"It's $28 billion or $29 billion, give or take a billion," Mr. Michael said. Some of the bone-weary aides in the room laughed. But off to the side the Mayor just glowered silently and said nothing.
 
Quest for Revenue
 That Mr. Michael could not be bothered to give a precise answer at such an important moment and that Mr. Dinkins quietly suffered that attitude then and in the many months since sums up what the Mayor's critics regularly describe as the air of casual attention to some problems and appearances of propriety that has so often seemed to prevail on his watch.
The city investigation did not suggest that Mr. Michael sought to profit personally from Lockheed's gain. As the architect of the city's spending plans, deeply in need of any new revenues in the face of a recession and huge budget gaps, he was apparently trying to increase the revenue from the Parking Violations Bureau, while Mr. Riccio was also guarding his own bureaucratic turf.
Nor did the report this week hint that the Mayor had done anything improper. Indeed, it never so much as suggested that he was even especially aware of the feuding that was dividing his aides.
"I had some awareness of the struggle, because some of it was mentioned in the press, and I inquired, 'What's this about?' " the Mayor recalled yesterday. "Norman was busily trying to resolve it," referring to First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel.
The report did suggest, however, that Mr. Michael -- by offering in the presence of Lockheed executives to help Mr. Riccio withstand other budget cuts if he granted a small pilot contract to Lockheed -- surrendered his claim to impartiality and gave Lockheed an inapproriate advantage in the bidding.
The Mayor's press secretary, Leland T. Jones, said Mr. Dinkins had no recollection of any conversations with Basil A. Paterson, a former Secretary of State for New York State and one of Mr. Dinkins's oldest friends, whom Lockheed hired to help lobby the city. It would have hardly been unusual if Mr. Paterson had, because Mr. Dinkins has been a figure in city politics for more than two decades, socializes with the former city officials who now lobby the government and is willing to be waylaid by even the least powerful ones who have been known to ambush him from a bench outside his suite.
In its report on Lockheed, the Investigation Department also criticized Mr. Steisel -- who is often advanced as the administration's chief manager and is even now in charge of removing asbestos from city schools -- saying he had failed to make a vital initial finding, whether farming out the collection of tickets was in the city's best interests.
Allowing for campaign hyperbole, Mr. Giuliani's words yesterday had an uncomfortably acute sting.
"I can't imagine that any parents in the city are resting any easier today knowing that Norman Steisel, the same person who seemed not to know what he was doing in handling Lockheed, is now in charge of asbestos removal in the schools," Mr. Giuliani said. "It is really pretty astounding that we've got the highest level in the Dinkins administration appearing to know nothing of what they were doing with what was in fact the largest contracting-out project of the Dinkins administration, which is now cratered."
The Mayor countered: "Mr. Giuliani does not disappoint. One can pretty much guess what kind of comment he would make." Mr. Dinkins now has just over 10 weeks to see whether New Yorkers agree.

HEADLINE: New Director Known as Skilled Manager

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
Carol O'Cleireacain once said that she majored in economics at the University of Michigan because it was the hardest subject she could find.
Ms. O'Cleireacain (pronounced oh-CLARE-eh-can), who was named New York City's interim Budget Director yesterday, replacing Philip R. Michael, is known by fellow administrators as an intense, ambitious and skillful manager, eager to tackle subjects that appear hopelessly arcane to others. 
 As Finance Commissioner, she earned praise for aggressively and swiftly making the administration of the city's tax codes more efficient. She also replaced about half of the senior staff members in her department and cut the overall size of her department by 500 employees.
Before joining the Dinkins administration in 1990, she spent 13 years as chief economist at the city's largest union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. During those years she also taught at the New School for Social Research and at Columbia University.
She also worked as chief economic adviser to the Rev. Jesse Jackson during his campaign for President in 1988.
Ms. O'Cleireacain, 47, was born in Chicago and raised in Skokie, Ill. She studied at the University of Michigan for a master's degree in economics and earned a Ph.D. at the London School of Economics.
When a reporter interviewed her for a profile last year, she said her hobbies were listening to Irish music and reading detective novels.

HEADLINE: Unemployed Man, 22, Is Arrested in Four Sex Assaults in Queens

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
An unemployed man from Queens was arrested on Wednesday in four sexual assaults since January that were primarily in Jamaica Estates. The police said the man was under suspicion in other cases.
The suspect, Gary Heeralal, 22 years old, who has worked as a livery driver, messenger and mechanic, was seized at his house in Jamaica and identified in a lineup, the police said. He faces charges of first-degree rape, first-degree sexual abuse, attempted sodomy, second-degree robbery and endangering the welfare of a child. 
 The assailant would "stalk his victim and then he would come up from behind once she had passed," Sgt. Rolf Mahler of the special victims squad said. "He was an opportunist basically waiting for someone to come along."
 
Daylight Attacks
 Many attacks were in daylight but were not seen because the assailant dragged the women to the sides or rears of houses.
The most serious was a rape on Feb. 25 of a 24-year-old in Jamaica Estates, the police said. The rapist grabbed her from behind at 182d Street and Aberdeen Road at 8:45 A.M. and also robbed her. The attacker was described as wearing a baseball cap and a light blue nylon jacket with "Dodgers" on the back.
The youngest victim, a 14-year-old, was assaulted at 3:15 P.M. on Feb. 9 at 196th Street and 56th Avenue in Bayside. Her assailant punched her, knocked her down and tried to pull down her pants but fled when she screamed.
 
Other Cases Investigated
 The first incident was on Jan. 14, when an 18-year-old was approached from behind on Henley Road, punched and fondled.
The most recent attack, on July 31, was in front of 176 Croydon Road. The attacker punched and knocked down a 28-year-old and fondled her.
Two other incidents that fit the pattern, said Sergeant Mahler, were attempted rapes on Jan. 24 on Highland Avenue and on Feb. 9 on Henley Road. The police said that they were investigating whether Mr. Heeralal was involved in those attacks, but that he has not been charged in them.

HEADLINE: Gore Jumps Into the Job Of Cutting U.S. Waste

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Strolling around a Pentagon courtyard filled with attentive Federal employees, Vice President Al Gore is holding another gripe session.
Microphone in hand, sweat soaking his blue shirt, Mr. Gore exhibits the moist concern of an afternoon talk show host, offering up equal doses of empathy and outrage. But instead of tales of faithless husbands and long-suffering wives, he is talking about overpriced steam traps (for heating systems) and overregulated ash trays, unwieldy personnel practices and all manner of bureaucratic slag. 
 In campaign-style trips to Government agencies and in short-hop, out-of-town investigative missions, Mr. Gore listens to and retells the same horror stories over and over and over. If ever a temperament was matched to a task, this is it.
The point of compiling these tales of woe has been grandly called reinventing government, a task Mr. Gore has been handed to fulfill a Clinton campaign pledge to cut waste and address the widely held perception that Washington does not work. If that were not enough, Mr. Gore, during the budget fight, was also saddled with the job of fulfilling optimistic promises to Congress to find big, quick spending cuts -- and he has to do all this while remaining the President's bashful sidekick.
 
Real Theory, Vague Hope
 On Sept. 7, the Vice President is scheduled to present his findings, discovered not only by him but also by 1,000 full- and part-time employees. On that day, reinventing government, or REGO, as it has been nicknamed, will become reality instead of theory, or at least a real theory instead of a vague hope.
It will also become the well for a lot of expectations and promises, and the focus of fierce resistance from many people in the Government whose programs are to be reinvented out of existence.
Mr. Gore's group is expected to recommend plans to combine departments, revamp rules governing the civil service and abolish commissions in a manner that remains faithful to the vision of David Osborne, an author whose writings have influenced Mr. Clinton and who has worked on the project.
In "Mandate for Change," a book published by the Progressive Policy Institute, an arm of the Democratic Leadership Council, Mr. Osborne recommended legislation to eliminate or consolidate about 500 grant programs, an increase in waivers to allow state and local governments to bypass Federal regulations, and the appointment of a Cabinet member in charge of overseeing the process.
 
Hard Task Lies Ahead
 But the Clinton Administration will be forced to handle another familiar problem the moment the ambitious plans are announced.
Mr. Clinton must push this latest initiative despite the inertia of bureaucrats, lawmakers and lobbyists satisfied with the status quo, while at the same time promoting important proposals on health care and international trade that opponents say will increase taxes and cost jobs.
"It's not that his Administration is going to stand or fall over whether the procurement system is streamlined," said William Kristol, a conservative Republican who was Vice President Dan Quayle's chief of staff. "But politically it's very important for him."
Clinton Administration officials hope that by providing evidence that they really intend to clean up the Government, Republicans can be wooed, Ross Perot quieted and debts repaid to senators, like Bob Kerrey, who provided the crucial budget vote in part on the basis of high REGO hopes. But Washington bookshelves are full of the dusty fruit of previous efforts to streamline the Government.
"Some describe it as pressure," Mr. Gore said in an interview in the characteristically cautious manner that makes him seem such a polar opposite to Bill Clinton. "We view it as opportunity."
At the least, it will be another opportunity for Mr. Gore to prove how central he has become to the Clinton Administration. Officials said Mr. Gore had played a central role in developing environmental policy, budget strategy, staff maneuvering and the politics of defending the President.
His constant proximity to the President has become a running White House joke. When the White House staff gave Mr. Clinton a birthday party recently, Mr. Gore gave Mr. Clinton a life-sized cardboard cut-out of himself, suggesting that the stiff figure could keep him from getting lonely as he set out on trips around the country without his trusty sidekick nearby.
It got a big laugh, which Mr. Gore liked. He has grown fond of mocking himself, and uses his own supposed shortcomings as a sort of humanizing shield to deflect criticism or questions he does not want to answer.
Such was the case when he was asked to say, prematurely, how much money the streamlining initiative will save. Self-consciously, he began to spin out jokes that the comedian Jay Leno has told about his stiffness and his dancing style. Quickly, his press secretary, hovering nearby, joined in.
Reminded that he had not answered the question about cost savings, he demurred.
"I've tried to avoid any numerical estimates on the savings that are coming out of this, other than to say I'm confident they will be significant," he said. And that is all he will say.
Mr. Gore and his aides have already begun to lower expectations about how sweeping the REGO plan will be. Mr. Clinton is expected to sign a number of executive orders aimed at reducing waste in the Government when he presents Mr. Gore's report on Sept. 7. But Mr. Gore also warned that some of the more far-reaching solutions might not occur for eight or 10 years.
Mr. Gore, who spent 16 years in Congress, seemed to notice a storm brewing in February, when he noted how few Republicans applauded the President's economic speech to a joint session of Congress.
"Political change has sometimes been described as the metaphor of a sailboat tacking against the wind," he told reporters the next day. "When one side comes up out of the water, it's a vivid image. That visual image and that metaphor reminds me very much of what happened in the chamber last night. I saw the mirror image of it during the beginning of the Reagan era, when one side of the chamber stands and applauds wildly and the other side sits with their hands folded in their laps.
"Visually the image is very much that of a great ship changing course, with one side out of the water and the other, sort of sinking."
 
Easy to Talk About
 Mr. Gore made those comments six months before he cast the tie-breaking votes on the President's economic package. Bipartisanship, he acknowledges, is a lot easier to talk about than it is to accomplish.
Among the props Mr. Gore uses to promote his effort to reinvent government is a moth-eaten old wool glove knitted from mohair produced in part because of Federal subsidies that protect goat farmers.
Mr. Clinton had proposed eliminating the mohair subsidy in his budget, but it survived, saved by two lawmakers from Texas, Senator Phil Gramm, a Republican, and Representative Charles W. Stenholm, a Democrat. Neither man voted for the budget, even with the subsidy restored.
"There is absolutely no justification for it whatsoever except politics," Mr. Gore said through gritted teeth.
But the gloves are not his favorite story.
Leaping out of the wing chair in his West Wing office to rifle through the props during an interview, he reached for a heavy glass ash tray.
"Not ash trays," he explained, flipping through a manual of purchasing guidelines. "Ash receivers, tobacco, desk-type."
In order to meet Government standards, he read, the ash tray must, when dropped, break into "a number of irregular pieces, not greater than 35, and it must not dice."
The Vice President breaks off, exasperated. "It's crazy!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vice President Al Gore has been given the awesome task of reinventing government by squeezing waste and excessive regulation out of the bureaucracy in Washington. He held a few of the briefing books assembled by his group of 1,000 people assigned to help in the research. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
