HEADLINE: GlenFed Stockholders Back Bailout, Ceding Most Equity

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
In the largest private-sector bailout of a distressed savings and loan, GlenFed Inc. said yesterday that it had completed a plan to raise $425 million in new capital. Shareholders of the ailing California savings institution narrowly approved the plan, under which they are to give up most of their interest in the company to keep it from being seized by Federal regulators.
GlenFed is the parent of Glendale Federal Bank, the country's fifth-largest savings institution, which faces a takeover by the Office of Thrift Supervision if it does not meet minimum capital standards by Sept. 30. The bank must raise its core capital from 2.65 percent of its assets to more than 4.5 percent. If this goes as intended, Glendale Federal would have core capital of 4.81 percent. 
 Analysts said GlenFed was fortunate that the deadline came at a time when many investors were eagerly buying new securities from banks.
"Six months ago, this deal would be have been difficult to complete," said Stephen J. Trafton, GlenFed's chairman. "And it was difficult enough as it was."
Under the complex plan, which was approved by only 53 percent of the shares outstanding, existing stockholders will receive 2 percent of the shares of the recapitalized company. Holders of GlenFed bonds and preferred stock will get a total of 18 percent of the shares, and the remaining 80 percent will be sold for $250 million.
In addition, the company last night sold $175 million in new convertible preferred stock to institutional investors.
The stock and bond holders will also receive warrants allowing them to buy shares of the company for $9 each. If all of these are exercised, it would raise $81 million of the new equity. GlenFed has received binding commitments from institutional investors, mainly mutual funds, to buy enough additional shares to raise the full $250 million.
Many analysts were astounded at the willingness of investors to put new money into a company that has not earned a profit since 1990 and will probably just break even this year.
"This deal is not cheap," said Gary Gordon, an analyst for Paine Webber, who said he would not recommend buying GlenFed shares at $9. He calculated that the stock would sell for about 70 percent of its fully diluted book value while similar companies sell for 50 percent of book value.
"Investors are starved for yield and they are willing to take unusual risks to get it," said an investment banker at a Wall Street firm.
Mr. Trafton said, however, that the ability of the company to raise the new capital was the best sign of a revival. "Despite the many vocal people who said this is a dead institution," he continued, "the recapitalization clearly speaks well for the perceived value of the company to investors and their perception of the economy and how that will affect us."
The transaction, which will merge the holding company into the bank, will have the effect of creating one new share of stock for every 10 existing shares. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, GlenFed shares closed unchanged at 93.75 cents.
Under the plan's provisions, existing shareholders will receive four new shares for each 100 they now own.
The convertible preferred stock, which was underwritten by the First Boston Corporation and Friedman, Billings, Ramsey & Company of Washington, D.C., pays a dividend of 8.75 percent. That is far higher than the 6 percent rate of a recent similar issue by H. F. Ahmanson & Company, the nation's largest savings institution, which is in much better financial health than GlenFed.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Decline 1.8%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing claims for state unemployment benefits fell last week by 6,000, or about 1.8 percent, to 325,000, the Labor Department reported today. The figure compares with 331,000, a figure that was revised, for the previous week.
Private economists had expected the number of first-time claims to rise to 333,000 for the latest week, which ended on Saturday. 
 The Labor Department said its four-week moving average of initial claims also declined, falling to 347,500 from 354,250.
The number of people filing for unemployment compensation under a special Federal program slipped to 37,171 from 41,443.

HEADLINE: Review/Dance;
In Celebration of Philadelphia

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
In a continuing celebration of Philadelphia and its artists, Lincoln Center Out of Doors presented three soloists and one company on Wednesday afternoon at the Fountain Plaza. All were winners of Pew Fellowships in the Arts.
To judge from the three solos that opened the program, dance in Philadelphia is a matter of quiet, rather abstracted musings on movement and its expressiveness. Steve Krieckhaus's "Entering and Spreading," performed to a peaceful hum of a score by Steve Berkowitz, offered a chance to watch a gifted artist work his way through the smallest curls, leans and lilting walks. The solo was a minimalist journey through time, with surprisingly strong dynamic changes and even a sense of building drama given the refinement and slow pace of the dance. 
 Mr. Krieckhaus is a dance poet whose medium is air. He does not jump through it, but rather establishes the feeling and buoyancy of air with the slight rise of a foot at the start of a pivot and with an even slighter tilt backward of the head, as if to let the sun and breeze caress his face for a moment.
Ilse Pfeifer has a compelling way of making everyday moves seem slightly comical as well as dancy. In "The Wondrous Endeavor of Isabella," she appeared to be a voyager through history and the world. But the solo, danced to music by Peter Price with a text spoken by Ms. Pfeifer, needed a much simpler setting and a better sound system.
In contrast, Karen McMahon looked like a caryatid in motion, sculptured, perhaps, by Henry Moore, in "Between Blue Rock." Set to music by Brian Eno, the solo was a thing of pleasingly blunt, thick body shapes. But it needed editing.
The program ended with a burst of vivid African music and dance from the Ibeji Performing Arts Company. The 12 beautifully costumed performers, who included four charming little girls, stood out for their precise and subtle way with rhythmic changes in "Lengjengo," an initiation dance, and "Econcon," a harvest and hunting tableau, from West Africa. Somehow, the sense of a village square and ceremony was created and the two adventurous and comic stilt-dancers featured in the closing segment had the audience as wide-eyed as children. Ibeji is directed by Hodari Banks and Jeannine Osayande.

HEADLINE: Review/Rock;
Edgy, Cool Steely Dan Back on Stage and Tour

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
As timing goes, now would hardly seem to be the right moment for the first Steely Dan tour since 1974, which came to Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night. Pop music has veered sharply away from everything the group's core, Donald Fagen and Walter Becker, cared about most.
Instead of Steely Dan's cool, subtle, meticulous, elegantly ironic songs, matching oblique lyrics to harmonically ambiguous jazz chords, the rock mainstream has turned toward noise, simplicity and blunt impact. Where Mr. Becker and Mr. Fagen could agonize for months over perfecting a smooth transition, hip-hop has brought sudden jump-cuts instead. The band's influence has survived mostly in pop-jazz tunes that saunter along, half-heard, on background-music radio stations. Steely Dan camouflaged its subversive edge a little too well. 
 But the fact that there's nothing like Steely Dan around has built up a demand; its Madison Square Garden show sold out in 40 minutes to an audience that included few people under 30. Mr. Fagen, Steely Dan's singer, recently released an album, "Kamakiriad" (Warner Brothers), that was produced by Mr. Becker, and Mr. Becker is working on his own album and collaborating on songs again with Mr. Fagen. Mr. Becker even sang two new songs, revealing a plaintive voice that had been unheard since the band's first albums. Onstage, the revived Steely Dan doesn't care about being unfashionable; the band plays as if its private musical sphere is the only one worth inhabiting.
Mr. Becker, on guitar, and Mr. Fagen, on keyboards, have always been wise guys, and the show had some typically inside jokes; opening with an instrumental version of "The Royal Scam" (a reference to reunion tours in general?), pointing out that the hall wasn't the original Madison Square Garden (lest anyone carp that the band wasn't the original Steely Dan), introducing Mr. Fagen as Tristan Fabriani (the pseudonymous author of liner notes on the band's first album, "Can't Buy a Thrill" from 1972) and Mr. Becker as Gustav Mahler. It didn't play the song everyone might have expected: "Do It Again."
Hearing the songs again only underscored Steely Dan's range and finesse. Steely Dan wrote about aging ("Hey Nineteen"), psychotic killers ("Third World Man"), stock-market crashes ("Black Friday"), Orientalism ("Bodhisattva") and even more enigmatic subjects with telegraphic economy; the entire lyric of "Green Earrings" includes only 47 words, yet suggests a complex tale of romance and betrayal. ("The Fall of '92," a new Becker-Fagen song sung by Mr. Becker, was uncharacteristically blunt, calling the George Bush Administration "Nazis in Washington.") Mr. Becker and Mr. Fagen also prized musical ingenuity, making every detail gleam; the few sustained notes in the introduction to "Josie," for instance, create almost unbearable suspense, while "My Old School" proves that it's possible to steal from soul music without simply copying it.
The show was generous, with two sets adding up to more than two-and-a-half hours of music, including some instrumentals by the band. The touring group, with the guitarist Drew Zingg, has polished the songs in the style of the group's 1977 album "Aja" (MCA); the group includes three saxophonists who lace the songs with riffs and responses and take dramatic solos. Steely Dan concentrated on its later material, including most of "Aja," although only its 1974 masterpiece, "Pretzel Logic" (MCA), was unrepresented.
Many of the songs the band chose are based on the blues; verses vamp on the basic chords, then choruses take off on unlikely chromatic tangents. Songs from "Kamakiriad" also used that strategy, but with less distinctive melodies than the older songs, though the rhythms still cruised along. Steely Dan's principals were and are connoisseurs of grooves; each vamp, even at slow and medium tempos, was lifted by a different syncopation, with Peter Erskine on drums and Tom Barney on bass both providing muscle and finesse.
For most songs, the group recreated arrangements from the albums, stretching them with solos for Mr. Zingg, Warren Bernhardt on piano or the saxophonists (Cornelius Bumpus, Chris Potter and Bob Sheppard). But the band couldn't resist tampering with "Reelin' in the Years," from 1972; it moved the song's famous twin-guitar line to saxophones, and where that line had repeated the saxophones skewed it to imply stranger, jazzier harmonies. The audience roared approval for the change. It may be a reunion tour, but with Steely Dan the payoff is in craftsmanship, not nostalgia.
Steely Dan is to perform Tuesday and Wednesday at Jones Beach, and at the Meadowlands on August 27.

HEADLINE: Champion Freedom in Peru

 BODY:
Peru's present version of democracy is the most restricted in South America, thanks to President Alberto Fujimori's 1992 coup that abolished an elected congress and intimidated critical voices in the press. And its human rights record is also the continent's worst, as Mr. Fujimori's actions to eliminate judicial independence and abolish procedural safeguards compound problems generated by a notoriously abusive military.
Prisoners are often held incommunicado, tried in secrecy before faceless judges and denied effective legal representation. And while fewer people mysteriously "disappear" from streets and villages than in the recent past, many still do, often with apparent military involvement. 
 By withholding most foreign aid since the coup, America has armed itself with what could be an effective tool for expanding the scope of freedom in Peru. But the Administration's proposed human rights conditions for releasing much of that aid are disappointingly weak, settling mainly for promises of improvement rather than hard specifics.
Senator Patrick Leahy and Representative David Obey, who head the relevant foreign aid subcommittees in each house, rightly ask the Administration to press harder. The most important changes they seek concern imposing greater accountability on the armed forces and insuring access to independent international legal experts.
America ought not to simply walk away from Peru in disgust. There have been some positive changes since the coup, like continued economic reform, and some modest political liberalization, like the election of a constituent assembly. The U.S. also has an interest in engaging the Peruvian authorities on areas of mutual interest, like narcotics control.
But human rights must remain a central concern. Economic and political reform cannot thrive without the rule of law. And an unaccountable army cannot be a reliable partner in drug interdiction. America is the most powerful potential champion Peru's human rights victims can look to. The Clinton Administration should not let them down.

HEADLINE: LETTER;
Raise Capital Gains Tax and Cut Deficit

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The extraordinary buoyancy of the stock market, now trading at its highest levels, gives the Government an opportunity to reduce the deficit without hampering economic growth.
Americans are estimated to hold something like $1.25 trillion in unrealized capital gains. The wealthy, who hold most of this, don't need to sell to pay the rent or other living expenses. They will hold on to their appreciated assets -- and pay no capital gains taxes, perhaps ever -- unless they have incentive to do so. 
 Lowering the capital gains tax does not provide the needed incentive, but an increase does. In 1978-82 the tax was cut in half, from 49 percent to 24 percent, but not much happened. Taxable gains rose slightly, sank, edged up again. But in 1986, when a tax rise from 20 percent to 28 percent was announced for the beginning of 1987, taxable gains more than doubled, from $200 billion in 1985 to $410 billion in 1986, as people took their long-held gains before the increase took effect.
Raising the rate does not hamper economic growth. During 1982-85 the tax was 20 percent, and capital gains tax revenue averaged $19.8 billion. However, after the raise to 28 percent in 1987, revenue increased 60 percent, averaging $31.8 billion in 1988-91. Since the 1987 increase, stock market prices and volume have also risen.
Raising the capital gains tax does not hamper economic growth because 97 percent of the action on Wall Street consists of trades of old shares, which is not an investment to economists. It is a transfer of an asset. No money goes to the company that issued the security, which helps explain why genuine investment in the United States lags so far behind such competitors as Japan and Germany.
What should be done is to announce today that the capital gains tax will increase to, say, 40 percent, effective next Jan. 1. This will trigger a wave of selling. If shareholders and owners of other types of assets cash in three-fourths of their $1.25 trillion unrealized capital gain, that creates $940 billion in taxable capital gains. At 28 percent, that could take a big bite out of the deficit.
 
HAROLD PEPPERELL
 
Tiburon, Calif., Aug. 9, 1993

HEADLINE: Letter;
Demise of Egyptian Tourism Is Exaggerated

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Islamic Guerrillas Take to the Hills in Egypt" (news article, Aug. 12) states that, as a result of extremist activities, tourism to Egypt has been "wiped out." This is untrue. From January to June 1993, 1,197,753 foreigners visited Egypt, 74,695 from the United States. In June alone, 201,119 foreigners visited the country. 
 While these figures represent a decline of 19.4 percent over the same period last year, tourism revenue still contributes significantly to Egypt's economy. There is also some evidence that the tourism decline slowed between April and June over the same months a year ago.
We believe this is because increased security precautions have successfully halted incidents directed at tourists. In recent months there have been no attacks on tourists, and no foreigner has been killed on Egyptian soil since Feb. 26, the day that a bomb exploded at the World Trade Center.
 
ABDEL-MONEIM RASHAD
 
Regional Director
Egyptian Tourist Authority
New York, Aug. 13, 1993

HEADLINE: BUDGET DIRECTOR OF NEW YORK CITY IS FORCED TO QUIT

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The New York City Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, resigned at the request of the Mayor yesterday, one day after a city investigation determined that he had shown favoritism to a company seeking a $150 million contract to collect parking ticket fines.
Mayor David N. Dinkins announced Mr. Michael's resignation yesterday at City Hall after a tense day of meetings with his top staff to fashion a response to the report, which asserted that his administration gave the company, Lockheed Information Management Services, unusual time and attention and special treatment. 
 Mr. Dinkins, effectively accepting one critical finding of the report, said Mr. Michael had been "overzealous" in arguing forcibly within the administration for accepting the company's proposal to take over many responsibilities of the Parking Violations Bureau.
 
Swept Up by a Promise
 The report found no evidence of criminal activity by Mr. Michael or any other administration officials, but it suggested that they had been swept up by Lockheed's promise that it could vastly increase the city's collections of unpaid parking tickets.
In sacrificing Mr. Michael, Mr. Dinkins moved to quiet demands for action -- from City Council members and political opponents -- before they caused further damage to his administration or his re-election campaign. The Mayor, who canceled the contract Wednesday night, said he decided not to take any action now against three other high-ranking officials who were criticized to a lesser degree in the report, including his First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel.
After a late-night meeting with his closest political advisers, Mr. Dinkins requested Mr. Michael's resignation yesterday morning in a two-hour meeting in the Mayor's basement office at City Hall, officials said. Even as he ended Mr. Michael's tenure, the Mayor praised his skill in balancing the city's budgets during a bitter recession.
 
Effectiveness 'Compromised'
 "Phil Michael and I mutually agree that his ability to be as effective as we need in these very difficult fiscal times has been greatly compromised by the report of the Department of Investigation," Mr. Dinkins said. "But that ought not to diminish the contributions that he has made."
Mr. Dinkins would not elaborate on his decision, but his aides said he was worried that Mr. Michael's credibility had been so badly damaged by the report, which suggested that he had been less than forthright with investigators on some questions, that he could no longer be effective as budget director. The aides added that it was a sensitive time because of the election, but that the Mayor would have made the same decision in a different year.
For his part, Mr. Michael said he accepted the Mayor's judgment that he could no longer be effective, but denied he had done anything illegal and continued to defend his actions.
"I did nothing wrong," Mr. Michael said. "My only sin was trying to raise money for the city of New York. I agree that is exactly what I did and I wished I had tried to raise more."
 
Steisel Is Also CriticizedXxx
 The First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, was also criticized in the report, which said he failed to rigorously study the question of whether the city should have private companies do the the work of the Parking Violations Bureau in the first place.
Mr. Michael's decision to step down came on a day when some City Council members and the Mayor's political opponents called for a wider shake-up in the administration.
The Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, quickly seized on the report as a political weapon, saying it was evidence of poor management and ethical lapses in Mr. Dinkins's administration. He called on the Mayor to immediately relieve Mr. Steisel of his duties, including the huge survey of asbestos in the city's schools that began two weeks ago.
"With this cloud hanging over Norman Steisel, I would imagine the Mayor is going to have to remove him for a time during the asbestos removal and put someone else there until these questions are cleared up," Mr. Giuliani said on a morning talk show. "It is really pretty astounding that we've got the highest level in the Dinkins administration appearing to know nothing of what they were doing with what was in fact the largest contracting-out project of the Dinkins administration."
To offset the attack from his Republican opponents, Mr. Dinkins and his aides have tried to pin some of the responsibility for the affair on Mr. Giuliani, arguing that when Mr. Giuliani was a United States Attorney in 1987, he wrote a letter to the city's lawyers that gave Lockheed Information a clean bill of health.
In fact, in the letter, Mr. Giuliani merely gave his approval to a settlement of a civil lawsuit the city had reached with the Lockheed subsidiary -- which was then known as Datacom Systems -- because company executives had cooperated with Federal prosecutors. The letter does not refer to whether the city should do business with the company.
Carol O'Cleireacain, who has been the city Finance Director since 1990, will take over as Budget Director immediately, Mr. Dinkins said.
Mr. Michael, 53, was appointed budget director in 1990 after serving for a year as the executive director of the State Financial Control Board. A native of San Francisco who began his public career as a trial lawyer in the United States Justice Department in Washington, Mr. Michael came to New York in 1972 as the Deputy Commissioner for Trials in the Police Department. He was appointed a deputy commissioner in the Department of Investigation in 1978 and Finance Commissioner in 1989.
Mr. Dinkins reached his decision after a night and a day of tense and anguished meetings with his closest aides while reporters clustered outside his office in a phalanx of cameras, notepads and inquiring faces.
Mr. Michael arrived at the Mayor's office at 10:30 A.M. and was closeted with Mr. Dinkins for more than two hours. He strode out of City Hall at about 12:30 P.M., refusing to comment to reporters.
Lockheed Management Information Services is a business unit of the Lockheed Corporation, a major manufacturer of aerospace equipment and military contractor that is based in California. Lockheed says the unit is a small part of its portfolio of businesses, accounting for less than 13 percent of its sales and less than 3 percent of its profits in 1992.
 
'Showed Favoritism'
 Investigators said that Mr. Michael "showed favoritism" to the Lockheed subsidiary by meeting repeatedly with the company's executives, reporting back to them about talks among top city officials and arguing forcefully within the administration that the city should shift much of the Parking Violations Bureau to private business to save money.
Investigators also accused Mr. Michael of trying to coerce the Transportation Commissioner, Lucius J. Riccio, to grant Lockheed Services a small, related contract. Mr. Michael, the report said, told Mr. Riccio he would restore some cuts to the Transportation Department budget if Mr. Riccio approved the contract.
While it did not suggest there were bribes or criminal activity, the report harshly questioned the decisions of several other top Dinkins aides that ended up tilting the competition in favor of the company. The report found substantial evidence that Ellen Baer, chief of staff to the First Deputy Mayor, violated the City Charter when she was interviewed for a job with Lockheed while taking part in talks with other city officials about the drafting of the contract proposal.
The report also determined that Mr. Steisel had made the crucial decision to broaden the bid specifications to include contracting of other operations besides collecting payments, which the report said gave Lockheed an edge in the bidding. Mr. Steisel made the decision in June 1991, a day after meeting with two influential lobbyists for the company, James Capalino, a former aide to Mayor Edward I. Koch, and Basil A. Paterson, a close friend of Mr. Dinkins.
 
Lockheed Also Assailed
 The report, which followed a five-month investigation, also suggested that Lockheed Services had failed to disclose to the city that three current officials of the company had been involved in conversations about bid-rigging at the Parking Violations Bureau in 1985.
Investigators also found that Lockheed had misled the city when it certified that it had not tried to discourage other companies from bidding. In fact, the report says, Lockheed had reached a broad agreement in 1989 with another company, American Management Systems, that in effect took it out of the competiton.
Since acquiring Datacom Systems in 1984, and swiftly being engulfed in New York's scandal, Lockheed Management Information Services has grown rapidly as a provider of computerized services to state, local and Federal agencies. The company said yesterday that it had 130 government contracts, for work in processing water bills, family support payments and other government programs.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 26, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in some editions on Friday and a picture caption on Saturday about Carol O'Cleireacain, who was appointed to replace New York City's Budget Director, misstated her title. She is to be Budget Director, not interim Budget Director.

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Agrees to Renew Talks on Plans for New York Coliseum

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority told the Dinkins administration yesterday that it has accepted the city's suggestion for further talks over the New York Coliseum development, which has been stalled by disputes over the project's size.
In a letter to Mayor David N. Dinkins, the chairman of the M.T.A., Peter E. Stangl, agreed to meet again with the site's developer, Mortimer B. Zuckerman. 
 But he also said he was "surprised and disappointed" that the Mayor's Deputy for Finance and Economic Development, Barry F. Sullivan, had in an earlier letter to Mr. Stangl accused Mr. Stangl of being unwilling to "engage in constructive dialogue" with the developer.
Mr. Zuckerman, who bought The Daily News in January, has had an option to develop the site at 59th Street and Columbus Circle since 1985, through his company Boston Properties. But his plans were delayed by court challenges until last September, when the downturn in New York's real-estate market made his original plans for the site impractical. Since September, Mr. Zuckerman has been talking with the M.T.A. and with city officials about cutting the development's size and cutting the price that he would pay for the land from the 1985 level.
 
'Less Favorable to the City'

 Because of the complicated ownership arrangement for the 3.4-acre plot that now holds an exhibition hall, office building and parking ramp, the city and the M.T.A. must both sign off on any agreement.
Mr. Stangl, responding yesterday to Mr. Sullivan's letter, wrote to Mayor Dinkins that the latest Zuckerman proposal, made in early August, "is even less favorable to the city and the M.T.A. than the version we were negotiating in June."
Mr. Stangl's letter said he had objections to the new Zuckerman plan, which he said included reducing the purchase price below what he said is the site's current value to the M.T.A., and breaking it into a two-stage project that could delay revenues for the M.T.A.
Mr. Stangl agreed to Mr. Sullivan's suggestion that further negotiations proceed with the aid of Vincent Tese,Commissioner of the State Department of Economic Development. He also urged the city to set a closing date for the sale to "stimulate serious negotiations" and added: "I do not believe that the city should allow Boston Properties to extend its free option on this site indefinitely at the expense of farepayers and taxpayers."

HEADLINE: Deep South and Down Home, But It's a Ghetto All the Same

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JONESTOWN, Miss.

 BODY:
This forlorn little town of rickety shotgun shacks and 1,467 people, surrounded by the table-top-flat cotton fields of northwest Mississippi, has the spent air of a place that history has passed by.
But throughout this forgotten corner of America and in the other poorest parts of the South, hamlets like Jonestown are writing a bitter epilogue to integration. Small towns that were once economically stable and racially mixed are becoming pockets of poverty and overwhelmingly black -- 75 to 100 percent so.
 
100 With Jobs
 The pattern is so striking that some experts say a new kind of ghetto is evolving: rural instead of urban, but sharing many conditions of the inner city: white flight, black poverty, a disappearing job base, reliance on government welfare payments, rising crime and social isolation. 
 The phenomenon is taking some of the luster off one of the great success stories of the South, its rising tide of black elected officials. Almost 20 percent of black elected officials nationwide come from Mississippi and Alabama alone. But many of them have come to political power only to inherit the dust of economic abandonment.
"You're in charge, but how much can you do?" said Bobbie Walker, who recently lost her bid for re-election after four years as mayor here. "We have 1,476 people, but we may have 100 who actually work. Almost all the stores have closed. The town is basically broke. People expect miracles because there are black people in office, but this town is so strapped, and the tax base is so small, you can barely stay afloat."
What is happening in towns like this is happening in small towns across America. But here, in the upper reaches of the Mississippi River Delta, it is has a peculiarly Southern twist, one that largely reflects the South's historic concentrations of poor blacks, most of them dependent on an agricultural economy that no longer needs as many workers because of decades of increasing mechanization.
But equally striking is how many of the issues raised in isolated towns like Jonestown reflect the national debate over the urban ghettos, particularly the role of racism in creating and sustaining them, and the future of welfare and other programs for the poor.
Charles S. Aiken, a geographer at the University of Tennessee, described the phenomenon in a 1990 paper on an area south of here. "A new type of black ghetto has emerged in the Yazoo Delta since 1960," he wrote. "To many whites, the ghetto towns have become nonplaces, areas of black population that are to be isolated and ignored, just as the black residential areas of municipalities traditionally were isolated and ignored."
 
Years of Inequality
 The Mississippi Delta has always been based on inequality. The fortunes of the region's planters and white working class were supported for most of its history by the labor of black slaves, then of black sharecroppers. Until integration, whites controlled all the towns, except for Mound Bayou and Winstonville, which were all black.
In Jonestown, blacks outnumbered whites even before integration. The 1950 census showed that of the town's 741 people, two-thirds were black. But, particularly after the schools integrated in the 1960's, young whites began to leave, either for big cities like Memphis or Jackson or the larger towns like Clarksdale or Cleveland. No whites moved in to replace them, and the white population began to dwindle.
Meanwhile, the black population has steadily increased, though economic opportunity has not. Today there is only a handful of residents in what is left of the white section of town; the population is 95 percent black, primarily the elderly and young women with children. No one can imagine the balance swinging back.
The figures vary from town to town, but the trend is similar throughout most of the rural Delta. There is Glendora, 51 percent black in 1950, 90 percent black now; Friars Point, 66 percent black in 1950, 90 percent now; Shelby, 62 percent black in 1950, 87 percent black now. In 1950, the small town of Sledge had the smallest percentage of blacks in the Delta, 19 percent. Now blacks make up 56 percent of the town.
 
The Old South Rising?
 To many blacks, the rural ghetto is the racism of the Old South in a new form, now employing economic deprivation instead of Jim Crow laws.
"There's racism all over the United States, but it's not as systematically oriented and as ideologically grounded in religion and Southern tradition as it is here in Mississippi," said Bruce Williams, a sociologist at the University of Mississippi who has studied the small Delta towns. "The rural elite is interested in maintaining the status quo, and that's it."
In fact, except for the general decay, the economic hierarchy in Jonestown is not much different from what it was during segregation. The only major business in town is the Delta Oil Mill, a farmers cooperative that produces $22 million in cottonseed oil a year. All the clerical and supervisory jobs are held by whites, and many of the laboring jobs are held by blacks. There are still blacks working in the cotton fields but none at the small Jonestown branch of the Sunburst Bank.
What has changed most is the degree to which Jonestown exists almost solely because of social welfare programs.
"If you're not old enough for Social Security, or sick enough for S.S.I., or don't have children for A.F.D.C., you're left out in the rain," said Mrs. Walker, referring to Federal relief programs. "There's nothing else here."
 
Other Forces Involved
 But many people here, black and white alike, see something more complicated than just racism at work. Small towns are withering on the vine around the country, and in the battle to attract jobs, few places have less resources to work with than impoverished, poorly educated, rural black towns like this one.
"I think race may enter into it," said State Senator Willie Simmons, who is black and who represents part of the Delta, "but race is probably not as great a factor as it is with the location and the lack of resources. These small communities don't have the resources to compete with larger communities."
And if racism, first in the form of slavery and then of the legalized segregation of Jim Crow, is ingrained in the history here, many say that that alone is no longer what's holding the town back.
Quincy Bryant is the last white store owner in Jonestown and as such, from a battered green recliner, presides over the last reminder of the town's more prosperous past. His business is called Q&B Used Furniture, but it is really an old-time general store where Mr. Bryant spends his days selling Snickers bars and Super Soakers, nails and toothpaste, underwear and wigs, bantering amiably with his customers and doing magic tricks for the children who congregate there.
 
White Family Leaves
 Mr. Bryant raised his six children in Jonestown, but he now lives in Clarksdale, and all his children live elsewhere. He is committed enough to the town that he has promised to buy pillows and drapes from a fledgling company Mrs. Walker is trying to get off the ground. But he said the crime and social decay in the town would dissuade almost any businessman from locating here. He said youths recently broke into his store and stole $2,800 in merchandise. Now he has installed a new alarm system for $1,000.
"This used to be a nice little town," he said. "Now if something isn't done about the crime, there isn't going to be a town. People have been through, looking at putting in businesses, but if you wanted to put in a 7-Eleven here, you'd have to have a night watchman on duty 24 hours a day. People look the town over and they get scared."
The grim straits of many of the towns evoke all the racial stereotypes of the old South. Many whites are not reluctant to take note of the towns' decline as blacks have taken control.
"This is a town of 200 whites and 2,400 welfare recipients," said David Favi, the owner of David's Diner in nearby Shelby. "They're not interested in working. All they care about is the welfare check."
 
Town's Own Problem's
 To many, what is happening is one more cruel twist in a long history of black deprivation in one of the poorest parts of America. But if there is something perverse in blotting out history and blaming blacks for the ills of the Delta, many blacks agree that some of the most grievous wounds are now being inflicted from within.
Donal Lee Burnett, owner of the Jonestown Service Station, a combination service station, fishing shop and barbecue joint, is one of the few black businessmen in Jonestown. He takes the existence of racism as a given. But when asked about the problems of Jonestown, he begins with the 14-year-old mothers, the 30-year-old grandmothers and the family decay he sees all around him. He knows Jonestown needs jobs, but he does not think economic opportunity alone is the answer.
"People have to take responsibility for the community they live in," he said. "I don't see that here. If businesses came here and people aren't responsible enough to work, you're not going to get anywhere. You have too many people waiting for the welfare checks. If you were lying in bed, and someone kept bringing you food, so you never had to get up, what would you do? You'd probably just lie there."
There are glimpses of hope throughout the Delta, like the nuns from Minnesota who have opened a health clinic here, or the home-building by Habitat for Humanity here and elsewhere. To wander into the town of Ruleville and see the Ruleville Beautification Committee, including a white descendant of the town's founder and a group of blacks and whites planting periwinkles along the town's main street, is to be reminded of how much real change has occurred and how hard some people are working to keep their towns alive.
But many people assume there are only two prospects for towns like this. The first is that they will wither and die. The second, perhaps even more dire, is that they will become permanent pockets of blight and despair.
"Martin Luther King said he wanted to go to the mountaintop," 64-year-old Bertha Saxton said as she stood among a crowd of young men milling in front of a local grocery in the midday heat. "But it seems every time we get near the mountaintop, someone's always pushing us back down."

HEADLINE: Charles Baldwin, 91, Ex-U.S. Ambassador

 BODY:
Charles F. Baldwin, a former United States Ambassador to Malaya, died at home in Cockeysville, Md., on Wednesday. He was 91.
The cause was cardiopulmonary arrest, his family said. 
 In 1961, President Kennedy named him Ambassador to Malaya, encompassing what is now Malaysia and Singapore. After retiring as ambassador in 1964 he served several years as the diplomat in residence at the University of Virginia.
His career in government began in 1927 in the Commerce Department. He served in the automotive division and Shipping Board Bureau and as the United States trade commissioner in Sydney, Australia.
In World War II he served as a Navy intelligence officer in London, reaching the rank of captain.
Joining the State Department in 1945, he held posts in the embassies in Chile, Norway and Italy. He was economic counselor in London, Consul General in Singapore and Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Economic Affairs.
In 1955, during a break in government service, Mr. Baldwin was a European officer in the Motion Picture Export Association of America.
Mr. Baldwin was born in Zanesville, Ohio. He grew up in Washington and graduated from Georgetown University.
His wife of 52 years, Helen, died four years ago.
His survivors include a son, C. Stephen Baldwin of Manhattan; a sister, Cordelia Baldwin of Washington, and eight grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Hunger Strikers Allowed to Ship Supplies to Cuba

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 21

 BODY:
A group of ministers who have staged a three-week hunger strike in a school bus along the Texas-Mexico border to protest the United States trade embargo against Cuba won permission today to deliver supplies to the island nation.
The agreement was reached after two days of talks between representatives of Pastors for Peace and the Federal Government, said Michelle Smith, a spokeswoman for the Treasury Department. 
 "We are pleased to have been able to work constructively with the Pastors for Peace to resolve the situation on the border at Laredo, Tex.," Ms. Smith said in a telephone interview from Washington.
Fourteen protesters began a hunger strike on July 30 at a customs station on the Texas-Mexico border inside a school bus that customs agents had impounded. The bus was part of a 95-vehicle convoy carrying about 100 tons of supplies bound for Cuba. The other vehicles had entered Mexico without incident the day before.
Customs Service officials said the bus had been impounded because the people on board had declared it an export in violation of the 33-year-old trade embargo against Cuba.
The Rev. Lucius Walker Jr., who left the bus on Thursday to begin negotiating with the Government, was not available for comment, but Federal officials said they believed the agreement meant that his hunger strike was over.
 
Shipments via Mexico
 Organizers said the convoy was carrying computers, medicine, wheelchairs, school supplies and other materials for Cuba. The supplies were to be shipped to Cuba from Mexico, which unlike the United States has no restrictions on such exports.
In announcing the agreement, the department said it had been assured that the World Council of Churches would oversee delivery of the supplies as humanitarian aid to a church in Havana.
Customs agents inspected the bus at the border in preparation for crossing.
"The bus is going to be on the way to Havana, Cuba," Ms. Smith said.
During the hunger strike, sympathizers have held demonstrations in 36 cities.
The pastors' group, which is based in Minnesota, contends the trade embargo against Cuba is wrong because Washington does not enforce similar sanctions on other nations that have worse human-rights records.
The protest came at a time when Cuba's leader, Fidel Castro, has stepped up calls for an end to the embargo. Mr. Castro, whose nation is trying to stave off economic collapse, has said he would like to enter direct negotiations with the United States to end the boycott.

HEADLINE: HEALTH INDUSTRY IS MOVING TO FORM SERVICE NETWORKS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Without waiting for details of President Clinton's health plan, hospitals, doctors and insurance companies around the country are already linking up to form the health care networks that Mr. Clinton is likely to propose as the foundation of a new medical system.
The health care market, not the Government, is the driving force behind these networks, which are being formed in New York and many other metropolitan areas. But doctors, hospital executives and insurers say they are also trying to position themselves for success under any legislation Congress might pass in the next 15 months. 
 The competition to establish these networks is being intensified by the belief that whoever moves first will be able to profit by controlling the shape of the new health system.
 
A Fixed Price
 In addition, many doctors have concluded that they will be left in the cold, without a significant source of patients or income, if they do not join a network. Insurance companies, fearing that Mr. Clinton's health plan will eliminate their ability to make money by selecting only the healthiest customers, are purchasing hospitals, clinics and doctors' practices so they can deliver and manage care, rather than just finance it.
The new networks typically offer a full spectrum of care, from treatment of minor infections to open-heart surgery, for a fixed price. Consumers, in theory, will no longer receive their care from a multitude of unconnected services.
The new networks resemble health maintenance organizations in some respects, but they are bigger than the typical H.M.O. These huge new conglomerates may include outpatient clinics, freestanding doctors' offices, nursing homes, hospices, home health agencies, retail pharmacies, drug treatment centers and medical equipment suppliers, as well as hospitals.
With nearly 40 percent of hospital beds empty, the American Hospital Association is exhorting its members to form "community care networks." The association's biweekly magazine, published since 1936 under the title "Hospitals," changed its name in June to add the phrase "& Health Networks."
 
'Integrated Delivery Network'
 Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, said, "In recent months, there has been an unprecedented wave of health care industry mergers, acquisitions and consolidations." He warned that this trend may restrict patients' ability to choose their doctors and the doctors' freedom to make medical decisions -- a concern shared by some consumer advocates.
Just this month eight hospitals in the St. Louis area, all either Roman Catholic or Baptist, announced that they were forming an "integrated delivery network" to cut costs and reduce duplication of services.
A model of the new vertically integrated organization is the network being formed by the Henry Ford Health System in Detroit, Mercy Health Services and Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Michigan.
The Michigan network, which includes at least 13 hospitals, will offer health care to groups of 100 employees or more for a fixed payment averaging $2,400 a year for an individual and $5,600 for a family. It promises that premiums will not rise more than 5 percent a year in 1994 or 1995.
New York Hospital, the main teaching hospital of Cornell University Medical College, is forming a network that includes Booth Memorial Medical Center and the Silvercrest Nursing Home in Queens, the Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn, and the Hospital for Special Surgery and Gracie Square psychiatric hospital in Manhattan.
 
Fee-for-Service Option
 George A. Vecchione, executive vice president of New York Hospital, and Stephen S. Mills, the head of its network, said the organization would offer care to employers in the New York City area, New Jersey and Connecticut. Employees can enroll in a health maintenance organization or get care in the customary way, on a fee-for-service basis.
These networks are just like the ones President Clinton wants to establish all over the country. Under his plan, initially outlined in the 1992 campaign, large purchasing groups, representing hundreds of thousands of consumers, would buy health care from large corporate networks of doctors and hospitals.
Many states, including Minnesota, Washington, Florida and Vermont, have recently passed laws encouraging formation of these networks, known as accountable health plans or integrated service networks.
Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of Ralph Nader's Health Research Group, said the proliferation of networks could harm consumers because insurance companies, in selecting doctors for their networks, often emphasize cost over quality.
The Medical Society of the District of Columbia is preparing a lawsuit against the local Blue Cross and Blue Shield plan to challenge the exclusion of hundreds of doctors from a network that serves many Federal employees. Dr. Harold Weiss, president of the society, said that the selection criteria, though secret, "appear to emphasize economic issues rather than quality."
Elsewhere, doctors complain that hospitals are putting pressure on them to join networks in which hospitals have the upper hand. Dr. Lee H. McCormick, a family practitioner in Pittsburgh, said: "There are a lot of good reasons for hospitals and physicians to work together. But hospitals are rushing in, taking charge, intimidating the physicians."
With improvements in medical technology, many procedures formerly done in hospitals are now done in doctors' offices. "Hospitals do not have patients," said Dr. McCormick. "They only have physicians who take care of patients. That's why hospitals are approaching physicians to work together; they have to. Their survival depends on it. Hospitals now need physicians more than we need them."
Rather than work for networks run by hospitals or insurance companies, doctors are organizing their own networks in some states. The South Carolina Medical Association is forming a statewide network of doctors that will negotiate contracts with employers and accept responsibility for controlling their health costs. The Medical Society of the State of New York is forming a similar network.
In South Carolina, the doctors will negotiate an annual health care spending goal for each company. If actual costs are below that goal, the doctors will share savings with the company. If costs exceed that amount, the doctors will forgo a portion of the income they would otherwise receive.
Hospitals have been merging and diversifying their activities for years. But the latest trend is different because the new networks are bigger and more tightly knit than the loose affiliations of the past. In addition, they are responding to new demands. Employers, the main source of health insurance coverage for workers in the United States, are encouraging formation of these networks so they can negotiate a single contract for the care of all their employees at a guaranteed price.
The trend toward networks of doctors and hospitals has probably gone further in Southern California than in any other part of the country. "Solo practitioners are getting to be increasingly rare out here," said Robert H. Calverley, a spokesman for the Los Angeles County Medical Association.
Dr. Ben Shwachman, an anesthesiologist and lawyer who is president of the Los Angeles association, said: "You can't just hang up a shingle, open the door and get patients any more. You have to get contracts, and contracts go through huge conglomerates formed by hospitals, physicians or insurance companies."
Dr. Shwachman said, "This trend has created a class of millionaire entrepreneur-physicians who own and operate the networks." In transactions between networks and insurance companies, he said, "the patients are moved around like cattle," even though they may receive good care.
Michael D. Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, a trade group that represents investor-owned hospitals, said there was "a whirlwind of activity" by hospitals and doctors trying to get ready for the new health care system envisioned by Mr. Clinton.
But Mr. Bromberg said that hospitals were at a disadvantage, compared with big insurance companies, because they do not have subscribers and generally do not have expertise in calculating premiums or bidding for the business of large employee groups. To be sure that these highly specialized tasks will be performed well, Mr. Bromberg said, hospitals may need to form joint ventures with insurance companies, including them as full partners in their networks.

It has started a network of health organizations under the direction of George A. Vecchione, executive vice president. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Higher Base Wage Urged

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
In a memorandum to President Clinton, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich has made a strong case for a 25-cent rise in the Federal minimum wage to $4.50 an hour and an automatic annual adjustment in the minimum wage linked to inflation, the Labor Department said today.
But Mr. Reich stopped short of recommending a specific course of action and said the agency would report on the pros and cons of such a policy before Oct. 20. 
 While Mr. Reich will almost certainly propose legislation along these lines, such legislation may not move forward this year. A rise in the minimum wage would attract strong opposition in Congress because it would raise business costs and might cause job losses, and the Administration's legislative agenda is already full.
 A minimum wage of $4.50 in 1994 "is a minimum prerequisite to reaching the goal of lifting families of four with full-time workers out of poverty," Mr. Reich wrote in the July 20 memorandum. The document was released first by the Employment Policies Institute, a business research group, and its authenticity was later confirmed by the Labor Department.
"If the minimum wage is not indexed, or if it is indexed at a lower level, the goal will not be achieved," Mr. Reich wrote. Indexing the minimum wage to the Consumer Price Index would mean that the minimum wage would go up each year at the same rate as inflation.
 Alan Krueger and David Card, economists at Princeton University, say a 25-cent increase would directly affect about five million workers who now earn from $4.25 an hour, the current minimum, to $4.50. More than two-thirds of these workers are 20 or older and about a third are in families with annual incomes of less than $12,500, roughly the poverty line for a family of four.
But making it more expensive for business to hire entry-level workers could cause business to replace some of these workers with machines or, more likely, a smaller number of more skilled workers.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
No Confirmation Is Offered On Saudi Aircraft Orders

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Despite signals this week from President Clinton that he helped get a $6.2 billion aircraft order from Saudi Arabia's national carrier for the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, no confirmation emerged yesterday.
Spokesmen at both companies had no comment on reports of the pending order, and officials at the Saudi Embassy in Washington said they had no announcement to make. 
 White House officials said that the President, who is vacationing on Martha's Vineyard, had encouraged King Fahd of Saudi Arabia to patronize the American aerospace industry but had not lobbied for any particular manufacturer.
"The President has said he would do all he could to promote U.S. aircraft and aircraft manufacturers," Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said in a briefing.
 
How to Divide the Pie
 News of the deal was announced Wednesday by Senator Patty Murray of Washington.
In addition, the United States Export-Import Bank has approved a tentative commitment to finance the potential sale of Boeing jetliners to Saudi Arabia.
"I would be astonished if the Saudi Government were to change its mind," said Wolfgang H. Demisch, an analyst at BT Securities. "I think this is a done deal."
Even so, there were some misgivings about the way the news of the order had leaked out, because it broke an industry rule of thumb that an order for airplanes from a specific manufacturer is never final until it is announced by the customer.
 
Premature Suggestion
 In the past, some deals have fallen apart at the last second. Several months ago, for example, a French official said that Airbus Industrie, the European manufacturing consortium that is the largest competitor to Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, would win orders for 44 jets from Saudi Arabia. This proved premature and some industry analysts believe it angered Saudi officials.
If anything were to happen to the reported United States deal it would be an embarrassment for President Clinton, who apparently involved himself personally in trying to draw the Saudi orders away from Airbus. Through speeches to Boeing employees and his appointment of a national commission to study the airline business, the President has shown a strong interest in the industry.
The Saudi order would be a welcome one for Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, both of which have cut thousands of workers in recent months. The order is the largest on the horizon for them.
Boeing stock closed yesterday at $39.50, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange; McDonnell Douglas closed at $83.75, up $1.75.

HEADLINE: Fed Affirmed Its Bias Toward Higher Rates

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 20

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's main policy-making committee voted in July to maintain its bias toward raising short-term interest rates, even though some members urged it to drop that bias because economic growth was so weak.
As Federal Reserve officials and private economists gathered in this Rocky Mountain resort for an annual conference, the economists were divided over whether the Fed's policy-making committee had maintained the bias when it met on Tuesday. 
 The Fed panel meets eight times a year but its deliberations are not disclosed until after the next meeting.
Several economists speculated that the Fed maintained its tilt toward higher rates because it was eager to convince financial markets that it wanted to keep inflation subdued. But others said they thought the Fed adopted a neutral stance because it was pleased by recent inflation reports but worried about slow growth. Federal Reserve officials refused to discuss what was decided at Tuesday's meeting.
According to a summary that the Federal Reserve released today of the July 6-7 meeting, the policy-making committee, known as the Federal Open Market Committee, voted 11 to 1 to continue its bias toward tighter rates. The action gives the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, the authority to raise rates somewhat without seeking board approval, although he usually consults board members before acting
At the July meeting, Wayne D. Angell, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, cast the dissenting vote, arguing that the central bank should raise interest rates immediately. He said that there was a disappointing lack of progress in reducing inflation and that monetary policy was overly expansive because the central bank's short-term interest rates, currently 3 percent, were less than the inflation rate.
Several committee members called for dropping the bias toward raising rates, suggesting that a neutral policy was more consistent with the weak growth and the subdued inflation being reported. But those members ended up voting with the majority after being convinced that if the committee abandoned that bias so soon after adopting it in May it "could convey a misleading impression" -- in the report's words -- that the Fed had become less committed to fighting inflation.
The central bank adopted the bias toward raising rates in May, when its members grew upset that inflation was running at an annual rate of more than 4 percent in the first four months of this year.
According to the summary of the July meeting, many Fed officials felt that the statistics pointed to a sustained rate of economic expansion -- a sentiment that may have been too optimistic because in late July the Commerce Department announced that the economy grew by a lackluster 1.6 percent in the second quarter.
The report of the July meeting said, "While current monetary policy seemed likely to support further economic expansion, the committee needed to remain alert to the potential for intensifying inflation."
Some members said that while the need for any change in policy seemed somewhat remote in coming months, the next policy move was more likely to be toward tightening rather than toward easing.
At the July meeting, the policy-making committee decided to put less stock in trying to meet certain targets for growth in the money supply. The members noted that the relationship between economic growth and growth in M-2 -- a broad definition of the money supply that includes cash in circulation and deposits in checking and savings accounts -- had largely broken down. A certain amount of growth in M-2 was no longer producing the expected rate of overall economic growth.
The committee considered, but rejected, relying on an even broader measure of the money supply: M-2 plus bond and stock mutual funds. The central bank concluded that that measure would be unreliable.
Federal Reserve officials said one reason M-2 had became such an unreliable yardstick was that millions of Americans had moved their money from savings and checking accounts, which are considered part of the money supply, into bond and stock mutual funds, which are not considered part of the money supply.

HEADLINE: D. Lee Bawden, 56; Washington Economist

 BODY:
Dr. D. Lee Bawden, senior economist at the Urban Institute in Washington, who wrote more than 70 papers and books evaluating social programs, died on Wednesday at his home in Great Falls, Va. He was 56.
The cause was cancer, the institute, a social and economic policy-research organization, said. 
 Dr. Bawden joined the institute in 1974. Four years later he became director of its employment and labor policy division, now known as the Human Resources Policy Center.
His principal subjects were poverty, welfare policies and employment and training programs for those without either. His most recent books, published by the institute, included "Rethinking Employment Policy," with Felicity Skidmore (1989); and, as editor, "The Social Contract Revisited: Aims and Outcome of President Reagan's Welfare Policy" (1984).
Dennis Lee Bawden was born in Wolf Point, Mont. A graduate of Montana State University, he earned a doctorate in agricultural economics at the University of California at Berkeley. He served as a lieutenant in the United States Air Force.
Dr. Bawden is survived by his wife, Carlene Crumpton Bawden; four children, Hilary A. and Darin L., both of Madison, Wis., Robert Crumpton Jr. of Lakeville, Minn., and Sharon R. Crumpton of Reston, Va.; his mother, Alice B. Bawden of Billings, Mont.; two brothers, John B., also of Billings, and James G., of Crown Point, Ind.; and a granddaughter.

HEADLINE: Pressure of Costs Drives Some Contractors to Stress Worker Safety

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON TOWNSHIP, N.J.

 BODY:
Shouting over the cough of heavy machinery and the roar of air compressors, Steven T. Thies is a preacher of workplace safety at a construction site where the congregation of hard hats at times seems deaf and often blind to his exhortations.
But like the newly converted businessmen and contractors in the construction industry who send safety managers like Mr. Thies into the field to reduce accidents and to lift profits, the foremen and laborers are beginning to hear the message. 
 That is the consensus of leaders in the construction industry, where workers' compensation premiums and other soaring costs related to death and injury in a dangerous occupation are forcing management to push safety programs to remain competitive and profitable.
 
Insurance Company Pressure
 Construction is one of the most dangerous jobs in America, placing workers in a constantly changing raw environment where one misstep or forgetful moment can snuff out a life or crush a limb. Pressures to finish a job quickly often push foremen and workers to take risks, industry experts say, amid a macho culture of muscle, sweat and swagger that tends to belittle safety measures and confuse caution with timidity.
The new push for safety, the experts say, is being led by large companies forced by the recession to try to save money and become more competitive by taking advantage of revised insurance industry policies that reward good safety records. "When companies understand that safety saves them money and increases productivity, they become believers," said Mr. Thies, corporate safety manager for Henkels & McCoy, a 5,000-worker utility construction company based in Blue Bell, Pa.
Others in the industry suspect that little is happening at most work sites even as big companies make progress.
 
An Epidemic of Deaths
 Workers' compensation costs for on-the-job deaths, medical treatment and lost wages due to injuries, have tripled in the past decade for construction and building trades work, according to the insurance industry.
"A watershed period of concern is forcing the industry to focus on safety issues and make rapid changes," said Knute Ringen, director of the Center to Protect Workers' Rights, a Washington research arm of 15 A.F.L.-C.I.O. construction trade unions.
In July, the center sponsored a national conference of delegates from organized labor, contractors, universities and government to map strategies to end what Mr. Ringen described as a "cowboy mentality of risk-taking" among both workers and bosses that he said produced some 2,000 deaths and 210,000 serious injuries a year.
"Any other industry with that record would be shut down," he said. "A disease with that many victims would be declared an epidemic."
 
No Safety Culture
 Mr. Ringen blamed the transient and episodic nature of construction work for the lack of public outcry about its dangers. "The average contractor employs 8 to 10 workers and the construction worker signs on with 6 to 8 contractors a year at different locations," he said.
More than 8 million people share work that is equivalent to fewer than 5 million full-time jobs. And a contractor can hire unskilled workers off the street and put them to work on a dangerous work site with no training.
"All this combines," he said, "to work against a strong safety culture throughout the industry."
Lee Penman, president of Kamp Associates, a New Jersey consulting firm that advises construction projects on risk management, agreed. "Money and work schedules drive the industry so there's still an attitude that work must be completed quickly even if it means taking safety shortcuts," he said.
 
A Different Breed
 "You can walk on to almost any job site and find safety violations and I don't see anyone shutting down operations because of them."
Instead, he continued, it is fairly common to see workers flout safety standards. "I've seen bosses walk girders on a high building blindfolded to show the ironworkers he can still cut it," he said.
Yet some owners and contractors are establishing higher safety standards than those mandated by the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration, said James Lapping, safety director for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in Washington.
 
Security, Not Safety
 From its inception in 1970, OSHA often was attacked because of its demand for safety measures that many in the construction industry portrayed as intrusive, impractical and costly.
Those attacks decreased after the Reagan Administration officials closed some 40 inspection offices and cut staff by 20 percent. Then the Bush Administration sought wider compliance by a tenfold increase in the size of fines for willful violators.
The number of field inspectors was not restored to full strength. As a result, OSHA officials concede, projects employing large work crews are more likely to be inspected than smaller ones, even though those have a higher proportion of the untrained and inexperienced workers most susceptible to serious accidents.
Risks also remain great for unskilled laborers and illegal aliens who feel powerless to challenge a boss who fails to provide safety equipment or orders them to perform unsafe work.
"In a recession, job security is more important than job safety and workers don't ask questions when a foreman tells them to do something that might be dangerous," said Dennis Gaughan, head of the OSHA field office in Avenel, N.J., which inspects work places on Staten Island and parts of central New Jersey.
 
A Role for Unions
 But Joseph Busacco, health and safety officer of Local 472, Heavy and General Laborers Union in northern New Jersey, said, "If our guys are sent into bad conditions, we'll tell the contractor to make the place safe or we'll shut him down."
Moreover, he said, unions are becoming less supportive of workers who flout safety rules. "We tell the contractor if one of our guys won't wear a hard hat or safety vest to send him back to the union hall," he said.
In New Jersey, unions and contractors cooperate in an organization called Project Build. A mobile unit operated by the Heavy and General Laborers Union, with contributions from contractors, visits work sites to show safety videotapes to workers.
 
The Message in the Ditch
 The message, at times, has trouble making its way from the front office down to the guy in the ditch with his boot on a shovel. In Jackson Township, where Henkels & McCoy is laying a natural gas pipeline, Mr. Thies, the safety director, came face to face with an attitude among some workers he describes as "How much can I get away with not doing?"
Coming upon laborers and welders laying a 30-inch pipe in a 10-foot deep trench, he spotted some minor infractions that were immediately cleared. But 50 yards further he discovered a major violation: The trench had been inadequately shored by timbers to prevent a cave-in.
Mr. Thies told Sal Simao, the foreman, to halt construction until the problem was fixed, an order that caused some rolling of eyeballs under hard hats along the line. Mr. Simao protested that the trench had been prepared by another crew. The slowdown, he grumbled, would reflect badly on him.
"Routine is the enemy of safety," Skip Parry, one of Mr. Thies's inspectors, observed later. "The old theory was 'I am only going to be down in the ditch for two minutes and it's never caved in before.'
"The new theory is 'We're going to protect lives even if you're down there for only 30 seconds, even if we could lay 14 more feet of pipe in the time it takes to do it right.'

GRAPHIC: Photo: "When companies understand that safety saves them money and increases productivity, they become believers," said Steven T. Thies, third from left, corporate safety manager for Henkels & McCoy. He pointed out a possible safety problem at a construction site in Freehold Township, N.J. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 43; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 533 words

HEADLINE: Rally in Long Bond Cools Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The 30-year Treasury bond retreated slightly yesterday, after a two-week rally that sent its price sharply higher and pushed its yield to record lows. But many traders expected the rally to resume.
Other Treasury issues were mixed, with the price of the 10-year note edging up slightly. 
 In trading yesterday, the new 6.25 percent bond due in August 2023 slipped 7/32 . Its yield rose to 6.22 percent, from 6.20 percent on Thursday, its lowest point in the 16 years that the Treasury has issued 30-year bonds on a regular basis. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note, which is becoming an alternative benchmark for long-term interest rates, rose 1/32 of a point, while its yield was unchanged at 5.61 percent. Shorter-term issues also showed little change.
 
New Issue's Strength
 Traders noted that the new 30-year bond, which was auctioned by the Treasury on Aug. 12, continued to outperform the previously auctioned 30-year bond by a wide margin.
Reflecting sharply higher demand for the new bond, its yield in the secondary market was around 15 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, lower than the old bond's yield.
Analysts said the strong demand for new 30-year bonds was fueled by an impending drought of coming issues, which has driven up their price. The Treasury Department has acted to sharply scale back its sales of 30-year bonds. The 30-year auction on Aug. 12 was the last for six months.
But the wide gap between yields of the old bonds and the new, or "cash," bonds has created some problems for many traders, who depend on consistency in their value to carry out their transactions.
"The cash bond is trading on a completely different planet from the rest of the market," said John Canavan, an analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J.
Part of the volatility was tied to an unusually small number of investors holding a large portion of the newly auctioned bonds, Mr. Canavan said. That means a few transactions can tilt the bond's value in secondary trading.
 
Spurred by Deficit Data
 On Thursday, the 30-year bond rallied on an unexpected surge in the nation's trade deficit, which added to a string of recent evidence that the economic recovery is sputtering. Slow economic growth and low inflation help the value of fixed-income securities. Traders said some investors had decided to take their profits before the weekend.
Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said that the market seemed positioned to rally further but that it could be setting itself up for a correction.
"Right now people are fundamentally bullish," he said. "But I think they can be in for some disappointment. I don't think the economy is as weak as some of the recent data have suggested."
The discount rates on Treasury bills edged up slightly, with the rate on the three-month bill rising a basis point, to 2.97 percent, and the rate on the six-month bill also rising a basis point, to 3.09 percent.
But the Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, slipped to 2.94 percent, from 3.02 percent on Thursday.
