The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 22, 1993

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1920 words

HEADLINE: Again, That Hankering

BYLINE: By DEANNE STILLMAN; Deanne Stillman is working on a book about surf culture, to be published next year by Dell.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
At the Chicago World's Fair in 1893, the historian Frederick Jackson Turner startled the intellectual establishment when he read a paper asserting that "the true point of view in the history of this nation is not the Atlantic Coast. It is the Great West." And it was now closed, according to a United States Census Bureau report of the same time, fully restrained by reservations, barbed wire, mining claims, civil disputes over grazing rights and the railroad.
A century later, the West is further hobbled by planes, automobiles, rest stops and all-night minimarts whose offerings of lottery tickets allow them to pose as 20th-century gold mines. Yet in the country's heart of hearts, the frontier remains forever open, waiting to be rediscovered whenever America needs to go home. Judging from the bafflement that attends the mind-boggling riddles of today -- is it O.K. to lie, cheat, steal? -- this is just such a time. 
 To reclaim the title of an old Glenn Ford western, "The 3:10 to Yuma" is leaving -- again. The national commandment to "Go West, young . . . whatever you call yourself" has wrested its power back from other periodically operating watchwords, such as "Greed is good" and "Eric Clapton is God." And it is reverberating in every aspect of culture today, in film, television, art, pop music and literature. In fact, if you take the number of handgun owners, multiply it by the number of times Dean Martin fans have seen "Rio Bravo" (12 times for me), and factor in those who have at least one Western item as a household accessory, like a lucky horseshoe, a cactus lamp or twig furniture, it seems as if the whole country is yearning for the time when you didn't have to memorize your PIN number.
After the success of films like "Thelma and Louise," "Dances With Wolves," "Unforgiven" and "Posse," more than a dozen westerns are currently in production and at least a dozen more are in development. (It's not for nothing that Hollywood -- the Xerox machine of America's dreams -- is in the desert, land of the original mirage.) Never a medium to miss the chuck wagon (or the gravy train), the television networks will carry several new series about the West this fall.
Why is Harley Davidson the vehicle of choice among those who are born to be mild? Why is one of every five MTV videos shot in the desert? And where does the guitar player plug in?
This national journey that is both inward and outward bound is being made for several reasons. First, the West is cheap. With the recession-driven trend toward "downsizing" -- a term that vies with "job retraining" for euphemism of the year -- excess is out. The national bank is bust; the look is high-plains drifter.
Second, the West is simple. Which brings us to a pop quiz: Are you ecstatic when you see a tumbleweed? Do you sleep better under the Big Dipper? Do you eat with your hands? A yes to two out of three means that in a previous life you were Pegleg Smith and you should buy a harmonica and quit your job, as various television characters are planning to do this fall.
Third, the West is where the heart is. It's America's primordial sandbox. But where is it really? Did it ever exist? Dancehall girls died young of venereal disease. Cowboys were drunks. There wasn't any water in the desert. But none of that matters; historians -- who are simply socially acceptable spin doctors -- told the story otherwise, made people want to get there faster. The Donner Party may have been the first to find that shortcuts are a bad idea, but they are hardly the last. Perhaps the final act of spin-doctoring on the subject of "westward ho" will come from Ken ("The Civil War") Burns, whose frontier documentary is scheduled to be shown by PBS in 1996.
Then there is the fourth reason for the current surge of interest in the West. Out here, you can still drive fast. The forerunner of driving fast was riding fast. Thus, the American condition: wandering. The urge to saddle your car and move quickly through time and space has resulted in that ancient national ritual, the road trip, and the sacred texts that have accompanied it: "Roughing It," "The Land of Little Rain," "On the Road," "The Petrified Forest," "American Graffiti," "Baghdad Cafe," "Born to Be Wild," among others.
The road trip would not be possible, or desirable, without the vast stretches of desert space that characterize the West. And, as Wallace Stegner has written, it is this feature -- space, not place (as in the East) -- that infuses the American character, accounting for the intense cultivation of the concept of personal rights. It's a free country. . .
I can do what I want . . . How come the other guy didn't get a ticket? . . . As the land continues to be stripped of its identity, driving fast on the open road, and the geography that invites the act, become touchstones, relics, suitable for framing.
Two current exhibitions here explore the iconography of the West from a contemporary point of view and use popular culture as a way of invoking classic American themes. The first is the photography of David Levinthal, at the Gene Autry Western Heritage Museum in Los Angeles through October, in which we see scenes from America's desert primeval: outlaws rob the Wells Fargo stagecoach, cowboys lasso wild horses, gunslingers have a showdown. But the scenes are literally playful; the figures are toys, placed on sand and fake sagebrush, and the moments are frozen in big, color Polaroid prints.
"I have childhood memories of the films of John Ford, and westerns on television," Mr. Levinthal says. "Some photographers go to Monument Valley. I wanted to deal with the unreality of Western mythology. My imagery is intentionally ambiguous. Some people see it as homage to Remington and Charles Russell, others as a critique of the myth."
"Kustom Kulture: Von Dutch, Ed 'Big Daddy' Roth, Robert Williams and Others -- Customized Cars and Their Effect on the Arts," at the Laguna Art Museum through November, also looks at modern Western mythology. The artists are a triple-header of car culture: Mr. Dutch is the father of modern hot-rod pinstriping; Mr. Roth is the king of car customizers, as well as the creator of "Rat Fink," the notorious Mad magazine character, and Mr. Williams was one of the most radical underground comic illustrators of the 1960's.
"It's our gene disposition to travel, to go to new frontiers," says Bolton Colburn, curator of collections at the museum, referring to the show's reflection of the car's connection with the West. It features classic works like Mr. Dutch's "Flying Eyeball" jacket, Mr. Roth's custom car, "Beatnik Bandit," and a Williams painting entitled "Land of Retinal Delights."
"In California the idea of manifest destiny turned inside out because you can't go any further; you run into the ocean," says Mr. Colburn. "There was a whirlpool effect here. Our connection with the car and freeway is a result of no place else to go. Here the emphasis is on where you can go and how fast you can get there. The desire to go anywhere you want any time you want is our sublimated genetic drive to emigrate."
WHENEVER I FEEL the genetic drive to emigrate, I get in my car and head east, away from Los Angeles, and into the Mojave. I know I am in this most American of deserts when I spot my first Joshua tree, the peculiar-looking plant that grows only in the Mojave and only between 2,000 and 6,000 feet. This is the land of cars without emission controls, of modern outlaws living in abandoned movie sets -- a civics lesson in personal rights, a stage upon which the country's secret self is anything but a mirage.
Various westerns have been shot here, including the 70's classic "Tell Them Willie Boy Was Here," the true story of the so-called last Indian roundup. It features Robert Redford as the reluctant lawman, Robert Blake as the luckless Willie Boy, and Katharine Ross as Willie Boy's Indian paramour. The site of Willie Boy's murder is now marked on local maps and accessible via four-wheel drive, kind of a drive-in geography-imitates-art-imitates-life outdoor museum exhibit.
When you cruise this terrain, you realize that it makes perfect sense that the rock group U2 named their recent album, with its apocalyptic undertone, "Joshua Tree," and it makes perfect sense that on his new release, "Fate of Nations," the rock singer Robert Plant belts out a desert rapture called "29 Palms," site of the Joshua Tree National Monument. "I feel the heat in your desert heart," Mr. Plant sings, driving the stairway to heaven, "leading me back down the road that leads back to you. . ."
Among the various forthcoming westerns and television series, most are shot in the more "classic" desert terrain of Oregon, Texas, Arizona and New Mexico. They include films that reassess great American heroes -- two about "Wyatt Earp" (one with Kevin Costner, the other with Kurt Russell, Robert Mitchum and Charlton Heston), "Maverick" (with Mel Gibson) and "Davy Crockett" (from David and Jerry Zucker). Other westerns coming soon include the all-girl "Outlaws," "The Quick and the Dead," starring Sharon Stone, and "Lane Frost," with Luke Perry playing Lane Frost, the rodeo champion who was recently trampled to death.
On television this fall, in addition to the popular CBS show "Dr. Quinn: Medicine Woman" (with Jane Seymour), viewers can hit the trail with new series like Fox's "Adventures of Brisco County Jr." (about an adventurer with a Harvard law degree who is hired by a group of wealthy businessmen to hunt down the 12 most notorious outlaws); CBS's "Harts of the West" (featuring Beau Bridges as a 41-year-old lingerie salesman who buys a broken-down Nevada ranch to fulfill his lifelong dream of being a cowboy), and CBS's "Walker, Texas Ranger" (starring Chuck Norris as a modern-day lawman who solves crimes the old-fashioned way).
But perhaps the most original western series to hit the airwaves this season is "Ned Blessing: The Story of My Life and Times," also on CBS. Set after the Civil War, the show is about a bandit (Brad Johnson) who comes home to Plum Creek, Tex., in search of his father.
But it is really about a kind of rainbow coalition of misfits who somehow bump into one another when they stop for a rest. To its credit, the show smuggles in the cast Trojan-style -- not in a horse but on one. In addition to a well-crafted round of good and bad white guys, there is a secretive Indian character named One Horse (Wes Studi) and a Mexican healer and cook called Crecencio (Luis Avalos), who plays Ned Blessing's sidekick. Because of these elements, Bill Wittliff, who created the show (and also adapted Larry McMurtry's "Lonesome Dove" as a mini-series), says that "Ned Blessing" is really a "southwestern."
Does this frontier-mania mean that America has stopped treating its creation myths as regional literature? Is "The 3:10 to Yuma" leaving for good this time? Certainly, the West has fueled the country's most epic works of art, sculpture, film, photography, music and prose. But it has also fueled the land's wanderlust. We may be incapable of slowing down long enough to fully examine our childhood stories. When this current wave passes, at least the libraries and video stores will have more to choose from on the shelves where "the old days" live. (Although, certainly, "Rawhide" alone could keep any red-blooded gal going for years). "The American community," Stegner wrote, "is an overnight camp." And its P.O. Box is the West.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
In Torrington, Spicy Subcontinental Fare

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
INDIAN restaurants are so rare in Connecticut that discovering Indo-Bangla in Torrington comes as a treat for any fan of the hot, well-spiced food of the subcontinent.
That's the good news. The less happy report is that one wishes it were better. It's not just that the restaurant itself is so lackluster -- a large, characterless room in a freestanding building, with wood-veneer booths, low ceiling and tile flooring. None of that would matter if the food tasted fresher and had more zest and zip. It wasn't bad; in fact, a few dishes were actually delicious, but many others tasted as though the kitchen were just going through the motions. 
 Most Indian dishes are complex and require considerable preparation, thus a restaurant needs a steady day-in, day-out clientele for the food to be freshly prepared and at its best. Otherwise, if there isn't that steady traffic, the dishes are sometimes held over and often end up tasting tired. It is a cuisine that is perhaps best suited to a large population center with adventurous diners.
Indo-Bangla deserves passing marks for trying to introduce this fascinating and diverse cuisine to the Torrington area, and even higher marks for making prices so accessible. While portions are small, as is often the case in Indian restaurants, several extras are included in the price of each entree, adding considerably to the value. These include onion relish (a delicious, spicy mixture of coarsely chopped raw onions, green pepper, cumin and red hot pepper), dal (lentils in a soupy state), tamarind sauce (thinner and sweeter than usual), cobe vajee (steamed, deeply spiced, shredded cabbage) and basmati rice (a generous portion, with sultana raisins, almonds, bay leaf, cardomom pods and wisps of fried onion).
Many dishes at Indo-Bangla (named for both India and Bangladesh) will be familiar to aficionados of Indian food. Especially well-made and fresh-tasting was lamb sajahani, a Moghul specialty that immersed chunks of braised lamb in a well-seasoned, ground-almond cream sauce. Lamb saag, which blended lamb with spinach and spices, lacked sparkle.
Saag paneer, which joins creamy cooked spinach with little cubes of bland farmer-style cheese, can be a well-resonated dish, as the Indian cuisine often does wonders with spinach and other vegetables. In this instance, though, the spicing was muted and the net effect was on the blah side.
Shrimp vindaloo, a Goan specialty, was skimpy with the jumbo shrimp, all too generous with potato chunks, and profuse with the fiery hot, cayenne-fueled sauce. Vindaloo is usually the hottest item on an Indian menu. At Indo-Bangla, where punches were pulled on many other dishes, the vindaloo was full throttle, four alarm, requiring a few spoonfuls of the refreshingly cool yogurt dish called raita to quench the fire.
Chicken dhansak was a dish that needed an infusion of pep. A mixture of chicken pieces, spinach and lentils, it was listed as "a little hot" but was surprisingly subdued. Chicken Madras, another traditionally hot South Indian number, was indeed incendiary. A paltry serving of dry-baked chicken tikka had intense seasoning but tasted reheated.
One of the better dishes at Indo-Bangla was chhole poori, a well-spiced appetizer of chickpeas, tomatoes, onions, cumin and other seasonings, served with puffy, if greasy, poori bread. Naan, the popular, soft unleavened bread served with so many Indian dishes, wasn't real naan but warmed pita bread.
There is no liquor, beer or wine license at Indo-Bangla, but you are welcome to bring your own. You can pay as little as $10 a person at Indo-Bangla for an appetizer and entree. It's hard to dine out more economically than that.
A LA CARTE -- Rumba, the small, bouncy Cuban-Caribbean restaurant in Danbury, moved to larger quarters last month. Now at 106 Federal Road (next to Day's Inn Motel), Danbury, the new expanded place seats 250 (compared with its former seating for 54), with a dance floor, where live Latin music is featured Friday and Saturday evenings. The cheerful tropical decor and food are much the same as in the former cozy location. New telephone: 791-0003.

HEADLINE: United Fights for Its Health as Unions Fight for United

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
LEAN and fit, Stephen M. Wolf, the 52-year-old chairman of United Airlines, works out every chance he gets in the personal gym adjoining his office here. And he's attacking the problem of getting the carrier into fighting trim with an equal zeal.
United became the nation's largest airline in June, edging out American by the crucial measure of miles flown by passengers. But far from celebrating, Mr. Wolf is looking critically at what industry analysts agree is an unhealthy amount of fat. Indeed, United's parent, UAL Corporation, posted an operating loss of $538 million last year, far more than AMR, American's parent, which posted a $25 million operating loss. 
 Particularly worrisome, Southwest Airlines, the only major carrier to report a profit last year, is competing on an increasing portion of United's routes -- 16 percent, double the 8 percent overlap of only five years ago -- and Mr. Wolf realizes that United has to match Southwest's low-cost structure if it is to remain competitive.
The most dramatic result of Mr. Wolf's efforts is the possible buyout of the airline by its unions. Responding to his appeal for help last month, the pilots, machinists and flight attendants'unions politely indicated a willingness to make concessions in return for a controlling stake in UAL.
The development is remarkable for several reasons. While unions have traded concessions for equity at Trans World Airlines and Northwest Airlines, they did so only with their backs against a wall. United, by contrast, has a $1.9 billion cash cushion. Moreover, three previous attempts by United's unions to buy the carrier not only failed, but were marked by confrontation and invective.
Now union leaders -- who largely balked at Mr. Wolf's invitation earlier this year to discuss concessions -- have adopted his earnest, conciliatory stance of trying to find a way to assure the carrier's long-term viability and secure workers' jobs. "We seek to pursue a collaborative effort now with a still healthy company," the unions said.
Labor leaders have shared few thoughts lately about the move, but they clearly were swayed by unpalatable alternatives and an industry-wide contraction that has helped make United the latest example of bedrock American companies trying to orchestrate a shift to a lithe, more profitable structure. United also reflects how transportation companies are scrambling to cope in a deregulated market of lower-cost airlines pressuring the largest carriers.
Mr. Wolf is not relying on just one strategy to restore United to health. United is shedding money-losing routes, just recently cutting its daily departures from Orlando by more than half. United has also established a new subsidiary, the UAL Leasing Corporation, to lease the planes it is otherwise grounding. Air Wisconsin, a small fleet that feeds passengers to United hubs, has been sold. United has also replaced cleaning staff and skycaps with contract workers.
It is reviewing bids to buy its 17 flight kitchens, which employ 5,800 workers and has raised the possibility of selling its pilot training center in Denver. All these changes are on top of the $400 million United carved out of its 1993 operating budget.
The most controversial suggestion so far, however, is that United might spin off an airline with nonunion pilots to take over unprofitable short-haul routes.
United's top managers have deployed a vice president, Frederic F. "Jake" Brace, to study the issue full-time, and they continually comment on the importance of the so-called Jake Brace project as the big fix for their domestic operations.
"There is one issue standing between us and glory," said John C. Pope, United's president and chief operating officer. But the pilots reacted sharply in June when the possibility of a spun-off carrier came to light, reminding the airline that such a "breach of faith" prompted a strike in 1985, and that "we will again respond with every legal means at our disposal."
That made the unions' friendly response last month all the more surprising. Industry analysts credit, to some degree, Mr. Wolf's high-minded stump speeches about the need for change. Over the last several months he has campaigned to convince employees that the industry faces deep-rooted problems.
"The unions recognized many years ago the need for restructuring, but to his credit, Wolf has succeeded in persuading them that management's view of the airlines is sincere and accurate," said Joseph R. Blasi, professor of management and labor relations at Rutgers University, who has been retained by United's nonunion employees to advise them as the buyout talks progress.
It was Mr. Wolf who first floated the notion in Washington that a national commission should be appointed to study the industry's ailments. In speeches, interviews and internal employee newsletters, Mr. Wolf and his lieutenants tell and retell a lesson in Airline Economics 101 about secular changes under way in the business. In his monthly editorial in the July issue of United's in-flight magazine, Mr. Wolf addressed the importance of increasing productivity of American workers, a message no doubt written with United's unions in mind as they consider the airline's restructuring plan.
"It's not a case of anyone being bad or dumb," Mr. Wolf said during an interview here over a lunch of vegetables and rice. "We're saying we need to do it now from a position of strength, before we get to the edge of the precipice looking straight down."
The airline has become increasingly aware of the precipice in part because of Southwest Airlines. As Candace Browning, a Merrill Lynch analyst, noted in a recent report, Southwest's more productive workers and lower costs enable it to charge at least 25 percent less than United and still turn a profit. Given United's hubs at San Francisco and Los Angeles, the carrier's executives have concluded that they face many future battles with Southwest that they are almost certain to lose.
"It is like a cancer eating you up," said Rakesh Gangwal, United's senior vice president of planning. "If we cannot fix our domestic business, we will go the way of Pan Am and Eastern."
The unions apparently share that concern. Wage concessions are not easy for the rank and file, but fear of losing jobs is a powerful incentive for making them. Still, they come dear. United's labor leaders are seeking control of the carrier, and it is far from certain that the unions can forge a proposal that appeals to United's board and shareholders.
Although the unions say they want nothing less than a majority stake, nobody is ruling out the possibility that they might agree to swap concessions for a minority interest.
Nor is anyone certain that the labor coalition will not crumble. There are long-standing strains among pilots and machinists to overcome. But for now, the unions are presenting a unified front as they join United on the high road of cordial talks rather than cope with a probable loss of jobs. They have put together a number of proposals, but none has so far emerged as a favorite, according to people close to the talks.
They confirmed recent reports that one proposal calls for the unions to exchange 15 percent wage cuts, worth roughly $3.4 billion, to help gain control of the company. Current stockholders would retain 40 percent of the company. In exchange for the other 60 percent, they would be given $20 a share, to be financed by using $500 million from United's cash reserves, plus new equity whose value would be increased by the worker givebacks.
THERE is skepticism in the industry over whether lenders would support a union-led company. Wall Street remembers vividly the unions' failed attempt in 1989, a deal that prompted a 190-point plunge in the stock market when it crumbled on Friday, Oct. 13 of that year.
But Mr. Blasi said that the details would determine the level of enthusiasm for this latest effort. "If the unions can show they can make work rules flexible, and cut staff, wages and benefits, then all of that is music to investors' ears," he said.
In contrast to United, American has refrained from asking employees for concessions out of fear that it would foster resentment and hurt customer service. Instead, it is dropping unprofitable routes and focusing on subsidiary businesses like computer consulting. The No. 3 carrier, Delta Air Lines, has been laying off pilots to cut costs.
In this light, the decision by United and its labor leaders to at least talk about concessions while United is strong is all the more remarkable. Traditionally, the industry rule of thumb has been that American acts first and is followed six months later by United, then by Delta even later.
If anything happens to scuttle a deal at United, management will have to make deeper cuts, almost certainly sparking tussles with labor. Mr. Wolf has stood up to union leaders before during showdowns at United, and in earlier jobs running Republic Airlines and Tiger International, both of which were bought later by other carriers. And he would doubtless do so again to shrink United to a more profitable core.
"There was only one thing that troubled me when I joined United, and that was the relationship between labor and employer," he said. "Five and a half years later, it's the issue that still troubles me."
 
WILL BARGAINING END HIS JOB?"
IF United Airlines' unions and management are able to negotiate a deal that everyone from the board and shareholders to rank-and-file workers and lenders would accept, it would be a victory for the airline's chairman, Stephen M. Wolf -- even though it could put him and some of his top managers out of work.
Such prospects, though, may not be entirely unwelcome by Mr. Wolf. He and his lieutenants could profit handsomely from a buyout. His employment contract, like those of many United managers, includes provisions that if the airline were to change hands, his many stock options would be accelerated.
United's shares have jumped roughly 15 percent in recent weeks to around $145 a share since the unions said in July that they were interested in a buyout. If it works out, a buyout could well lift the stock further, perhaps making a fistful of out-of-the-money options that Mr. Wolf holds as performance incentives suddenly worth something.
He has 50,000 options exercisable at $170 on May 29, 1994; 50,000 options at $196 in 1995 and 50,000 options at $225 on May 29, 1996.
And while that potential profit may be a motivator, there may be other issues driving Mr. Wolf to seek a deal besides his stated goals of maximizing benefits for other shareholders and United employees.
Acquaintances say that he may be tiring of the nonstop pace of the airline business, and that he might happily bow out. After all, he can reflect on a career of accomplishments that few airline executives share. He runs the world's largest airline, earning $575,000 per year, and he has secured a tidy personal fortune even if the options are never exercised. And if he were able to restructure United with the unions' help, he might be viewed as a leader in labor-management relations -- something that might help if he harbors any political or diplomatic ambitions, as some acquaintances suggest.
He also mentioned during a recent interview that he misses a few of life's pleasures, including trout fishing, pursuing his interest in food, and the old Jaguars he has restored at a garage in New Hampshire but never has time to drive.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stephen Wolf, chairman: troubled by employer/labor relations. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
With Business Weak, Stocks Are Strong

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
AFTER the Mississippi flooded and New York boiled in July, August has finally produced a summer rally. And not just on Wall Street. Europe also is clanging along. The economies may not be growing much, meaning that there is no great need to build plants or buy equipment. But cash has to go somewhere, and now it is going into stocks and bonds.
Every major U.S. stock index moved to a new high last week, with the Dow Jones industrial average topping 3,600. But it is hard to find much joy among investors. Perhaps that reflects the fact this rally has not been like the barnburners of old. "We have crawled higher," says Hugh Johnson, the strategist at First Albany. 
 The tradition of summer rallies is a great one. And if it has often been hyped by brokers trying to sell stocks, that does not obscure the fact that some of the great market turning points have occurred in hot weather. On July 8, 1932, the stock market hit its Depression low. Two months later, it was up 94 percent. The great 1980's bull market began on Friday, Aug. 13, 1982.
And six years ago this week, on Aug. 25, 1987, the Dow peaked at 2,722.42. It was the 55th, and last, time that the index hit a new high in 1987. The crash came in October.
Six years ago, the Dow was ridiculously overvalued. Now it is about one-third higher. The economy is larger, but by some standards, stocks are almost as overpriced. At the peak, the Standard & Poor's 500 index had a miserly dividend yield of just 2.6 percent. Last week the figure was 2.7 percent. Historically, markets with yields much below 3 percent are hazardous to wealth.
But a case can be made for stocks. "The valuation of the market is not strained," said Byron Wien, the Morgan Stanley strategist, pointing to indicators based on interest rates. Mr. Wien was one of the few on Wall Street to forecast a good summer rally, in part because he thought the yield on 30-year Treasuries would fall to 6 1/2 percent. At the time, that forecast seemed bold. Now Treasuries are below 6 1/4 percent. In 1987, he recalled, interest rates were moving up, a fact the stock market managed to ignore for only a limited period.
Last week's rally was ignited in part by lower interest rates, and in part by a recovery in this year's big losers, the consumer products and health stocks. "If the market were to have a strong run here, it would surprise most observers," Mr. Wien said. "But it is quite possible, especially if the laggards keep performing." He thinks a Dow peak of 3,800 to 4,000 is possible, but adds that he doubts more than that is likely without a correction.
Intuitively, stocks ought to do best when the business climate, and thus the profit outlook, are the brightest. But that is not always the case. Perhaps the stock markets here and in Europe are destined to do well until healthy economic growth returns, providing alternative uses for capital. Rising short-term interest rates would be a sign that is happening, but that sign is not here yet.

And Some Disappointments," lists change in stock price since Aug. 27, 1987 for Digital Equipment, I.B.M., Westinghouse, Amerian Express and Ford.

HEADLINE: Profile: Herbert M. Baum;
Quaker State's Quick-Change Artist

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

DATELINE: OIL CITY, Pa.

 BODY:
HERBERT M. BAUM, the new head of the Quaker State Corporation, and the first outsider to lead the oil company since it was founded in 1931, refused when the board asked him to add his picture to a row of portraits of past chairmen.
"This is stifling," he said, gesturing toward the display lining a hall on the top floor of the company's headquarters here. So he ordered that the pictures of the solemn-faced executives be moved into the boardroom and replaced with lively photos of the company's products, employees and customers. 
 The switch was an appropriate one for a marketing man like Mr. Baum, who made his name rejuvenating sales and developing new products at the Campbell Soup Company after a successful career in advertising.
Indeed, Mr. Baum's marketing savvy, and the energy and fresh approach he brings as an outsider, might be just what is needed, some analysts say, to help regain market share for Quaker State, the country's second-largest retailer of motor oil after Pennzoil, based in Houston.
There is worry within the company; his emphasis on marketing rather than research and product development could leave the company vulnerable to a competitor who might come up with an innovative product. But Mr. Baum is moving into the motor oil business with gusto.
"There are no givens on what has to happen at Quaker State," said the 56-year-old Mr. Baum, who took over as the chairman and chief executive in June and has already earned a reputation as a workaholic. "Everything is open to change."
And plenty will have to change, analysts say. The company lost $93 million last year, on sales of $724.4 million, in contrast to income of $22.7 million the year before.
Much of the loss came from writedowns from the sale of its coal operations, but operating profits slid 29.7 percent, to $29.8 million from $42.4 million in 1991.
Earnings have picked up this year, reaching $4.38 million, or 16 cents a share, in the second quarter, up 37 percent from $3.19 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier.
The stock, having hit a low of about $7 in 1990, closed Friday at $13.125 -- less than half the $30 a share it reached in 1987.
One problem is that Quaker State Q Lube -- the company's chain of quick-lube service stations -- which accounts for about 14 percent of its business, has been struggling for several years. More important, Quaker State's bread-and-butter product, motor oil, which accounts for 60 percent of sales, has been losing market share at an alarming rate -- down to 13 percent from 20 percent in 1984. (An insurance division makes up 18 percent of Quaker State's business and a unit that makes specialty lights for trucks contributes 8 percent.)
R. Bentley Offutt, an analyst who follows the company for Offutt Securities in Baltimore, said a major challenge for Mr. Baum would be to rebuild the sales and marketing staff which was trimmed during a cost-cutting drive in the mid-1980's.
"That's the heart of their problem," he said, adding that Mr. Baum was well suited for the job because of his background and that he was already seeking a new senior vice president of marketing to revamp the staff.
Indeed, marketing and advertising are the heart of Mr. Baum's plan to get the company back on track. In a radical departure from the approach of his predecessor, Jack W. Corn, Mr. Baum plans a cash rebate campaign -- the first in many years -- that would cut the price of a new line of motor oil by about 30 percent for a time to regain market share.
And local sales representatives are expected to be given more leeway to offer special pricing deals to large retailers for a variety of oil grades.
But eventually, Mr. Baum said, "people will pay a premium" for the strong brand name of Quaker State, once he gets the advertising and marketing effort going.
LIKE many oil companies, Quaker State sharply raised its motor oil price when the Gulf War sent the price of crude oil soaring. Unlike many others, though, it kept the price high. Steep discounting by Pennzoil and others eager to win sales at big off-price chains like Kmart, where motor oil is sometimes used as a loss leader, cost Quaker significant market share.
Quaker State has also been hurt, as have many other consumer products companies, by the abandonment of premium brand labels by price-conscious buyers. Still, Mr. Baum is determined to win back what was lost by building brand loyalty.
Last month the board halved the dividend to 10 cents a share from 20 cents, a move Mr. Baum said was necessary because the dividends had exceeded earnings. Although the stock gave up $1.25 on the dividend news, Mr. Offutt praised the move because it would free up money for the new ad campaign.
Under Mr. Baum, Quaker State will end its contract with Burt Reynolds, whose smart-aleck commercials added to brand recognition but did little to stem the sales slide. Until Grey Advertising comes up with a new campaign, Quaker State is developing an interim campaign that will focus on car owners who have used nothing but Quaker State to keep their "cream puff" cars running for hundreds of thousands of miles.
Mr. Baum can be expected to play a strong role in overseeing the new campaign. He came to management by way of advertising. After graduating from Drake University in Des Moines in 1958 with a degree in business administration, he did stints as an announcer at speedways in the Chicago area and as a publicist for movie stars in Chicago.
He then worked as an account executive for several ad agencies. In 1973, he was named a vice president of Needham, Harper & Steers in Chicago and put to work on the Campbell Soup account. Five years later, Campbell asked him to join the company as the associate director of new products in the canned foods division.
Campbell, which then controlled about 85 percent of the market for condensed soups in the United States, was largely an insular, complacent company that was being challenged by rivals like Progresso. Campbell watched its sales slide as consumers' eating habits shifted to emphasize less salt and more fresh food.
Mr. Baum's challenge was to add products and rejuvenate the core business without cutting into the dominant position of the traditional Campbell soups. A new line of lower-salt soups called Healthy Request and new products like Prego spaghetti sauce were introduced.
He rose quickly in the company. In seven years, he became the president of Campbell USA, the largest division of the company. When he left to join Quaker State, where he faces a similar challenge -- revitalizing a proud, old company, he was president of Campbell's operations in both North and South America.
At Campbell, his style was to listen, be informal and approachable and work seven days a week to bring in some fresh thinking.
"He was not a guy with a booming voice," a colleague at Campbell recalled. "He had a gentle way of dealing with people. He did not like to order someone to do things unless he had to."
Yet, the Campbell executive added, Mr. Baum was also very determined and focused. This at times put him in conflict with top executives, some of whom left the company because they felt he wanted to run things his own way.
At Quaker State, he is off at a blistering pace, getting to the office at 5 A. M. and working late into the night and on weekends -- an approach he says is made possible by his wife, Karen, who takes care of everything at home.
"He leaves everything to me," she said. She lost no time in moving the family from Voorhees Township, N.J., near Campbell's headquarters in Camden, to Oil City in western Pennsylvania, where on the first day of a house-hunting trip she bought a sprawling old home from a surgeon who had kept it meticulously.
Once an oil boomtown, Oil City's downtown, apart from Quaker State's five-story glass and concrete headquarters, is now dotted with empty office buildings and stores. But Mr. Baum sees better times ahead.
"We're going to find the rebirth of Quaker State," he said. "I'm a brand builder."
 
 
 
SPEED, SERVICE AND LOYALTY
QUICK-LUBE centers are a key to regaining a strong marketing position, Herbert M. Baum, Quaker State's chairman and chief executive contends, because customers also end up using the company's products.
Fast-lube stations offer oil changes and lubrication without the need for an appointment and generally charge about $25 for the service. For a time, the quick-lube market prospered, as the number of gas stations that traditionally did such work declined, and the remaining stations and car dealers were slow to respond to the demand for the fast and inexpensive service.
The centers captured about 10 percent of the oil-change market, with 40 percent remaining with the gas stations and dealers. Drivers who changed their own oil accounted for the other half of the market.
The recession put more of the market into the hands of the do-it-yourselfers, resulting in a shake-out in the business and stiffer competition.
Jiffy Lube, based in Houston, which pioneered the business in the early 1980's, grew too rapidly: It opened 1,000 centers but got into severe financial problems in the process. It was bought by Pennzoil in 1990 and since then has been run by a new management team that is spending heavily to upgrade its centers, train its staff and set up computer systems to track each car that is serviced. Quaker State cannot afford to lag.
Quaker State jumped into the quick-lube business in 1985, during the industry's go-go years, when it bought Arctic Circle Inc., the owner of Minit Lube, and expanded quickly from a base of 100 centers. There are now 433 of the stations around the country; most are company-owned, but some are franchised.
After earning $6 million in 1990, the Quaker State chain lost $1.1 million in 1991. Its small operating profit last year was more than offset by the high costs of an ambitious overhaul of the Minit Lube chain that began before Mr. Baum arrived. Its name was changed to Quaker State Q Lube.
One cost was for computer systems to tie the centers together. Since customers get oil changes only about every six months, it is hard to build loyalty. But in marketing surveys, Quaker State learned that customers would prefer to go to centers that kept computerized service records for their cars.
The company also found that many customers were more concerned about the quality of the service than getting the lowest price. So, Quaker State has put more emphasis on training its staff to answer questions and solve problems. The face lifts for the centers in Reno and Phoenix last year, which include new signs, paint, customer waiting rooms and landscaping, have also been expensive.
"The reaction has been extraordinary," said Conrad A. Conrad, president and chief operating officer of Quaker State. "Profits have increased significantly."
The company plans renovations throughout the chain and is now working on those in Salt Lake City and Atlanta.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/August 15-20

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
As Baby Bells Object, A.T.&T. Bids $12.6 Billion for McCaw 

In the nation's fifth-largest takeover ever, A.T.&T. is to pay $12.6 billion in stock for McCaw Cellular Communications, the biggest American cellular phone company. The deal, which must pass Federal antitrust muster, would profoundly alter telecommunications, in part by enabling long-distance cellular companies to bypass local phone lines. The Baby Bells -- which billed A.T.&T. $14 billion in access charges last year -- are crying foul over this aspect of the buy. They've been banned from long-distance competition ever since A.T.&T. was broken up years ago, they argue, but long-distance companies like A.T.&T. are allowed to vie for local business. Let us enter the long-distance market, the locals say. Still others are worried that the new A.T.&T. -- which bought NCR for $7.9 billion in 1991 -- is starting to look like the old, monolithic A.T.&T. But one group's decidedly not upset: the four McCaw brothers, who stand to get nearly $2.9 billion from the deal.
 
 
 
 
 
Hughes Wins Satellite Suit
After 20 years in court, Hughes Aircraft has secured a judgment that NASA has infringed its patents for geosynchronous satellites. These satellites, which appear to hover in one spot over the rotating earth, have been widely used for 30 years as navigational aids and scientific data-gatherers. A major issue in the long dispute: Was the Hughes engineer who invented the geosynchronous system in 1959 working on a Government contract at the time? If so, rights to the idea might have belonged to NASA. But Judge James Turner of the United States Court of Claims said no. Next, the court must calculate damages. NASA says $100 million; Hughes counters with $3 billion.
Turner Buys 'Turtles' and More
Seeking a sure supply of shows for its entertainment channels, Turner Broadcasting has bought two film production companies for more than $667 million. One acquisition, New Line Cinema, has produced the "Nightmare on Elm Street" and "Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles" movie series; the other, Castle Rock Entertainment, has made "A Few Good Men" and "In the Line of Fire." The deal -- which will also buy for Turner the worldwide distribution capabilities of New Line -- continues the growing vertical integration of the entertainment field.
First Loss Leads Dell to Refocus
Chastened by its first quarterly loss since going public in 1988, Dell Computer has shifted its focus from sales and growth to profits and cost-cutting. The company incurred a $75.7 million second-quarter loss despite registering a jump in sales to $700 million, from $457 million, over the same quarter last year. A $71 million one-time charge -- for canceling a line of notebook computers, among other things -- accounted for the bulk of the period's loss. But even without the charge, Dell lost $4.7 million -- a surprise for a company whose sales rose 53 percent in a year. One reason for the anomaly is increased price competition from I.B.M., Compaq and others. Dell can't stop the competition, but it does plan cost cuts and worker incentives that maximize profit rather than sales.
Continental Cuts Fleet, Flights
Recently emerged from bankruptcy, Continental Airlines announced plans last week to shed 2,500 jobs, ground 30 planes and stop service to nine cities. Four of the nine dropped destinations are in Australia and New Zealand, thus stopping all Continental service there. The personnel cuts -- 6 percent of the airline's 42,000 workers -- will be made by year's end. Continental has trimmed down before, and other airlines, such as American and Delta, have taken similar actions. Analysts applaud these moves as correctives to industry overcapacity.
Donna Karan to Go Public
Donna Karan wants to become the first American couturier to take her company public, and she is hardly a long shot. Women have eagerly flocked to her easy-to-wear styles, helping her rack up an awe-inspiring average annual compounded growth rate of more than 50 percent since 1986. But as analysts dissected her planned initial public offering last week, its success seemed more iffy than her track record suggests. First, she's on the frontier of fashion. While Wall Street is familiar with apparel stocks, Ms. Karan's would be the first high-end fashion house to go public. Second, the fickleness of fashions makes all such stocks volatile. Finally, the offering prospectus reveals that Takihyo Inc., Ms. Karan's founding partner, will take big payouts from the stock sale and assume a much smaller role in the business. In fact, a basic disagreement between the partners may have spurred the offering. Reportedly, Ms. Karan wanted to market a perfume internally, while the partners favored using a cosmetics concern.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Nafta: Some Done, More to Do
 
The United States, Canada and Mexico finally completed the labor and environmental side deals to the North American Free Trade Agreement, but the treaty's still far from a reality. The side pacts -- urged by groups worried that Nafta signatories will ignore their own domestic labor and environmental laws -- authorize fines up to $20 million on offending countries, plus trade sanctions if necessary. But many were unimpressed. "It's a sellout," said a union president. "A fig leaf," said another. "Window dressing," said an environmentalist. The Administration defended the pact, though, and designated William Daley, a lawyer and brother of Chicago's Mayor, to push for its passage in Congress this fall. Also unresolved: A court ruling that an environmental impact statement must be prepared for Nafta. That case is on appeal.
 
China Stops 'Stir Fry' Land Deals
 
Seeking to cool its overheating economy, the Chinese Government is clamping down on real-estate developers who make huge profits from chao di, or "stir-frying property." Promising it will "sternly punish" those who continue in the frenzied speculation of buying and reselling land, the Government has imposed sharp limits on land leasing and on the building of luxury villas, office buildings and country clubs. The rules are part of a broad program to slow the economy in order to avoid inflation -- a fear that recession-racked Europe and a weakly recovering United States might look on with envy.
 
Bass-Led Specialty Food Buyout
 
It was overshadowed last week by the A.T.&T.-McCaw megadeal, but it was a billion-dollar event nonetheless. In a $1.1 billion leveraged buyout, a group of investors led by Texan Robert M. Bass purchased eight American specialty food companies from Beledia N.V., a Dutch food conglomerate. With $2.1 billion in combined revenues, the eight acquisitions -- all leaders in their fast-growing markets -- make such well-known products as Bagel Crisps and Country Hearth bread. The deal creates one of the largest specialty food companies in the country.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
N.J. Sting on Insurance Fraud
 
"All Aboard!" The standard train-and-bus directive got an insidious second meaning last week, as New Jersey investigators announced the results of a three-year insurance fraud sting. Aimed at "ghost riders" -- people who enter buses or trains after an accident and fraudulently claim injury -- the probe consisted of fake, videotaped bus crashes and netted not only bogus passengers but also doctors and lawyers who added their own fraud to the scam. New Jersey is apparently not alone. The National Insurance Crime Bureau, an industry group, estimates that 10 percent to 30 percent of the country's $1.3 billion medical bill for vehicle accidents consists of fraudulent or abusive claims. But, notwithstanding these numbers, "ghost riders" and other forms of fraud "have not been addressed in the health care debate," said Samuel Fortunato, New Jersey's insurance commissioner.

Business to Foot Health Bill
 
In his first health care speech since taking office, President Clinton told the nation's governors that business will foot the insurance bill under his reforms -- but not all right away. Employers will make payments ranging from 3.5 percent of payroll for small businesses to 7 percent of payroll for large ones, Mr. Clinton said, but these levies will be phased in over five to seven years. During that time, savings from the cost-control measures of health reform will accumulate; that money will then help subsidize the insurance costs of small and low-wage businesses when the payroll plan takes full effect. The President also confirmed that health reform will extend coverage to America's 37 million uninsured, and will assemble large purchasing cooperatives for whose business insurers will compete. The complete plan will be revealed next month.
 
Six Companies Vow to Recycle
 
If you make it, we'll buy it. Recycled paper, that is. Such was the message six large companies sent the nation's paper makers last week, vowing to use more recycled paper by decade's end. Assembled by the Environmental Defense Fund, the group consists of Duke University, Johnson & Johnson, McDonald's, Nationsbank, Prudential Insurance and Time Warner. The vast paper needs of the six -- Prudential alone buys $300 million of paper a year -- will encourage the paper industry to make more recycled paper, the Environmental Defense Fund hopes. Similarly, President Clinton is soon expected to require Federal agencies to include more recycled product in the 300,000 tons of paper they use yearly. These giant private and public consumers can surely help the cause, but there's still a long way to go: Only 6 percent of writing and printing paper is now recycled.

Surprise! A Giant Trade Deficit
 
Lots coming in, but not much going out: What's good for a bank account was unwelcome news for the nation's trade balance in June, which registered a $12.06 billion deficit. "Holy moly!" said one of the many trade experts flabbergasted by the figure, the largest monthly deficit in five years. Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown offered one gloss on the gloomy news, saying economic stagnation abroad has lessened foreign demand for American goods. This would explain the 3.3 percent drop in exports from May, to $37.65 billion. But what about the 5.1 percent jump in imports, to $49.71 billion, from May to June? A strong recovery that sharply increased American demand for imports would be a good explanation -- but in fact, the domestic recovery has been weak. Trade experts continue to ponder the mystery.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Man, Office and Mechanical Bride

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
SOMETIMES a cigar is just a cigar, said Sigmund Freud, but usually it's not. Everyday objects have meaning as well as utility, a point made wittily by the exhibit that opened last week at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in New York. "Mechanical Brides: Women and Machines From Home to Office," as the exhibit is called, juxtaposes objects used in what is typically regarded as "women's work" -- the washing machine, telephone and typewriter -- with images used over the years to sell the objects. It is a painless, fascinating nutshell history of America's romance with consumption, socio-economic changes associated with that romance in the last century and the different experiences of men and women.
In the late 19th century, technological innovations transformed the middle-class household. Women who had labored at -- or supervised -- the production of food, clothing and furniture or housewares became consumers of mass-produced goods. The male-dominated world of commerce learned to sell its products to women, or rather, to the prevailing cultural stereotypes of women, appealing to emotions as well as utility. "Everything your heart desires," promised a Eureka swivel-top vacuum cleaner ad reprinted in a book called "Mechanical Brides" published by the Cooper-Hewitt and the Princeton Architectural Press. "So quiet!" "Adjustable suction!" "Gets it all!" "Follow your heart (and commonsense, too)." 
 Designers followed suit. From the 1920's into the 50's, appliances were designed in the streamlined form of modes of transportation. The classic, unfussy appliances of that era, their moving parts concealed by a smooth, easy-to-clean exterior, were meant to appeal to women, who were regarded as the "chief custodians of modern standards of hygiene," the book says.
The female-as-object strategy apparently worked so well that by mid-20th-century, J. Gordon Lippincott, a leading industrial designer, would inscribe the principle in his textbook "Design for Business": "If hard-headed business men could build up . . . the cosmetic industry in a few years, and do it on sheer emotional appeal to the American woman, there is no reason why such common everyday objects as alarm clocks, prefabricated homes, hair curlers, and helicopters should not be sold on the same basis."
Contemporaneous with the revolution in consumer behavior were changes in what would become the white-collar workplace. Until the last quarter of the 19th century, nearly all clerical workers were men. An industrious clerk could dream of advancement and upward mobility, perhaps into a high-prestige secretarial position. The almost exclusively male province changed, the exhibit notes, with "unprecedented speed." By 1890, women held 60 percent of all typing and stenography jobs in the United States; 10 years later, 77 percent. By 1920, women held 9 out of 10 typing and stenography jobs. By 1990, 99 percent of secretaries were women.
The change represented a convergence of supply and demand. The explosion of commerce at the end of the century created a market for educated workers; expanded educational opportunities for women created a qualified pool -- and a qualified pool that would work for low wages. The introduction of the -- genderless -- typewriter cleared the way for employers to hire women, who were assumed to be working for "pin money," without being criticized for displacing men.
By the turn of the century, the sexual division of labor outside the office had begun to replicate itself at work. Scientific manag- ers, with their hierarchies and division of tasks into infinite regressions of repetitive motions, imposed their will on offices, which came to resemble factories. Women landed at the bottom of the hierarchy and with them went the prestige and promise of clerical work.
But they would remain the consumers of equipment, a fact reflected in ads for typewriters and telephones. The title "Mechanical Brides" is an homage to Marshall McLuhan, who included an essay on technology and the female body in his 1951 book "The Mechanical Bride: Folklore of Industrial Man." Women's bodies, McLuhan observed, were viewed as sets of constituent, detachable parts that could be plucked out of one context and set in another. Legs were used to sell stockings, hands to sell coffeemakers; rarely was the entire woman in evidence.
The detachable parts images were especially prevalent in ads for office furniture and equipment. In one ad, "The shortest distance between the thought and the perfectly typewritten letter is the new easy-writing Royal typewriter." The thought is represented by a purposeful-looking man, the perfectly typewritten letter by a Royal typewriter and two female hands. The disembodied parts of women link the man, the technology and the task.
One of the strengths of the exhibit, which the Cooper-Hewitt hopes to take on the road, is that the voices of people as well as their images are present. The room dedicated to telephones -- the exhibit is sponsored by the Nynex Corporation -- contains a bank of phones visitors may use to "call" retired operators, who reminisce on tape. In its early days, the telephone company simply absorbed what was regarded as women's special relationship with the telephone -- the pleasure they take from chatting during those leisure hours made possible by the Eureka vacuum cleaner -- and made it policy. The first operators were men, one of the operators says, but they didn't have the patience to deal with the public. Women were polite and sunny.
New technology has weakened the association of women with keyboards and telephones, though many high-tech companies seem unsure of what to make of the brave new division of labor. Apple, in one of the few Powerbook ads it directs at women, uses the not-very-now image of salon hair dryers. Apple's marketing division might want to take a little trip to the Cooper-Hewitt.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
60 or Older? Aim to Preserve Wealth

SERIES: Third of three articles on investing by generation.

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
AFTER investing for growth in their 20's and 30's, then building wealth in their middle years, 60's-plus investors -- on the verge of retiring or already there -- should structure their fund holdings to provide cash flow and preserve wealth.
"People need to understand that at 70 they still have a substantial life expectancy," said Harold R. Evensky, a financial planner in Coral Gables, Fla. So they need income to cover expenses and protection from inflation. Equity could provide that protection, but stocks are more volatile than bonds. Thus retirees must balance three conflicting goals: income, growth and low volatility. 
 Most important is to recognize that what happened in the 1980's -- when investors earned double-digit returns on such super-safe investments as certificates of deposit and money market funds -- was a historical anomaly. There's no such thing as a "safe" 8 percent return anymore, planners say. Still, the most common mistake many retirees make today is to invest too conservatively. Investing in C.D.'s and bonds "won't protect against purchasing-power erosion," said Carol C. Pankros, a planner in Palatine, Ill.
That's why most advisers recommend gradually shifting into bonds as you grow older. One rule of thumb: subtract your age from 100 to derive your percentage in equities. For example, a 70-year-old would keep 30 percent of his or her portfolio in stocks. But retirees with more than $1 million in assets might consider leaving up to one-half in equities, Ms. Pankros advised.
To reduce stock fund volatility, Mr. Evensky would eliminate aggressive growth, growth and international funds (which invest only outside the United States), replacing them with balanced and equity-income funds. He likes T. Rowe Price Equity-Income and SoGen International, a global balanced fund. (Global funds include domestic stocks.)
Similarly, Katharine A. McGee, a planner in St. Louis, said she recommends stock funds with "downside protection and dividend income." She likes high-dividend-paying funds, like Wellesley Income and USAA Mutual Income, especially for pension plan rollovers because, "If the stock market moves sideways, as it did in the 70's, the dividend yield is an assured return." Ms. McGee's two other favorites: Fidelity Utilities Income and Dodge & Cox Balanced.
On the bond side, consider after-tax returns, said Ross Levin, a planner in Minneapolis. "A lot of people think they should invest only in munis, but that's not always the best answer," he said. Some retirees can control their retirement plan withdrawals and remain in low tax brackets, but that would reduce the "taxable equivalent yield" on their municipal bond funds.
To calculate the "taxable equivalent yield" of a muni bond fund, divide the tax-free yield by 100 minus your tax rate. For example, if a muni fund yields 4 percent and you are in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent yield is 5.6 percent (4 divided by .72).
People in low tax brackets might consider increasing yields with intermediate-term bond funds. Mr. Evensky recommends two: PIMCO Total Return and Managers Intermediate Mortgage.
Muni bond investors should be aware that loading up too heavily on tax-free investments can backfire if they collect Social Security. One-half of Social Security payments becomes taxable when adjusted gross income plus one-half of the payments plus tax-exempt income exceeds $32,000 for couples ($25,000 for single taxpayers). Starting in 1994, up to 85 percent of payments will be taxed for couples earning more than $44,000 ($34,000 for singles).
When figuring your cash needs, focus on total return, which takes into account income plus capital appreciation. So when it's time to rebalance your portfolio, "Don't automatically move out of growth funds into high-dividend-paying stocks or income funds," Ms. McGee said. Instead, to avoid paying the capital gains tax due when shares are sold, liquidate part of your portfolio each year to generate income.
For cash, withdraw money from taxable investments first and allow tax-deferred accounts to continue to grow, keeping in mind that minimum distributions from retirement plans must begin by April 1 of the year after you turn 70 1/2. (Wealthy investors can reduce the required minimum distribution by adding a young beneficiary to their account.)
Best bet for cash: Use the systematic withdrawal plans that many mutual fund companies offer, Ms. Pankros said. The fund will automatically liquidate shares and send you checks at regular intervals. "Pick two of your 10 funds, knowing that they will be depleted in two or three years, then switch" to another fund, she said.
As for estate planning, couples should "equalize estates to take full advantage of the estate tax exclusion," which exempts up to $600,000 of assets on each estate, said Eileen Sharkey, a financial planner in Denver. If one spouse holds title to the house, for example, shift the title to mutual fund retirement plan investments to the other spouse.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Mitsubishi's New Galant Makes Its Bow

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
"Turbochargers, intercoolers, air dams, 0-60 times . . . these are not the priorities for today's typical mid-size car buyers."
 Mitsubishi company literature
WELL, maybe, but it depends on whom you talk to. Certainly, it is true for most shoppers in the burgeoning middle segment of the market, and those are the people whom Mitsubishi is targeting with its all-new 1994 Galant. 
 They are, according to the company, a diverse group that ranges from young professionals and families to more mature couples. That makes them harder to please than buyers in a smaller niche, and the Galant faces tough competition from Toyota's Camry, Honda's Accord and Ford's Taurus, among others.
But the third-generation of Mitsubishi's bread-and-butter sedan offers a raft of features that ought to help it do well.
For a start, the front-wheel-drive Galant is considerably bigger than its predecessor in all of its dimensions, making it a true mid-sized car. In addition, it is now among the most aerodynamic automobiles in the world, and the style is pleasing if somewhat bland.
The four-door body is far stiffer than in the past, but front and rear "crumple zones" are designed to absorb the force of an accident, while tubular door beams protect against side impacts. Dual air bags are standard, and antilock brakes are optional.
Mitsubishi views the Galant as its key model for the '90's, and it is being built at the company's Diamond Star assembly plant in Normal, Ill., which also turns out the Eclipse sport coupe. That means that domestic production will account for nearly 60 percent of the company's American volume, and the Galant will be exported around the world.
The car comes in four flavors, starting with an S model and escalating through ES, LS and GS. Prices range from $13,600 for the S to $21,277 for the GS, a new designation for a sporty version that has more power, a fancier interior and a rear spoiler.
The test car was a $16,775 ES, the middle of the line with a standard automatic transmission. Its only options -- $924 antilock brakes and $73 floormats -- brought the total price to $17,772.
The rounded body was dressed in silver-gray metallic paint, with contours reminiscent of the Diamante, Mitsubishi's luxury flagship. Headlights are integrated into the grille, and the lines of the low nose flow up to the cabin and around curved glass to blend with the tapered corners at the rear.
The fluid shape gives the Galant a .29 coefficient of drag, down from .35 for the '93 model, and the aerodynamics are helped by a smooth underbody and a front skirt that directs air away from the suspension and lower part of the engine.
Bumpers are body-colored and rated to withstand a 5-mile-an-hour impact without damage. At the rear, liftover is at bumper height, making it easy to load the reasonably large trunk, and the rear seatback folds down with the push of a single button, extending the 12.5-cubic-foot cargo area for long objects.
Inside, the ES was not exactly luxurious, but it was well thought out and had such niceties as standard power windows and doorlocks. The switches for both were conveniently situated in the armrests, and the driver's window had a one-touch down function.
The ES also lacked the sunroof that is standard in the LS and GS models -- a feature that probably ought to be an option. Power seat adjustments are absent from all Galants, although the manual levers tailor a position five or six ways, depending on the model.
In fact, the seats are quite comfortable, with long lower cushions on the front buckets. There is good room in back as well, and the test car's gray vinyl and cloth interior was spruced up with seat inserts that put a dither of red speckles among the gray.
The Galant's four-spoked wheel houses an air bag, and the bag for the front passenger resides over a very large glovebox. Storage elsewhere is good, too, and a padded lid over a console bin serves as a center armrest. A retractable dual cupholder hides at the forward end of the console, just above an ashtray that is large and usable.
Instrumentation is likewise large and easily readable. The two main gauges, a 140-m.p.h. speedometer and an 8,000-r.p.m. tachometer, are flanked by smaller dials for temperature and fuel.
Of those, the gas gauge was the most interesting, with the needle drifting down ever so slowly in a week's worth of driving, and a check of consumption and the size of the tank showed why. Economy is rated at 22 miles per gallon, city, and 28, highway, and the tank -- tucked safely ahead of the rear axle -- holds 16.9 gallons, which gives the car a range of more than 400 miles between fill-ups.
All of the '94 Galants are powered by a new 2.8-liter four with 16 valves, mounted sideways and driving the front wheels. Horsepower for all but the GS model is rated at 141, up 20 from the '93 car. The GS produces 160 horses, and that alone might make the sportier level of trim worth considering.
In fact, if there is one problem with the new Galant, it is that acceleration is somewhat less than dashing, particularly when the new and environmentally friendly air-conditioner puts a drain on the engine. But then, as the literature said, hot-rodding is not what this car is about.
Its strong suits are space, comfort and safety, and those things are liable to garner more than a polite tip of the hat from today's savvy shoppers.

HEADLINE: Iran's Shadow;
Fundamentalism Alters the Mideast's Power Relationships

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE bomb explosion that killed five people and wounded Egypt's Interior Minister in downtown Cairo last week added a sense of urgency to Washington's concern over the challenge of Islamic fundamentalism to the West and its allies in the Muslim world.
A group known as al-Jihad claimed responsibility for the attack on the minister, Hassan al-Alfi, but so far Egyptian police have made no arrests. From his hospital bed, Mr. Alfi condemned the attackers and questioned how true Muslims could plot murder against their brethren. His harsh tone mirrored the stern measures Egypt has taken against radical Islamists. Since December, Egyptian military courts have sentenced to death 25 Muslim fundamentalists who have been engaged in violent anti-Government activity, including four condemned yesterday for murder and plotting to overthrow the Government. 
 Some American officials are worried about Islamic fundamentalism the way they once worried about communism, and regard it as being in some ways more vexing. Unlike the old Soviet bloc, radical Islamic clerics using the teachings of Mohammed and the tactics of urban guerrilla warfare cannot be confronted by a Strategic Defense Initiative or an arms buildup. And, as in the case of the limited American action against Sudan last week, tough diplomatic or military measures are often ruled out because of other concerns.
The West, Hassan al-Turabi, leader of Sudan's National Islamic Front, once boasted, "is even more apprehensive about Islam than it was about communism, because while it knows how to deal with material challenges, it has no idea how to go about facing a spiritual challenge."
The diplomatic complexities were evident in the Clinton Administration's response to what it sees as the threat posed by Sudan. The State Department, accusing the Sudanese of supporting groups that seek to undermine friendly Arab countries, last week put Sudan on the list of countries that sponsor international terrorism. While the decision renders Sudan ineligible for some American aid, the Administration stopped short of breaking diplomatic relations. State Department officials said they were concerned that Sudan might use such a decision as a pretext for blocking distribution of food and medicine in the famine-stricken south.
"As far as our relationship with Sudan, that's pretty low down on our list of policy interests," a State Department official said of concern over Sudan's support of terrorist groups. "The humanitarian crisis in the south ranks well above anything else." Maybe so, but this doesn't mean the Administration is sanguine about Sudan's ties to Iran or its strategic location for exporting revolution to other Arab countries.
Elsewhere, the Administration has supported Israel's effort to inch closer to the Palestine Liberation Organization, which increasingly is viewed as more acceptable than fundamentalist Palestinian groups like Hamas. And although the United States has a longstanding policy that seeks to isolate Libya, it has raised no objections to the warming of relations between Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and the Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi.
Mr. Mubarak visited Libya last week in a vain attempt to broker a deal by which Mr. Qaddafi would surrender two suspects in the bombing of Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, which killed 270 people. The United Nations Security Council has given Libya until Oct. 1 to hand over the men or face international economic sanctions. Diplomats say Mr. Mubarak is worried that such sanctions could mean the return of thousands of Egyptian expatriate workers in Libya to Egypt, where they would add to his country's unemployment.
 
Prime Target
 Indeed, the United States is above all concerned about the stability of Egypt, its best friend in the Arab world and the country many see as the prime target of the fundamentalists. "The prize, of course, is Egypt because of its tremendous population," said Patrick Clawson, an expert on Iran at the National Defense University and a former Sudanese desk officer at the International Monetary Fund. "It is the cultural and political center for the Arab world. If you have an Islamic government in Egypt you will have influence throughout the Arab world."
Still, if the growth of radical Muslim fundamentalism has its own domino theory, then Sudan may be considered the first domino. Ever since Iranian Muslim clerics overthrew the Shah in 1979, Iran has sought to export what it terms the Islamic Revolution. The emerging ties between Iran and Sudan indicate that the effort is succeeding in a strategically placed nation, American officials say.
"Take out a map and look at it," said a senior Clinton Administration official. "From the Iranian point of view, Sudan is strategically located: south to Africa, north and west to Egypt and North Africa. It gives the Iranians a strategic toehold, which can help promote its revolutionary cause in Algeria, Egypt, Tunisia, Sudan itself and south."
Though the listing as a terrorist state came at a time when some press reports linked Sudan with a plot to bomb the United Nations building and other targets in New York, State Department officials say their action was based on evidence that the Sudanese Government allows groups like Abu Nidal, Hezbollah and Palestine Islamic Jihad to operate out of Sudan and menace nearby countries. Administration officials would not say whether the al-Jihad, the group suspected in the Cairo bombing, has direct ties to the Khartoum government.
 
Militant History
 While denying support of terrorist groups, Sudanese leaders do not shy away from the claim that they are behind fundamentalists operating in other countries.
Sudan itself has a history of militant Islamic fundamentalism. In the 1880's Mohammed Ahmed ibn al-Sayyid, a spiritualist, proclaimed himself the "Mahdi" or messiah, and led a revolt against the country's Turkish, Egyptian and British rulers. In 1885 the Mahdists conquered Khartoum and killed Gen. Charles George Gordon, the British governor.
After a period of relative tolerance the country imposed strict adherence to Muslim law in the 1980's. But it became bogged down in a debilitating civil war against the largely Christian southern part of the country and was not considered a major player in the broader Islamic movement. Then in December 1991 Iran's President, Ali Akbar Hashemi-Rafsanjani, and other leaders of Iran's Islamic Revolution visited Khartoum and agreed to supply Sudan with free oil, sell it arms, send Revolutionary Guards to help the Sudanese Government in its battle with southern rebels and provide training in Sudan to Sudanese and Arab fundamentalists.
Some analysts say the role of Sudan in the fundamentalist movement is more symbolic than real; that the attractiveness of such groups in Egypt, Algeria and Tunisia owes more to poverty and social inequities than to Sudanese material support.
Moreover, there are centrifugal forces in the relationship between Iran and Sudan. One is the theocratic differences between Sunni and Shiite Muslims. And Iran, still reeling economically from its Iraqi war , has not fulfilled its pledges of economic assistance to Sudan.
Still, American policy makers say they cannot ignore the boasts coming out of Sudan that the sweep of fundamentalism is inevitable. "It's a matter of time, actually," Mr. Turabi, the Islamic Front leader, warned last year. "In 10 years you will have quite a number of countries."
