HEADLINE: Building Slump Is Seen as Brake On a Recovery

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
Construction, normally an important engine in America's economic recoveries and a big creator of jobs, is continuing its slump and acting as a drag on the rebound, economists say.
In every other business cycle over the last 20 years, real estate construction -- especially commercial construction -- has helped lead the economy into recovery. But this time, the overbuilding of the 1980's and the subsequent crash in values have slammed the commercial real estate industry into its worst depression since the 1930's, sending total construction to its lowest level in years. And most real estate analysts see no immediate change ahead. 
 "If we had had a normal real estate market recovery, the growth in the economy would have been one-half to one percentage point higher each year," said Kenneth T. Rosen, a professor at the Center for Real Estate and Urban Economics at the University of California at Berkeley.
 
Commercial Overbuilding
 Construction typically accounts for about 5 percent of the gross domestic product, he said, but the entire building sector, including related industries that benefit from construction, probably accounts for 10 percent or 15 percent.
While the recession has hurt all American construction, the hardest-hit sector has been commercial office space, where the worst of the overbuilding took place in the 1980's. That market is not likely to see significant new construction until 1997 at the earliest, predicts David G. Shulman, a managing director at Salomon Brothers who earned a reputation as a seer for predicting the real estate crash. He estimates that it will take more than 11 years to absorb the nation's existing supply of office space.
Other segments of the construction market, though less badly hurt, are not showing their usual post-recession strength, either. Single-family housing starts, one of the nation's most closely watched indicators, have shown steady but moderate increases this year, and most economists expect the weakness in apartment construction, now at less than $9 billion in annual activity, to end soon.
Industrial construction spending is at a seven-year low, running at about $18 billion a year. And retail construction is at a 10-year low of about $22 billion a year, down from a 1985 high of about $35 billion.
But office-building construction -- which represented one third of all nonresidential building at the peak of the market -- has taken the deepest nose dive. At the top of the commercial construction boom in 1985, office construction spending was running at about $37 billion a year in constant 1987 dollars, according to statistics compiled by the Census Bureau. By the second quarter of this year, that had dipped to an annual rate of $13.1 billion, marking the 17th consecutive quarter of decline and the lowest level since 1979, with no turnaround in sight.
 
An Effect on Jobs
 The continued shrinkage in commercial construction has contributed to the nation's slow growth in jobs. Construction done under contract typically contributes about 10 percent of the jobs generated in the first year of a normal recovery, said David A. Wyss, research director at DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic consulting firm. "But in this recovery, in the first year, contract construction jobs declined 2 percent," he said.
The effects can be seen in the business of real estate developers like Mortimer B. Zuckerman, owner of the Boston Properties development concern. "We used to build well over a million feet a year, but we have not started a new building now in three years," he said. Furthermore, the company has not built a speculative building -- that is, one without a previously agreed-upon tenant -- for five years.
Prospects for a recovery in the office-building market remain grim for many reasons: the shakiness of the recovery, the huge amount of overbuilding that took place, the repercussions from a global economic slowdown, the general trend toward cutting corporate payrolls, the decline in military-related industries after the cold war's end, and changes in technology and demographics that are changing the American work force.
The world of real estate is littered with the carcasses of development concerns that went out of business as a result of the crash or have tried to pull back and focus on activities other than building. Perhaps the most spectacular meltdown was that of Olympia & York, the Canadian real estate giant whose Canadian and English branches went into bankruptcy, nearly pulling the United States branch with them. The Trammell Crow Company, a Dallas-based developer that was the nation's largest, has turned from an empire with $15 billion in assets into two entities: a property management and brokerage corporation and a separate property ownership wing with $5.5 billion in assets.
 
Looking Overseas
 Other developers have been nimbler. Jerry I. Speyer, president of Tishman Speyer Properties, said the crash in development opportunities in the United States has led his company to focus on overseas building. "At any one time in the 10 years from 1978 to 1988, we typically would have two to four buildings in planning, two to four in progress and two to four in completion," he said. "Today we basically have zero in that category of development or construction in the United States, but we have replicated that development situation outside of the United States."
As some developers have shriveled, the number of construction jobs in the United States has fallen from a peak of 5.1 million in 1988 to 4.5 million last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. But because of construction's ripple effect on the economy, other jobs have been lost, too -- in architecture and design firms, real estate brokerages, and companies that make products like cement, nails, wallpaper and furniture.
Beyond the construction industry, the slump has had other effects that are less visible. The real estate industry, which typically pays huge property-tax bills, is providing less revenue for governments. And because a house or building is often the biggest asset of a family or a small business, the decline in real estate values during the slump has hurt the economic flexibility and well-being of many Americans.
The pain is also being felt in big corporations and financial institutions. An estimated 25 percent to 40 percent of the assets on corporations' balance sheets are real estate assets. A huge part of the portfolios of banks, insurance companies and other investors comes from real estate, including everything from loans on office buildings to Wall Street securities made of real estate debts. Institutions that lent money for buildings have also been forced to acknowledge that the properties are worth much less than the mortgages issued at the peak of the boom.
 
Some New Money
 Of course, a real estate slump also offers opportunities. Businesses can find better office space at lower rents, which could allow small and start-up enterprises to eventually bring a kick to the economy. Housing is more affordable, especially with lower interest rates. Some investment money has started to come back into the real estate market, particularly in real estate investment trusts, lured by the promise of buying at the bottom of an industry.
Over all, however, many parts of the real estate industry look like a wasteland, with a few bright spots provided by bottom-fishers picking up bargains from distressed sellers.
Economists who look to renewed construction to boost the recovery see few signs of an immediate strong turnaround. Demand for space -- which will precede new building -- has been firming in the apartment market, and Mr. Shulman of Salomon Brothers said the retail real estate sector is showing "some signs of strength." But demand for industrial space is still very soft.
The picture is even grimmer for commercial space. Overbuilding has brought high vacancy rates: 26.7 percent of the office space in central Los Angeles is empty, according to the brokerage Cushman & Wakefield, as well as 22.2 percent in central Chicago, 17 percent in midtown Manhattan and 25.1 percent in Atlanta.
 
Fewer Workers, Less Space
 The office-space market also is lacking some of the ingredients that fueled a turnaround after the last big real estate recession, in the 1970's. At that time, strength in the office market was generated by growing demand for white-collar jobs, and the entry into the workplace of baby boomers, including vast numbers of women.
Today, corporations are cutting back not only on staff but also on space, sometimes in connection with new technologies that allow workers to be productive outside a traditional office. Job growth is running at about one-third the rate it showed in the last recovery.
The range of predictions on a recovery is wide.
In the view of Mr. Speyer of Tishman Speyer Properties: "The pendulum goes 180 degrees; it will come back. And I have every reason to believe that New York is leading the way. The activity in midtown Manhattan in the last six months shows serious evidence of some recovery."
But Mr. Shulman said the crash in real estate in general and construction in particular have yet to work their way through the economy. "I think we're in a very long and extended bottoming process, and unlike the real estate recession of the 1970's, we will not see a quick turnaround," he said. "This will certainly take some of the juice out of any recovery."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 24, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Sunday with an article about the slump in the construction industry misstated the amounts of construction spending on office buildings. The figures were in billions of 1987 dollars, not trillions.

HEADLINE: SAUDI STABILITY HIT BY HEAVY SPENDING OVER LAST DECADE

BYLINE: By Jeff Gerth, Special to The New York Times; The following article is based on reporting by Stephen Engelberg, Jeff Gerth and Tim Weiner and was written by Mr. Gerth.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia, long seen as one of the world's wealthiest countries, has undermined its financial stability with a decade of unrestrained spending, huge military purchases and irregular banking practices.
The $121 billion in financial reserves amassed by Saudi Arabia less than a decade ago have almost vanished, drained by expenditures for weapons, social programs, foreign aid and the Gulf war. The spending has far outstripped the tens of billions of dollars earned annually from the largest oilfields in the world, which the Government owns. 
 Saudi Arabia began to feel the pinch in the mid-1980's, when oil prices fell sharply. Since 1983, the Saudis have racked up 10 consecutive years of budget deficits.
 
Worse Than U.S. Deficit?
 In 1992, according to the United States Department of Commerce, the deficit represented 9.2 percent of Saudi Arabia's gross domestic product, nearly twice the comparable figure in the United States. Other estimates, including those by the International Monetary Fund, are lower.
As the Saudis have forged ahead with ambitious plans to build a well-armed modern state, they have spent their national savings, and now are beginning to buy on credit.
"The Saudis have been drawing down reserves for 10 years," an American official said. "They're a mere shadow of their former selves."
Saudi officials in Riyadh and Washington declined to answer officially a series of requests for interviews and questions concerning the financial condition of the country submitted in writing to the Saudi Embassy. But some Saudi officials and businessmen agreed to discuss their country's financial problems provided they were not identified.
 
'Not a Scandal'
 With plenty of oil and relatively little foreign debt, the Saudis contend they have financial prospects far better than most developing countries. "It's not a poor country," said a Saudi official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "It's not a scandal that we're not paying cash anymore. We have an infrastructure that will take us way into the 21st century."
The weakened financial condition of Saudi Arabia is no secret to some in international financial circles. But the magnitude of the decline, and its potential political and economic consequences, have not yet grabbed the attention of the United States Congress or the highest levels of the executive branch.
Evidence of the Saudis' financial straits was supplied by Saudi businessmen and officials, American foreign-policy and financial officials, Saudi Government documents and independent analysts in the United States, Europe and the Middle East. Most spoke on the condition that they not be identified, citing the Saudi Government's sensitivity to the topic.
These are among the Saudis' troubles disclosed:
*Strains on the banking system, including billions of dollars in uncollected loans to members of the Saudi royal family, the indictment in the United States of the head of the largest Saudi bank and sudden demands from the Saudi Government to borrow money. Saudi banks took on a threefold increase of Government debt from 1989 to mid-1992.
*Requests for billions of dollars in loans and credit guarantees from the West.
*Anxiety among international institutions, including the Bank of England and the International Monetary Fund. The staff of the I.M.F., in a secret report in 1992 on the Saudi economy, expressed new concern about the country's chronic budget deficits, which it said were fueled last year by military spending and a reluctance to trim social programs.
These developments have profound implications for the United States and the Middle East.
Saudi Arabia is America's largest supplier of oil, closest Arab ally and best customer for weapons exports. Washington relies on Riyadh for a host of favors, from discreet cajoling of its Arab neighbors to covert financing of Central Intelligence Agency operations. Saudi Arabia has long played a pivotal role in moderating increases in oil prices by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
Until now, the Saudis have used their riches to buy security at home and abroad. The estimated 10 million citizens of Saudi Arabia pay virtually no taxes and enjoy an elaborate array of benefits, from education to health care.
In the region, the Saudis have spent tens of billions of dollars to buy off potential enemies, from Iraq to Jordan to the Palestine Liberation Organization. The Saudi ruler, King Fahd, keeps rivalries in check by allowing the kingdom's 4,000 princes easy access to the banking system, Government subsidies and secret commissions on weapons deals, according to American and Saudi officials and businessmen.
In part because of a cash shortage in Saudi Arabia, its lavish aid to foreign countries has been trimmed, the officials said. Few new orders are likely for the ailing American arms industry. But while the Saudis have postponed one major deal, the country remains committed to buying nearly all of the $30 billion of weapons already under contract.
American officials agreed that years of stagnant oil prices and an immense military buildup had brought Saudi Arabia to a crossroads. But officials in Washington said they remained confident that the ruling monarchy had the resilience and ingenuity to make the tough choices that were unimagined in the boom years.
Saudi officials have in recent months informed their American counterparts of a fundamental decision: They intend to put the purchases of weapons first, and cut Saudi citizens' subsidies where necessary. But independent analysts, including the I.M.F. officials, have raised questions about whether the Saudis had the political will for this sort of austerity.
The most recent I.M.F. staff report on Saudi Arabia noted that the Saudis intended to continue payments to their neighbors in the Middle East.
While the report commended the Saudis for planning to make budget cuts, it said the cuts would not stop the Saudis' trade and budget deficits from deepening by billions of dollars over the next five years.
"There's a whole lot of things they can do that will let them slide for the next two to three years, but their underlying structural problems are enormous," said Patrick L. Clawson, a senior fellow at the National Defense University and former I.M.F. economist. "Saudi Arabia is now our strategic ally. If your strategic ally has structural economic problems, you have to worry.
"Combine that with the fact that your ally is an absolutist monarchy that has moved very slowly to democratization of a society in which political opposition is expressed in a way that can easily turn into anti-Westernism, you really have to worry."
 
The Economy
After the Oil Boom, An Economic Bust
 Saudi Arabia has a one-crop economy that underwrites a welfare state. The price of that crop, oil, collapsed in the 1980's, and today stands significantly lower than in the boom years.
Though the Government has slowed some spending, revenues have never kept up. "They are spending and living as a country the same as they did in the 1970's," said an American who works for a leading Saudi business. "They haven't adapted to the sea change in the marketplace."
Saudi Arabia's treasury began to reap the benefits from the pools of oil first discovered in the 1930's when price increases were imposed by OPEC after the 1973 Arab-Israeli war. The Saudis used the flood of cash to transform their country from a tribal state into a modern monarchy. They installed telephones, built highways and carved out seaports. Beginning in 1980, the Government poured money into education, health care and social services, Saudi budget documents show.
Then came the world oil glut, and a drastic drop in prices for the source of three-quarters of the Government's revenue. The value of the dollar, the currency used for oil sales, also dropped.
 
A Decade of Deficits
 In the 1980's, the fiscal policies of the Saudis began to resemble those of the United States. A decade of deficits began in 1983 with a huge military buildup. The rulers of Saudi Arabia refused to cut entitlement programs and continued to pay off potential adversaries, including more than $20 billion in payments and loans to Iraq. Oil revenues remained far less than the country was spending. Annual budget deficits ranged from $4 billion to $18 billion, according to I.M.F. estimates.
Saudi Arabia also ran huge trade deficits. From 1983 to 1991, its imports of goods and services exceeded the value of its exports, primarily oil, by $120 billion, according to the I.M.F.
No goal was too costly. Saudi officials decided to turn deserts into wheat fields using price supports and water drained from ancient aquifers. Saudi Arabia is now the sixth-largest exporter of wheat in the world, according to Commerce Department statistics. Leading members of the royal family are the principal beneficiaries of the subsidies, according to a Saudi official.
"Subsidizing wheat is crazy for the Saudis," said William Quandt, a former National Security Council official who has studied Saudi Arabia for 20 years. "But, of course, a lot of Saudis have made money on this."
 
The Gulf War
A Hefty Price Tag Adds to the Burden
 The gulf war tightened the financial pressures on Saudi Arabia. President George Bush sent half a million Americans to defend the kingdom and push Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait, but insisted that the Saudis bear the brunt of the financial burden.
The war cost the Saudis $55 billion, according to a 1991 study by the International Monetary Fund. Of that, $12.8 billion was paid directly to the United States. Most American officials agreed with the assertion by the Saudis that the high cost of the war -- equal to the entire annual budget of Saudi Arabia -- was responsible for most of the country's current difficulties.
But the I.M.F. studies questioned that argument. Soon after the United Nations banned the sale of Iraqi crude oil, Saudi Arabia's oil output jumped to 8 million barrels day from 5.5 million, the studies said. That extra oil was worth an additional $24 billion in revenue for the Saudis in 1991, and at least the same amount in later years.
As a result, industry analysts said, the ban on Iraqi oil has allowed Saudi Arabia to recover most, if not all, of the costs of the war.
Deficit spending continues. Saudi Arabia announced this year that it would spend $7.4 billion more than it would take in. The Government said it planned to establish 6 new colleges, 800 new schools, 500 health care clinics and 500,000 telephone lines. The largest portion of the $52 billion budget, $16 billion, was set aside for defense and security.
 
The Remedies
Postponing a Saudi Day of Reckoning
 Saudi Arabia has used an array of strategies to postpone the day of reckoning, according to Government officials and private analysts.
The Saudis began by drawing on the huge dollar reserves built up when oil prices were high.
According to official Saudi statistics, the foreign assets and currency reserves of the central bank fell to $51 billion at the end of last year from $121 billion in 1984.
But that lower figure was overstated, private analysts and Saudi officials said. It included as much as $20 billion in loans to Iraq that are unlikely to be collected. Much of the rest is unavailable to the Saudis, the I.M.F. said, because it must be set aside to back the Saudi currency and to finance trade deals. One Saudi official estimated that his country's liquid reserves -- money that can be readily tapped -- were as low as $7 billion.
 
Resistance from Lenders
 As reserves dropped in the late 1980's, Saudis went to international banks for loans -- and met with some reluctance, despite their billions of barrels of unpumped oil.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York put together the first big international line of credit for the Saudis in 1991, to help meet a demand from Congress for quick payment of the bills from the Gulf war. But British banks refused to participate.
According to American and Saudi officials, the British central bank, the Bank of England, has expressed strong concerns about the creditworthiness of Saudi Arabia.
A Saudi official disagreed with the bank's view, but said it had hurt his country because other central banks assumed it was accurate.
 
Guarantees Needed
 American officials and bankers estimated that Saudi Arabia would need to borrow $3 billion to $10 billion this year. International banks are unlikely to lend these amounts unless European or American governments guaranteed that the money would be repaid. Similarly, it is clear to American and European airplane companies angling for a $6 billion contract with the Saudi national airline that the deal will require government-guaranteed financing.
Like other developing countries, Saudi Arabia needs a steady flow of dollars to finance trade deficits and movements of capital out of the country by wealthy citizens.
This points up an important difference between Riyadh and Washington. While both countries are running budget and trade deficits, the United States can easily sell its bonds, in dollars, around the world. Saudi Arabia cannot.
Imposing taxes would ease the budgetary burden. "But then," Mr. Quandt, the former National Security Council official, said, "people might get around to asking for representation in exchange."
 
The Banks
Holes in a System Concern the U.S.
 American officials wring their hands over the financial statistics of Saudi Arabia because no one believes all the numbers the Saudis publish. But what worries them most is the country's secretive banking system.
Buried deep in the most recent annual report of the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency, the country's central bank, is a statistic that speaks volumes: From 1989 to mid-1992, the Government's debt to Saudi banks more than tripled. It rose to $15.1 billion from $4 billion -- to 32 percent of all bank deposits from less that 10 percent. A Saudi banker estimated that the total Government debt held by the banks was now $20 billion -- or 40 percent of deposits -- roughly twice the percentage of the Government debt owned by American banks.
Saudi bankers and American officials said some of the banks were resisting demands by the Government to take on further Government debt, but appeared to have little choice.
Some American officials said they believed that Saudi Arabia's published financial statements concealed a grimmer story. They said Saudi banks held a portfolio of bad loans and investments gone sour that could, in relative terms, rival the savings and loan crisis in this country.
 
Fear of Unpaid Loans
 The fear among some American officials stems in part from the billions of dollars in unpaid loans to members of the royal family from the National Commercial Bank, the largest private lending institution in Saudi Arabia. The unpaid loans were described by a number of Government and business officials in the United States and Saudi Arabia.
One American official called the unpaid loans "the biggest black hole in the Saudi economy." Another official noted, however, that he had been assured that the royal family would resolve the matter because it had the "means and the incentive."
A Saudi official said the banking system had ample liquidity but acknowledged there were problems in the National Commercial Bank's relationship with the royal family.
The National Commercial Bank has not issued an audited financial statement in three years. The bank's last audited statement, dated May 15, 1990, disclosed that "certain loans and advances granted to clients and partners" were in violation of Saudi banking law.
 
A B.C.C.I. Connection
 The bank's offices in New York and London were closed last year after criminal fraud charges were brought against its former chief executive.
The charges stemmed from the collapse of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. Some powerful Saudis were among the best customers of the Arab-owned B.C.C.I.
The National Commercial Bank is fighting a $10 billion claim brought by the liquidators of B.C.C.I. The former chief executive of the Saudi bank is also contesting the criminal charges.
Michael Callen, the senior adviser to the chairman of the bank, said the bank would not discuss its customers, but said "the numbers being tossed around for nonperforming loans, like $10 billion, are ridiculous and that will be crystal clear when the audited statements come out," which he said would be no later than September.
A Saudi banker said the loans to the royal family had put Saudi officials in a difficult position, in which they must serve as professional bank regulators yet respect the wishes of an absolute monarch.
The royal family believes "they own the country," he said, adding: "They took it by force of the sword. When the King says, 'Give me a loan,' they believe they're taking their money back."

HEADLINE: Why Do You Do the Things You Do?

BYLINE: By Anthony Gottlieb; Anthony Gottlieb is on the editorial staff of The Economist. He is working on a history of Western philosophy.

 BODY:

THE NATURE OF RATIONALITY
By Robert Nozick.
226 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
Princeton University Press. $19.95. 
 ROBERT NOZICK, the Arthur Kingsley Porter Professor of Philosophy at Harvard University, always attacks his problems in a disconcertingly original way. In 1969 he published a discussion of a bizarre imaginary dilemma, thought up by a scientist at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California but unpublished until then, which opened up a new path for research in decision theory (the theory that tries to work out principles for calculating the desirability of alternative courses of action). Five years later, his first book, "Anarchy, State, and Utopia," was widely acclaimed as a tour de force in political thought. Using a range of techniques, from applications of economics to colorful puzzles about men with death rays, it was an extended argument for a near-anarchist "minimal" state. In 1981 came "Philosophical Explanations," a bloated masterpiece groaning with novel suggestions for coping with several of the main topics of academic philosophy. And in 1989, in "The Examined Life," he took on nothing less than the meaning of life, a subject that academic philosophers tended to steer clear of -- and still do, despite his best efforts.
From Mr. Nozick you always expect fireworks, even if some of them go off in their box. His questions, hints, counterarguments and suggestions come so thick and fast that it is next to impossible to appreciate all of them. Start pondering a sentence and you will find yourself led away prematurely by a parenthetical question; think about the question and you will be dragged into a discursive footnote; from the bowels of the footnote, another parenthetical query will leap out at you. If you escape back to the main argument with your concentration intact (unlikely, after a while), the whole wearing business just starts over again. Yet it is worth the effort -- certainly for regular readers of philosophy, and often for others.
"The Nature of Rationality," Mr. Nozick's latest book, and his most narrowly focused one, happily and untypically manages to concentrate on one topic. One topic, but not just one discipline. The theory of rationality touches many areas of probability: economics, decision theory, anthropology, psychology, biology and computer science. Mr. Nozick pokes into many of them. His learning is deep enough to stop such forays from degenerating into the farces of multidisciplinary cross-dressing that they can easily become in lesser hands.
The questions he addresses are fundamental in the true philosophical sense: Why exactly should we want to act and believe rationally? Why should we formulate principles of action and try to stick to them? The questions are not moral but explicatory. He is not out to argue that unprincipled or irrational behavior is immoral; rather, he invites us to consider what we are trying to do, and what the justification for such behavior is. He argues, plausibly, that "principles . . . provide one means to control and reshape our desires." Among his other main philosophical questions are: What is the connection between rational belief and rational action? And what is the relevance of the fact that rationality is something that has evolved?
Mr. Nozick throws a meaty bone to economists and the many other social scientists who work with decision theory. He proposes several modifications of orthodox accounts that will be found controversial and stimulating. He argues, for example, that a phenomenon he calls "symbolic utility" needs to be written into decision theory. This amounts to a type of connection between an action and its consequences that concerns not the act's propensity to bring these consequences about, but the way in which the act is regarded as representing the valued project of which the action is a component. His characterization of symbolic utility is a little vague, but it won't be by the time the academics have finished with it. This discussion, and much else in the book, are sure to attract a great deal of interest.
THIS part of the book is not accessible. It is not simply difficult; it is very difficult. The browser will find a few equations and other formulas, and will perhaps fear that he or she will not be able to understand them. But, in fact, the equations are the easy part and often come as welcome relief. Too much of the intricate, argumentative prose has too few concrete examples and illustrations to make it anything less than unnecessarily exhausting. Mr. Nozick writes, "I do not want the topic of rationality to be taken away from the general reader." But he has not tried as hard as he might have done to prevent it from becoming so.
Fortunately, there is more than enough here of genuine general interest. The tentative outline of an overall theory of rationality that he proposes to deal with what might be called "Hume's Horror" raises as many questions as it is designed to resolve, but that comes with the territory, and it is a start. (David Hume famously argued that "it is not contrary to reason to prefer the destruction of the whole world to the scratching of my finger.") Mr. Nozick's discussion of the evolutionary significance of rationality is fascinating, particularly the suggestion that some philosophical problems remain unsolved because the mind did not develop to deal with such puzzles. This treatment closes with a reflection that is salutary for those who are oddly distressed by biological intrusions into the human mind and its rational productions: "When the very loftiest human creations are seen to derive from humble origins and functions, what needs revision is not our esteem for these creations but our notion of nobility."

HEADLINE: Two Myths About Mexico

BYLINE: By Harley Shaiken; Harley Shaiken, a visiting professor at the University of California at Berkeley, has written two books on Mexican industry.

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif.

 BODY:
Will the North American Free Trade Agreement unleash economic growth throughout the Americas, as proponents promise, improving environmental and labor standards in the process? Or will it undermine U.S. jobs and wages, as critics charge?
Much of the debate is based on two myths: that Mexico's export sector is limited to low-tech and low-productivity operations and that world-class wages in Mexico will automatically follow world-class productivity. 
 While average productivity is far lower than in the U.S., a new wave of export plants in industries from cars to electronics use advanced technologies and match or exceed U.S. quality and productivity levels. The Ford Escorts produced in Hermosillo, all exported north, ranked fifth in quality out of 46 assembly plants in North America last year, surpassing five Japanese-owned plants.
This quality and productivity, however, is combined with third-world wages. Ford workers in Mexico earn $2.38 an hour compared with $17.50 an hour for workers producing the same model near Detroit. Not only won't Mexican workers be buying many Escorts at these wages, but U.S. consumers will continue to pay the same price wherever the car is produced.
Many say Mexico's market reforms will cause wages to rise. In fact, reform hasn't come to Mexico's controlled labor markets. The Government holds down wages to attract investment, labor rights are truncated and employers often conspire to set wages. As a result, rising productivity doesn't translate into better wages. Although productivity rose by 41 percent between 1980 and 1992, the wages and benefits of a Mexican manufacturing worker last year were only 68 percent of what they were in 1980, a low level to start with. Average compensation totaled $2.35 an hour last year, one-seventh of U.S. earnings.
Proponents of Nafta argue that the increased demand for industrial workers alone will raise wages. Why then hasn't this taken place in the border assembly plants -- maquiladoras -- where employment rose from 131,000 in 1981 to 505,000 in 1992? Instead, wages averaged about $1.15 an hour last year, lower than 1981 levels.
The flip side of low wages is low purchasing power. In Tijuana, the average export plant worker must labor over an hour for a half-gallon of milk and about four hours for a pound of meat, hardly the makings of a robust market.
If artificially depressed wages prevent Mexican workers from entering the middle class, in an increasingly integrated economy, U.S. workers may be knocked out of the middle class. New Mexican plants achieving U.S. productivity levels at one-seventh the wages offer a powerful incentive for many U.S. firms to relocate production or lower their labor costs by threatening to move or both.
Although Trade Representative Mickey Kantor admits that "for decades, Mexico has looked the other way when companies polluted or violated the most basic of worker rights," the side agreements announced the other day provide little protection. The labor accord excludes industrial relations issues -- violations of the right to strike or organize independent unions -- from the possibility of fines or sanctions.
Representative Richard Gephardt criticizes the side agreements as inadequate. This position seeks to expand trade by insuring that people on both sides of the border can buy what they produce. Stronger labor and environmental protections will not artificially raise Mexican wages but will insure that these wages do not remain artificially depressed, undermining U.S. wages and purchasing power.
Expanded trade offers considerable promise for the U.S. and Mexico. A pact that guarantees investment but ignores jobs, incomes and the environment won't realize that promise.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: NORTH AMERICA (94%); UNITED STATES (93%); NORTH & SOUTH AMERICAS (73%); 

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (79%); 

CITY: SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA, CA, USA (59%); 

COMPANY: NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE AGREEMENT (93%); NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE AGREEMENT (93%);

HEADLINE: Arms Industry Yields to Show Business

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
JOHN C. MARKOWICZ was walking through his company's 7,000-square-foot sound stage in Waterford recently explaining how Sonalysts Inc. had achieved the quietest studios in the nation by employing the same technology it used to make American submarines the quietest in the world. But it took a construction crew to force home his point.
As Mr. Markowicz opened a dividing door and stepped into a second sound stage, the din of hammers and drills filled the air. Six men were working on a sliding overhead door, but so perfectly are the studios insulated for sound that there had been no hint of the work in the next room. That kind of quiet is expected to give the company an advantage in attracting film productions because producers will not have to worry about errant noise ruining a "take." 
 Sonalysts Studios, the company's entertainment division, has just opened a 24,000-square-foot film installation in a wooded area off Interstate 95, with sound stages, high-technology film editing equipment, production crew quarters and a 21-seat theater where rushes from a day's shoot can be reviewed.
"That way, you can shoot it, edit it, and go back down there and shoot it again if you don't like the way it came out," said Michael Watt, Sonalysts vice president for marketing. "It's a one-stop film-production facility."
The company has animation capability, a trades building where sets can be constructed, a green room for actors to rest in between shoots and two stars' dressing rooms, identical in size and fixtures so there can be no quibbling over quarters.
 
A Composer on the Staff
 The company's comprehensive approach to movie making can be seen in the two audio suites. Not only does Sonalysts have state-of-the-art music recording, mixing and editing capabilities, it has a composer on the staff.
"To have someone who can sit down and write a piece, score it, and then play the instruments for it, gives us an edge over the places that just do engineering," Mr. Watt said.
And the company already has a reputation in the industry, having won an Oscar two years ago for the sound effects in the movie "The Hunt for Red October."
Mr. Markowicz said film makers could find all Sonalysts' facilities in New York, but it might mean shooting in one location, then driving cross town to edit and another trip to view the rushes. "Every time you have to move from one site to another, your costs go up," he said. "We hope the advantage of being able to do it all in one location is going to attract producers."
The company is already producing live and animated commercials, training films, and other projects for media clients like CBS, Fox Network and the Public Broadcasting System as well as commercial contracts for Loctite, Kaman Corporation, ESPN and the New England Sports Network.
Mr. Markowicz gave a clue to one prospective film project recently when he had "When You Wish Upon a Star" played over the loudspeaker at the studio opening.
The opening showed Mr. Markowicz just how much the studio had captured the imagination of the region. He originally hoped to have 600 people at the opening, but based on early returns from the invitations the estimate climbed to 800, then 1,200. The night of the opening, 2,700 people showed up, including many people in the movie industry.
Mr. Markowicz predicted that the 27-employee, $2 million film division would double over the next 12 to 18 months, and double again over the following 12 to 18 months. Beyond that, he declines to predict where it might go.
 
Diversification Wins Praise
 "Five years ago, I couldn't envision we would be opening this studio," Mr. Markowicz said. "It wasn't even a dream. Don't ask me what the company's going to be doing five years from now.
"We are the new kids on the block in this industry, but we can offer New England as a backdrop," Mr. Markowicz said. "We're going to learn the business. We're not going out next week and produce films. But that will come."
Sonalysts Studios is widely praised as an example of the kind of defense diversification Connecticut must achieve if it is to rebound economically. Sonalysts was founded in 1973 as a naval research and development company. Even today, 65 to 70 percent of its $36.5 million revenues come from the Defense Department, but that percentage is dropping by 1 or 2 percentage points a year as revenues increase 15 or 20 percent.
Among its successful spinoffs have been Vita, a computerized badging system in use at Cornell University, the Chicago Transit Authority and a number of companies. Vita grew out of security work done for the Navy. So did the nuclear consulting division, which now has two dozen people working with the Department of Energy and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to improve safety procedures and training at Russian nuclear plants.
The company has had some flops. It started a second mortgage company in the 1970's that wrote a couple of mortgages before rates soared to 18 percent and the industry foundered. Its business software spinoff won only a couple of contracts before it quietly folded back into the main company, and a football video game developed by Sonalysts for the consumer market never caught on.
 
Help for Other Companies
 Still, the company has done well enough that the state Department of Economic Development recently awarded it a $75,000 contract to help other defense companies diversify.
"You can't fault a company for trying and failing, even failing repeatedly," said a spokesman for the department, Joseph Cohen. "Defense diversification is a time-consuming, dollar-consuming process that is going to be rife with failure."
Defense companies have spent decades in a situation where quality, not cost, is the primary motivation, in established niches where few companies had their expertise. As they turn to consumer products, the emphasis is on price, and there are a lot of competitors.
"This particular company is very good at controlling costs, and that's going to be a big selling point in this latest project they've undertaken," Mr. Cohen said.
That latest project, the film studio off Interstate 95, is a $4 million gamble for the company, but one most people seem to think will pay off. State officials said the Sonalysts studios give Connecticut the potential to become a major movie-making state.
"I don't think 'thrilled' would be overstating our position," said Edward D. Dombroskas, executive director of the Connecticut Division on Tourism, which includes the State Film Commission. "The addition of Sonalysts is a quantum leap for Connecticut's film-making capabilities, giving us all the modern requirements for film production. It's an opportunity for Connecticut to really start to attract film producers."
Locally, a company called Exclusive Connections has already organized to provide transportation, lodging and catering for production crews that might use the Sonalysts studios. And southeastern Connecticut attractions are registering with the Film Commission so movie makers will know what is available.
 
'A Great Future' Predicted
 A spokeswoman for the Mystic Seaport Museum, Elizabeth A. Gwillim, said some of the museum's boats and staff would be in Martin Scorcese's new film, "Age of Innocence," and Mystic Seaport was the boat wrangler -- it obtained the boats -- for Billy Joel's new music video, shot on the Connecticut River. Some fashion layouts and commercials have been filmed at the museum.
"But we've never really looked at the question," Ms. Gwillim said. "If Columbia Pictures showed up here and wanted the entire facility for four days of shooting, would we do it? With Sonalysts in the area, it's opened up the discussion. That could happen, and we want to be ready for it.
"We plan on being very much in a position to cooperate with Sonalysts," Ms. Gwillim said. "We think there's a great future there."
The town has also cooperated with the Sonalysts studio. First Selectman Thomas A. Sheridan said he had guaranteed the company a 24-hour response on any permits required to make a movie.
"That's supposedly a big thing in the movie world," Mr. Sheridan said. "If they want to close a road or put snow down, and you've got a crew standing around waiting, it costs a lot of money for every delay."
 
Town Educates Itself
 He said he had gone to New York City and Wilmington, N.C., to talk to officials in those cities about what might be necessary to accommodate Sonalysts.
"We're educating ourselves as quickly as we can," Mr. Sheridan said. "If they sign a $50 million contract, we want to be ready to respond immediately, and the biggest thing we can do is not hold them up."
He said the town did not bend over backward for every industry, but movie making was clean, relatively innocuous and lucrative. "The financial ripple effect of a feature film to a community is just spectacular," Mr. Sheridan said.
Sonalysts' studio is actually four buildings under a single roof, each isolated from the others by 18 inches of concrete, several layers of gypsum board and six inches of sound insulation. To make it as quiet as possible, the designers incorporated some of the submarine technology Sonalysts developed or refined.
The motors that drive some of the mechanical systems in the building, for instance, are all mounted on large springs, on a concrete pad separate from the main building. The more those sources of vibration are isolated, the less chance they will be heard. The air-conditioning ducts are 36 to 40 inches in diameter, capable of pushing huge quantities of air very slowly and whisper quiet, so the blowing sound typical of air-conditioners is never heard.
A result is a decibel rating of NC15, which is about 64 times lower than NC21, the level that people can hear, Mr. Watt said. "The isolation is so perfect you could be working in one with pneumatic tools and be shooting a quiet love scene in the next studio," he said.
Mr. Watt said the company had also assembled the expertise it needs to attract large productions. Four full-time animators give the company the second largest amount of animating power in New England, behind a company in Sturbridge, Mass., that did the special effects for the movie "2001: A Space Odyssey."
 
Defense Work Still Sought
 The company still competes fiercely for defense contracts, and Mr. Markowicz was one of the loudest voices in the efforts to save the Naval Underwater Warfare Center in New London and the Naval Submarine Base in Groton from closing.
"The first law of diversification is, hold on to what you've got," Mr. Markowicz said. "If you don't have the resources going into it, you can't make the next step. If you've lost the people and the money, you're just not going to make it."
In fact, the company has used its diversification spinoffs to win new military contracts. It is in discussions now with Armed Forces Radio and Television about productions that might be done in the new studios.
On the third Saturday of every month, employees get together to talk about projects. The meetings are well attended because each employee has a direct interest in the company through an employee stock-option trust, and more than 125 employees have bought their own shares outright.
"The feeling is, 'We're all in this canoe together, so I'd better grab a paddle,' " Mr. Markowicz said. "I like to tell people they're a part owner, whether they buy it directly or own it through the trust, so shut out the lights when you leave -- it's our electric bill. There's a big difference between being an owner and being a renter. There's a tremendous team spirit."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Guests at the recent opening of Sonalysts Inc. viewing videos in the 24-track sound studio, above, and a life-size cut-out, below, of Humphrey Bogart stationed in a sound studio. (Photographs by Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Border War Heats Up

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
THE Westchester Industrial Development Agency's latest radio ads are pitching the county's $25 million budget surplus, its hold-the-line policy on taxes and its green parks, scenic shorelines and "unsurpassed quality of life."
"Hello and welcome to another edition of the Westchester Business Challenge," the ads say. "If you're ready, here's today's question: Why is Westchester a great business location?" 
 Unfortunately, the county's top-rated schools, its low crime rate and the many other attributes touted in recent advertisements by the development agency, whose members are appointed by the County Executive, were not enough to lure a company like the Witco Corporation, a Manhattan-based manufacturer employing 8,400 workers and looking to relocate.
Wined and dined in Connecticut by "everyone from the Governor down to aides" -- and offered an $8 million state grant to offset moving expenses -- Witco announced in June that it was moving 800 workers to Fairfield County, in a corporate park that is a stone's throw from the Westchester border, said Carl R. Soderlind, a senior vice president for the company.
"It's not that Westchester didn't do a good job wooing us," Mr. Soderlind said. "It's just that Connecticut did better."
Also, Trans World Airlines, now headquartered in Mount Kisco, announced this month that St. Louis had offered the carrier a deal worth $70 million to move its administrative offices and as many as 200 workers there as part of a bankruptcy reorganization plan. The airline is selling some of its assets, like gates and baggage systems, to the St. Louis Airport Authority and leasing them back.
"The city of St. Louis went above and beyond in their efforts to bring us home to the Midwest," William R. Howard, T.W.A.'s chairman and chief executive officer, said when the deal was announced.
Economic development officials and business leaders in Westchester, who are frustrated in their efforts to retain companies and attract new businesses, have placed at least part of the blame for losses like Witco, T.W.A., Mastercard and other companies on what they consider antiquated business policies at the state level.
 
'We End Up Begging'
 "Places like Connecticut see incentive packages as an investment in its future," said Lawrence E. Dwyer Jr., president of the 800-member Westchester County Association. "New York only sees it as an expense.
"The problem is that Connecticut is out there aggressively pursuing new business, and in New York, there is a lack of organization and a lot of pointing of fingers. So we end up begging for companies, but we don't have a lot of clout behind us, even though we know that the county is a wonderful place to be."
Jeffrey W. Schneider, a spokesman for the state's Office of Economic Development, agreed that there were "few places on earth that can compete" with the Hudson Valley region, but he said it did not make economic sense to pay high premiums for new jobs brought into the state.
"It's not the way we do business," he said, explaining that St. Louis, in offering T.W.A. $70 million for 200 jobs, was in essence paying "$350,000 a job, if you do the math."
"It would impinge on our ability to do economic development in general if we spent too many dollars in one place," Mr. Schneider said.
Alan C. Sullivan, Executive Deputy Commissioner for the State Department of Economic Development, accused states like Connecticut and New Jersey of "going crazy in bidding wars that escalate to an unrealistic degree."
"We compete," he said, "but New York is not about to bankroll some company. Witco won the sweepstakes, but how can you justify something like that to taxpayers?"
 
News Not All Bad
 Meanwhile, the losses for Westchester have added up, and the county's vacancy rate for commercial properties -- a key indicator of economic activity -- was 27.1 percent in June, up from 21.9 percent the same time last year, according to a mid-year report by the Rostenberg-Doern Company, a corporate real-estate firm with offices in Purchase and Stamford. Downtown White Plains was especially hard hit with a vacancy rate of 34.9 percent, the report said.
By contrast, Fairfield County's vacancy rate dropped to 23 percent in June, from 25.4 percent a year ago. The Rostenberg-Doern report also pointed out that in addition to Witco's decision to move to Connecticut, Dun & Bradstreet announced that it was moving to Fairfield County from Manhattan.
Dun & Bradstreet, a financial information company, received a $7.2 million grant from Connecticut to move its headquarters staff of 300 people to Wilton from midtown Manhattan.
The news, however, was not all bad for Westchester, said County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, who announced this month that 34 new businesses have moved, opened a branch or started a business here during the first half of the year -- generating about 500 new jobs and $3.4 million in new business leases over the course of the year.
"You win some and you lose some in this minuet we all do to court companies," Mr. O'Rourke said. "What we can't do is compete with the footlong laundry list of things that Connecticut is willing to give to a company."
A report released by Mr. O'Rourke's Office of Commerce and Economic Development also found that some large retail companies -- Tops Appliance City, T. J. Maxx, Pace Warehouse, World of Interior Design and Bradlees -- have opened in Westchester this year, generating an additional 700 new jobs.
 
Bigger Not Necessarily Better
 According to the report, an economic analysis for the first half of 1993, two-thirds of the new firms were in the fields of accounting, computer services, telecommunications, advertising, marketing, financial services and consulting.
County officials have recently begun to chart a different course for the future, depending less on the large corporations for Westchester's economic viability, explained Margaret S. Soter, Director of Commerce and Economic Development for the county.
"What we're trying to do now is attract a variety of small- and medium-sized companies," Ms. Soter said. "It's healthier, because they don't send the big tremors through the local economy when they downsize, the way an I.B.M. or a Reader's Digest does."
Rostenberg-Doern's report called the continuing consolidation of I.B.M.'s operations "devastating" for Westchester. The computer company -- which announced that it would cut 500 jobs in the county this year -- plans to vacate 320,000 square feet of office space in White Plains, 425,000 square feet in Purchase and at least 171,000 square feet in Tarrytown.
 
'More Wins Than Losses'
 Westchester's job base is 376,000, down 8,200 from a year ago, according to statistics from the State Labor Department. Half of the job losses were in manufacturing, which includes the I.B.M. jobs.
"We're saying to the smaller firms, 'Come, grow and create jobs here,' " Ms. Soter said. "In the long run, this will be a more stabilizing influence for the county."
George W. Delaney, president of the Westchester Business Partnership, an association of 36 leaders from the public and private sectors, said that despite some setbacks the county had seen "far more wins than losses."
"The bottom line," Mr. Delaney said, "is that Westchester, with its AAA bond rating, is still in better shape than most counties in the nation."
He defended state economic policies by pointing to a recent offer of $2.5 million in low-interest loans from a new state fund to entice the Ciba Corporation to remain in Westchester.
Ciba, a developer and manufacturer of pharmaceuticals, some plastic materials and vision-care products, wants to sell 12 buildings that it owns on 60 acres in Ardsley. It is considering four sites in Westchester and one in Connecticut. Eric S. Jackson, a spokesman for Ciba, said that both states were actively pursuing the company.
 
Way Behind the Times
 In contrast to Mr. Delaney's views, most county officials and economic leaders who were interviewed said state policies were hampering the county's ability to do business. They criticized the state for not having an up-to-date brochure describing New York's attributes. And they said New York's tax structure, its costly medical plans and workers' compensation packages and its insistence on cumbersome environmental-review processes all worked against attracting and retaining businesses.
Others like the County Executive question the state's focus on manufacturing rather than service industries saying that such an approach was behind the times and too narrow in scope.
But Mr. Sullivan, of the Department of Economic Development, defended that policy. "We have a certain amount of dollars to work with, and our thinking is that manufacturing is what drives the service industries," he said. "It's the essential core, and if you don't have that, then you don't have the need for the services."
Mr. Sullivan said that as an example, the state's efforts in 1985 for the General Motors assembly plant in North Tarrytown -- tax incentives and infrastructure improvements worth $25 million -- had provided a solid return on investments, even with the planned closing of the factory in two years.
Mr. O'Rourke questioned whether the General Motors incentive package merely allowed a weak and inefficient manufacturing company to continue. "Are we sometimes resuscitating dinosaurs?" he said. "I don't know. But I see the focus now less on manufacturing and more on high-tech."
Mr. O'Rourke is seeking modifications in the State Constitution that would allow Westchester to operate more independently of Albany in offering incentive packages to companies, much the way New York City can. The changes would permit the county to reduce taxes for a company and develop grant packages.
For example, he said, Westchester is hoping to convince Unicef to move its headquarters to New Rochelle. But New York City recently won legislative approval to waive property taxes in its bid to keep the United Nations agency within its borders. "Westchester needs more of those tools," Mr. O'Rourke said.

HEADLINE: Japan's New Prime Minister Vows Major Changes in Election System

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Japan's new Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, today pledged a fundamental reshaping of what he described as the corrupt electoral system and stronger efforts to reduce Japan's yawning trade surpluses.
At least in terms of oratory, Mr. Hosokawa's first policy address offered a remarkable shift from the statements of the conservative governments of the postwar era. He criticized Japan's narrow-minded pursuit of economic gain and the collusive institutions that excluded outsiders and worked against the interests of Japanese consumers. 
 Ignoring occasionally loud heckling from some opposition members in the Parliament, Mr. Hosokawa effectively launched the first Government in 38 years to exclude the Liberal Democratic Party by echoing many of Japan's long-time critics.
"It is time to candidly admit that Japan has so far put its highest priority on economic development and has not paid sufficient attention to improving the quality of life for each and every person," Mr. Hosokawa said, adding that a reduction in the trade surplus would help rectify this imbalance.
 
A Tenuous Coalition
 In several key respects, however, he promised continuity in a policy agenda that is, like the frail seven-party coalition government he heads, a mix of right-wing and left-wing goals.
Mr. Hosokawa said he placed his highest priority on maintaining strong relations with the United States and would continue to support the security treaty with Washington. He also vowed to continue Japan's role in international affairs, particularly through participation in the United Nations.
But while his proposals for political reform were sweeping, Mr. Hosokawa offered few assurances he would take strong action to reinvigorate the economy, which is being battered by a two-year-old recession and the soaring yen. Making matters worse, Mr. Hosokawa's coalition is badly divided over how to respond to the economic difficulties.
The Socialist Party, the largest party in the coalition, has traditionally favored tax cuts, since they benefit individuals rather than the big corporations long supported by the Government when it was in the hands of the Liberal Demcratic Party. Even some trade groups representing big corporations favor tax cuts.
 
Fear of Rising Deficit
 But Finance Ministry bureaucrats and more conservative members of the coalition oppose tax reductions because they feel such measures will not result in much new spending and will just inflate the budget deficit.
Mr. Hosokawa was vague in his economic prescriptions. He merely said his Cabinet was preparing "a range of measures from the broader policy perspective in response to the urgent situation confronting us today."
These measures will include, he said, deregulation of the economy and steps to try and pass along cheap import prices to consumers, who pay some of the highest prices in the world.
"I intend to work vigorously for expanded domestic demand and improved market access and for such consumer-oriented policies as rectifying the disparity between domestic and international prices and promoting deregualtion," he said.
Few here doubt that deregulation is needed; one government agency has determined that in 1992 there were 10,942 types of permits and licenses that the Government required various businesses to obtain.
The promise of a new electoral system was central to the strategy followed by Mr. Hosokawa in the recent election. But he stressed today that he would follow a tough line and eliminate completely corporate contributions to politicians and parties. He said he would also toughen laws on election financing violations.
 
Support for Nuclear Treaty
 In addition, Mr. Hosokawa ended months of debate and said that Japan would support an indefinite extension of the treaty on preventing the spread of nuclear weapons.
The previous Government had hesitated on the treaty's extension, creating concerns that Japan wanted to preserve the option of being able to develop its own such weapons if it faced a serious threat from North Korea or other neighboring countries.
Mr. Hosokawa also repeated his conciliatory comments on World War II.
"I would thus like to take this opportunity to express anew our profound remorse and apologies for the fact that past Japanese actions, including aggression and colonial rule, caused unbearable suffering and sorrow for so many people and to state that we will demonstrate our new determination by contributing more than ever before to world peace," he said.

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Soccer Success Forges New Bolivia Optimism

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 22

 BODY:
They come to the games with their faces painted in the national colors -- red, yellow and green -- and dance down the central boulevard, El Prado, to celebrate victories with a new pride and greater social unity than Bolivia has ever known as a country. And all because of a soccer team.
This land-locked country is the poorest in Latin America, sets the record for military coups in the region and is often mocked by neighbors of fairer complexion for its large Indian population. But Bolivians dare to dream the impossible -- qualifying as one of the 24 teams in next year's World Cup in the United States. 
 In its five-team South American group, Bolivia has beaten everyone -- Venezuela (twice), Ecuador, Uruguay and Brazil. No ties. No losses. It has scored more goals, 20, than any other Latin American team in the qualifying rounds and toyed with Venezuela today in the thin air of this capital city 12,000 feet above sea level, winning by 7-0. With today's victory over Venezuela, Bolivia has won all four of its home games, but must play its three remaining qualifying games away.
The team and the country suddenly have an international profile. American advertising agencies are already soliciting the Bolivian Soccer Federation about marketing the team in Latin America and the United States. Invitations have come from Miami to play in soccer matches with Mexico and Sweden and from Europe to play against Ireland and Scotland.
Only twice before in the 63-year history of the World Cup has this Andean country played in the final round, in1930 and 1950, and both appearances were by invitation of the host country (Uruguay in 1930 and Brazil in 1950).
Bolivians hope that the emergence of the soccer team as a power alongside such familiar World Cup champions as Brazil and Argentina is a precursor to the emergence of the country as an attractive place for foreign investment, with a track record of economic stability and 10 years of uninterrupted democracy.
"There's a real change in your image when you make the finals of the World Cup," said Marco Antonio Etcheverry, the team's star striker, who is also known as El Diablo (the Devil). "I remember when Colombia qualified for the 1990 games. It was like, 'Wow, the country's reputation soared overnight to another level.' We were in awe of them. That's what we're hoping will happen to us."
Such bright-eyed faith in the future comes at a time when, politically, the country seems to be leaving behind dictatorships and strongman rule and embracing the initial stages of sharing political power, particularly with its vast indigenous population.
Last June, in its Presidential elections, a former dictator, Hugo Banzer Suarez, was soundly defeated in the voting, as the public chose a ticket that was known as the "Gringo and the Indian."
The country overwhelmingly elected Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, an American-trained mining executive who speaks Spanish with a thick American accent, and his dark-skinned vice presidential running mate, Victor Hugo Cardenas, a philosopher, educator and an Aymara Indian born on the banks of Lake Titicaca.
It is the first time in any Latin American country that an indigenous leader has been elected to such a high national office.
"When I came here, the soccer team reflected the national identity, a very low self-image, a conquered people, down on themselves, such that if things got tough they would just quit," said Xavier Azkargorta, the team's coach and trainer from Barcelona, Spain.
"The first thing they had to learn was to respect and like themselves, and dignify the image of a soccer player," Azkargorta said. "And I think that is what's happening in the country as well.
"Bolivia is a country with everything: minerals, natural resources, vast agricultural lands. It only lacks development. There's nothing to be ashamed of. And that's exactly the same with soccer players."
 
Low Inflation, Mineral Riches
 And there are the nascent signs of such change. The country has the lowest inflation rate in all of Latin America, averaging 8 percent a year. American mining companies are beginning to find new deposits of gold and other minerals, and international oil executives say that they have no estimate as to the extent of the energy riches yet undiscovered in the country.
But these changes come against the backdrop of a history of problems. The Spanish plundered Bolivia's silver and gold, forcing the Indians to work in the mines, where many died. Since independence in 1825, Bolivia has lost territory in wars with all of its neighbors. Years of hyperinflation and backwardness have left the country with the highest poverty rate in the Western Hemisphere, with the exception of Haiti.
Indeed, its international image among its greatest detractors in Latin America was summed up last month by a former Chilean admiral, Jose Toribio Merino, who described Bolivia as consisting of "metamorphosized llamas who have learned how to speak but not to think."
But soccer may change some of that. On Sundays during games, local television stations transmit images of fans singing national songs with such lyrics as "Long Live Bolivia Near My Heart," and "Bolivia's My Country, Oh How I Love It."
"Soccer gives you two things, pride and joy," said Guido Loayza, president of the Bolivian Soccer Federation. "In a country like Bolivia, where so many people are poor, there are very few times when a country as a whole can feel pride and joy. This is one of those times."
 
Team and El Diablo Front-Page News
 The soccer team and El Diablo, the striker Etcheverry, are front-page news almost every day. Recently, during a headline-grabbing visit by Fidel Castro, a frustrated Sanchez de Lozada, in his typically biting humor said, "apparently Bolivians have forgotten that they have a new president."
Meanwhile, the soccer craze has given Bolivia perhaps the biggest moral victory to date in its struggle to legitimize the use of coca leaves. For centuries, Bolivians have chewed coca to allay hunger pangs and cope with the thin air in the Andes. They have also used it as a folk-medicine remedy.
Here, an herbal tea called mate de coca, made of coca leaves, is served to visitors to help them cope with the effects of the altitude. Pope John Paul II, Queen Sofia of Spain and former Vice President Dan Quayle have all partaken of the brew. It is even served in the American Embassy; however, agents of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration are forbidden to drink it.
But as raw material for cocaine, the export of coca leaves has been banned by international organizations. And for years, Bolivia has struggled to convince the international community that the fault lies with the consuming nations, since cocaine is produced only when chemicals are added, and that as a leaf, coca is less harmful than coffee. Bolivians describe cocaine, in fact, as a foreign substance.
Then in early August, FIFA, soccer's international governing body, conducted a surprise anti-doping test here during the Bolivia-Brazil game.
Two of the players, Bolivia's Miguel Angel Rimba and Brazil's Armelino Donizetti, also known as Zetti, tested positive for cocaine and were suspended after the match. But after a few days of explanation it turned out that both players had consumed small amounts of mate.
They were reinstated by FIFA, which Bolivians interpreted as the first international recognition that chewing coca or drinking coca tea is not the equivalent of taking cocaine.
Even with the victory today, Bolivia statistically is not assured of a place in the final round. But a tie in any of its final three games (at Brazil, at Uruguay and at Ecuador) would assure Bolivia of a trip to the United States next June.
Azkargorta is given much of the credit for the improvement in the team. Previously, soccer players were not held in particularly high regard, and what Azkargorta found when he arrived here to work with the players early this year was low morale and a tendency to give up.
"They were intermittent soccer players, only for a few days leading up to a match," the coach said. "But you have to be a soccer player all the time and consider that it is a dignity to be one."
One of the hardest cases was El Diablo himself, who arrived back in Bolivia after playing with Albacete in Spain (his contract was purchased by the Chilean club, Colo Colo) feeling depressed, with family and drinking problems.
Still, while morale was low when Azkargorta came, the technical skills were high. This was in large part due to the Tahuichi Aguilera Soccer Academy in Santa Cruz, known for training outstanding young players, including El Diablo, who is considered one of Latin America's next superstars. At present, six graduates of the academy are on the national team.
Only five countries are definitely in the finals so far: Mexico has qualified in the World Cup elimination round for Central America; Russia and Greece both qualified from European Group 5; the United States as the host country, and Germany as the defending champion.
Colombia and Argentina, along with Peru and Paraguay, are in South American Group A. The winner of that group advances to the finals while the second-place team will have to play Australia in a playoff for a berth in the finals. Bolivia, Brazil, Venezuela, Ecuador and Uruguay comprise Group B. Should Bolivia make it out of Group B (the top two teams will advance to the finals), the players will have to be satisfied with emotional, rather than monetary rewards. While every Argentine player will get a $100,000 bonus if the team qualifies for the final round and every Brazilian player will get $50,000, the Bolivians will get no more than $8,000 apiece.
 
Basque Coach Is a Folk Hero
 But with the World Cup finals still almost a year away, Azkargorta has become a kind of folk hero here, even though he is Spanish and could be seen as an extention of Spain's conquistadors.
"I'm Basque," he is quick to point out. "We had our own number of bloody and cruel conquistadors, but at the same time we are now an oppressed people ourselves so I can feel for the Bolivians."
Azkargorta does not let the team focus on future games. "The most dangerous opponent right now is Venezuela," he said. And he stresses that mental approach by the use of three words, "here and now." And he will not discuss with reporters whether the team will beat Brazil, in Recife, Brazil, on Sunday but he says he has no fears of the superpowers of the soccer world.
"If Brazil qualifies for the finals, they would go as one of the heavy favorites to win and we have already beaten them," he said. "Now you're not going to say to me that we cannot stand on our own against anyone."
