HEADLINE: U.S.-Saudi Deals in 90's Shifting Away From Cash Toward Credit

SERIES: Dwindling Riches: Saudi Arabia's Ailing Finances -- Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By Stephen Engelberg, Special to The New York Times; The following article is based on reporting by Stephen Engelberg, Jeff Gerth and Tim Weiner and was written by Mr. Engelberg.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia's financial decline, the consequence of a decade in which the country lived beyond its means, is fundamentally reshaping the relationship between Riyadh and Washington.
When the Saudis were flush with so-called petrodollars, they bought whatever they could from the United States -- warplanes, missiles, jetliners. The purchases generated tens of thousands of jobs for American military and aerospace workers. 
 Today, the United States is making every effort to insure that the Saudis can buy on credit what they once bought with cash.
Many officials of the Clinton Administration say they see the sales as crucial to keeping American arms makers afloat while the American military shrinks. They are confident the Saudis can afford their pending purchases, which include $30 billion in American weapons and $6 billion in airliners.
But others, including some Government experts, Western advisers to Saudi Arabia and independent analysts, say they are worried. They contend that the heavy spending on weapons has forced the Saudis to cut the subsidies and patronage that have bought domestic tranquillity for the monarchy. Saudi officials have told their American counterparts that they intend to choose guns over butter.
"They've tilted the wrong way," said William Quandt, a former White House official in the Nixon and Carter Administrations responsible for the Middle East. "All the billions they've spent on arms haven't been very useful to them."
 
'Not a Popular Regime'
 He added: "This is not a popular regime. It's a huge patronage system that has spread the wealth around. If you take that away, you could contribute to a political crisis."
Saudi officials declined to respond to repeated requests for interviews or to written questions on this subject. But officials from the United States and Saudi Arabia, speaking on condition of anonymity, acknowledged that the nature of the relationship had changed.
The Saudis, accustomed to dealing with Washington in secret and on the basis of handshakes, now find themselves forced to live by the rules by which other developing nations play -- rules about supplying financial data to obtain credit and paying debts.
These are some of the signs of the changing relationship:
*A decision by the Pentagon to ease the terms of payment when a Saudi cash-flow crisis threatened billions of dollars worth of weapons deals last year.
*Dimming prospects for future Saudi arms orders for American military manufacturers already reeling from the end of the cold war.
*Promises by the United States Export-Import Bank to guarantee more than $6 billion in loans for the purchase of airliners by Saudi Arabia. If the deal goes through, the United States Government will co-sign huge loans that private banks have deemed too risky to underwrite alone.
*Debates within the United States Government about how seriously the financial troubles of Saudi Arabia affect its creditworthiness. Federal Reserve officials argued unsuccessfully this year to lower the Saudis' credit rating, which would have damaged the ability of Riyadh to borrow from American banks.
For their part, Saudi officials said they felt pressured by the budget problems in the United States, which they said had forced Washington to sell more weapons to Riyadh -- and to demand quick repayment of the costs of the Persian Gulf war.
"In the 1970's," a Saudi official said, "the United States wouldn't have accepted one penny from Saudi Arabia" for fighting the war.
 
The Old Order
Handshakes Sealed Billion-Dollar Deals
 Throughout the 1980's, the Saudis' dealings with the United States Government often were conducted through the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon, institutions that share the Saudis' passion for secrecy.
From 1984 to 1987, the Defense Secretary, Caspar W. Weinberger, and the Saudi Ambassador, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, met or talked at least 64 times, according to Mr. Weinberger's diaries. The son of the Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Bandar is a confidant of Presidents who has wooed and won Washington officials for a decade.
The Ambassador and the Defense Secretary fought hard to help the Saudis acquire spy planes, sophisticated antiaircraft missiles and other American weapons over the strong objections of Congress. In the 1980's, the Saudis paid $28.4 billion to the United States for military equipment, according to the Pentagon. They also paid more than $1 billion for C.I.A. operations around the world, including secret support for Nicaraguan rebels that was handled by Prince Bandar and King Fahd after Congress cut off funds for the rebels.
 
A Saudi Binge
 The relationship was sealed in blood when the United States went to war to defeat Saddam Hussein and defend the Saudis. Riyadh's commitment to repay the United States for the gulf war was based on a handshake.
After the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, "Bandar went on a binge," as a United States official described it. The spending spree lasted more than two years. When it was over, Saudia Arabia had promised to buy more than $26 billion of American weapons, including fighter jets, missiles, tanks and armored personnel carriers, Defense Department records show. Saudi and American officials said the Saudi Finance Ministry was initially unaware of all the arms deals the Ambassador had made -- and did not include all the costs in the national budget.
The effects of the purchases are being felt now. But there was a warning at the time.
 
The Cost of War
 The war and the weapons sales put Saudi Arabia "under considerable economic stress," Richard G. Darman, President George Bush's budget director, told Congress on July 31, 1991. "They are now, for the first time, borrowing considerably to service their own needs."
Congress, impatient for the Saudis to pay the United States for the costs of the gulf war, thought them wealthy enough to pay for American weapons and goals.
The testimony of Mr. Darman was essentially ignored -- by Congress, by the press and by his colleagues in the Bush Administration.
Henry S. Rowen, a former senior Pentagon official, said the Bush Administration had turned a deaf ear to the Saudis' protestations of poverty.
"It was not something we paid a lot of attention to," Mr. Rowen recalled. "We said: 'You've got it. Now come on, put it on the table.' "
 
The New Reality
With Little Cash, Spending Declines
 Despite its financial woes, Saudi Arabia remains the best foreign customer of American military contractors. Its arms contracts signed with the Pentagon since June 1990 total $30 billion, roughly equal to the amount spent by the American military on major weapons systems this year.
But the stream of cash is running dry. A State Department report to Congress this year projected a significant drop in Saudi military orders, to $2.75 billion next year, from $12.5 billion this year.
Indeed, while the Saudis had promised to pay the Pentagon for almost everything they ordered, Defense Department officials said they had quietly dropped two contracts: one for $64 million of rocket launchers, the other, worth more than $1 billion, for 150 battle tanks. A spokesman for the General Dynamics Corporation, the maker of the tanks, said the company believed the Saudis had merely delayed the purchase.
When foreign countries buy weapons through the Pentagon, they put money in a foreign military sales trust fund. They must deposit enough to cover cancellation fees and the next quarterly payment. Military contractors are paid as they finish their work.
A few years ago, the Saudis maintained a multibillion-dollar surplus in their account. But Pentagon officials said the surplus disappeared after the gulf war. First, the Saudi account fell below the level required by the Pentagon rules. Then it dwindled further, and in early 1992 was close to the point at which "stop work" orders must be sent to contractors.
This is how some Government officials, including some from the Pentagon, described the cash flow crisis:
By May 1992, Saudi Arabia owed the Pentagon $16 billion. Saudi officials suggested stretching out the payments, to 10 years from 4.
The Saudis had "what they characterized as a two- to three-year cash-flow problem as a result of Desert Storm," a senior Pentagon official recalled. But experts in the Administration, including those from the Central Intelligence Agency, insisted that "if there was a financial problem, it was short term," according to a former Bush Administration official.
After a round of high-level meetings, the Pentagon decided against allowing the Saudis to renegotiate their weapons contracts. Instead, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney signed a waiver aimed at helping Saudi Arabia through the trying period. With the stroke of a pen, Saudi Arabia was excused from advancing $1.3 billion to cover potential cancellation fees.
A few months after they raised the alarm about the burdens of paying for arms, the Saudis placed new orders that totaled nearly $11 billion.
In September, with his re-election campaign hanging in the balance, President Bush flew to the headquarters of the cash-starved McDonnell Douglas Company in St. Louis. Before a cheering crowd of flag-waving employees, Mr. Bush personally guaranteed that Saudi Arabia would buy 72 of the company's F-15 fighters.
 
A Mixture of Motives
 A former Bush Administration official said the White House had a mixture of motives for pushing the $9 billion Saudi deal, including the political needs of President Bush, the financial troubles of McDonnell Douglas and the possible loss of tens of thousands of aerospace jobs.
Money was never an issue, he said: "There was no one saying: 'What about their ability to pay for this?' "
Some in the Pentagon argued that the purchase was unwise from a military standpoint, and that the Saudis would have been better off buying larger quantities of cheaper planes. They lost. "The bottom line was: You can't close the F-15 assembly line," a former official said.
Under the Clinton Administration, the cash problem in Saudi Arabia has drawn Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown to Riyadh. In May, he urged Saudi officials to complete the planned purchase of 17 C-130 air cargo planes manufactured by Lockheed Aeronautical Systems in Marietta, Ga., officials said. The Saudis stopped taking delivery after receiving the 10th plane last year.
"They made it clear they have a requirement for 17," said Robert E. McAndrew, the director of international marketing at Lockheed Aeronautical. "They bought 10 and deferred the other 7. If the fact is they don't have the money, it's just going to take more time."
 
The Changing Rules
Loan Guarantees Replace Good Will
 Huge commercial deals are still going ahead. Saudi Arabia's state airline, Saudia, wants a new fleet of planes -- worth about $6.2 billion. The Boeing Company hopes to manufacture them. McDonnell Douglas is also interested.
President Clinton called King Fahd last week, seeking assurances that the Saudis would buy the planes from the American companies instead of their chief competitor, the Airbus Industrie consortium in Europe.
It was clear months ago that the deal would require government-guaranteed loans.
Enter the Export-Import Bank, a Federal agency that promotes American exports to developing countries by backing deals the private sector considers too risky. To make the jetliner sale happen, the bank is prepared to guarantee, or co-sign, as much as $6.2 billion in loans -- the biggest deal in its history. The American Government will be liable if the loans are not repaid.
If the airplane sale goes through, Saudi Arabia would leap overnight from being one of the bank's smallest clients to one of its biggest. That, along with the bank's other obligations, would stretch its budget to its limit. So the bank wants Congress to remove the cap on the total liabilities it assumes.
Shortly before agreeing preliminarily to underwrite the jetliner deal, the bank doubled its fees for aircraft financing, to 4 percent of the amount lent, from 2 percent. Officials at the bank said they expected to make a profit on the deal.
There is a diplomatically sensitive catch. The Export-Import bank has insisted that the Saudi Government must also guarantee the loan, according to American officials.
In essence, the United States is saying that the state-owned airline company is less than a sure thing. "It's a vote of no confidence" in Saudi Arabia, said a Saudi official who termed the request "insulting."
 
The Risk Factor
A Closer Scrutiny Of Credit Ratings
 For the first time, the credit ratings accorded the Saudis by agencies of the United States Government have become the topic of a heated debate. The question is: How risky a business is Saudi Arabia?
Until the 1990's, Saudi Arabia cared little about credit ratings, bank loans or guarantees by the United States Government. As long as the kingdom paid cash, its hazy figures on its budget and its banks were not important.
These days, bank regulators are looking much more closely. If they conclude that loans to Saudi Arabia are risky, loans from American banks would become more costly, or even impossible to get.
In March, a group of Federal bank regulators, called the Inter-Agency Country Exposure Review Committee, gathered for a closed-door meeting in northern Virginia. The committee, comprising officials from the Federal Reserve, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, rates the creditworthiness of foreign countries on a seven-step scale. The March meeting was described by Federal officials who spoke on condition of anonymity.
 
A Move to Downgrade
 Economists from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York urged the committee to lower Saudi Arabia's rating, which stood at "moderately strong," the second-highest category. Had the committee taken the New York Fed cue, Saudi Arabia's rating would probably have fallen to "weak," the third-highest notch.
Knocking down the rating of a country is not taken lightly. The ratings are distributed to American banks and almost inevitably become known in the financial industry. International banking is based, in part, on confidence and perception. If American regulators are seen as nervous about a country, that alone can further shake its standing.
A Treasury Department official who oversees Saudi affairs, Elizabeth Hughes, argued strongly against cutting the rating of the Saudis. Her views prevailed.
The Government agencies that grant credit for export deals and agriculture have a separate rating committee. It, too, is grappling with the question of whether to downgrade Saudi Arabia. According to Clinton Administration officials, the panel last year gave Saudi Arabia a "B" average, based mostly on the Saudis' history of paying their bills on time.
 
The Consequences
Political Stability: The Next Casualty?
 The United States' special handling of Saudi Arabia has amounted to an unpublicized foreign aid program. The practice is not unique. Such favors also go to two other allies in the Middle East: Israel and Egypt.
In the past, that list might also have included two countries that provided oil to America: Iran and Iraq. But Saudi Arabia is not Iran -- that is an article of faith among most American foreign-policy, financial and intelligence officials.
With few exceptions, they said the Saudi monarchy had the wisdom to fend off challenges by religious extremists, the will to open a closed society and the willingness to set the country on a sound fiscal course.
Others think differently. American businessmen and political analysts said fiscal problems could undermine the political stability of Saudi Arabia. And, they said, there was a danger that Washington might remain wedded to a stereotype of Saudi Arabia as a bottomless treasure chest.
 
More Debts and Dependence
 "People think we have a wonderful gold mine in Saudi Arabia, that we can sell a lot of military equipment to them to create jobs, to help the defense industry's transition out of the cold war, to improve our balance of payments and to make Saudi Arabia safer," said a leading adviser to the Saudis who has seen their most closely guarded financial data.
He said the weapons sales, by sharply increasing the Saudis' debts and dependence on Americans, gave ammunition to fundamentalist opponents of the Saudi Government.
"I don't think the U.S. Government knows what it's doing by shoving weapons down the Saudis' throats," the financial adviser said. "They're forgetting that what they are doing is creating instability in Saudi Arabia. That could be the greatest risk to Saudi security."
No amount of arms spending will insure the security of Saudi Arabia, a prominent Saudi official said. "In the war, we discovered that no matter how built up we become, we can't replace the U.S.," the Saudi said. "The U.S. is our protector."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Central-Bank Gripes About A New World

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 22

 BODY:
To most people the analogy would be far-fetched, but at a conference of central bankers at this Rocky Mountain resort, the bankers often compared themselves to generals waging war.
The reason offered is that those who forge monetary policy, like those who wage war, have to grapple with an unending torrent of chance and change. 
 "Monetary policy is hell," declared Donald Kohn, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Board.
Benjamin M. Friedman, a Harvard University economist, said, "It may be true that war is the human activity most vitally subject to chance and happenstance, but monetary policy runs a close second."
 
Change Brings Confusion
 At the three-day conference, which ended on Saturday, central bankers from two dozen countries and private economists talked -- and grumbled -- about how enormous changes in the financial world have made it harder for central banks to carry out their central role: holding down inflation.
Another theme heard through the conference was that central banks are perhaps becoming less powerful than they used to be in the face of developments like the explosion in cross-border movements of capital.
"Central banks don't have as much leverage over their economies as they used to," said Michael Mussa, director of research at the International Monetary Fund. He said that to reduce inflation pressure to a certain degree, some central banks might have to raise interest rates twice as much as they once had to.
As a result of the rapid changes in capital markets, many central banks have discovered that their tried-and-true rules for carrying out monetary policy have become as useless as buggy whips. Without neat rules to lean back on, central bankers often feel exposed. Many are increasingly turning to seat-of-the-pants discretion to guide policy -- a development that caused heated debate here.
Much of the conference, sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, was devoted to analyzing a litany of changes that have made the central bankers' work hellish. These include:
*The nearly $1 trillion that moves around the world each day in foreign-currency trading makes it harder for the bankers to keep exchange rates where they want them. Witness the repeated European monetary crises over the last year.
*The growing popularity of adjustable-rate mortgages and other financial tools that use varying interest rates increases the pain when central banks raise rates. Hans Tietmeyer, vice president of Germany's central bank, noted that this increased pressure not to take such unpopular steps.
*The proliferation of offshore banking centers has made it more difficult for central bankers to require commercial banks to increase their minimum reserves, a step that tends to slow inflation by reducing the ability to lend. Banks can respond by shifting activities to offshore sites without reserve requirements.
*Savings and loan institutions no longer hold as many home mortgages as they did because mortgages are now bundled together and sold to investors, freeing far more money for further mortgage lending. As a result, when the Federal Reserve raises interest rates to reduce economic activity, those rate increases are less potent than before in slowing home sales and construction.
*The role of commercial banks has declined as companies borrow increasingly from finance companies and the bond market. Perhaps along with this, the ability of central banks to slow the economy by restricting lending has declined, too.
 
Fed's Broken Compass
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said that as a result of these developments, the effect the Fed "once had on the credit flows provided for businesses and home construction is largely dissipated."
Probably the strongest lament among the central bankers was that the tool they used most to guide monetary policy -- growth in the money supply -- had become unreliable.
For much of the 1970's and 1980's, the Federal Reserve and many other countries' central banks sought to create a certain level of growth in the money supply. Those targets would more or less steer their economies toward a desired level of inflation and economic growth. Briefly put, X amount of monetary growth produced Y amount of economic growth.
That relationship has broken down because of financial deregulation and major changes in the way that individuals invest their savings. The Federal Reserve has concluded that it can now produce a certain amount of growth with less growth in one of its major money-supply indexes, the M-2, a measure of money that includes cash, savings and checking accounts, and small certificates of deposit.
But because M-2 is acting erratically by previous assumptions, the Fed does not know exactly how much monetary growth is needed to produce a desired level of economic growth. The main reason for this uncertainty is that so many people have moved their money from savings accounts, which are part of the money supply, into mutual funds, which are not considered part of the money supply.
 
Verities or Situations?
 "This behavior has, at least for the time being, greatly undermined the use of M-2," Mr. Greenspan said.
The inability to rely on measures like M-2 as a yardstick has left central bankers groping for new tools to guide monetary policy. Some are searching for the perfect new rule to follow, while others have settled on central bankers' using their discretion, constantly monitoring the economy for signs of inflation or recession.
"To return to a purely discretionary policy regime puts credibility at risk," said Andrew Crockett, executive director of the Bank of England. "How, economic agents may ask, can we assess the objectives of policy, and the likely reaction to different types of disturbance? How can we trust the authorities not to weaken or abandon their commitment to stated policy goals?"
Britain's new approach is to forecast what inflation will be in a year or two and then adjust interest rates with the aim of limiting inflation to a maximum of 2 percent a year at that time.
The Federal Reserve has taken more of a discretionary approach, frequently watching figures on inflation, unemployment and other developments, and then adjusting interest rates with the goal of keeping inflation subdued while producing moderate growth.
Allan Meltzer, an economics professor at Carnegie Mellon University, attacked such an approach, complaining that it leaves people involved in financial markets guessing wildly what the Federal Reserve plans to do.
"The gains of discretion are less than the costs," he said. "Discretionary policy relies on forecasts. But forecasts cannot reliably distinguish a boom or a recession a quarter or a year ahead."
Mr. Meltzer urged the Federal Reserve to rely on some clear rules that financial professionals and investors can look to. But Professor Friedman of Harvard praised the Fed's discretionary approach, saying, "If the Fed had followed the rules it followed in the past, that would have led to major policy errors."
Testifying before Congress in July, Mr. Greenspan said the Federal Reserve would increasingly turn to a new tool -- what he called "equilibrium real interest rates." Real interest rates are interest rates minus expected inflation, while the equilibrium real rate is the rate that would steer the economy to its maximum level of growth without increasing inflation.
Many economists criticized Mr. Greenspan's idea because it was not at all clear how to determine the equilibrium real interest rate. Mr. Kohn, the Federal Reserve economist, acknowledged here that it was hard to measure real interest rates and to assess what the desired equilibrium rate would be a year, 5 years or 10 years down the line.
Several economists viewed his statement as a retreat by the Federal Reserve from using equilibrium rates. But Mr. Kohn said, "Although difficulties in using real rates are formidable, in theory as well as in practice, there is a potential significant place for them in policy."

HEADLINE: Microsoft Confronts Its Success

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22

 BODY:
In seizing the mantle of computer industry leadership from I.B.M., the Microsoft Corporation is earning the headaches of power as well as the influence.
The extent of the software publisher's legal problems became clearer on Friday. Shortly after the Federal Trade Commission ended a 38-month investigation into Microsoft's business practices, the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department said that it would pursue its own inquiry. 
 The new investigation is likely to raise complex political issues for the Clinton Administration, which has made support for American high-technology companies part of its main agenda.
Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., was started by William H. Gates and Paul Allen after Mr. Gates dropped out of Harvard University in 1975. It is widely viewed as a model of the kind of company that creates the skilled jobs that the Administration wants to encourage.
 
Specter of I.B.M. Case
 I.B.M. fought a Justice Department investigation from 1969 until 1982, a case that produced more than 760 million documents and ultimately had a debilitating effect on the world's largest computer maker.
Yet Microsoft, which controls almost 80 percent of the market for personal computer operating systems, and which was investigated by the F.T.C. on accusations that it had locked customers into using its MS-DOS program, had deliberately created incompatibilities for competitors, and had unfairly linked its applications to its operating system, is a very different competitor from I.B.M.
"I.B.M. was a monolith that was a government in itself," said Susan Braden, a Washington attorney who was part of the Justice Department team that investigated I.B.M. and who later worked at the Federal Trade Commission. "Microsoft is more of an opportunistic culture that is involved in many different parts of the industry."
Indeed, Microsoft's preoccupation with creating as many new industry alliances as it can, in areas as diverse as interactive cable television, wireless portable computing and office equipment, may limit the damage from any prolonged investigation.
"Microsoft is waltzing ahead with cable and all the other things where all the action is going to be," said Esther Dyson, publisher of Release 1.0, a computer-industry newsletter.
Moreover, Microsoft's main software business is going through many of the same changes that the personal computer hardware business has already been through, suggesting that the software publisher might be more willing to strike a quick deal with the Justice Department as it moves ahead to new markets.
"It's all a market-share game," said Mark Stahlman, president of New Media Associates, a consulting firm. "There's no growth in PC software. As unit prices fall, the competitive game shifts and the question is will Microsoft wind up being handcuffed in a brand new ball game."
A number of industry executives have suggested that Microsoft may be willing to cut a deal with the Justice Department because any restrictions will presumably come in business areas that are now of less importance to the company.
 
Divided Opinion on F.T.C.
 The F.T.C. dropped its investigation on Friday after its commissioners deadlocked twice on proposed charges assembled by staff attorneys. There are five commissioners; one, Roscoe B. Starek, refrained from both votes because of a possible conflict of interest.
In February, commission investigators sought to bring a suit against Microsoft in Federal court accusing it of "exclusionary tying practices," creating incompatibilities between its own and its competitors' operating systems, and illegal licensing practices.
In July, the F.T.C. staff tried to persuade the commissioners to issue an administrative complaint against Microsoft for violations of the Federal Trade Commission Act, as well as for violating Section 3 of the Clayton Antitrust Act, which forbids contracts or selling agreements that exclude use of competitors' products or which tend to create a monopoly.
 
Rivals Offer Their Research
 At a meeting on Aug. 4 with financial analysts, Mr. Gates said Microsoft had not engaged in anticompetitive practices. However, a number of competitors have supplied the F.T.C. with volumes of information in an effort to limit Microsoft's power.
Novell Inc., the Provo, Utah-based maker of computer office network software, has been the leader in a campaign within the industry against Microsoft. Novell, which has a dominant share in its own market and which publishes a PC operating system that competes with Microsoft's, has hired several law firms, economists and public relations people as part of the effort.
Operating systems govern a computer's basic functions, and thus a supplier of such a program has tremendous influence both with hardware manufacturers and with companies who write applications like word-processing programs, spreadsheets and data bases.
A principal issue before the Federal Trade Commission was whether Microsoft had licensed its MS-DOS operating system program to personal computer companies in a way that it made it impossible for competing companies to sell their products.
One issue has been whether Microsoft forced computer makers to pay royalties for each personal computer they sell, regardless of whether or not a copy of MS-DOS was shipped with the machine.
Microsoft has repeatedly insisted that its licensing practices do not require companies to make such commitments.
But an executive at a competitor, who spoke on the condition that he not be further identified, said he frequently found that customers would tell him that they would only get the best royalty rates if they agreed to license a copy of MS-DOS for every personal computer they shipped.
"If you agreed to pay royalties based on the number of Intel-compatible systems you shipped, as opposed to the number that actually went out with the software, you got a substantial discount from Microsoft," he said. MS-DOS is an operating system designed for Intel-compatible computers.
 
Illegal or Simply Aggressive?
 But whether or not such a pricing strategy is illegal has yet to be decided.
A separate issue before the F.T.C. was the relationship between Microsoft's two operating system products, Windows and MS-DOS. A number of competitors had charged that Microsoft's applications programmers were able to take unfair advantage of undocumented instructions in MS-DOS -- secret operating-system functions that are not in programmers' manuals. These undocumented capabilities could theoretically be used to give Microsoft's word processors, spreadsheets or data bases a feature advantage.
Microsoft in theory could also take advantage of the relationship between Windows and MS-DOS, which have both become industry standards.
 
A Message Varies
 The issue was raised in the September issue of Dr. Dobbs' Journal, a programmer's magazine. Andrew Schulman, a technical writer, examined a mysterious message found in the Windows 3.1 source code, the instructions readable only by a programmer. The message, which appeared in one pre-release version of Windows, informed a user running Windows with a non-Microsoft version of the operating system that a nonfatal error had occurred and suggested that the user call Microsoft.
Mr. Schulman discovered that in the release version of Windows, Microsoft had turned off the feature, but had left the instructions buried in the program. In his article, he raised the possibility that Microsoft could use the instructions to discourage customers from using non-Microsoft operating systems, which would be a violation of antitrust law.
Microsoft has replied that the code was developed to determine if MS-DOS was being used, in an effort to reduce the support burden on the company. The instructions were not activated in the release version, it says, because the company was concerned about further accusations.

International
Saudi Arabia's financial decline, the consequence of a decade in which the country lived beyond its means, is fundamentally reshaping the relationship between Riyadh and Washington. Today, the United States is making every effort to insure that the Saudis can buy on credit what they once bought with cash. [Page A1.] 
 The North American Free Trade Agreement's advocates and opponents are liming up and rallying grass-roots supporters. The three-nation accord requires approval by simple majorities in the House and the Senate. [D1.]
Japan's persistent recession and the crisis of the soaring yen are forcing the new Prime Minister to emphasize economic issues, which are deeply divisive to his frail seven-party coalition. [A2.]
 
The Economy
Central bankers and economists ended a three-day conference in Wyoming grumbling about how enormous changes in the financial world have made it harder for them to carry out their primary role: holding down inflation. [D1.]
Federal regulators expect to issue new rules this week requiring savings and loan associations to maintain extra capital to keep them from going broke when interest rates shift unpredictably, according to Administration officials. [D2.]
Seasoned by two or three months of working at jobs in New York, summer interns share two realizations: it's a tough world out there, but they are a step ahead of the game. [D1.]

Microsoft is earning the headaches of power as well as the influence. Shortly after the Federal Trade Commission ended a 38-month investigation into the company's business practices, the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department said that it would pursue its own inquiry. [D1.]
 
The Media Business
Rupert Murdoch is close to creating the first truly global television empire. With his $525 million purchase last month of a controlling interest in Star TV, Asia's pioneer satellite television service, Mr. Murdoch has the potential of reaching two-thirds of the world's people. Star's five satellite channels can be seen in 38 nations in Asia and the Middle East. [D1.]
Romance novels are a $750 million industry and account for 46 percent of mass-market paperback fiction sales, according to industry figures. But not just anybody gets published. [D6.]
There are just six weeks left for the nation's cable systems to reach monetary agreements with broadcast stations or else drop those stations from their lineups. Television. [D6.]
The Philadelphia Inquirer and the Philadelphia Daily News say they won't stop publishing if there is a strike when union contracts expire Aug. 31. [D6.]

The stock of Luby's Cafeterias has been hitting new highs, as some analysts predict a turnaround. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Starting the Climb -- A periodic look at summer interns;
Career Preview Also Works As Mirror for the Job Hunter

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
As the time to return to classes fast approaches, summer interns, seasoned by two or three months of working at jobs in New York, share two realizations: it's a tough world out there, but they are a step ahead of the game.
"A job isn't going to fall in your lap," said Brett Grossman, an intern with the Avrett, Free & Ginsberg advertising firm. "You're going to have to work on it, and you get a lot of rejection." 
 The brutal employment situation is reflected in a new survey by the Hanigan Consulting Group, which showed that hiring by major corporations fell 55 percent from 1989 to 1993. This follows the annual Lindquist Endicott Report by Northwestern University, showing a tiny improvement in prospects compared with 1992 but still representing what the report's author, Victor R. Lindquist, terms "the worst situation in 20 years."
 
'A Step Ahead'
 Participants in summer internships fare much better than others. The Northwestern survey of 258 corporations showed that 17 percent of those hired immediately after graduation this year had been interns or the equivalent. Of interns, 37 percent are offered jobs, and 49 percent of those accept.
"You're kind of a step ahead of people who didn't do one," said Amy Luberto, an accounting student who has spent the summer as an intern at KPMG Peat Marwick. She said interns who were hired permanently by the same employers could "pick up from where they left off and be a step ahead."
Fully half of employers say they plan to increase their internship programs. One of them is the Union Carbide Corporation, which plans to raise the proportion of interns to half of its new hires in technical fields, from 40 percent. It attaches so much importance to the effort that it is identifying potential interns as early as freshman year for internships more than two years in the future.
"Junior year is too late," said Don Gatewood, Union Carbide's recruiting manager. When Union Carbide finds a good freshman prospect, a company representative stays in contact, showing an interest in the student's progress. With minority students, who are much in demand, this effort is particularly important.
Companies say the expense is far less than the expense of hiring unknown people less apt to fit in.
As summer interns being profiled in this series of articles met for the first time recently to discuss their job plans, the atmosphere was pleasant. There were jokes about how Mr. Grossman had been assigned to roam drugstores to scout out competing products and about the remuneration of William McRae, a law summer associate at Chadbourne & Parke and, at $1,600 a week, the highest paid of the group. Philosophical tidbits from cabdrivers were passed on. It seemed generally difficult to walk by New York's many beggars without giving them some change.
The interns were quick to make the transition -- albeit with strained humor -- from the psychic anguish of rejecting a poor person's entreaties to their own worries about being turned down for jobs. The toughest turndowns were the ones they fear might happen to them. These young people competed hard to be chosen as interns, scrambled through the summer to improve their skills and make a good impression, and are now gathering energy and sharpening wiles for the real job hunt.
 
Aggressive Approach
 "You've got to push it every way you can, but not seem like you're pushing it either," said Nick Lobel-Weiss, who has spent the summer working for the American League of Theaters and Producers and is now scouting for a new internship to replace his fall semester at Oberlin College and get college credit in the process.
"There are people who have finished graduate school in theater management who can't find that $100-a-week job to start," he continued. "There's a lot of no."
He said he had learned to be very aggressive in the face of such competition. "I used to write letters that began, 'I'm sorry to bother you,' " he said. "Now, I begin, 'You are the person I want to work for and you want me.' "
Mr. Grossman said he had learned much but found the experience humbling because it had made him realize how much more there was to know.
He said that he had proudly displayed his portfolio to three advertising professionals and that they had questioned a number of important details he said he had never considered. "What I thought was really good isn't good enough," he said. "I want to be an art director, and it isn't as refined as it should be. You have to be so meticulous."
 
Sharpening the Message
 The Southern Methodist University junior said his appreciation of his craft had become much more refined. But, oddly enough, he said this meant breaking things down to "the simplest factors."
"The yardstick by which you change yourself is totally changed in New York," he said. "In Dallas, people sort of sit back and take a look at the big picture. New York is like a Polaroid."
Mr. McRae jumped in to say that among law students, "New York is pretty much the one city that scares the hell out of them."
"I heard some law firms actually have cots and laundry service so you could basically sleep in the office to keep your billable hours up," he said.
His experience did not turn out to be that harsh. "I have stayed a few late nights," he said. "But it's not the sort of twisted work ethic that has made New York's reputation."
Mr. McRae said that statistically graduates of Harvard Law School, which he attends, had a very slim chance of ending up unemployed. But in a way, this added another fear, he said, or perhaps joked. "What if you're that one person in 500 who just happens to repulse employers so much that nobody will hire him?"
 
Learning Corporate Lore
 Ms. Luberto, who will return to Pennsylvania State University soon, said her experience in New York had reduced some fears, particularly about the corporate world. One source of security was being in a class of 20 interns in KPMG's New York office, though very often they would be dispersed, working for different clients. Another was the accounting firm's elaborate program of intern supervision, through which she learned valuable pieces of corporate lore and practice.
And that help will continue. "I can keep in touch with my mentors all through my senior year," she said.
Perhaps because she hoped to come back to Peat Marwick, Ms. Luberto did not seem nervous about the immediate future. But she also emphasized that she was well aware that people often changed courses abruptly, citing the example of her sister, who did not go to culinary school until she was 28, then did an internship at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at 30 and became a chef.
 
'Dick Tracy Society'
 Some of the interns said they expected great change in their professions, though those in law and accounting foresaw a steady demand for the same skills. The boldest vision of future shock was sketched by Mr. Grossman.
"I see a Dick Tracy society," he said, saying that small wireless and paperless devices will instantly supply people's needs. At the other extreme, he mentioned reading about a plan to send a billboard into space, one that could display messages two miles long across the sky. People's personal notebooks will connect "with anywhere in the world," he predicted.
"All the new technologies will become advertising vehicles in one way or another," he said. "And the industry will have to adjust."
 
Worried About Debts
 A big concern of the interns was student debts. Mr. McRae said he was $80,000 in debt and saw his beginning years in legal practice as "being a conduit to the banks." Mr. Lobel-Wiess, who also expects to be tens of thousands of dollars in debt upon graduation, was only slightly sympathetic.
"That conduit will at least be flowing," he said. "For me, it's a little scary."
Natika Smith, who had already returned to her home in California, had the chance to her offer her comments by phone after the group meeting. She was one of 25 participants in Cornell University Medical Center's Summer Research Program for Minority Premedical Students.
She said that as a result of her summer work she had definitely decided on a medical career, though definitely not as a surgeon. "I don't think I could do that all day," she said.
A professional cellist, she first majored in music and only decided on a premedical course last year. Accordingly, she has two more years of college at the University of California at San Diego, then eight years of professional training. Actually starting a permanent job as a physician is thus a long, long way off.
"It's a little too early to be seriously thinking about it," she said.

HEADLINE: Merchants Say Revival Bid Has Hurt, Not Helped

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MERIDEN, Conn., Aug. 17

 BODY:
John Butler's grandfather opened the family paint store here on June 25, 1876, the day Custer made his last stand at the Little Big Horn. Now it is the 58-year-old grandson who says he is making a last stand to keep Butler Paint open.
Mr. Butler and other downtown merchants say they are the victims of a $24 million redevelopment project that, instead of reviving downtown retailing, they say, has crippled it. 
 "We've been here 117 years," said Mr. Butler, "and we've been through depressions, floods and hurricanes, but nothing has disrupted our business more than this project."
Mr. Butler and other merchants were upset last year when road reconstruction and the installation of underground utility lines made most downtown streets impassable for more than six months. But they were furious when the city recently tore up the streets again to put in new sewer lines.
"Incompetence has ruled this project from the beginning," Mr. Butler said. "They tore up all the streets at the same time last year and nobody was able to get down here at all. Now, they do the same thing all over again."
With the streets closed and the sidewalks ripped up, customers stopped coming downtown and some stores closed. Those that survived say business has been cut almost in half. Many merchants say the project has ruined whatever chance they had to compete with the nearby Meriden Square Mall.
Worst of all, merchants say, the city and the redevelopment agency failed to recruit new business or promote downtown Meriden's coming renaissance, choosing to wait until the project was completed.
"The project has been just a big waste of money if they can't bring retail business back here," said Natale Ieraci, owner of the Harry Israel clothing store, which has been on West Main Street since 1904. Because of the recession and the construction work, Mr. Ieraci said business has been bad for three years. "It's been very depressing," he said. "It's never going to be the downtown it used to be."
Customers agreed.
"They can fix the streets, put up new lights and lampposts," said Janet Kwiatkowski, a lifelong Meriden resident, "but I hardly ever come down here because there's nowhere left to shop. There's just nothing here."
Randall Kamerbeek, executive director of the redevelopment agency, said both the city and agency believed it would be better to promote downtown Meriden after there was a finished product, adding that a promotional campaign will begin in the fall.
"When everything is finished, we believe the project will speak for itself and will draw businesses here," Mr. Kamerbeek said. "There have been delays on some aspects of the work, but the overall project is on schedule and in the end will bring people downtown."
 
Strategy Criticized
 But Carol Way, executive director of the Greater Meriden Chamber of Commerce, said the city and redevelopment agency made a big mistake in sitting by and watching as old businesses lost their customer base.
"I think the city should have built on its strengths, its existing businesses, rather than wiping the slate clean, which is the situation we are in now," Ms. Way said. "Their strategy was backward." Ms. Way also criticized the decision to hold off the marketing and promotion effort.
"If they had promoted it all along, they would have at least had some new businesses ready to go," she said. "But I think a good marketing program now can still work."
But it is too late for Gary Verdolini, the former owner of Verdolini's, a popular downtown restaurant that drew customers from around the state, until it was forced to close after a flood last year badly damaged a 200-year-old brick oven.
Mr. Verdolini, along with a group of other merchants, is suing the city. They say the project's construction work was a major factor in the downtown flood last June. They say the city's sewers became clogged because a storm drain was capped during the construction work.
City leaders deny that, insisting that Meriden's flooding problems have been constant throughout the years.
Mayor Angelo D'Agostino conceded the project has been poorly planned and badly managed. Still, he said, it had to be undertaken.
"We had antiquated utility lines and roads and we were losing business even before this construction, so something had to be done," he said.
The project was approved by the City Council in 1988 after years of debate, but work did not begin until 1990. When it is completed in October, the city plans to celebrate with a weekend of festivals, concerts and fireworks.
Downtown merchants say a funeral would be more appropriate.
Stephen M. Prescott, owner of the Justin Time Diner, on Colony Street, said that when he bought his business more than three years ago he should have given it another name.
"I should have called it the Just Too Late Diner, because that's the reality for me," said Mr. Prescott, who added that his business has been devastated by the project. "I'm down to zero employees. It's just me and my wife."
Mr. Butler, still standing outside his paint store, talked about the city's plans to celebrate.
"They're going to celebrate what? A lot of empty buildings and nobody on the streets," said Mr. Butler. "This is just a ghost town now after the way they completely mishandled things."

HEADLINE: Double Sword For President

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
For months it was a sleeper issue in the health care debate. But last week, after President Clinton's initial sales pitch for his plan-in-progress, his proposal that all employers be required to pay for health coverage emerged as one of the most fiercely contested aspects.
The employer mandate, as it is known, presents Mr. Clinton with a dilemma. This President certainly does not want to harm the hundreds of thousands of small-business owners who say, with backing from economists, that the proposal would cause job losses and bankruptcies. And he hardly wants to hand the Republicans a convenient club for attacking his proposals. 
 Yet the mandate is a cornerstone of his most cherished goal, the one that may earn him his place in history: guaranteeing health coverage for all the country's citizens.
 
Alternative Is More Taxes
 Mr. Clinton needs the tens of billions of extra dollars that companies would be forced to pay toward the cost of covering more than 37 million uninsured people, most of whom are workers and their families. As it is, the White House is struggling to find sources for the tens of billions of additional dollars it would need to subsidize threatened companies and cover the unemployed.
Without the large new contribution from employers, the Administration would have to come up with more money itself -- almost certainly through even higher taxes than the proposal already requires. Politically, that may be more dangerous than the wrath of small business.
But Mr. Clinton's dilemma is one faced by his Republican critics as well. If they do not support an employer health care requirement, they either have to come up with other revenue sources, not an appealing prospect, or back away from universal coverage. This may explain why critics like Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, were careful to leave negotiating room on the mandate question.
In his speech to governors last week, Mr. Clinton spoke of a "shared responsibility of employer and employee, building on the system we have now" as the only practical route to universal coverage. His aides say he will propose that employers be required to pay at least 80 percent of the cost of premiums, with employees paying the rest.
 
To Be Phased In
 But Mr. Clinton also stressed the need to phase in the requirement gradually and to limit the obligations of struggling small or low-wage businesses. Officials have discussed putting a cap on the contributions of vulnerable companies to 3.5 percent of payroll, with the Government paying the rest. They have not yet determined the criteria for awarding subsidies, a task that could be an administrative nightmare.
Administration officials also note that if subsidies were offered to uninsured workers without a general employer requirement, many companies that now offer insurance might stop doing so, knowing the Government would fill the gap, and the entire system would unravel.
The debate assumes that the nation will base most health financing on the workplace. The chief alternatives -- a Government takeover of all medical payments, favored by some liberals, or a shift to individual responsibility, favored by some conservatives -- have so far been judged as either undesirable or unrealistic by the President and majorities in Congress.
Expanding employer coverage "is the most pragmatic and least disruptive way to go," said Karen Davis, an expert on health policy and executive of the Commonwealth Fund, a private foundation in New York.
 
System Emerged 50 Years Ago
 The employer-based system emerged during World War II, when companies offered health coverage in lieu of raises, which were prohibited by wage controls. Today, a majority of employers help pay for worker coverage, but many smaller companies, as well as larger companies like retail and fast-food chains that pay low wages, offer few benefits if any, especially to entry-level employees.
The first prominent proposal for mandating employer coverage came not from the Democrats but from President Richard M. Nixon in the early 1970's. His health plan died along with his Presidency, but similar mandates were later proposed by President Jimmy Carter and a succession of Democrats in Congress.
About three-fourths of the nation's workers are already covered by employers, either directly or through a working spouse. But a majority of companies with fewer than 100 employees do not offer health benefits, said William Custer of the Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington.
The debate has been hampered by disagreement over cost estimates. The Administration estimates that in 1993 the nation's companies and workers will spend $275 billion on health premiums. Simply extending the current system to all workers would require additional outlays of close to $70 billion, which would be paid by employers, workers and Government through its subsidies.
But the new system will save such large sums through reduced administration and other changes that the cost of covering all workers will be far less than that, said Kenneth Thorpe, an official in the Department of Health and Human Services and an architect of the Clinton plan. Costly emergency-room visits for routine care by people with no insurance or doctor will also decline, he said. But Mr. Thorpe refused to disclose the Administration's working estimate of the ultimate costs.
The politics of the employer mandate are more convoluted than the chorus of attacks on Mr. Clinton last week would suggest. Leading Republicans in the Senate, where the battle over the health plan may be closest, have voiced deep concern about the mandate, but they have also been careful, as John H. Chafee of Rhode Island put it, "to avoid drawing lines in the sand."
Senator Dole, when asked whether he supported universal coverage, said, "I think that's our goal, but I'm not certain how quickly we can achieve it."
Asked how this could be financed without an employer requirement he said: "I'm not sure we have an alternative yet. There may be other ways to finance it." But Mr. Dole also said of Mr. Clinton's plan, to be unveiled more fully next month, "Let's see what he has to offer before taking shots at it."
 
What Business Prefers
 As an alternative to guaranteed universal coverage, some Republicans and other critics have discussed a more decentralized approach involving expanded public clinics, rules to reduce insurance costs and tax incentives to help the uninsured find coverage.
That is the approach of the National Federation of Independent Business, which lobbies on behalf of 600,000 small businesses and is leading the campaign against a mandate. "What we say is 'universal access,' " said Michael Roush, chief Senate lobbyist for the federation.
The federation is implacably opposed to a mandate, with or without subsidies, which, Mr. Roush said, "will only at best mitigate the bad effects."
A majority of the federation's members actually do offer health coverage to some employees, but in some cases it is less generous than what Mr. Clinton would require. Even many owners who now offer costly benefits tend to oppose any new Government requirement.
Still, Mr. Clinton will find considerable support for the mandate within the business community. The United States Chamber of Commerce, for example, which represents businesses of various sizes supports a mandate provided it is accompanied by adequate subsidies for small business.
"The chamber's view is that unless everybody in the health system is playing by the same rules, this nation is never going to get a grip on runaway health costs," said Kristin Bass, manager of human resources with the organization. She noted that as hospitals and doctors make up the costs of treating uninsured patients through excess charges to the insured, smaller companies that offer benefits are being penalized.
Large corporations, almost all of which provide health benefits, may provide the strongest support of all. These businesses say they are not only forced to help pay for the uninsured but also are unfairly saddled with the health costs of entire families when the spouse has a job without benefits.
"If it's going to be the policy of this country to rely on employers to finance health care, then it's got to be all employers," said Walter B. Maher, director of Federal relations for the Chrysler Corporation.
The experience of individual states provides ammunition to both sides. So far, only Hawaii has required insurance payments by employers, and only Hawaii has achieved near-total health coverage of its population.
Hawaii passed its mandate in 1974, a time when health costs were much lower. Businessmen there say the mandate has sometimes caused hardship but that in general employers have adjusted well. A recent study by state officials asserts that business has not suffered and notes that unemployment in Hawaii has fallen steadily since the 1970's while small businesses have thrived. But critics question Hawaii's relevance, given its isolation and strong economy.
On the mainland, the first state to vote for a mandate was Massachusetts, in 1988. But as the economy soured and a Republican Governor took office, small-business owners counterattacked and won a delay of the plan until 1995. Opponents are expected to make another push to delay or kill the plan.
Oregon passed an employer mandate that was originally scheduled to take effect in 1995. But as in Massachusetts, business opposition has grown, and this month the Legislature voted to defer the requirement until 1997. "If the economy turns sour I think the mandate could disappear," said Courtney S. Campbell, a medical ethicist at Oregon State University.
Earlier this year Washington State also passed an employer mandate but it will not be in full effect until 1999.

HEADLINE: Conquering the Rift on Puerto Rico;
Mainland Residents Stung by Exclusion From Vote on Island

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
For many years Puerto Rico's leaders paid but passing attention to people of Puerto Rican descent living on the mainland, making a few courtesy calls and campaign stops in the Northeast.
But that is changing. 
 Mainland residents of Puerto Rican heritage, including three members of Congress who played a major role recently in preserving corporate tax breaks for companies doing business on the island, have shown that they have influence and are willing to use it.
The result has been a tilt of power and a slow recognition by political leaders on the island that they must court their compatriots on the mainland. But many people in New York and elsewhere on the mainland, who retain close ties to the island and say they care deeply about its future, feel that recognition has been too slow in coming. As proof, they point to the island government's recent rejection of calls to allow mainland participation in the November vote about Puerto Rico's future political status.
 
A Changing Relationship
 "The relationship here in the past between both communities has been characterized on the part of Puerto Rico's leadership looking down on us as those poor, dark-skinned hillbillies who moved to the mainland and forgotten us," said Jose Luis Rodriguez, the head of a Hispanic cable television station in Manhattan who is active in Puerto Rican affairs.
"They conveniently establish relations with us when they feel their interests are at stake. If they helped us in any way, it was a coincidence."
In the non-binding vote, Puerto Ricans will choose among the island's continued status as a United States commonwealth, statehood or independence. But Congress will make the final decision.
After island officials decided against allowing voters on the mainland to participate, Hispanic politicians in New York decided to hold their own nonbinding vote on Oct. 6-8, a move that Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer said was a strong message to the island's leaders.
"We finally told them our vote and voice conveys enormous political and moral weight," Mr. Ferrer said. "It cannot be ignored. This is a message being sent to these folks that they need to understand."
Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy in New York City, echoed the thought, noting that by the year 2000 the mainland and island Puerto Rican populations will be about equal. There are now about 2.6 million Puerto Ricans on the mainland; the island population is 3.7 million. "What is happening now is irreversible," he said. "What we're seeing now is a real changing relationship for the next few years. We've been invisible for a long time. We hope that will change."
In some ways, Gov. Pedro J. Rossello of Puerto Rico has gotten part of the message, as seen in a recent leadership conference among Hispanic leaders in San Juan and his more active courting of mainland Puerto Ricans and other Hispanic leaders. Also, he and other officials have sought help in lobbying for the tax breaks provided under Section 936 of the Internal Revenue code and have held regular meetings with the three members of Congress of Puerto Rican heritage, Nydia M. Velasquez and Jose E. Serrano of New York City and Luis V. Gutierrez of Chicago.
 
Integration of Leadership
 "There is an integration of the leadership in Puerto Rico and the Puerto Rican political leadership in the mainland," Governor Rossello said. "What I foresee here in the future is a strengthening and integration of agendas."
He added that while mainland residents will not participate in the island's November plebiscite, they will have an important role to play as the process unfolds in Congress. "There is no question that the Puerto Rican mainland community and the Hispanic community directly and indirectly, through their representatives in Congress, will be a major factor," he said.
An early sign of the growing political strength of mainland politicians could be seen five years ago, during the Democratic Presidential primary in New York. Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon came to New York City's Puerto Rican neighborhoods to stump for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts. He did so even though the city's Puerto Rican elected officials had already endorsed the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
Governor Hernandez Colon's endorsement typified the relationship that the island's politicians had with their counterparts here, said a number of observers who described the island's politicians as too long out of touch with the lives of their stateside countrymen.
That feeling was echoed again in 1990, when Puerto Rico's three political parties rejected the idea of allowing nonresidents of Puerto Rican heritage to vote in the plebiscite on the island's status. The reasons offered in opposition ranged from technical and logistical difficulties to questioning the "Puerto Rican-ness" of those who had left the island to seek economic opportunity on the mainland.
But many mainland residents rejected the reasoning, saying they hoped to return to the island eventually. That, combined with strong nationalistic feelings, leads them to conclude that having a say in the island's future is their birthright.
The recent lobbying effort to maintain the tax breaks, which included the gathering of 350,000 signatures on petitions in New York alone and a meeting between President Clinton and the three Puerto Rican members of Congress, laid the groundwork for political parity on fundamental issues affecting the island.
"It gave them a big lesson and might be part of a learning process for them to realize they have a big resource in us being in the Congress," said Ms. Velasquez.
Hector Cordero-Guzman, the research director for political economy at the Center for Puerto Rican Studies at the City University of New York, said increased numbers of Puerto Rican politicians at both the national and local levels have given the mainland residents the chance to have a new degree of influence.
"There is increased visibility among our elected officials, and they have been around longer with a measure of power and some impact on public policy," Mr. Cordero-Guzman said.
He and others noted that while mainland leaders were courted for support of the tax breaks, their exclusion from the plebiscite was sending mixed signals about the kind of relationship that island leaders want.
"They would ideally like an off-the-shelf lobbying effort, but they don't want anyone to tell them how to run their own house," Mr. Cordero-Guzman said.
He traced part of the reason to the backgrounds of political leadership here and on the island. Mainland politicians, he said, often have grass-roots origins; the island's leadership tends to come from social elites.
Nonetheless, a number of people noted that Governor Rossello has been cultivating people on the mainland to improve long-term political influence. In that respect, Mr. Serrano noted, Governor Rossello represents a departure from the past.
When Mr. Serrano was elected to the House, he said he took office not only representing his South Bronx district, but also Puerto Rico.
He said that Governor Rossello had a keen understanding of the role he and his Congressional colleagues could play. He speaks daily with a member of the Governor's office and has weekly conversations with the Governor.
"He knows he has entree into the Congressional Hispanic Caucus because of us, the Illinois delegation, the New York delegation," said Mr. Serrano, who is the chairman of the caucus.
Governor Rossello refers to Mr. Serrano and his Puerto Rican colleagues as his unofficial delegation.
"In that sense I feel very grateful to the Puerto Rican and Hispanic leadership that have adopted our causes and have become in essence advocates for those causes."
City Councilman Jose Rivera, Democrat of the Bronx, said that while he is not totally satisfied with the current relationship, he has seen some hopeful signs.
"It's a long struggle, letting the leaders in Puerto Rico know they have nothing to fear from the leaders in the United States," he said. "We're their brothers and sisters, and we feel as they do for Puerto Rico. We have a contribution to make."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Star TV Extends Murdoch's Reach

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch, the man who brought "The Simpsons" to an American television audience and satellite television to much of Britain, is on the verge of bringing both to tens of millions of viewers in Asia.
With his $525 million takeover last month of Star TV, Asia's pioneer satellite television service, Mr. Murdoch has bought himself at least the potential of reaching two-thirds of the world's population. And as a result, he is now close to creating the first truly global television empire. 
 Star's five satellite channels can be seen in 38 nations in Asia and the Middle East -- from Tokyo to Tel Aviv, from Mongolia to Malaysia, and all of China and India -- and can reach, by Star's estimate, 45 million people who have the necessary equipment.
Hong Kong-based Star, Mr. Murdoch's most important acquisition since his debt-restructuring crisis in 1990, completes the arc of a Murdoch television empire that also includes Fox Broadcasting in the United States and half-ownership in British Sky Broadcasting, the largest satellite service in Europe.
 
A Vast Asian Market
 Mr. Murdoch's willingness to risk half a billion dollars for a controlling stake in a two-year-old television service that has not turned a profit, and may not anytime soon, underscores the excitement in broadcasting circles about the possibilities of pan-Asian television.
"The potential in Asia is enormous," Mr. Murdoch said in announcing the deal for his News Corporation to buy 63.6 percent of Hutchvision Ltd., the parent company of Star. Hutchvision was founded by Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. and the family of the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing.
John Kaye of the Survey Research Group, a Hong Kong-based media research firm, said that while it was too early to judge the price paid by Mr. Murdoch, "it's a reasonable risk he's taking if you bear in mind what everybody expects to happen in this part of the world -- a very large, growing population of people with disposable incomes."
Financial analysts say Mr. Murdoch will almost certainly use Star as a vehicle for rebroadcasting programs produced by Fox and Sky, including such popular American fare as "The Simpsons" and "Beverly Hills 90210," which are thought likely to attract the sort of young, affluent audiences that major advertisers covet as much in Hong Kong as they do in Houston.
 
Four Channels in English
 Star is currently available free to anyone with a satellite dish. Its advertisers include Coca-Cola, Citibank and McDonald's.
Four of the five channels are broadcast in English: MTV Asia, the Asian cousin of MTV, or Music Television; BBC World Service News, the British answer to CNN; a sports channel, and an entertainment channel that depends on syndicated programs from the United States, including Oprah Winfrey's talk show, and reruns of American series. The fifth channel features Chinese-language entertainment. A pay-television service, scheduled to begin later this year, plans eventually to show films in Cantonese and Mandarin, as well as Hindi, the principal language of India.
In only a few years, satellite television has created a revolution in popular culture across Asia -- a continent that is home to millions of people for whom a television set would be an unimaginable luxury, but also to some of the world's fastest-growing economies.
MTV Asia is a cultural phenomenon, altering the musical tastes and buying habits of tens of millions of middle-class Asian teen-agers who are bored by the much more limited offerings on local television. Millions of Asian adults now get their news from BBC World Service Television or from Cable News Network. CNN is not carried by Star; its signal is bounced off various satellites.
The news that such a powerful cultural tool is now in the hands of a Western businessman has already led one Asian leader to worry whether Asia is being subjected to a sort of mass-media colonialism.
Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia suggested this month that Mr. Murdoch might have bought Star because he wanted "to control the news that we are going to receive" in Asia. If not, he said, why would Mr. Murdoch, a naturalized American citizen from Australia, have paid "such a fantastic price for a network that has never shown any profit?"
Mr. Murdoch has said through spokesmen that he has no intention of interfering in the political affairs of the nations that receive Star TV. In a statement released after Mr. Mahathir's remarks became public, the News Corporation said that it intended to make Star a service that "Asian families can enjoy in their homes" and one that Asian governments will consider both "friendly and useful."
Despite his soothing words, Mr. Murdoch is bound to come up repeatedly against Prime Minister Mahathir and others in the region who see satellite television as a threat to cultural values and political stability. Both Malaysia and neighboring Singapore ban most private ownership of television dishes. As a result, Star TV is not routinely seen in either country, although both nations allow their Government-controlled television networks to rebroadcast news programs from CNN.
 
A Jump on the Competition
 In acquiring control of Star, Mr. Murdoch has bought himself a head start of at least a year or two over several large television competitors that are now angling to enter the satellite market in Asia. Star is now the only large satellite network to reach all of Asia, including China and India. Its near-monopoly of Asian satellite capacity will end, however, when several new satellites are placed into orbit over the continent during the next few years.
Only days after Mr. Murdoch's announcement, Dow Jones & Company, the owner of The Wall Street Journal, said it would join with a group that planned to start Asia's first satellite business news channel. Its partners in the project include Tele-Communications Inc., the largest cable television company in the United States.
Star's most powerful rival may prove to be a consortium formed this year by the Turner Broadcasting System, the parent of CNN; Time Warner, parent of the year-old Home Box Office Asia; Capital Cities/ABC, majority owner of the ESPN sports channel, and TVB, the dominant television network in Hong Kong.
TVB, which stands for Television Broadcasts, is seen by financial analysts as the pivotal member of the group, since it controls the world's largest library of Chinese-language television programs, which are the key to television markets in Hong Kong, Taiwan and, most important, a vast potential audience in China.
"We produce about 5,000 hours of programming a year, and we've been in the business for 26 years, so we measure our library in tens of thousands of hours of programming," said S. K. Fung, general manager of TVB's international arm. "That's why we're valuable to our American friends. They see us as the locomotive that can pull a whole series of train cars along to the market."
Mr. Murdoch understands the value of that library, which was a major reason for his attempt to buy 22 percent of TVB earlier this year. The deal was put on hold after it appeared that the Hong Kong Government would not relax rules governing the ownership of local broadcasters by companies based outside Hong Kong.

HEADLINE: Philadelphia's Newspapers Prepare for Possible Strike

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Labor strikes have deprived residents here of their daily newspapers 11 times since 1970. The most recent walkout, in 1985, was the longest, lasting 46 days and costing the local economy millions of dollars through the loss of the city's principal channels of print advertising.
With 14 contracts for 10 unions expiring at midnight on Aug. 31, about 3,000 employees of the city's major dailies, The Philadelphia Inquirer and the tabloid Philadelphia Daily News, may be ready to walk again. So far, three unions have voted to authorize a strike. But this time, the publisher of both papers, Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., which is owned by the Knight-Ridder chain, intends no disruption of service. 
 For the last four weekends, managers have practiced publishing both newspapers. The company has also informed the unions that it will hire temporary replacement workers in some production areas.
"Obviously, we can't do it solely with our people," Charles Fancher, a vice president of Philadelphia Newspapers, said. "Some temporary help will be brought in but not as permanent replacements. We have no intention to do that. But we are prepared to publish even if all of them walk out."
With an average weekday circulation of 502,740 during the six months ended on March 31, The Inquirer was ranked as the 14th-largest daily newspaper in the country by Advertising Age magazine, based on figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations. With weekday circulation of 197,481, The Daily News was ranked 57th.
While Pennsylvania law prohibits companies from retaining replacement workers hired during a labor dispute, union leaders say the tactic of hiring temporary workers is intended to weaken solidarity during tough economic times.
"Basically, this is a strike no one wants," said a member of the Newspaper Guild, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Guild is the union for reporters, photographers and advertising employees. "Most unions don't want to go out. But it's the teamsters who are most threatened. They're the ones who could lose the most jobs."
Local 628 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents the newspaper's truck drivers, is concerned about changes in the newspapers' distribution system since the company opened a $300 million printing plant in the suburbs last year. Before the plant opened, drivers carried bundles of newspapers from the main building downtown to 65 warehouses in the metropolitan area; from those warehouses, distributors picked up the newspapers for delivery to local retailers.
With the new plant, Mr. Fancher said, the company was able to eliminate 19 warehouses. Also, some distributors now retrieve their own bundles directly from the plant. The company has not eliminated any jobs, but union officials say many drivers have had workweeks reduced to the point that they cannot qualify for health benefits. A teamsters local representing mailers, workers who combine sections of the newspaper at the plant, also argues that new technology has cost them work.
"This is a question of job security," said Joseph M. Lyons, president of the Philadelphia Council of Newspaper Unions, an umbrella organization that negotiates for all the unions. "You don't know where it's going to end. We have to stop the bleeding."
A big issue for the Guild, the largest union, with 1,100 members, is the classification of about 200 contributing reporters and photographers who are generally paid on a per-article basis. Mr. Lyons said many of them worked nearly as many hours as full-time employees but did not receive the same company-paid benefits.
