HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Junk Bond Sales Surge As Interest Rates Fall

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Sales of junk, or high yield, bonds -- those below investment grade -- have smashed last year's record sales less than eight months into 1993. And analysts and junk bond portfolio managers said that they expected the surge to continue.
So far this year, new issues of junk bonds have totaled $37.4 billion in the public market, compared with $37.3 billion last year. And when a new wave of private placements of these low-grade corporate debt instruments is added, the total for the year is already about $48 billion, according to the Duff & Phelps/MCM Investment Research Company. 
 A driving force behind the heavy sales is a country full of investors and fund managers who are scrambling for higher yields as interest rates plummet in the face of slow economic growth and low inflation. Even with some selling on Friday, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond is at 6.23 percent, just above its lowest level in 16 years, and the yield on the 10-year note is 5.61 percent, its lowest in more than 20 years.
 
Widening the Market
 The high yield bonds from companies at the top of the non-investment-grade ranks, those with credit ratings of BB and Ba, have already been received warmly. These are from companies like the News Corporation and the Turner Broadcasting System.
But the search for yields is now opening the market to companies, like Dal-Tile International, a leading producer of tiles, with much lower credit ratings -- in this case, the C level.
Six months or a year ago, Dal-Tile could not have sold a bond issue, said Margaret D. Patel, a senior vice president at Boston Security Counselors, a junk bond fund manager in Boston. In early August, however, it sold $133 million of senior secured five-year notes, although Ms. Patel said the prospectus made clear that the company did not have the resources to pay off the principal when the bonds matured. "Welcome to the junk bond market," she said.
On the issuer side, many companies are doing what homeowners, states, cities and towns are doing: paying off old, higher interest-rate debt with new lower-rate bonds.
 
Restrictive Loans
 In addition, a lot of companies are selling bonds so they can get out from under the restrictions that come with their current bank loans, said Kingman Penniman, the head of junk bond research at Duff & Phelps/MCM. Even with the sometimes higher interest rates on the bonds, the companies do not have collateral or cash tied up, and they do not have to pay back any of the principal borrowed until the bonds come due. Banks want some of the principal right away.
Ms. Patel said she thought the rally in junk bonds would continue. "I don't think there is a significant general risk in the junk bond market," she said. That would mean there is no threat of wide default, which is what killed the market at the end of the 1980's.
She said the spreads between the yields on junk bond issues and comparable Treasury securities have remained relatively wide and, therefore, still "signal a buying opportunity."
 
A Glut of Issues
 The risk, she said, "is on a credit- specific basis." In the rush of new issues, especially those with lower credit ratings, there are chances to make wrong choices. "There are so many issues coming that it is hard to go through and sort them out, even with a large staff," she said.
Kevin Mathews, portfolio manager of the Van Kampen Merritt High Yield Fund, said that in the last two or three weeks, the market had weakened because there were so many new issues coming to market while the supply of cash among investors had shrunk a little. Because of that, many issues had been sold at a higher yield, and thus a lower price, than the underwriters thought possible before the sales.
"Going forward, you are going to have to see the new-issue market get cheaper to get investors into it," he said. "So in the near term there is technical weakness, but in the longer term I am still bullish."
But Mr. Penniman said he was worried that the market was too high. "Are we starting to get close to a peak?" he asked. "I think so."
 
A Problem Signaled
 He said he was worried that the decline in interest rates, which is sending investors to the higher yields in the junk market, may be signaling a problem.
The decline in rates, he said, has come in part because traders and investors are expecting the economy to remain sluggish for a lot longer than many economists had forecast. Among those forecasters is Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who predicted that growth in the second quarter would be about 2.5 percent to 3 percent. It could now wind up about 1 percent.
If the market is right and the economy is not picking up some momentum, that is bad for the companies that sell junk bonds, he said, because they need a revived economy to generate cash to keep them healthy.
"The high yield market depends on economic activity to maintain these credits," he said. "So, we don't say that Treasury yields going lower is necessarily good for the high-yield market."

HEADLINE: Patents;
An energy clock to tell homeowners when to turn up or turn down the electricity.

BYLINE: By Teresa Riordan

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IF Norman E. Chasek's idea for monitoring electricity comes to full fruition, an energy clock will hang in every American home. Depending upon how much community-wide demand is being put on a household's electrical utility at any given time, green or red lights will light up.
"Three greens would mean now is a good time to use lots of electricity," Mr. Chasek said. "Three reds would mean it's time to turn off the air- conditioner." 
 An electrical engineer who lives in Stamford, Conn., Mr. Chasek, 64, received a patent last week for his "system for developing real time economic incentives to encourage efficient use of the resources of a regulated electric utility."
The patented process would save electric utilities from having to build new energy plants to meet temporary and erratic demand peaks, Mr. Chasek says, and it would ultimately reduce the cost of electricity.
"It doesn't throw out the regulators but it brings market forces to bear on the price of electricity," he said. "It also makes it possible to introduce conservation without penalizing the utilities."
Mr. Chasek referred to "time-of-day" rates that many utilities now use as a "crude" version of what his invention might achieve.
Under the patented process, which covers a software algorithm, consumers using energy during low demand periods would receive bonuses credited to their bill; those using energy at peak times would be severely penalized with surcharges.
"The price difference could get quite extreme," said Mr. Chasek, who added that the energy clock would be updated every hour of every day. "Eventually people would just get smart."
He said he hoped a commentary piece he has written for a coming issue of Public Utilities Fortnightly, an industry magazine, would stimulate interest in his idea among regulators.
Mr. Chasek, a full-time inventor, said he also had patented a traffic light system that responded in real time to traffic flow and an electronic turnpike card that eliminated the need for toll takers.
He received patent 5,237,507.
 
Blood Substitute To Cut Disease
 In an attempt to capture what is estimated to be at minimum a $1 billion blood transfusion market, about a half-dozen companies are aggressively developing red blood cell substitutes. Unlike human blood, such substitutes would not transmit AIDS, hepatitis and other yet-to-be discovered viruses.
Enzon Inc., a biotechnology concern in Piscataway, N.J., this month received a patent for its substitute, which it calls PEG-hemoglobin.
The substitute basically consists of bovine blood whose infinitessimally small molecules of hemoglobin, which release oxygen to the blood system, have been chemically glued to the inside of tiny, elongated plastic sheaths.
The plastic sheathing disguises the substitute's foreign nature from the transfusion recipient's immune system, according to Enzon's vice president of research and development, Dr. Robert G. L. Shorr. Dr. Shorr also said the plastic covering, by turning the hemoglobin into a "monster-size molecule," makes it more stable and prevents it from leaking through capillary walls or filtering through the kidneys.
"The beauty of this is that it delivers oxygen wonderfully," Dr. Shorr said. "It stays where it's supposed to be, does what it's supposed to do, and doesn't go where it's not supposed to."
Dr. Shorr said that in trials with dogs the substitute continued delivering oxygen for 120 hours after transfusion. The company plans to file an application with the Food and Drug Administration to begin human trials in 1994.
Enzon was assigned patent 5,234,903.
 
A 'Pocket Toilet' When It's Needed
 Whether it's on the freeway or in the city, the need to go to the bathroom sometimes occurs when no proper facility is conveniently at hand. Hence Brice Belisle's idea for a "pocket john."
"It works great," said Mr. Belisle, 59, an illustrator in Brooklyn who received a patent for the invention last week. "You can sit in a car and put a newspaper on your lap and no one will be the wiser."
The invention, which is meant to be used by men, is basically an expandable funnel-like plastic bag with a hole at the bottom which sits within a second bag that catches urine. For ease of handling, according to the inventor, a pair of finger grips flank the top of the device.
Once finished, users of the invention can remove a strip that covers a piece of double-sticky tape and securely close the opening.
"It's very waterproof," said Mr. Belisle, who suggested that the best place to use his invention in a congested area like Manhattan is in a phone booth.
Mr. Belisle said that he had had an initial batch of pocket johns, which will sell from $2 to $3 each, manufactured in Hong Kong and that he recently had received a small order from a catalogue company. He is currently trying to develop a version of his invention for women.
Mr. Belisle received patent 5,235,7095.
Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
It's a Question of Judgment, Not Zeal

BYLINE: By Alan Finder

 BODY:
HE still does not get it. Philip R. Michael was forced to resign as the New York City's Budget Director last Thursday after investigators concluded that he had shown favoritism toward a company trying to win a city contract. Mr. Michael maintains that he did nothing improper, and he said in his resignation letter that he was stepping down only because "some may think that the report reduces my effectiveness."
But this is what the Department of Investigation reported finding in its five-month inquiry: Mr. Michael met repeatedly with a company that was pursuing a lucrative city contract, and in a crucial meeting in November 1990, in front of the company's executives, he pressured the Transportation Commissioner, Lucius J. Riccio, to give the company a small, related contract. Mr. Michael said that if Mr. Riccio went along, he would ease budget cuts for Mr. Riccio's department. 
 And if that were not enough to raise questions about Mr. Michael's judgment, consider this: The company in question was Lockheed Information Management Services, which under a different name figured prominently in the city corruption scandals of 1986.
Most damaging of all, though, was the investigators' conclusion that Mr. Michael had not told the truth about the meeting with Mr. Riccio and Lockheed representatives. Mr. Michael denied that he had pressed Mr. Riccio on behalf of the company. But Mr. Riccio insisted that he had, and at least three people who were present backed up Mr. Riccio's version, the report said.
But Mr. Michael remains unrepentant, continuing to insist that he acted properly. In his letter of resignation on Friday, Mr. Michael told the Mayor: "It is clear I did nothing wrong and I am glad that you agree that my only 'sin' was seeking greater city revenues.
"Most other governments simply shrug each time they end a year out of balance; you made budget balance your highest priority," he continued. "For us to achieve this balance, in the face of a cumulative $8 billion gap, zealousness by the Budget Director becomes essential. For that zealousness, I make no apology.
"I never stepped over the line," he wrote. "There is no smoking gun here."
Mr. Michael is a decent man who has been in government for nearly two decades. He worked hard to keep the city's books balanced for four years during a brutal recession and anemic recovery. In fact, the investigators' report offered no evidence that in supporting Lockheed he was motivated by anything other than the desire to raise more revenue for the city.
He is understandably upset and defensive at being forced from office, and it is only natural that he should want to leave with his head held high.
But he apparently leaves without understanding why his judgment was called into question. The city investigators concluded that he ignored the appearance of impropriety and showed favoritism by promoting Lockheed, which had promised to increase the amount of unpaid parking fines the city collected by $100 million a year. That was surely a powerful lure for a budget director desperate to avoid layoffs of city workers or tax increases.
Mr. Michael crossed the line, the investigators decided, by pressing not just for contracting out, or "privatizing," the parking bureau's operations, but also for pushing a particular company. There is no indication in the report that he sought any personal gain or that his intervention helped Lockheed win the contract, valued at $150 million to $200 million over five years.
Mr. Michael was hardly the only official found by the investigators to have blurred ethical distinctions. Ellen Baer, the chief of staff for the First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, met several times with Lockheed officials to talk about a possible job before recusing herself from the deliberations over the contract.
Agapito Diaz, an assistant transportation commissioner, sat on the interagency committee that selected Lockheed for the $150 million contract without telling anyone that he was a close friend of the vice president in charge of Lockheed's New York office, Kevin T. Smyley. When Marvyn Bryson, a parking bureau contract manager, was overseeing a small keypunch contract that Lockheed won in 1992, Mr. Smyley treated him to lunch four times.
These actions, disclosed in the investigators' report, show a disturbing inattention to ethical standards, although it appears that none of the actions was a crime.
And so the Mayor, running for re-election and engaged in damage control, was probably right when he insisted on Friday that the actions described in the report did not represent the kind of "corruption scandal" that wracked city government seven years ago. He then dismissed the officials' actions as mere "overzealousness" by people working hard to prevent New Yorkers from having to pay higher taxes.
But at stake, Mr. Dinkins's critics argue, were more important things, like the appearance of fairness and propriety. The critics, including the Mayor's Republican-Liberal opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, will no doubt continue to hammer away at the point, contending that Mr. Dinkins, like Mr. Michael, still does not get it.

HEADLINE: New Guidelines for S.& L.'s Require Extra Capital

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Federal regulators expect to issue new rules this week requiring savings and loan associations to maintain extra capital to keep them from going broke when interest rates shift unpredictably, according to Administration officials.
The rules are among the most important regulations called for by Congress in response to the costly wave of bankruptcies in the 1980's, when many savings and loans found themselves paying higher interest on deposits than they received for mortgages and other loans. The ensuing crisis has cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars. 
 Officials of the Office of Thrift Supervision, in a briefing Thursday, said that most savings and loans had repaired their portfolios in recent years by issuing more short-term and adjustable-rate mortgages and by hedging their bets on the future direction of interest rates.
 
Interest Rate Risk Down
 Because of these changes, agency officials said, only 6 percent of all savings institutions now have above normal levels of interest rate risk and must adhere to the new capital guidelines.
Of those 125 institutions, 103 already have enough capital on their books to comply with the new rules, and the remaining 22 have until the end of 1994 to raise the necessary capital, which is estimated to be less than $100 million under current conditions. So the strain on the financial system from the new rules is considered to be negligible.
"The risk has been coming down consistently since 1991," when the thrift supervision office first introduced its model used to calculate the risks to portfolios from interest rate shifts, John Robinson, director of policy at the agency, said. "I'd like to think that the spotlight we have placed on the issue has encouraged this. We have been harping on it."
Other agencies that regulate banks are also developing regulations on interest rate risk, but the Office of Thrift Supervision rules are especially important because the savings and loans, which typically borrow short term and lend long term, are the most likely to suffer from changes in interest rates.
 
Data on Loans and Deposits
 The agency is already collecting data from the industry about the loans and deposits in each institution's portfolio, and its examiners will run the calculations for each institution to see what might happen if interest rates moved two percentage points in either direction.
It has taken the agency four years to develop the model it will use to monitor interest rate risks.
 
Providing Extra Capital
 If the model shows that the value of a portfolio would decline by more than 2 percent of the institution's assets, the savings and loan would have to set aside extra capital against the risk.
The purpose is not to eliminate the risks of such changes -- that would be pointless in an industry whose livelihood is made on the spread between interest rates on loans and deposits.
Rather, by requiring institutions to add capital to their balance sheets when risks are found by the model to be above normal, the rules are intended to insure that the savings and loans can absorb the financial shock of interest rate fluctuations.

HEADLINE: U.S. Cavalry for Soviet Borders?

 BODY:
A lively controversy rages inside and outside the Clinton Administration over what role America should play in the messy military conflicts now igniting the periphery of the former Soviet Union. Several of these conflicts directly involve Russian troops.
Next month the Administration plans to outline its formal policy as part of the guidelines it has promised on contributing U.S. military forces to future United Nations peacekeeping operations. Already Washington has assigned a senior diplomat to lead a high-profile American drive to achieve negotiated solutions to these conflicts. 
 Warfare that involves Eurasia's mightiest military machine outside Russia's lawful borders is certainly a matter for serious American concern. But military or even aggressive diplomatic intervention is the wrong response. The U.S. can contribute more constructively by focusing its efforts on the slow slog of Russian reform rather than the high drama of crisis management.
Bloody conflicts in the Caucasus and Central Asia were all too predictable. The political structures of a continental empire Russia acquired over four centuries was instantly shattered when the Soviet Union broke up in December 1991. Now, pro- and anti-Moscow factions fight to control newly independent states whose politics, demographics and boundaries were long manipulated to serve Russian needs and whims.
In Azerbaijan, Georgia and Tajikistan, where the worst fighting now rages, independence abruptly arrived when no national political leaders were in place except for compromised Soviet apparatchiks or inexperienced nationalist and religious dissidents. Worse still, no effective national armies yet existed, leaving the field open to Russian units of the old Soviet armed forces and the undisciplined bands of rival local warlords.
There is a case for a transitional Russian military presence in these former Soviet republics, and a far stronger case for guaranteeing the basic rights of the ethnic Russian populations now stranded beyond Russia's borders.
But there is no justification for political meddling by Russian military units in the domestic politics of independent states. Most of this meddling comes at the behest of ultranationalist political opponents of Boris Yeltsin and their military allies in units stationed in the Caucasus and the Central Asian republics.
Washington should speak out forthrightly when Russian military moves trespass on sovereignty and international law, without fearing that such criticism would somehow undermine the Yeltsin Government.
Nationalist emotion is a powerful factor in Russian politics. But if the United States and other Western countries carefully and consistently remind Russians that failure to play by the international rules could isolate Russia, they could reinforce the arguments of Moscow's more sophisticated political leaders that new imperial wars are the last thing the country's strained economy now needs.
On the other hand, the dispatch of American troops, even under a U.N. flag, and highly publicized U.S. mediation efforts would almost surely be seen by many Russians as humiliating and provocative.
America's most vital interest in the former Soviet Union is the survival and health of a responsible, reforming government in Moscow. That interest is best advanced by generous and consistent support for economic and political reforms in Russia itself -- not by a grandiose, self-assigned role patrolling the troubled imperial frontier.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Capital for Human Services

BYLINE: By Carol Moseley-Braun; Carol Moseley-Braun, Democrat of Illinois, is a member of the Senate Banking Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In East St. Louis, Ill., one of the nation's poorest communities, the doors of a new Family Support Center will open in a few weeks. Infants and preschoolers from very low-income families will receive high-quality, subsidized child care, enabling the parents to become or remain employed. At the same location, parents will receive health-care services, parenting training and educational opportunities.
This initiative was made possible because capital improvement dollars were available from the Illinois Facilities Fund, a private, nonprofit lender, to help construct the facility. Throughout Illinois, the need for capital to bring or expand human services in poor neighborhoods is acute. These services, whether for the elderly, the disabled or infants of working mothers, are an integral part of any economic development plan. 
 A lack of credit for providers is clearly limiting the availability of child care. But examples in Illinois and across the nation demonstrate how nonprofit, private lenders can help resolve that problem.
The Illinois Facilities Fund, financed by foundations and banks, makes below-market real estate loans to nonprofit human service agencies unable to obtain traditional financing. The fund has made loans to 23 child-care centers for expansion of services to low-income families. Similar efforts through other nonprofit leaders, like the Child Care Capital Investment Fund in Boston and the Self-Help Development Bank in North Carolina, have proved that nonprofit lenders are excellent partners in child care.
Traditional bank loans don't often work because of the special-use nature of child-care facilities and the need for appraisals that exceed the loan amount, among other reasons. More important, nonprofit child-care is experiencing tremendous growth. It is already underfinanced, with the Government subsidy for low-income families covering only about 75 percent of the cost of the service. This means fund-raising and other income are paramount. Nonprofit lenders are more sensitive to these factors and better able than commercial institutions to structure loans accordingly.
The Illinois Facilities Fund has taken its involvement in child care a step further: last year, it borrowed $13 million through the tax-exempt bond market and is now building seven child-care centers that it will own, including the one in East St. Louis. The bonds sold easily because, while the bond markets are just as profit-driven as the banks, there are different credit tests and regulators.
The repayment will come from the general revenue of the State of Illinois, topping off an innovative financing with one of the most creative partnerships I have ever seen.
Recognizing the need for investment in communities like East St. Louis, and the role played by nonprofit lenders, President Clinton has proposed the Community Development Financial Institutions Act of 1993 to help expand organizations like the Illinois Facilities Fund.
These lenders can do what even banks committed to community development cannot do -- meet the needs of marginal, nonprofit enterprises. With more capital, they can expand lending. The committed public-private-philanthropic partnership they represent offers real opportunity in community development.
In East St. Louis, some poor children will get a better start in life. Some parents can brighten their futures. And we can help more people like them, people who desperately want to help themselves.

HEADLINE: Are We Willing to Pay Price in Somalia?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Back to Basics in Somalia" (editorial, Aug. 10) concludes that the United States should get back to its basic "peacekeeping mission" in that East African country. This is at best naive, as Ronald Reagan may have learned when he folded his tents after having lost more than 300 marines in one blast in Lebanon. 
 Land a military force in a country where bullets are flying, and some of those bullets will fly at you. If the United States cannot project and accept an allowable number of casualties, and also be prepared to attack the cause of those casualties aggressively, it had better keep its soldiers at home.
A true United Nations-United States commitment to assisting the birth of true democracy in Somalia may entail 25 30 years of involvement; in effect, a period of benign colonialism during which complete disarmament, education, restructuring of the government and an overhaul of the country's economy can shape a new generation of Somalis.
Such a commitment is possible, and it could be the finest hour of the United Nations to date. But all members of that organization should share in the sacrifice -- including lives lost.
 
BUD GEISENHEIMER
Fort Lee, N.J., Aug. 11, 1993

HEADLINE: Last Call to Arms on the Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Just a week after trade ministers from Canada, Mexico and the United States struck labor and environmental deals related to the North American Free Trade Agreement, members of Congress and interest groups from across the nation are choosing sides, rallying grass-roots supporters and churning out press releases.
U.S.A.-Nafta, a coalition of 2,300 businesses that support the pact, sent executives to meet members of Congress in their home districts this week. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. mailed 1,500 letters to state and local union leaders on Friday, telling them that the labor and environmental side agreements would not protect workers. It assembled for mailing another 700 packages of bumper stickers, balloons, pamphlets, buttons and petitions. Ross Perot, the Texas businessman and Presidential aspirant, made a swing through New York and Pennsylvania over the weekend, condemning the agreement in speeches as an arrangement to ship American jobs to Mexico. 
 The trade agreement, if approved by a simple majority of both houses of Congress, would gradually eliminate trade and investment barriers from the Arctic to Mexico's southern border.
Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, said this morning on the NBC progam "Meet the Press" that there was "a significant majority of House Democrats probably against it or at least tending against" the pact. The Administration is counting on three-quarters of House Republicans and a third of House Democrats to pass the trade agreement.
President Clinton summarized the arguments for the pact on Thursday, when he tapped William M. Daley, a Chicago lawyer and banker, to head an interagency task force to push the agreement.
"By raising the incomes of Mexicans, which this will do, they'll be able to buy more of our products and there will be much less pressure on them to come to this country in the form of illegal immigration," the President said. "I think this will be a very stabilizing, economically healthy agreement."
Mr. Perot gave a very different view of the agreement on Wednesday, when he announced that he had written a book critical of the trade pact. "The real purpose of Nafta is not to promote trade but to protect U.S. and foreign corporations that want to locate their factories in Mexico, exploit low-wage Mexican workers and ship products into the rich U.S. market," he said in a statement.
The key players in the political struggle fall into three broad categories: advocates, fence-sitters and opponents. Here is a brief look at who they are:
 
Advocates -- After months of ambiguity last year, President Clinton said on Oct. 4, 1992, that he would put the trade agreement into law if side deals could be struck on several issues, mainly involving the protection of workers and the environment.
White House political operatives have been been unenthusiastic about this autumn's fight in Congress. But officials said this spring that it had been decided that dodging the fight would give the appearance of another broken campaign promise. The President's top aides in the effort are Mr. Daley and Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, two politically astute corporate lawyers who are quickly learning about trade policy.
Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, and Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, have been the most outspoken advocates of the pact in the Senate, where critics and supporters alike believe approval is fairly likely. Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California, and Representative Jim Kolbe, Republican of Arizona, are holding meetings of pact supporters in the House.
A big problem for supporters has been turmoil in the ranks of the wealthy corporate backers of the pact.
For the last two years, James D. Robinson 3d of the American Express Company and Kay R. Whitmore of the Eastman Kodak Company have been the most visible executives advocating the deal.
But both men have been ousted by their boards this year, following investor dissatisfaction with stagnant share prices, not with the trade agreement.
Mr. Robinson remains with American Express as a consultant, while Mr. Whitmore is staying on as chairman, chief executive and president of Kodak until a replacement can be found.
Opponents, worried about job losses from the pact, have been quick to point to the coincidence. "For me, this is a metaphor for Nafta," said Mark A. Anderson, the director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Task Force on Trade. "Get associated with Nafta and get fired."
Gradually replacing the two executives as the pact's chief business advocate has been Jerry R. Junkins, the chairman, chief executive and president of Texas Instruments Inc. He has replaced Mr. Robinson as chairman of the trade and investment task force of the Business Roundtable, a group of about 200 chief executives who hold periodic meetings and who set up U.S.A.-Nafta.
 
Fence-Sitters -- Some wavering Democrats have kept their own counsel, while others have agonized in public.
The quietest key player has been Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, which must handle the agreement first. Senator Moynihan, who is up for re-election next year, criticized the deal during the Presidential campaign last year, warning that Mexico's tarnished human rights record made it a poor trade ally. But this year, with a Democrat in the White House, he has been virtually silent, saying only that he will hold hearings on the labor and environmental deals when they become available.
The noisiest actor in the drama is Senator Max S. Baucus, the chairman of the Environment Committee and the Finance Committee's trade panel. After months of speeches dissecting the environmental issues of the trade pact in greater depth than any other politician, Mr. Baucus tentatively endorsed the labor and environmental deals a week ago while cautioning that he would want to read the fine print.
The most important fence-sitter is Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the majority leader and Missouri Democrat, who commands tremendous influence among House trade hawks because he ran for President in 1988 on a platform of confronting Japan on trade. Mr. Gephardt very publicly dismissed the side agreements as unacceptable when they were released. But Mr. Gephardt has continued to talk to Administration officials since then about possible compromises that may allow him to support the deal.
"I still have high hopes that things that will happen between now and the time the implementing legislation is presented to Congress in several weeks will persuade him to support this," President Clinton said on Thursday.
 
Opponents -- The free-trade agreement's foes are numerous but have yet to form a united front. Labor unions and liberal consumer, religious and environmental groups have been reluctant to join forces with Ross Perot and his political organization, United We Stand America.
Mr. Perot paid for a half-hour advertisement on national television during the Memorial Day Weekend that attacked the North American Free Trade Agreement. After criticizing the President's budget package during the summer, he has recently begun to make speeches again about the agreement.
The umbrella group for liberal opposition is the Citizens Trade Campaign and is led by Jim Jontz, who served three terms in Congress as a Democratic representative from northern Indiana. One of the group's most visible and financially generous backers has been Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group founded by Ralph Nader. Public Citizen worries that the pact will allow American food and product safety regulations to be challenged as illegal trade barriers.
Lori M. Wallach, trade policy director at Public Citizen, has been the most outspoken lobbyist and spokeswoman for the campaign. Public Citizen has filed a lawsuit, which has been joined by two other groups opposed to the free-trade agreement, seeking to require an environmental impact statement on the agreement from the Administration, which could take many months to produce.
A Federal judge ruled in favor of Public Citizen in July, but the Justice Department has filed an appeal. A decision is due in late September.
Unions have played a very limited role until now, with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. refusing to take a position until the side agreements were completed. The labor organization has now condemned the pact.
The liberal opposition has tried to portray the Clinton Administration as unfaithful to its Democratic roots. Ms. Wallach said in a statement on Thursday that, "Mr. Daley's job is to organize the religious right, the Council on Foreign Relations and chemical company C.E.O.'s to defeat the Democratic base by shoving a bad trade agreement through Congress over growing public opposition."
 
 
 
BATTLE LINES IN A NEW TRADE WAR
 Though his political advisers told him it was a non-starter, President Clinton has made the North American Free Trade Agreement a primary goal. The pact must be approved by majorities in both houses of Congress, where legislators and lobbyists are choosing sides.
 
FOR THE AGREEMENT

 CORRECTION:
An article and a chart in Business Day on Monday about lobbying for and against the North American Free Trade Agreement misstated the occupation of James D. Robinson 3d, listed as a supporter of the agreement. Mr. Robinson, who resigned amid criticism as chief executive and chairman of the American Express Company, is not a consultant to the company. The chart also misidentified Lori M. Wallach. She is the trade policy director of Public Citizen, not its head.

HEADLINE: United Way In Warnings On Fund Cuts

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Because of an $8 million shortfall in its fund-raising campaign this year, United Way of New York City has advised many of the 400 human-services agencies it helps that they should expect cuts in support of about 17 percent.
As result, the heads of several agencies have said they will press for a review of how United Way of New York distributes its money, as well as the policy that allows donors to designate what charities and areas they would like their money to go to. 
 In one instance, an agency head has suggested that he might sue the United Way affiliate over how it distributes funds.
The dispute over how the money is distributed comes at an awkward time for United Way. While it was able to raise $27 million from foundations, wealthy individuals and Federal, state and local governments for special programs, like those to combat drug abuse and to try to keep students from dropping out of school, it faced an $8.2 million decline in money from other sources.
 
Impact of Shortfall
 Lawrence Mandell, the executive vice president, said the shortfall means there will be only about $40.6 million available from fund-raising campaigns to be shared by the 400 human-services agencies and hospitals that traditionally benefit from the fund drives, like the Urban League, the Children's Aid Society and the Brooklyn Catholic Charities.
But on the other side of the ledger, he said, is the expansion of what United Way calls brokered programs -- those that the organization operates with other groups. The $27 million it raised in these programs, plus the money raised in its traditional fund-raising campaigns, will allow United Way to report total revenues of $91 million for its latest campaign.
One such program benefits Iris House, a residence in East Harlem for women with H.I.V. infection. The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation of Princeton, N.J., will give $325,000 in the next three years for the program, which likely will be the first in New York solely for women. United Way of New York City will give $105,000 over three years, and smaller sums will come from the Aaron Diamond Foundation, the Sisters Fund, the New York Women's Foundation, the Fund for the City of New York and the Manhattan Borough President's office. Like Iris House, many of the brokered programs involve emerging agencies that are not already under the United Way umbrella.
The drop in fund-raising totals in New York City echoed results from most of the country. The 1,400 United Way campaign locations around the country averaged a 4.1 percent decline, the first dip since World War II, national United Way officials said.
 
Faltering Economy
 But the results were not as devastating as predicted earlier, said Elaine L. Chao, who became the national president of United Way last year after William Aramony, who was forced out amid allegations of extravagance and mismanagement. And while officials had worried that the allegations would cause donations to fall, they said the main reason for the shortfall seemed to be the faltering economy and sizing down by companies. Seventy percent of the New York United Way's funds come from corporations and their employees.
"Of course, we hoped to do better," said Ms. Chao, "but the results were not bad at all, given the business losses at companies with at least 1,000 employees, which are so important in the campaign." She said Omaha and Orlando, Fla., and a few other cities had successful campaigns. The national total was about $3.04 billion, down from $3.17 billion a year earlier.
"When the pool of money is shrinking, people look for reasons," she said, referring to complaints from a some agencies about their reduced funds from United Way of New York.
Some of the complaints have focused on United Way's role in "brokering" arrangements, saying they likely would distract United Way from its main mission. Others have centered on the growing national trend across the country to give donors freer options to designate contributions to favored charities, like environmental or advocacy groups, and not limiting them to organizations providing human services.
Luis A. Miranda Jr., president of the Hispanic Federation of New York City, said donor choice programs were a disservice to agencies created to help minorities. Distribution of funds should be based on need, with every agency given a chance to plead its case, he said.
"If minority agencies do not receive a fair share, there will be many hands knocking at corporation doors," he said. "It will be a mess."
Mr. Miranda said he was considering legal action over the cuts. The Hispanic Federation, a relative newcomer representing 53 organizations, received nearly $1 million last year from United Way.
Leaders of United Way of New York City say they have seen signs that an increasing number of donors working in the city but residing in the suburbs have used the choice option to direct their gifts to charities in their home communities.
"If you are working here and residing in the suburbs, some money should stay here," said Ralph Dickerson Jr., president of United Way of New York City. "You cannot get on a train and ride away from the problems of the city. It is the hub, and the vitality of the region requires it remain viable."
Many of the agencies share this view, objecting that a polarization of urban and suburban communities has been encouraged by United Ways of Tri-State, the regional organization that conducts fund-raising campaigns at 164 of the region's largest corporations in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.
Tri-State was created 12 years ago to coordinate fund raising at companies that operated at several locations in the region. Funds from its campaigns are now shared by 31 local United Way organizations, which recently reaffirmed their ties to Tri-State. Two others dropped out earlier.
Tri-State enables corporate employees to choose which United Way charities receive their donations, said Betty Beene, president of Tri-State. "We provide donor choice as a service to companies," she said.
United Way of New York City gets the largest share of funds collected from the 164 companies in the Tri-State effort, this year receiving $32.7 million, down about $5.6 million from the year before. To compensate for the decline, the New York City affiliate received an additional $800,000 from Tri-State's reserves.
Several agencies that receive United Way money say they want a full-scale review of fund-distribution practices, including an evaluation of relations with Tri-State and the arrangement under which United Way of New York City shares campaign proceeds with the American Red Cross, the American Cancer Society, the American Heart Association and the Salvation Army.
Together, the four will share 35 percent of the $40.6 million collected this year, with the rest going to the 400 human-services organizations.
These sharing agreements with the four well-established charities were made years ago and are no longer applicable to today's conditions, said Philip Coltoff, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, adding, "If no re-evaluation takes place, agencies may be forced to consider whether maintaining their United Way ties is in their long-term interest."
Shrinking resources have underscored the need of smaller agencies to diversify their sources of funds and not be dependent solely on United Way, he said. "Any agency largely dependent on United Way for financing will be in deep trouble in the next few years," he said.
 
Plans for Retrenchment
 Because of the prospects of reduced financing, some human services agencies have already made plans for retrenchment. Brooklyn Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn plans to eliminate 11 positions and may have to make more cuts, said Thomas De Stefano, the charity organization's executive director. The charity, reaching 500,000 clients in Brooklyn and Queens, provides child and nursing-home care.
The Urban League of New York may have to close offices in the Bronx and Staten Island, said Dennis Walcott, its president. The offices provide referral services for people who have been evicted or require medical or other assistance.
Tri-State, reacting to the allegations of extravagance directed at United Way of America and Mr. Aramony, has moved to trim its budget. It also will move out of its quarters at 99 Park Avenue in Manhattan to rent-free space offered by Chemical Bank, an annual savings of $295,000.
"The United Way system is going through painful changes at a time when giving is down," said Ms. Beene of Tri-State. "The reality is that donor companies have demanded donor choice. Not to respond puts at risk our ability to raise maximum funds for people in need in our region."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1059 words

HEADLINE: Serious About Vacation, Clinton Keeps It Casual

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 23

 BODY:
"Whoa, mama, stay up!"
This was the President of the United States speaking, and he was addressing a pockmarked white ball that he had sent sailing on a long drive toward the right.
After taking a similar golf shot on his first Presidential vacation four years ago, George Bush said, "Oh, golly darn, get up there!"
 
Exact Opposites
 But Mr. Clinton has been demonstrating a casual golfing style that is almost the exact opposite of the frenetic pace Mr. Bush set on his vacations. 
 Mr. Clinton carries his own clubs and has been taking along golfing partners from Washington -- Webster L. Hubbell, an Associate Attorney General; Vernon E. Jordan, a prominent lawyer who helped supervise the Clinton transition effort, and Sheldon Hackney, head of the National Endowment for the Humanities -- for his favorite leisure sport.
Maybe the difference is regional. Mr. Bush, ever the Connecticut Yankee in spite of his efforts to adopt Texas as his home state, raced through outings of golf, speedboating, bonefishing, tennis and jogging.
For Mr. Clinton, the Arkansas native who has neither the lean physique nor, apparently, the manic sports competitiveness of his predecessor, the pace is decidedly more sedate. He has played golf only twice since he arrived here on Martha's Vineyard last Thursday, and each time, say those who have seen him, in a perfectly ordinary fashion.
On the course, he has a casual attitude. He is happily willing to take a mulligan -- the extra shot offered among social golfing partners when a first shot goes awry -- with little compunction. Purists might call it cheating when the first shot is not counted; Mr. Clinton's friends call it a generosity of spirit. He encourages others to take mulligans, too.
 
Reading, Eating, Relaxing
 "You've got to get a good shot on the first tee, Vernon," the President said at one point after Mr. Jordan had sent a tee shot behind a tree. Mr. Jordan obliged.
Aside from an occasional jog, aides said, the President has spent the rest of his time reading, talking, relaxing or going out to dinner.
Today, he ventured off the grounds of Robert S. McNamara's Oyster Pond home here just long enough for a brief family shopping trip in Vineyard Haven. He, his wife, Hillary, and their daughter, Chelsea, shopped and shook hands before climbing back into a Chevrolet Suburban for the trip to the second dinner in three days at the summer home of Katharine Graham, chairman of The Washington Post Company.
As if to remove any temptation to work, Mr. Clinton has no senior aides on this trip and has talked to Washington only occasionally, his press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, said. His daily intelligence briefing has become a paper report. He was not told about an incident in Somalia in which six American soldiers were slightly wounded until he awoke, three hours after the national security aide who is with him here received the information.
"I think he's trying to give his brain a rest," Ms. Myers said.
It is not that the President cannot be frenetic when he chooses. His Administration is notorious for late nights and cold pizza. And in the weeks leading up to his vacation break, he worked virtually around the clock to win support for his economic legislation. That pace is expected to resume next month when he begins traveling to promote his plans to streamline the Government, overhaul health care and relax trade barriers with Mexico and Canada.
 
An August Without Crises
 For a change, Mr. Clinton could afford to take the break. Unlike recent Presidential Augusts, this month has not presented him with coups in the Soviet Union, disputed Supreme Court nominations or invasions in the Persian Gulf. And the crises that have cropped up on the world stage, in Somalia and Nicaragua, have been mainly problems for other world leaders.
So as he wanders from hole to hole in a seven-cart motorcade at the Farm Neck Golf Club in Oak Bluffs, the President has looked like a man who was sticking resolutely to his pledge to take a real vacation.
He chats incessantly about golf -- the green, the wind, the tees -- as he plays. On Saturday, when he hit a ball into the rough, he momentarily lost track of it. When he found it again, it was at the feet of a group of photographers.
Mr. Clinton was delighted to find it, since a second ball he had hit to make up for the one he thought was lost had landed in a sand trap.
"This is my ball?" he exclaimed. "I can't believe it!" He then hit the ball to the green with a little too much force. "Stop! Stop! Stop!" he cried as it rolled past the hole.
 
Dressed for Vacation
 But while Mr. Clinton plays golf in an ordinary way, there are constant reminders that he is no longer an ordinary golfer. Last week he played with Jack Nicklaus and former President Gerald R. Ford in Vail, Colo. Here on Martha's Vineyard, hundreds of gawkers lined the road beside the golf course as he played.
A sure sign that the President is serious about his vacation is his attire. On Thursday he wore salmon-colored chinos to Mr. Jordan's house. No socks. On Saturday he was dressed entirely in purple for his first trip to the golf course and a subsequent visit with Chelsea to a local fair.
Unlike Barbara Bush, Hillary Rodham Clinton does not play golf, or even try to. Instead, Ms. Myers said, she has been reading and relaxing in private. The family watches videotapes of movies and plays games together, she said.
How much work has the First Couple done?
"Almost none," Ms. Myers said. "Actually, none.
"One of the things I think he misses in the minute-to-minute life in Washington is time to reflect," she added.
 
Waiting for a Glimpse
 The President has been so unexpectedly quiet and low-profile that his absence from the public eye has left the locals, many now wearing Clinton T-shirts, going to great lengths for a glimpse.
On Sunday evening, by the time the Clintons arrived for dinner at the Black Dog, the Vineyard Haven restaurant, about 100 people were waiting outside, some for as long as two hours.
Mr. Clinton ate grilled bonito, and Mrs. Clinton had a vegetable plate, according to the restaurant manager. Sticking to his new colorful vacation look, the President wore a raspberry shirt and green windbreaker with jeans and cowboy boots.
And as they left, they shook every hand.

LENGTH: 2328 words

HEADLINE: Nation's Land of Promise Enters an Era of Limits

SERIES: Reinventing California: First of three articles.

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Almost from the time modern Americans discovered Southern California, it has been the ultimate symbol of hope, opportunity and escape: hope for the aged looking for a nice climate in which to retire; opportunity for those on the make; sunny escape for the beautiful and the indolent.
But now, as the nation looks to this region for clues to the American future, utopian hopes have turned into cautionary tales. 
 This has long been a land of contradictions, at once a place of movie fantasy and brutal truth, a place where people have come to escape reality but often confronted it, a land of both natural beauty and sudden death, where tanning booths thrive even though the sun shines almost every day. It has been fertile soil for almost every imaginable trend in art, film, music, architecture, body building, surfer styles, clothing, language, food, aircraft and rockets.
Now, Southern California stands to lead again, in ways that are not always so welcome, as the region confronts the full force of powerful social and economic trends roiling the rest of the nation.
Southern California will demonstrate whether it will be possible to transform the American economy from one based on cold war military spending to one based on peace. While the region would presumably benefit from a national economic recovery, its longer-term health will depend on resolving structural problems of overdependence on military spending.
Southern California, the destination of roughly half the two million immigrants entering the nation each year, will also offer a gauge of just how much immigration American society can absorb. And other national questions will have their biggest tests here: What will race relations be when the most troublesome tensions arise from complex conflicts among Hispanic, Asian and black Americans? Can schools, hospitals and other public services maintain their quality in an era of government retrenchment? And can Americans feel safe from crime on their streets without Draconian policing?
Finally, Southern California will demonstrate whether any common identity and purpose can be forged in an urban future in which workers commute hours from distant suburbs and where the poor, the middle class and the rich live in isolation from one another.
President Clinton has linked the nation's recovery to the future of this state. "We can't turn this economy around unless we're going to lift California up," he told a college audience in the San Fernando Valley in March.
All this is playing out in what is probably the most problematic and improbable region of the United States, the most extreme southwest sector, an urbanized and suburbanized region of mountains, deserts and beaches stretching from Santa Barbara in the north, through Los Angeles and Orange counties to San Diego in the south, and deep into the Mojave Desert in the east, a region nearly the size of Ohio that has to pump in its water from hundreds of miles away, a region that has nonetheless built itself into an engine of both the global and national economies and of popular culture.
If Southern California were to be split from the rest of the state, as some politicians in Sacramento (mostly from Northern California) are seriously proposing, Southern Californians would still be living in the most populous state in the nation.
And it would be a state where unbridled optimism was long the unofficial credo, where people collectively convinced themselves that the economic vicissitudes that shook the Northeast, the Midwest and Texas in recent years were as remote and unlikely here as snow.
While there were brief economic dips after the Korean War and again in the 1970's and 1980's, Southern California's prosperity seemed as reliable as its monotonously sunny days. The region has enjoyed nearly unbroken affluence since it began its modern boom after World War II as the nation's pre-eminent center for making guided missiles, aircraft parts and fighter jets. The names McDonnell Douglas, Lockheed and Hughes became synonymous with the smug assumption that nothing could go wrong in paradise.
 
When Success Breeds Failure
 Now California is struggling through its longest and deepest slump since the Great Depression. Nearly two-thirds of the jobs lost in the United States in the last three years have been in California. Even as the national unemployment rate dropped to 6.8 percent in July, it rose in California by nearly a full percentage point, to 9.8 percent, the highest of any of the most populous states.
Optimists say they can take heart from promising signs: Asian and Hispanic residents of Southern California are beginning to acquire a political foothold; a new Mayor of Los Angeles is pledging to hold the line on services, and jobs are on the increase in industries like entertainment, biotechnology and health services.
For now, however, the region's troubles have given validity to the aphorism that "success, if left unfettered, breeds failure," words echoed by Michael J. Gage, a former Deputy Mayor of Los Angeles.
"California had not gone through many economic downturns before," said Mr. Gage, now president of Calstart, a Burbank company that is trying to establish an electric-car industry in Southern California. "We had assumed we were on the cutting edge and were always dabbling with the new. But we were also very caught up with doing things the old way.
"When everything is going well, you do not challenge your assumptions. The Midwest and Texas have come back stronger than before. It will happen in California as well."
Don Gevirtz, chairman of the Foothill Corporation of investment bankers in Agoura Hills, a suburb west of Los Angeles, said he believed that the region's economy was close to the bottom and that if unfettered from onerous government regulations, normal economic cycles would bring a lift. But, he added, "nobody dreamed this area was as vulnerable as it has turned out to be."
 
Chipping at a Symbol In Search for Savings
 Even the bronzed lifeguard in red trunks and sun-blanched hair, that ultimate symbol of California youth, vigor and beauty, is under assault. Its budget broken by the recession, the Los Angeles County government may reduce the lifeguard force by a quarter, leaving such famed surfer haunts as Malibu, Surfrider, Manhattan and Hermosa beaches unprotected part of the time.
Some see a cultural meaning in this. "It's as if they were saying, 'We're treadmill kind of people, 9-to-5'ers, not the kind of people who grab a towel and hit the beach,' " Mari Womack, a cultural anthropologist at the Northridge campus of California State University, told The Los Angeles Times recently. "I think they are signaling that the traditional gift that defines California, free and accessile beaches, is no longer important."
The region's economic future is also uncertain. David Hensley, who recently left California after three years as the most pessimistic -- and accurate -- of the local economic weathermen, foresees no recovery much before the spring.
"Housing is flat on its back, and manufacturing employment is dropping like a stone," Mr. Hensley wrote in his last report for the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles. "The window of opportunity for California to emerge from recession this year probably has closed: the economy is still sinking, and government cutbacks are just around the corner."
California has suffered a net loss of 519,000 jobs, the bulk of the 810,000 jobs that disappeared nationwide in the recent recession, said Larry Kimbell, new director of the forecasting project. One of every four jobs lost was in the aerospace and military industries, and 43 percent of the state's job losses occurred in Los Angeles County.
 
Surface Prosperity In Vivid Colors
 Today, an optimist here is somebody who says the economy has bottomed out, but the casual visitor might not quickly see much amiss. From the air, the wide freeways that crisscross the seemingly endless basin between the San Bernardino Mountains and the Pacific Ocean seem to throb like arteries pumping blood. The vision suggests all the decentralized energy and purposefulness of an ant colony.
Torrential spring rains have brought a glorious summer of hibiscus, lavender, bougainvillea and oleander blossoms. Even the impoverished South-Central area of Los Angeles, with its neat, well-kept homes behind the corridors of riot destruction, looks pretty in a way that leaves foreign visitors wondering how misery could coexist with such beauty.
In the Hollywood hills, muscled young men in T-shirts mingle with statuesque starlets at celebrity parties, gazing out over the twinkling matrix of streets in the coarser flats below as they compare notes on body waxing, nose piercing and the latest in the Heidi Fleiss call-girl scandal. The fantasy of movie and television land has hardly missed a beat. Vanna White daily turns the letters on "Wheel of Fortune," Jay Leno spouts his monologue in Burbank, and crowds line up daily at Paramount Studios on Melrose Avenue in Hollywood for one of the precious 323 seats to the "Arsenio Hall Show."
In one hopeful sign for the depressed region, Hollywood is having its best summer ever, reaping more than $1 billion in box office sales with hits like "Jurassic Park" and "The Firm." Employment in the industry for the first five months of this year was up 17 percent from the corresponding period last year. Universal Studios is reporting record attendance at its studio tour in August.
Economic experts also point to other business sectors that hold promise, especially environmental cleanup, computers and biotechnology. Computer makers like AST Research Inc. and Amplicon Inc., for example, have weathered the recession well.
 
Looking for Hope But Finding Little
 Still, a harder reality cannot be masked, a reality seen in the stretches of empty stores and offices in Los Angeles, Santa Monica and Beverly Hills, and even on the famed Sunset Strip in West Hollywood; a reality seen in the forests of for-sale signs near the vast weapons plants in Long Beach and the San Fernando Valley, where laid-off assembly workers are desperate. Since 1990, property values have sunk by a third to a half in such affluent areas as Brentwood, Bel-Air and Santa Monica. And job prospects for black and Hispanic youths remain bleak despite considerable efforts at training.
Even those still working worry. "People are in such distress," said Representative Anthony C. Beilenson, a Democrat whose district includes much of the valley. "They are afraid of losing their jobs. There is not much hope one can offer, except that after two or three years things will have changed. This is a difficult time of transition. We are suffering more in Southern California because we were overly reliant on the military economy. We had too much success."
Even illegal aliens complain. Martin Vera, a 33-year-old laborer from Morelia, Mexico, is one of the thousands of Mexicans and Central Americans who daily assemble on street corners on the West Side of Los Angeles to wait for odd jobs. Mr. Vera, who lives in his car, says he is lucky to work three days a week.
"This country isn't well off enough for me to stay," Mr. Vera said. "If there's work, it's better than Mexico. But if not, it's worse."
 
Emotional Cost Of Diversity
 Beyond the economic stress is psychological stress. Richard Keating, a prominent local architect, both revels in Los Angeles's kaleidoscopic diversity and fears it. "I feel a lack of control," he said. "Drive-by shootings can occur anywhere. Sometimes you want to go to the beach or the cliffs, to put your back against a wall so that you can see what's coming."
Almost from the turn of the century, Southern California has careered between optimism and doom, in its literature and polity. Listen to the dark vision of Nathanael West as he describes the early 20th-century newcomers from the Midwest in his classic 1939 novel "The Day of the Locust":
"All their lives they had slaved at some kind of dull, heavy labor, behind desks and counters, in the fields and at tedious machines of all sorts, saving their pennies. . . . Where else should they go but California, the land of sunshine and oranges? Once there, they discover that sunshine isn't enough. They get tired of oranges, even of avocado pears and passion fruit. Nothing happens. . . . The sun is a joke. Oranges can't titillate their jaded palates. Nothing can ever be violent enough to make taut their slack minds and bodies."
In fact, Southern California was built on sturdier stock than that. It was promoted during the 1920's as a kind of "neo-Babylonian city of Commerce," in the words of Kevin Starr, a historian at the University of Southern California, in effect a Chicago with sunshine and ocean waves. With its new port and rail lines, the region became a prosperous center of light manufacturing and food processing -- tires, meat packing, flour milling, pottery, oranges, metals. Later came heavier industry, automobiles, and with World War II, manufacture of fighter planes, commercial aircraft and rockets.
After all, the region had everything industry wanted: plenty of oil, water, electricity, a glorious dry climate, proximity to Central America and the Pacific Basin, abundant labor and weak unions.
But if that era has passed, what is to replace it? Are optimists like Joel Kotkin, an economics writer, correct in seeing recovery based on immigrant-driven entrepreneurship? Or is another writer, Mike Davis, correct in seeing a continuing slide into an exploitative third-world economy? Or is salvation to be found in Kevin Starr's preference for a return to the region's former economic role as processor and shipper of foods?
In any case, there is no arguing with Mr. Starr's dictum: "Expectations have to be shifted."

HEADLINE: Ex-Officers in Detroit Guilty In Beating Death of Motorist

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Two former police officers were convicted of second-degree murder today in the beating death of a black motorist, ending the country's latest racially charged trial involving the police.
A third former officer was acquitted of assault with intent to do great bodily harm in the case, which has haunted this city for nine months with its parallels to the beating of Rodney G. King in Los Angeles. Like the officers in the King case, the defendants here were white, and some officials feared that the outcome could touch off a firestorm in Detroit. 
 On the shabby and struggling block where the man, Malice Green, was beaten to death Nov. 5, the guilty verdicts set off a celebration of horn honking, rap music and prayers as well as tears from Mr. Green's sisters.
But there was also anger, because the two convicted officers, Walter Budzyn and Larry Nevers, were allowed to remain free on bond until their sentencing on Oct. 12.
"If a black was found guilty of murder, they'd slap the handcuffs on him and put him up under the jail," said Jesse Carter, 61. "But I'm satisfied with the verdicts, I guess. I know Malice is dead and gone but I hope his spirit will feel good now."
As night fell, the situation was calm, although half a dozen squad cars gathered near the site as a police helicopter circled overhead.
Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit, who had called the beating of Mr. Green a murder only hours after the incident, said today, "I believe justice has been done, and I assume that we will have a quiet and orderly reaction in the city."
The president of the city's police union, Tom Schneider, also issued a statement, saying that the verdicts would change the way officers work. "Meanwhile, it is the law-abiding citizen who suffers," he said.
 
Tears and Stares
 The reaction was also mixed inside Courtroom 402, where the three-month trial was held and the verdicts delivered.
Mr. Budzyn, who is 47 years old and had been a member of the Detroit Police Department for 19 years, looked straight ahead as jurors pronounced him guilty.
Mr. Nevers, who is 53 and was a 24-year veteran of the department, slumped over and covered his eyes as the verdict was announced against Mr. Budzyn. Mr. Nevers sobbed as jurors then declared him guilty.
Separate juries, sitting side by side during the trial, decided the cases against Mr. Budzyn and Mr. Nevers. The third officer, Robert Lessnau, 33, asked for a bench trial, which was held by Judge George W. Crockett 3d.
Judge Crockett had decided Mr. Lessnau's case last week, but all the verdicts were sealed until today.
The murder convictions carry mandatory prison sentences, with a maximum of life. Prosecutors said they had not yet decided the length of sentence they will recommend. All three officers were dismissed from the force shortly after the confrontation with Mr. Green.
The former officers cannot file appeals of their convictions until their sentencing hearing. Mr. Nevers's lawyer, John Goldpaugh, said he would probably base his appeal on issues like the judge's refusal to move the trial out of the city and the showing of the film "Malcolm X" to jurors during a break in the trial.
The movie includes the videotaped beating of Mr. King. Two of the four officers accused were convicted this year in Federal court of violating Mr. King's civil rights, but first they were acquitted on state charges, prompting Los Angeles to erupt into three days of fire and death.
The fear here over the last nine months -- often whispered -- was that the fire next time would be in Detroit.
 
The Role of Race
 In a news conference after the verdicts were announced, one member of the Budzyn jury, who asked to be identified only by his first name, Karl, said he voted for a guilty verdict under duress. Prosecutors said they doubted the statement would jeopardize the conviction.
What role, if any, race played in the week of deliberations is unknown. The undercurrents were obvious in a case in which the defendants were white and the victim black, but no testimony in the trial suggested that race was a motive in the beating. A black supervisor, Sgt. Freddie Douglas, was originally accused of involuntary manslaughter, but the charge was dropped; he now faces a trial on a misdemeanor charge of neglect of duty.
The jury deciding Mr. Nevers's fate included 10 blacks and 2 whites; the jury hearing Mr. Budzyn's case was made up of 11 blacks and one white.
Judge Crockett, who acquitted Mr. Lessnau, is black, as is 76 percent of the city of Detroit.
 
The Chain of Events
 The city was badly shaken by the events at 23d Street and Warren shortly after 10 P.M. on Nov. 5, 1992, when Mr. Green pulled up in front of a shabby two-story building.
Mr. Green, a 35-year-old unemployed steel worker, was dropping off a friend in front of the building, where the homeless went for shelter and the drug addicted went to smoke crack, when Mr. Nevers and Mr. Budzyn, working as plainclothes police officers, approached.
They demanded that he show them his identification. Mr. Green reached into his glove compartment and held something in his hand -- witnesses said it was probably a set of keys or a piece of paper. He refused officers' orders to open his hand.
Then the officers took turns beating his hand and his head with their heavy metal flashlights in front of witnesses, including four paramedics and several other police officers.
Some experts testified at the trial that Mr. Green had died from at least 14 blows to his head. But medical examiners testifying for the defense argued that the cocaine and alcohol found in his body played a role in his death.
Jurors declined to answer questions about the credibility of the former officers' testimony, but a prosecutor, Kym Worthy, said Mr. Budzyn's statements were particularly unbelievable.
Mr. Budzyn testified that he never struck Mr. Green and that he did not see Mr. Nevers or any other officers strike any blows.
A few miles from the courtroom today, along the curb where Mr. Green's life was beaten out of him, Gilbert Paul, 17, said he was relieved that the officers had been found guilty.
"There could have been some trouble otherwise," he said. "But I don't think we'd really be tearing up the stores where we shop at -- we're too smart. Detroit might seem like it's a bad place, but it's not."
Two of Mr. Green's sisters, Sherry and Monica Green, rushed to the site minutes after hearing the verdicts. The two sisters kneeled at the curb with about 50 people as a minister thanked the Lord "for the convictions."
But Sherry Green said she would not be truly satisfied until the former officers are sentenced, although she hoped everyone would remain calm.
"My brother wouldn't want to be remembered for a riot," she said.

HEADLINE: Japan's Leader Vows Action on Political System

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Japan's new Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, today pledged a fundamental reshaping of what he described as the corrupt electoral system and stronger efforts to reduce Japan's trade surpluses.
At least in terms of oratory, Mr. Hosokawa's first policy address offered a remarkable shift from the statements of the conservative governments of the postwar era. He criticized Japan's narrow-minded pursuit of economic gain and the collusive institutions that excluded outsiders and worked against the interests of Japanese consumers. 
 Ignoring occasionally loud heckling from some opposition members in Parliament, Mr. Hosokawa effectively launched the first Government in 38 years to exclude the Liberal Democratic Party by echoing many of Japan's longtime critics.
"It is time to candidly admit that Japan has so far put its highest priority on economic development and has not paid sufficient attention to improving the quality of life for each and every person," Mr. Hosokawa said, adding that a reduction in the trade surplus would help rectify this imbalance.
In several key respects, however, he promised continuity in a policy agenda that is, like the frail seven-party coalition Government he heads, a mix of right-wing and left-wing goals.
Mr. Hosokawa said he placed his highest priority on maintaining strong relations with the United States and would continue to support the security treaty with Washington.
But while his proposals for political reform were sweeping, Mr. Hosokawa offered few assurances he would take strong action to reinvigorate the economy, which is being battered by a two-year-old recession and the soaring yen. Making matters worse, Mr. Hosokawa's coalition is badly divided over how to respond to the situation.
The Socialist Party, the largest party in the coalition, has traditionally favored tax cuts, since they benefit individuals rather than the big corporations long supported by Liberal Democratic Party governments.
But Finance Ministry bureaucrats and more conservative members of the coalition oppose tax reductions because they feel such measures will not result in much new spending and will just inflate the budget deficit.
Mr. Hosokawa said he would offer measures to deregulate the economy and to help consumers, who pay some of the highest prices in the world.
"I intend to work vigorously for expanded domestic demand and improved market access and for such consumer-oriented policies as rectifying the disparity between domestic and international prices and promoting deregulation," he said.
The Liberal Democrats, now a formidable opposition party, were quick to criticize Mr. Hosokawa as overly vague both in his goals and in distinguishing his generally conservative policies from earlier Governments.
"Although he said his Government is a reform-oriented, non-Liberal Democratic Government, he did not reveal specific measures on how it was different from the Liberal Democratic Government or on how to achieve reform," said Yohei Kono, the combative new president of the Liberal Democrats.
The promise of a new electoral system was central to the strategy followed by Mr. Hosokawa in the recent election. But he stressed today that he would follow a tough line and eliminate completely corporate contributions to politicians and parties. He said he would also toughen laws on election financing violations.
In addition, Mr. Hosokawa said Japan would support an indefinite extension of the treaty on preventing the spread of nuclear weapons.
The previous Government had hesitated on the issue, creating concerns that Japan wanted to preserve the option of developing its own atomic weapons if it faced a serious threat from North Korea or other countries.
Mr. Hosokawa also repeated conciliatory comments on World War II. "I would thus like to take this opportunity to express anew our profound remorse and apologies for the fact that past Japanese actions, including aggression and colonial rule, caused unbearable suffering and sorrow for so many people," he said.

The Economy
A tax imposed at a growing number of airports to pay for projects like new or improved runways and terminals is expected to yield almost $800 million in the next fiscal year. But many airlines are protesting the tax, fearing that the resulting increase in fares is putting them at a competitive disadvantage. [Page A1.]
An economic upturn caused by lower interest rates has not occurred.
