HEADLINE: Economic Analysis;
With Rates This Low, Where's the Boom?

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
In pushing the nation to swallow the bitter medicine of deficit reduction, the Clinton Administration promised that there would be a sweet reward: a sharp drop in interest rates that would give the economy a huge boost.
Well, interest rates have fallen sharply, but the expected stimulus has not materialized, leaving economic growth as anemic as it was under President George Bush. 
 Even though interest rates have plunged to their lowest level in two decades, housing starts are not rising, commercial real estate remains flat, and businesses have scaled back their investment plans, when low rates would point to stepped-up spending on plant and equipment.
Administration officials are largely stumped by the economy's weak response to low rates. They recently scaled back their predictions of how much of a lift the drop in rates would give the economy and now say improvement will be felt in the second half of the year. But if things do not start to pick up soon, Mr. Clinton's poll ratings could drop even more.
Many economists say low rates are having less of an effect than in the past because of the weakened state of the banking system and the wave of corporate restructurings and layoffs. In addition, demographic trends are working against a strong pickup in housing construction.
Henry Kaufman, head of his own economic consulting firm in New York, said, "You may a need much larger decline in interest rates for them to become a noticeable economic stimulant in this cycle because we have gone through a great debt explosion that has immobilized many borrowers and financial institutions."
He said lower rates, perhaps including further cuts in short-term rates by the Federal Reserve, might be needed to make borrowers and banks feel strong enough to borrow and lend as they once did.
Still, some economists suggest that the problem is not the economy's underlying maladies but the reluctance of business and consumers to make big financial commitments.
"With interest rates the way they are, if you had a confident mood among businesses and consumers, the economy would take off like a rocket," said Lyle E. Gramley, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association. "But as long as you have all this fear and uncertainty out there, we'll only get a very modest response."
He said housing starts have failed to pick up either because Republicans convinced middle-class Americans that they would pay much higher taxes under the President's budget plan or because Americans fear higher taxes under the Administration's coming health care plan.
Mr. Gramley said the sooner the Administration released its health care plan, the sooner uncertainties would be removed and the sooner housing and other parts of the economy would pick up.
Alan Blinder, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, expressed optimism that the low rates would soon pep up the economy, helping push economic growth to 3 percent in the second half. For now, the Administration is keeping its fingers crossed, rather than planning any new stimulus program.
"We are disappointed about the small response of housing and we expect that housing will pick up soon," he said. "Pretty soon people will realize their taxes won't go up because of the President's budget. They will also see that their taxes won't go up much as a result of the health care plan."
Mr. Blinder said low interest rates had helped some interest-sensitive sectors. Consumers have increased spending on expensive items like automobiles, and corporate investment is up, although investment plans have been scaled back recently.
In his view, the best theory for why housing construction remains stuck at the rate of about 1.2 million starts a year is that there is such "pervasive insecurity" about layoffs and small salary increases "that people hesitate to take on long-term commitments like buying a new home."
The economy's failure to respond more robustly has turned up the heat on President Clinton, who is relying on low rates to lift the economy after most of the incentives he proposed to spur business and investment were deleted from his budget package.
Having promised to turn around the economy, the Administration is eagerly hoping the lower rates will turn slow growth into solid growth and offset the dampening effect of tax increases and spending cuts.
Relying on studies done by the Federal Reserve, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen has said that each drop in interest rates of one-tenth of one percentage point will produce as much stimulus as an extra $10 billion in Government spending. As a result, some officials expected the drop in rates -- 30-year Treasury bonds are at about 6.2 percent today, down from 7.7 percent last November -- to translate into at least $100 billion in stimulus over two years, more than six times the size of the Administration's $16 billion stimulus program, which was blocked by Republicans.
 
Devising a Schedule
 Administration economists say 30 to 40 percent of the benefit of low rates should be felt in the first year, and the remainder in the next year.
But the stimulus has been modest, and many economists and even Administration officials now expect a smaller boost than the $100 billion.
The Council of Economic Advisers now estimates that each drop of one-tenth of a point in rates will translate into $6 billion in stimulus, or its equivalent in extra Government spending.
Mr. Blinder said the downward move in rates of 150 basis points since the election could thus produce $90 billion in stimulus over the next two years -- or about seven-tenths of 1 percent extra growth in the economy this year and next.
Some economists say that even the Administration's scaled-back estimate is too generous. They say most of the decline in interest rates stems not from the deficit-reduction package, but from the economy's weakness and a drop in inflation.
 
Dividing Up the Stimulus
 Laurence H. Meyer, a St. Louis-based economic consultant, says that only 40 basis points of the decline in rates is attributable to the President's deficit-reduction plan. That amount, he says, will provide $24 billion in stimulus, increasing growth by two-tenths of 1 percent over each of the next two years.
He said the rest of the drop in rates resulted from weaker-than-expected growth and inflation. In his view, the portion of the rate decline attributable to these factors will give the economy only a minor lift.
But Administration officials say at least two-thirds of the 150-basis-point drop in rates stems from the President's program to cut the budget deficit by $500 billion over five years.

HEADLINE: United Technologies to Pay Fines Of $5.3 Million in Pollution Case

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The United Technologies Corporation, Connecticut's largest private employer, agreed today to pay $5.3 million in penalties for violating environmental laws at seven plants in the state.
The penalties include the largest fine ever agreed to in an out-of-court settlement under the Federal Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, Federal officials said. 
 The company, whose subsidiaries make jet engines, helicopters and other high-technology products, also agreed to conduct audits to insure that it complies with anti-pollution laws at its 26 sites in New England.
At a news conference today, Paul G. Keough, the acting regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency, said United Technologies had "perhaps the worst environmental record of any company" in New England. That record led to a separate $3 million criminal penalty in 1991, then the largest criminal fine in United States history for violating hazardous waste laws.
 
Dumping of Acid in River
 Today's settlement stemmed from a Federal lawsuit filed in 1990. The violations it cited included unauthorized discharges of pollutants, including the dumping of acid that resulted in a fish kill in the Quinnipiac River; improper handling of hazardous waste; storage of hazardous waste without a permit; inadequate record-keeping, and inadequate training.
But company officials stressed today that the company had changed its ways. "The attitudes and practices that led to these violations were unacceptable, and we have moved aggressively to change them," Robert F. Daniell, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a memo to all employees after the settlement was announced.
"There should be no need for further wake-up calls," he said.
State and Federal officials said they were confident that the company, which has 40,000 employees in Connecticut, would comply with environmental laws in the future.
"U.T.C. has been and always will be an asset vital to Connecticut's economic well-being," said the State Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal. "It now will be vital also to our environmental well-being."
United Technologies, which had $22 billion in revenues last year, will pay a $3.7 million fine under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act and $1.6 million in penalties under the Federal Clean Water Act and a state water-quality law.
Two years ago, United Technologies announced an environmental initiative that included hiring Leslie Carothers, a former state commissioner of environmental protection, as vice president for environment, health and safety.
"I'm pleased to report that our environmental initiatives have already generated positive results," Mr. Daniell said in his memo to employees today. "U.T.C. operating units have reduced total chemical releases by 67 percent. The amount of hazardous waste generated at U.T.C. locations has dropped by 31 percent."
Officials from the E.P.A. and the Department of Justice stressed the approach of long-term comprehensive audits to insure compliance with environmental laws. The audits, to be monitored by the E.P.A., would run through the 1990's, the officials said.
"This settlement reflects several themes that will mark environmental enforcement in this administration," said Steven A. Herman, E.P.A. assistant administrator for enforcement, "penalties that are meaningful, multistatute enforcement and environmental audits that will institutionalize corporate compliance."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
10-Year Note's Yield Hits a 1993 Low

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
After weeks of grinding long-term interest rates to lower and lower levels, the bond market finally seemed to realize yesterday that it was summer. Trading slowed and little happened as Labor Day loomed just two weeks away.
The day's biggest action was in the 10-year Treasury note, whose yield fell to another 1993 low. The price was up 1/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.60 percent, from 5.61 percent Friday. 
 The price of the 30-year bond was also off 1/32 as the yield remained unchanged from Friday's 6.22 percent.
 
'Sit Back and Watch'
 "Most of the traders on Wall Street are saying, 'let's sit back and watch,' " said David Ader of Technical Data in Boston. With the 30-year bond's yield at a 16-year low, he said, traders are going to be very cautious about trading it.
He said that the price of the 30-year bond moved higher overnight as speculators in Japan continued to buy. One reason for this gain, he said, was that the speculators wanted to own dollars in case the Federal Reserve intervened in the currency markets again to support the dollar against the Japanese yen. A surprise intervention to buy dollars on Thursday pushed the dollar more than 4 percent higher against the yen.
But with so many people on vacation yesterday and thus out of the market, there was no follow-through. The overnight gains were lost during the rest of the day.
 
2-Year Auction Anticipated
 Another reason the market slowed yesterday was that the Treasury is scheduled to auction two-year notes today and five-year notes tomorrow. In when-issued, or pre-auction, trading, the yield on the two-year note was at 3.98 percent while the yield on the five-year note was at 4.99 percent.
Mr. Ader said he did not think the auctions would be a problem, though, because of the recent revival of the shorter end of the Treasury market. The yield on the two-year note pierced 4 percent recently and the yield on the five-year note followed soon thereafter, dropping below 5 percent.
The main reason is that recent economic data have indicated that the economy is growing very sluggishly. It is possible now that the 1.6 percent growth estimate for the second quarter of the year could be cut to less than 1 percent when the revised data is released next week.
Because of this slowing of growth expectations, it is very unlikely that the Federal Reserve would move any time soon to raise short-term interest rates, as was feared just last month. Without this threat, the yields on some short-term Treasuries have been able to slide back toward their recent lows while the yield on the five-year note has hit a new 1993 low.
 
Bundesbank Meeting Thursday
 Besides the auction, the week's most important action could come from abroad on Thursday when the German central bank, the Bundesbank, holds its first meeting after a monthlong summer recess.
The refusal of the Bundesbank to make a meaningful cut in interest rates at its last meeting in July set in motion the selling of the French franc and other currencies that led to the effective disbanding of the European Monetary System for the time being.
Some analysts think that the Bundesbank could cut its discount rate, which is now 6.75 percent, by half a percentage point. If it did, that would open the way for other interest-rate cuts across Europe. That, in turn, would help support bond market rallies. But the Bundesbank could also disappoint by waiting until next month to move.
Interest rates have already begun to creep lower in Europe following the widening of the trading bands in the monetary system. The French made another small cut yesterday, when the Bank of France offered banks overnight funds at 7.75 percent, down from 8.25 percent on Friday, and the fifth interest-rate cut in two weeks.
While the main beneficiary of a new round of interest-rate cuts in Europe would be bond and stock markets there, a rally in the dollar against the German currency could help the bond market here a little as foreign investors buy dollars in an effort to make money on that rally. Many of those dollars would then be invested in the bond market.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auctions of 3-month and 6-month bills yesterday:

HEADLINE: Cars That Are Not Are Hot

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The Big Three's singular ray of sunshine these days comes from the mushrooming popularity of noncar cars: the pickups, mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles that are classified by the Government as "trucks" for purposes of energy and safety regulations.
Because trucks are one of the few segments that Japanese rivals have been slow to exploit and because they are more profitable than cars, Detroit's auto makers are devoting ever more money and thought to developing them and to thinking about the reasons they are so popular. 
 As a result, these vehicles increasingly come with amenities and in styles aimed at satisfying the tastes and needs of car buyers. For those who want to act rugged, but who haul more children than plywood, Detroit has added "extended cab" pickup models with classy stereos and rear seats. The Chrysler Corporation last week introduced the new Dodge Ram pickup, styled with a huge ornamental grille to attract those who want the look of a semi-trailer rig. Yet the Ram features a driver's air bag -- not yet required by law on noncars -- and a center console wide enough for a laptop computer.
 
Automobile Handling
 Or consider the Mercury Villager and Nissan Quest, mini-van clones built near Cleveland by the Ford Motor Company and engineered to mimic a car's handling characteristics. Styled with softer edges and less metal for women who are wary of the bulk and doughtiness of earlier noncars, the mini-vans have been a hit, with about 75,000 sales since they were introduced last fall.
Stoked by the first wave of mini-vans that replaced station wagons, the proportion of noncars to cars has steadily increased since the early 1980's; the vehicles now account for 45 percent of all sales for the Big Three. "I don't know how well we are doing at predicting how big this will get, but we are enjoying it," said Fred Cook, a director of marketing for the General Motors Corporation's GMC Truck division.
Because demand has been so strong, gross profit is about 20 percent higher on noncars than on cars, said Jerry Paul, automotive analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York. Models like the Ford Explorer and the Jeep Grand Cherokee, which is made by Chrysler, earn $6,000 to $8,000 in gross profit for each sale, he said, before deducting the corporate overhead costs.
"When sales are a little slow, it takes, on average, a lot less in advertising and rebate money to move light-truck models than cars," Mr. Paul added.
 
 
Knowledge of Customers
 An increase in specialization by the Big Three in noncars is consistent with the free-market model of competition. As more competitors penetrate an industry, companies typically specialize in products they can build and sell advantageously. "What United States auto makers have going for them is a better understanding of what consumers want in this type of vehicle," said Gary Saxonhouse, a professor of economics at the University of Michigan. He said that competition, as well as tariffs on imported trucks, had "spurred innovation."
Although compact Japanese trucks proved popular, they were not very profitable because of the tariffs. The Japanese companies tried to reach higher, but more expensive models like the Toyota Previa mini-van and Mitsubishi Montero sport-utility vehicle captured only a sliver of the market. The Toyota T100 full-size pickup, introduced last fall, has floundered because it is relatively expensive and does not offer a V-8 engine, which many Americans demand.
 
 
Owners Are Loyal
 Moreover, buyers of full-size Ford or Chevrolet pickups are fiercely loyal to their brand. Roughly 70 percent stick with one or the other, compared with the 40 percent loyalty rate typical for car brands.
"El-cheapo pickups were all right for kids and poorer people, but when the Japanese tried to move up in a sector that's absolutely American, they couldn't do it," said Ken Gross, an automotive marketing consultant.
Cheap gasoline, to be sure, has worked in favor of Big Three noncars. Since gasoline costs 75 percent less in the United States than in many industrialized countries, consumers are not much bothered that the bigger, heavier noncars are, on average, 25 percent less fuel efficient than cars.
And that does not seem likely to change just because Congress has increased the Federal tax on gasoline by 4.3 cents, to 18.4 cents a gallon. But if Americans are discouraged by the higher tax recently enacted, Chrysler has "an array of smaller engines," which are more fuel efficient than current engines, said David Bostwick, the company's director of market research.
 
 
Faxes and Coolers
 In the meantime, the Big Three are dreaming up endless variations to satisfy consumers' desire for roomier, more useful vehicles. Cup holders were just one step; G.M. and others are considering features like coolers and appliances like fax machines.
Little wonder that G.M., which is closing factories like the one that makes Chevrolet Caprice sedans in Ypsilanti, Mich., is adding a third shift to its Oshawa, Ontario, plant that makes extended-cab pickups. Indeed, for the last few years, Ford and Chevrolet have sold more noncars than cars bearing their brand names.
Recognizing that the life styles of former car owners are rapidly changing, Ford will introduce yet another mini-van, to be called the Windstar, next year. It will be built in a plant where Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz cars are now assembled.
Ross Roberts, vice president in charge of Ford brand vehicles, said: "Part of a woman's life used to be to drive station wagons. As her role changed, she needed a more versatile vehicle."
Carla Blackman, a product designer who lives in Westlake, Ohio, just bought a Ford Ranger extended-cab pickup. She did so, she said, in part to haul models of product designs and partly because "in my station wagon I felt like such a parental unit."
 
 
Crowded Garages
 Surveys by Ford showed that about half the buyers of noncars were adding them to household fleets that already numbered two or more vehicles. Chrysler learned through focus groups that when car owners switch to mini-vans, they tend to buy one mini-van after another; those who switch to sport utilities, however, often go back to cars.
That is in part because the mini-van is most popular among families with children, while childless couples and "empty nesters" are the biggest buyers of sport-utility vehicles. But younger, single buyers are most willing to consider pickups.
"The big question is what mini-van owners will do when the children grow up," said Joel Pitcoff, a research analyst for Ford.
 
 
Cars Seem Here to Stay
 Noncars have been trendy for less than 10 years. Might they one day overrun cars entirely? The auto makers do not think so.
"They're multipurpose, but they can't meet all needs," Mr. Bostwick of Chrysler said. "There's still a formality about a sedan, an acceptability. I might feel good about driving a pickup to dinner in Texas, but not in Chicago."
Mr. Roberts of Ford, on the other hand, believes auto makers must think harder about the noncars youngsters will want to buy. With today's youth in mind, Chrysler created the Jeep Ecco prototype, "designed to be in harmony with this new environmentally aware generation."
Perhaps with the Ninja Turtles in mind, the Ecco's body was inspired by "a tortoise shell," a Chrysler spokesman said. The Ecco's all-aluminum experimental engine meets 1994 clean-air rules and is capable of taking the vehicle up to 50 miles on a gallon of gas.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Chrysler Corporation's Jeep Ecco, a prototype that the company is not planning to build, is an example of how far auto makers are willing to stray from traditional designs as they develop specialty vehicles. (Chrysler Corporation)

HEADLINE: Stocks Down on a Day of Lowered Volume

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed lower yesterday for the first time in seven sessions in the absence of fresh economic data.
A listless bond market helped to put pressure on stock prices and renewed some concern over higher interest rates and their potential impact on corporate profits. 
 Sizable losses in the European markets, which had advanced to record highs last week, also weakened American stocks.
Early weakness pushed the Dow Jones industrial average below the 3,600 level three times in early trading before the index drifted higher to finish at 3,605.98, down 9.50 points.
Volume was one of the lowest of the year, with 212.5 million shares traded, down from 276.8 million Friday.
"The market did not have much going for itself," said Dennis E. Jarrett, chief market analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company. "I think the absence of any major news held everything in check."
The large consumer-product issues that helped move the market into record territory last week gave back some of that grouund yesterday.
"It was not a broadbased retreat, but rather one of select issues," Mr. Jarrett said.
Activity could pick up today, he noted. The market tends to become more active Tuesday through Thursday, with traders coming to work for a few days before taking long weekends off in what is probably the slowest part of the summer for the stock market.
The number of Big Board issues that declined in price totaled 1,032, compared with 935 showing gains. Most of the weakness was in blue-chip issues. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 0.93 point, to 455.23, and the Nasdaq composite lost 0.10 point, to 730.86.
Drugs and H.M.O. stocks gave back some of their gains from last week; Pfizer fell 1 3/8, to 62 3/4, and Bristol Myers Squibb dropped 7/8, to 55 1/2.
I.B.M. gained 1 1/4, to 44 3/8, partly on investors sifting the market for quality stocks that were recently beaten down, traders said.
Xyplex Inc., a telecommunication equipment company, rose 1 3/8, to 25 1/4, on the news that it and Newbridge Networks, a similar company that makes voice and data communications equipment, had formed a strategic partnership. Newbridge gained 2 1/8, to 69 1/4.
Sands Regent, which operates the Sands Regent Hotel/Casino in Reno, rose 1 1/2, to 17 1/2. The company said that the Copa Casino in Gulfport, Miss., in which it is a 40 percent partner, was scheduled for license hearings on Aug. 30 and that the acting executive director of the Mississippi Gaming Commission had recommended approval.
Traders said an unconfirmed report in Britain's Sunday Times that Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. was about to acquire A & W Brands, may have had an impact on A & W's trading yesterday, which closed up 1, to 19 1/4.Cadbury announced last week that it had agreed to buy a 20.2 percent stake in Dr Pepper/Seven-Up. Cadbury American depository receipts lost 7/8, to 28 7/8, while Dr Pepper/Seven-Up, gained 1/8, to 19 1/8.
Starsight Telecast, developer of an on-screen interactive television guide and VCR control service, climbed 2 1/2 yesterday, to 22 1/2, on a buy recommendation in new coverage by Kidder, Peabody. The company went public on July 30 at $15 a share.
DSG stock closed at 15 1/2, up 1 1/2, after Merrill Lynch raised the rating of the Hong Kong-based maker of disposable diapers to intermediate buy from above average.

HEADLINE: AIRLINES FIGHTING PASSENGER TAXES USED BY AIRPORTS

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
A tax imposed at a growing number of airports across the country for projects like noise abatement, security, and new or improved runways and terminals is inspiring a budding revolt -- not among the passengers who pay the tax, but among the airlines that collect it.
The passenger facility charge, as it is formally named, has proved hard to resist for airport authorities. In the 19 months the tax has been in effect, 130 of the 428 primary airports in the United States -- those with at least 10,000 passengers a year -- have been authorized by the Federal Aviation Administration to impose more than $7.3 billion in taxes. Thirty-eight more applications are pending. 
 In the next fiscal year, the tax is expected to yield almost $800 million.
 
The Future, the System
 "These funds are critical to the future of our airports and the national air transportation system," George Doughty, chairman of the Airports Council International-North America, a trade group of airport executives, recently told the House subcommittee on investigations and oversight.
Airlines disagree. Executives of some carriers, whose routes involve stops at airports that impose the tax, fear that the increase in fares is putting them at a competitive disadvantage. Others have less specific objections, contending that many of the airport projects are unnecessary and that any increase in ticket costs will deter people from flying.
One executive complained that the airports were displaying a "Taj Mahal complex."
James E. Landry, president of the Air Transport Association of America, the carriers' trade association, which is based in Washington, criticized what he called the "field of dreams" argument: If an expansion project is built, "the airlines will flock to the airport."
Northwest Airlines, contending that the F.A.A. had acted arbitrarily in approving the tax at many airports, sued the agency last month in the United States Court of Appeals in Washington. The agency denied the charge, and arguments are scheduled on Oct. 8.
While no airport can charge more than $3 a flight, the airport tax can amount to as much as $12 on round-trip flights that involve a stop or change of planes en route. For example, passengers flying from New York to Los Angeles -- both of which charge the tax -- could save $6 by booking their round-trip flights on a flight that stops at Cincinnati or Dallas, which do not charge it, rather than at Minneapolis or Detroit, which do.
Therefore Northwest Airlines -- which has hubs at Minneapolis-St. Paul, Detroit and Memphis, where the charge is imposed -- pays it, rather than risking being at a competitive disadvantage on routes where its rivals have hubs that do not impose the tax.
This is an expensive choice. "Having to absorb that tax costs us $20 million to $25 million a year," said Elliot Seiden, vice president of government affairs for Northwest.
Consequently, Northwest -- which lost more than $1 billion last year, and just recently averted bankruptcy -- has asked the F.A.A. to impose the tax only on passengers departing from or arriving at their final destination, not on those connecting to other flights.
"It still doesn't take care of the revenue drain," Mark Abels, a Northwest vice president, said, "but at least in competing markets we would not be at a competitive disadvantage."
 
Flight-Booking Priorities
 While few passengers are aware of the tax, many computerized reservation systems that book travel for corporate customers are programmed to find the cheapest flights, and many travel departments are required to choose them. And individuals often ask travel agents, who sell about 80 percent of all domestic airline tickets, to find the cheapest flight.
"There have been few complaints," said Earlene Causey, president of the American Society of Travel Agents in Alexandria, Va., "but only because Congress did such a clever job of lumping that tax in with all the others that passengers don't even know about it."
Mr. Landry of the Air Transport Association said the tax was a way of "obtaining funding from a voiceless constituency," then transforming it into "a general public works scheme." The airlines say the rate of increase of airport costs has far exceeded rises in their other costs.
A. Jaynne Allison, vice president of corporate real estate at American Airlines, said American initially favored the passenger facility charge. "But our experience," she said, "has been that the uses for which the P.F.C.'s are to be put have gone well beyond what the legislation intended."
To be allowed to charge the tax, airports must apply to the F.A.A., say what they intend to use the money for, how much individual projects will cost, and the tax's duration. To date, the agency has approved more than 1,000 projects worth more than $7.3 billion, and rejected $2 million worth. Applications totaling $6.3 billion were withdrawn after consultations with the agency.
Approvals range from a one-year tax to raise $55,500 for improvements at the airport at Morgantown, W. Va., to $2.3 billion in taxes over 34 years for Denver's new airport, which is to open this fall. Flint, Mich., plans to raise $32.3 million over 37 years for a variety of projects.
 
Help for New York Transit
 In the New York area, Westchester County Airport was authorized last November to raise $27.9 million over 30 years for projects that include land acquisition, a parallel taxiway system and a safety road.
And in July 1992, Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark airports were authorized to collect a total of $282 million with a three-year tax. Of that, $21 million is to study the feasibility of collecting $2 billion or so to link the passenger terminals and parking lots at Newark and Kennedy airports, and to build mass-transit systems connecting Kennedy and La Guardia with the subways and the Long Island Rail Road in Queens, and Newark airport with mass transit in Newark.
Ms. Allison of American Airlines objects. "Taxing the air transportation system to fund those kinds of local, off-airport projects," she argued, "is a good example of the kind of projects that shouldn't be funded."
Mr. Abels of Northwest added, "That may well be the best mass-transport line ever proposed, but it's not what Congress had in mind when it approved such taxes."
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey disagreed. "I'm well aware of the airlines' antipathy," Stanley Brezenoff, the executive director, said, "and I appreciate their concerns. But they failed to take into account that these projects will improve the competitiveness of the region and make the airports more efficient."
The mass-transit systems, he added, would serve not only airline passengers but also the 50,000 employees of Kennedy and La Guardia airports.
 
Chicago and Dallas, Too
 Chicago recently obtained Federal approval to impose more than $580 million in airport taxes at O'Hare Airport, a hub of United Airlines, and Midway Airport. And the board of Dallas/Fort Worth Airport, the principal hub for American, recently approved the filing of an application with the F.A.A. That project would help finance a proposed runway.
But many other airports have hesitated to impose the tax for fear of losing connecting passengers to hubs that do not collect it, and of putting their major tenants at a competitive disadvantage. These include Atlanta, Cincinnati and Salt Lake City, which are hubs of Delta Air Lines, and Raleigh-Durham, N.C., and Nashville, which are American hubs.
Industry executives and analysts argue that the airport tax's timing was especially inopportune, as the carriers have lost almost $10 billion in the last few years. "It comes at a time when carriers can ill afford to absorb additional taxes," said Lee Howard, president of Airline Economics, a Washington consulting firm, "and it seems especially inappropriate when a Presidential commission is trying to improve carriers' financial health."
 
Unused Tax Revenue
 Mr. Doughty of the Airports Council countered, saying that the revenue source was needed to help bridge the gap between the needs of airport development, which exceed $10 billion a year, and inadequate Federal funds.
Airline and airport executives complain that much of the $15 billion in the Aviation Trust Fund, intended for airport improvement and collected from a separate tax on tickets, has not been allocated -- ostensibly to limit the budget deficit. In 1990, the year Congress passed the passenger facility charge, it also raised the tax designated for the Aviation Trust Fund to 10 percent from 8 percent.
Airport executives insist that the funds are needed for long-term improvements, and they say that this system for collecting the money works well. Mr. Doughty said:
"The P.F.C. program must be preserved and must remain procedurally unencumbered if airport development in the interest of the overall air transportation system, rather than of a particular airline, or group of airlines, is to be met."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Airport Tax at Work" shows a sampling of the 130 airports that impose taxes on passengers to enhance safety, security or capacity. (Source: Federal Aviation Administration) (pg. D3)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Advances, But Weakens Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened against the Japanese yen yesterday after the Federal Reserve failed to actively support the dollar and a speech by Japan's Prime Minister did not break new ground on cutting the trade surplus.
But the dollar rose against other leading currencies, including the German mark. In New York, the dollar ended at 103.10 yen, down from 104.30 yen on Friday. But the dollar rose to 1.6835 marks up from 1.6755 marks. 
 Meanwhile, gold prices fell in New York after rising in Europe. Gold for October delivery, the most actively traded near-term futures contract, slipped 90 cents an ounce, settling at $373.70 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $372.50, down $1. Earlier in London, gold had risen more than $1 an ounce.
Traders said the currency markets had expected Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, in his first policy speech to the Japanese Parliament, to offer specifics about cutting the huge trade surplus. When he did not, the yen strengthened, they said.
The surplus drives up the value of the yen, since importers elsewhere have to buy more yen to pay for the goods.
 
A Test of Resolve
 In addition, the Federal Reserve did not intervene actively in the markets to support the dollar, as it did last week to keep the dollar from approaching 100 yen. The Bank of Japan did buy some dollars to keep the yen from rising further, traders said.
"The market is going to test the G-7's resolve to support the dollar," said Lee Kassler, senior trader at National Westminster Bank USA, referring to the Group of Seven major industrialized nations.
"If they don't come in in the next few days, it could lead right back to 100" yen, he said.
Meanwhile, the dollar edged up against the German mark and other European currencies as investors sold German marks for yen and dollars, traders said. The mark dropped partly because of the possibility that the German central bank, the Bundesbank, will lower interest rates at its meeting on Thursday, traders said. Lower interest rates often hurt a currency, since investments in that currency earn less.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Rise as Threat Of Nigerian Strike Grows

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Crude oil prices jumped yesterday in reaction to the increasing threat of an oil workers' strike in Nigeria, one of the United States' largest oil suppliers.
Nigeria's largest oil workers' union said it would strike on Friday if the country's ruler, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, did not relinquish power and install a civilian government as scheduled. 
 "Because Nigeria's economy depends so much on its oil sales to generate revenue, it's in the interest of all parties involved to resolve this issue, but it's mired in politics," a British petroleum trader said. "A long, drawn-out strike could pose problems for crude consumers on both sides of the Atlantic."
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for October delivery rose 24 cents a barrel to settle at $18.53.
 
U.S. Crude Prices Could Rise
 Nigeria produces about 1.9 million barrels a day of light sweet crude oil and an average of about 866,000 barrels of that has been sold to American refiners so far this year.
"The market could live with a strike that only lasted a few days, but if it's more than that, U.S. crude prices could rise quickly," a Chevron trader said.
Heating oil prices also rose, with the September contract gaining 0.59 cent a gallon, to 53.33 cents. American refiners prefer Nigerian crude because it yields a higher quantity of home-heating oil when refined.
Yet some traders said yesterday's oil rally bounce was misguided.
"People are focusing on this strike for a lack of other news," said Roger Volz, a trader with Pegasus Econometrics. "I don't think we're going to see much disruption because even if there is a strike. I'm sure there are more than enough OPEC members willing to step in and make up the production."
On other commodity markets, coffee prices soared more than 4 percent.
"I think we've seen pretty steady increases in demand," said Steve Platt, commodity analyst with Dean Witter in Chicago.
On the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, coffee for December delivery gained 3.3 cents, to 78.25 cents a pound. A plan by coffee producing nations, led by Brazil and Colombia, to withhold 20 percent of their coffee exports beginning Oct. 1 has also pushed up prices.

HEADLINE: Consider What Star Wars Accomplished

BYLINE: By Robert C. McFarlane; Robert C. McFarlane was national security adviser to President Reagan from 1983 to 1986.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At a meeting not long ago, I asked Ambassador Vladimir Lukin, chairman of the Supreme Soviet Foreign Relations Committee in the 1980's, what role U.S. policy in general and the Strategic Defense Initiative in particular played in the Soviet Union's collapse. His answer was straightforward: "You accelerated our catastrophe by about five years."
Remarkable. More than remarkable in that an investment of about $26 billion saved us and our allies at least five years of much higher defense budgets -- certainly more than $100 billion -- not to mention ending an era in which all humankind lived under a balance of terror. 
 But today the subject of "Star Wars" is raised not in the context of its strategic worth but rather for its potential for scandal -- an interesting comment on our political and social values.
Even allowing that the American contribution to the collapse of Marxism was relatively small, that role is no less striking. Anything that shortened an ideological change of such immense consequence is worth serious study.
In 1982, 25 years into the missile age, the U.S. had just about lost the struggle to maintain a strategic military balance based on offensive deterrence. It was clear that the Soviet Union would always be able to put more missiles in the field; it was not inhibited by an elected Congress or competing social demands on the treasury. The U.S. would have to compensate with superior quality, and for a time we did.
But by the end of 1982, when I was deputy national security adviser, two things seemed clear to me. First, we had squeezed just about all the comparative advantage we would find out of our technology, at least in offensive terms. Second, the American people and Congress were getting worried about a strategy that relied on building more and more nuclear weapons.
But what to do? We had to find a way either to get the Soviet Union to reduce the number of its warheads or to increase ours until we could fashion a new strategy. Unfortunately, we didn't have much leverage.
The value of defensive technologies -- the ability with confidence to destroy incoming missiles before they come close enough to do damage -- seemed attractive for many reasons. We had made a serious effort in the late 1960's to develop an effective anti-missile missile but were forced to conclude that the state of the art still favored the attacker.
By late 1982, however, new discoveries had been made. Adm. James Watkins, then chief of naval operations, advised Adm. John Poindexter and me that gains in the computational speed of computers and developments in high-energy physics (lasers, particle beams and other directed energy) had substantially lowered the technological risk of developing a truly effective antiballistic missile sytem.
As promising as the military implications might be, it seemed to me that such an investment would offer even greater political and economic leverage. Most important to me was the prospect that, as with the space program in the 1960's, our dedication of hundreds of scientists and engineers to this frontier technology would lead to scores of discoveries, all visible to the entire Marxist family and making it clear that our system worked better than theirs. To avoid such a threat to the ideological firmament, the Kremlin might be willing to pay a high price. Star Wars might be the leverage needed to get the Russians to decrease their number of land-based ICBM warheads.
Carrying out such a strategy faced huge problems. But I believed that if we played our cards right with Congress and the allies, we wouldn't have to build this system -- the Soviets would come our way on arms control. Slowly, everything came together, and by 1985 the program was a living "line item" in the budget.
As is now well known, our strategy worked. In Geneva, Mikhail Gorbachev and President Reagan pledged to reduce nuclear warheads by at least 50 percent for the first time. We had turned a corner.
As for the reports now that the Pentagon "rigged the tests" of Star Wars technology, I don't believe them. Surely no such "deception plan" was ever proposed to the President. And because any backfire would redound to his discredit, any such plan would have been cleared with him in advance by Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger. I don't believe that there was such a plan. After three failures -- all truthfully reported -- when a success was reported in the same manner, I saw no reason to doubt it. As we all know now, hitting a missile with a ground-based interceptor isn't as Buck Rogers a problem as it once was.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Europe Created Its Own Immigration Problem;
Safety Net's Pull

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your front-page articles on Aug. 9 and 10 on immigration and welfare benefits in Europe omit the crucial link: Europe's social security systems make it a perfect target for foreigners who want an easier life. 
 There was a time when people from the less developed countries couldn't cross borders or travel large distances safely, and therefore only those in real danger would make the journey. Such is no longer the case.
Most Europeans still welcome those genuinely seeking political asylum, but they are not prepared to pay taxes to support economic refugees. The more dependent Europeans feel their own jobs and benefits threatened, the more productive already feel overburdened by the taxation system that so many have grown up with as an apparent fact of life.
Meanwhile, the real tragedy is that those immigrants who have the get-up-and-go to seek work abroad are precisely the people required to develop the countries they leave behind.
Does any of this sound familiar to American readers? If not, there may be lessons to be learned from others' mistakes.
 
GILES PEEL
New York, Aug. 16, 1993

HEADLINE: Funds of Towns Belong in Savings Banks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I would like to urge the New York State Legislature to adopt legislation that would enable local governments to deposit municipal funds in savings banks. 
 State government should provide municipal governments with the opportunity to earn as much revenue as possible (especially if the arrangement does not hurt the state budget). The present law prohibits towns, like Greenburgh, from investing our dollars in savings banks. This state law limits the ability of municipal governments to earn the greatest possible return on our municipal deposits and investments.
If savings banks were allowed to compete for municipal deposits, chances are that all banks would try to do more to attract the business of local governments. As a result of the increased competition, interest rates would increase on our deposits. Banks seeking business from local governments would be more likely to invest in the community and to participate in additional community activities.
Expanding municipal deposit options would have no impact on the state budget but could be helpful in reducing property taxes imposed on residents by local governments. The state keeps mandating that local governments spend money on different programs. This proposed law will help governments stretch the value of taxpayers' dollars.
 
PAUL FEINER
Town Supervisor
Greenburgh, N.Y., Aug. 14, 1993

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%);
